Why soul I speak to those that understands me not.
Why? are you so difficult to be understood.
No, but understanding is so difficult to find.
So, and since there is such a total decay of understanding in every brain, as there is none to be found, but in your own, you will make a new Common-wealth in yours, where your thoughts, as wife Magistrates, and good Citizens, shall govern and traffic therein, and your words shall be as Letters of Mart, and your senses shall be as legate Ambassadors that lives in other Kingdoms, which takes instructions, and give intelligence, or rather your thoughts are destinies, and fates, and your words their several de∣crees.
Do you think my thoughts can warrant Laws, or can my words decree them?
I believe your thoughts are so wise and just, that what∣soever they allow of, must be best, and your words are so witty, rational; po∣sitive and powerful, as none can contradict them.
Good Sir, contradict your self, or Truth will contradict you.
Nay faith, I will never take the pains to contradict my self; let Truth do what she will.
Daughter, did you entertain the Lady Visit civilly?
Yes Mother, extraordinary civilly, for I gave her leave to entertain herself with her own discourse.
That was rudely.
O no, for certainly it is the height of courtship to our sex, to let them talk all the talk themselves; for all women takes more delight to discourse themselves, than to hear another; and they are extremely pleased, if any listens, or at lest seems to listen to them, For the truth is, that tal∣king is one of the most luxurious appetites women have; wherefore I could not be more civiller, than to bar and restrain the effeminate nature in my self, to give her tongue liberty.
But you should have spoken a word now, and then, as giving her civilly some breathing rest for her discourse to lean upon.
Her speech was so strong, and long-winded, as it run with a full speed, without stop or stay, it neither need spur nor whip; the truth is it had been well, if it had been held in with the bridle of moderation, for it ran quite beyond the bounds of discretion, although sometimes it ran upon the uneven ways of slander, other times upon the stony ground of censure, and sometimes in the soul ways of immodesty, and often upon the furrows of non-sense; besides, it did usually skip over the hedges of Truth, and certainly, if the necessities of nature, and the separations of Neigh-bour∣hood, and the changes and inter-course of, and in the affairs of the World, and men did not forcibly stop, sometimes a women's tongue, it would run as far as the confines of death.
But let me tell you Daughter, your tongue is as sharp, as a Serpents sting, and will wound as cruelly and deadly where it bites.
It proves my tongue a women's tongue.
Why should a women's tongue have the effects of a Serpents sting.
The reason is evident, for the great Serpent that tempted, and so perverted our Grandmother Eve in Paradise, had a monstrous sting, and our Grandmother whetted her tongue with his sting, and ever since, all her effe∣minate rase hath tongues that stings.
Lady, Monsieur Nobilissimo is so in love with you, as he cannot be happy, until you be his wife.
I wonder he should be in love with me, since I have neither beau∣tie to allure him, nor so much riches, as to entice him, nor wit to persuade him to marry me.
But Lady, you have virtue, good nature, sweet deposit∣on, graceful behaviour, which are sufficient Su•jests for love to settle on, did you want what you mentioned, out you have all, not only what any man can with or desire with a wife, but you have as much as you can wish and desire to have your self.
I will rather be so vain, as to strive to believe you, than rudely to contradict you.
It is neither erroneous, nor vain to believe a truth, Lady.
Nor civil to make a doubt, Sir; but I am obliged unto you for that, you help to cover my defects, and wants in nature, with your civil com∣mendation, and your kind estimation of me.
My fair wit, you look as if you were angry with me.
You dwell not so long in my mind, as to make me angry, my thoughts are strangers to your figures.
Nay faith, now I have you, I will keep you perforce, until you pay me the kiss you owe me.
Let me go, for I had rather my eyes were eternally sealed up, my ears for ever stopped close from sound, than hear or see you.
I care not whether you hear, or see me, so you will kiss me.
Let me go, or otherwise my lips shall curse you, and my words be∣ing whetted with injury, are become so sharp, as they will wound you.
I will keep you until your words begs for mercy in the most humblest stile, and after the most mollifying manner.
Hell take you, or Earth devour you like a beast, never to rise.
Love strike your heart with shooting thorough your eyes.
May you be blown up with pride, until you burst into madness, may your thoughts be more troubled than rough waters, more raging than a tempest; may your senses feel no pleasure, your body find no rest, nor your life any peace.
May you love me with a doting affection; may I be the only man you will embrace, and may you think me to be as handsome as Narcis∣suss did himself.
You appear to me in all the horrid shapes that fancy can in∣vent.
Why, how now daughter, always quarrelling.
Can you blame me, when I am beset with rudeness, and assaulted with uncivil actions.
Let her alone, Monsieur Importunate, for she is a very Shrew.
Well, go thy ways, for all the Shrews that ever nature made, you are the cursest one.
I am not of the humour; as most women are, which is, to please themselves with thinking, or rather believing, that all men that looks on them, are in love with them: But I take pleasure, that all men that I look on, should think I am in love with them; which men will soon be∣lieve, being as self-conceited as women are.
But where is the pleasure, Lady.
Why, in seeing their fantastical garbs, their strutting postures, their smiling faces, and the jackanapesly actions, and then I laugh in my mind, to think what fools they are, so as I make my self merry at their folly, and not at my own.
But men will appear as much Jackanapeses, when they are in love with you, as if they thought you were in love with them, for all Lovers are apish, more or less.
I grant all Lovers are, but those that think themselves beloved, ap∣pears more like the grave Baboon, than the skipping Iackanapes; for though their actions are as ridiculous, yet they are with more formality, as being more circumspectly foolish, or self-conceitedly vain.
Well, for all your derisions and jesting at men, I shall see you at onetime or other, shot with Cupids arrovv.
By deaths dart, you may; but never by loves arrovv; for death hath power on me, though love hath none.
There is an old saying, that time, importunity and opportunity, wins the chastest She, when those are joined with wealth and dignity; but
to yield to a lawful love, neither requires much time, nor pleading, if the Sui∣ters have but Person, Title and Wealth, which women for the most part do prize, before valour, wisdom or honesty.
Women hath reason to prefer certainties before uncertainties; for men's Persons, Titles and Welds, are visible to their view and knowledge, but their Valours, Wisdoms and Honesties, doth rest upon Faith; for a coward may fight, and a fool may speak rationally, and act prudently some∣times, and a knave may appear an honest man.
They may so, but a valiant man, will never act the part of a cow∣art; nor a wise man prove a fool, nor an honest man appear a knave.
There can be no proof of any mans Valour, Wisdom or Ho∣nasty, but at the day of his death, in aged years, when as he hath past the danger in Wars, the trials in Miseries, the malice of Fortune, the tempta∣tions of Pleasures, the enticements of Vice, the heights of Glory, the changes of Life, provokers of Passion, deluders of Senses, torments of Pain, or painful Torments, and to chose a Husband that hath had the Trials, and ex∣periences of all these, is to chose a Husband out of the Grave, and rather than I will marry death, I will live a maid, as long as I live, and when I dye, let death do what he will with me.
Well met, I have travelled thorough all the Town, and have inquired of every one I could speak to, and could neither hear of thee, nor see thee.
It were happy for me, if I had neither ears nor eyes.
Why, what is the matter, man?
The chiefest friend I had, which mas my heart; For that is dead, being killed with my Mistress cruelty, and buried in her incon∣stance.
I dare swear, not the whole heart; for every mans heart, is like a head of Garlic, which may be divided into many several cloves: Wherefore, cheer up, man; for it is but one clove, that death, or love, hath swallowed down into his Stomach, to cure him of the wind-cholick; and since thy heart hath so many cloves, thou may well spare him one, and be never the worse; But if it be buried, as you say, in your Mistresses incon∣stance; it is to be hoped it will be converted into the same inconstant humour, and that will cure the other part of thy heart.
O! She was the Saint of my thoughts, and the Goddess of my soul.
Prithee let me be thy moral Tutor, to instruct thee in the know∣ledge of Truth, and to let thee know, that virtue is the true Goddess, to which all men ought to bow to; and that youth, beauty and wealth, are sixth to be forsaken, when virtue comes in place; and virtue is constant, both to its principals and promises; Wherefore, if thy Mistress be inconstant, she cannot be virtuous, wherefore let her go.
I think his heart is dead in good earnest; for it hath no sense of what I have said.
Daughter, you have a sufficiency of wit and beauty, to get many Lovers to chose a Husband, if you had but patience to enter∣tain, and prudence to keep them; But your being cross, will lose your Lo∣verse, as soon as your beauty hath taken them.
It is no prize for a woman to have such Lovers, that hath amo∣rous natures; for it is their nature that drives them to her, and not the women's beauty or wit, that draws them to her; and there is less force required to drive, than to draw; but the truth is, that most men hath such threed-bare souls, as if the nap of their understanding were worn of; or indeed, their souls seems, as if there were never any woven thereon, as that nature hath made all their souls, thin and course, or as if time had Moath-eaten them, which makes me, although not to hate you, yet to despise that Sex; for men that should imitate the Gods, yet are they worse than Beasts, which makes me shun their beastly company.
Daughter, you speak and judge passionately, and passion can never reason well; for how is it possible, for reason to exercise its function, when passion opposes, and is too strong for it.
Truth may be delivered in passion, but not corrupted with passion; for truth is truth, howsoever it be divulged, or else it is no truth, but false∣hood.
You are wondrous fine, to day, Madam.
If I seem fine, to day, I am obliged more to my fancy, than my wealth, for this finery.
The truth is, you are so adjousted, so curiously accoutred, as I perceive, judgement and wit were joined associates in your dressing.
I had rather be commended, or applauded for judgement and wit, than for wealth and beauty; for I had rather have my soul commended, than my person, or fortunes.
Certainly, I believe you have a more rational soul, than any other of your Sex have.
Alas? My soul is but a young soul, a mere Novice soul, it wants growth, or my soul is like a house, which time the architectour hath newly begun to build; and the senses, which are the Labourers, wants information and experience, which are the material for the rational soul to be built on, or with; but such materials as hath been brought in, I strive and endeavour to make the best, and most convenient use for a happy life.
How say you? the best use for a good Wife!
No, that little reason I have, tells me, to be a Wife, is to be unhap∣pie, for content seldom in marriage dwells, disturbance keeps possession.
If you dispraise marriage, you will destroy my hopes, and frustrate my honest design.
Why? what is your design?
To be a Suitor to you.
And what is your hopes?
To be your Husband.
If I thought marriage were necessary, although unhappy, yet there would be required more wit and judgement in choosing a Husband than in dressing my self; wherefore it were requisite, that some of more wit and judgement than my self, should chose for me, otherwise I may be betrayed by flattery, outward garb, insinuations or false-hood, and through an unex∣perienced innocence, I may take words and shows, for worth and merit, which I pray the Gods I may not do; for to marry an unworthy man, were to me to be at the height of affliction, and marriage being unhappy in it self, needs no addition to make it worse.
Madam? Discretion forbids me to commend my self, although I am a Lover; For had I merits worthy great praises, it were unfit I should mention them; but there is not any man or woman, that is, or can be ex∣actually known, either by themselves or others; for nature is obscure, she no∣ver divulges herself, neither to any creature, nor by, or through any creature; for the hides herself under infinite varieties, changes and chances; She dis∣guises herself with antic Vizards, she appears sometimes old, sometimes young, sometimes voted and withered, sometimes green and flourishing, sometimes feeble and weak, sometimes strong and lusty, sometimes defor∣med, and sometimes beautiful; sometimes she appears with horror, some∣times with delight, sometimes she appears in glimsing lights of knowledge,
then clouds herself with ignorance. But, Madam, since we are as ignorant of our souls, as of our fortunes, and as ignorant of our lives, as of our deaths; we cannot make any choice upon certainties, but upon uncertainties, and if we be good whilst we live, our deaths will be our witness to prove it; in the mean time, let our promises stand bound for us, which is the best engagement we can give; although it may sail; and let our marriage be as the Bond of agreement, although we may forfeit the same, yet let us make it as sure as we can.
I will consider it, and then I will answer your request.
That is, to yield.
It is like enough.
My fair Shrew, are you walking alone.
My thoughts are my best Companions.
Pray, let a thought of me be one of the company.
When you enter into my mind, you do appear so mean, as my nobler thoughts, scorns that thought that bears your figure.
Thoughts are as notes, and the tongue is the Fiddle that makes the music; but your words, as the cords, are out of tune.
You say so, by reason they are not set to your humour, to sound your praise.
I say you are very handsome, nature hath given you a surpas∣sing beauty, but pride and self-conceit, hath cast such a shadow, as it hath darkened it, as vaporous clouds doth the bright Sun.
Your opinions are cloudy, and your tongue like thunder, strikes my ears with rude, uncivil words.
I perceive humility, dwells not with beauty, nor with; but is, as great a stranger, as with Riches and Titles.
Madam, the same of your wit, drew me hither.
I am sorry my wit hath a greater fame, than my worth, that my vain words should spread further than my virtuous actions, for noble fame is built on worthy deeds.
But it were pity you should bury your wit in silence; Besides, your discourse may profit the hearers, either with delight or instruct∣once.
O no, for discourses pleases according to the humour, or under∣standing of the hearers; Besides, it is the nature of mankind, to think each other fools, and none but themselves wise; Then why should I wast my life to no purpose, knowing times motion swift.
You do not wast your life through your words, if your words gets you a fame, and esteem of the World.
What shall I be the better, in having the VVorlds esteem, nay, it is likely that praises (whilst I live) may do me harm, creating vain and false opinions in my imaginations of self-conceit, of being wiser, or wittier, than really I am; which opinions may make me commit errors, and I had rather the World should laugh at me, for want of wit, than scorn me for my follies.
But if witty discourses, will get you an esteem, what will your wise actions, and virtuous life; and praise is the reward to all noble en∣devours; beside, praise is no burden, but it often serves as a balance, to make the life swim steady in Sea-faring World: But yet, Lady, I would not have your wit out-run your praise, which it will do, if you spur it too hard, for wit must be used like a strong spirited horse, it must be restraind with a bridle, not pricked with the spur, least it should run away, and fling the Rider, which is, the Speaker, into a ditch of disgrace; neither must it run wildly about, but must be wrought, to obey the hand and the heel, which is, time and occasion, to stop, and to change, as when to speak, and to whom to speak, and on what to speak, and when to make a stop of silence, other∣wise, it will run out of the smooth paths of civility, or the clean ways of modesty: Besides, wit must not only be taught, to amble in rhyme, and to trot in prose, but to have a sure footing of sense, and a settled head of reason, least it should stumble in disputes, or fall into impertinent discourses; like∣wise, wit may be taught to go in aires of fancies, or low, upon the ground of proof.
But Sir, you must consider, that women are no good managers of wit, for they spoil all their tongue rides on, hackneys it out, until it be∣comes a dull jade.
Least I should give an ill example of tyreing in our allego∣recall discourse, I shall kiss your hands, and take my leave for this time.
Monsieur Discretion is a handsome man, he hath a wise count∣nonce, and a manly garo; his discourse is rational and witty, sober and di∣forced: But good Lord! how foolishly I talk to him? I never spake duller, nor so senselessly, since I was taught words, and he came purposely, as he told me, to hear me speak, and prove my wit; But it was a sign he heard none, for he grew soon a weary of my company, he staid so short a time: I am troubled often with prating fools, whose visits are as tedious, as their discour∣ses: But Lord! why do I condemn others, as fools, when this Gentleman, Monsieur Discretion, hath proved me one.
What? musing by your self, alone! May I question your oughts?
If you do, you will not be resolved, for there is none at home, to give you an answer.
Why, where are they? wandering abroad?
They like a brood of Birds, are flown out of their Nests; for thoughts flies with swifter speed, than time can do, having large wings, of quick desire.
Faith, you are a great wit!
You are a great trouble!
What, you will not force me to stay against my will?
Yes, that I will; For your Father saith, you shall be my Wife, and then you will embrace, and kiss me, as coy as you are now.
Which if I do, I wish my arms, when they do wind about your waste, may sting as Serpents, and that my kisses may prove poison to your lips.
What, are you seriously angry; Nay, then it is time to leave you.
I have heard, that gallant men are civil to our Sex, but I have met with none, but rough, rude, rugged natures, more cruel than wild Tygars.
Why do you complain of our Sex, Lady? what is it you would have?
I would have a gray-headed wisdom, a middle-aged humour, a
fresh mouthed wit, a new bloomed youth, and a beauty that every one fan∣cies.
Why, so you have.
Then I have what I desire.
O! She hath a sharp wit, it is vitral wit.
Lady, you have killed a Gentleman.
Who, I! why, I never had the courage to kill a fly.
You have killed him with your disdain.
I am sorry he had so weak a life, as so slight a cause, as a women's disdain, could destroy it; but for my part, I disdain no man, although I can∣not intimately love all men.
He is but one man, Lady.
And I have but one particular love to give, or rather I may say, to be gained, for I cannot dispose of it; for it will be only disposed by it self, without my leave, so as I must be guided by that which will not be guided by me? I can lend my pity, but not give him my love.
I suppose you have given him some encouragement, and hopes, if not an assurance, by reason, he says, you have forsaken him.
Not unless common civility, be an encouragement, and ordinary conversation gives hopes; as for an assurance, indeed I gave Monsieur Pro∣fession; For I did assure him, I could not love him, as he would have me love him, as Husband. But, O vain man! to brag of that he never had.
It is no brag, Lady, to confess he is forsaken.
It is a brag, for in that he implies, he hath been beloved, for the one must be, before the other.
Pray Madam, let me persuade you, to entertain his love, he is a Gentleman who hath worth, person and wealth, all which he offers you, as to his Goddess, and a good offer is not to be refused, Lady, when it may lawfully be taken.
You say true, Sir, and could I persuade my love, as easily as you can commend the man, it is likely I should not refuse him.
But you will be thought cruel, to let a Gentleman dye, for want of your love.
Why, put the case I have other Lovers, as passionate, and worthy as he; how would you have me divide my self amongst them? Or can you
tell me how to please them; I cannot marry them all, the Laws forbids it, and to be the common Mistress to them, all honour, and honesty forbids it; for though there is some excuse for men, who hath by custom their liberty in amours, because their amours obstructs not nature, so makes breach of honesty; but women are not only barred by nature, but custom of subjection, and modesty of education, wherefore, if they should take liberty to seve∣ral Lovers, or loves courtships, they would not only dishonour themselves, and their whole Sex, and their living friends; but their dishonour would out∣reach their Posterity, and run back to their Fore-fathers, that were dead long, long before they were born; for their unchaste lives, would be as marks of disgrace, and spots of infamy upon the Tombs of those dead Ancestors, and their ashes would be fulled with their stains, whereas, a chaste woman, and a gallant man, obliges both the living, and the dead; for they give honour to their dead Ancestors in their Graves, and to those friends that are living in the World, and to those that shall succeed them; Besides, their exam∣ples of their vermes, for all Ages to take out patterns from.
Madam, you have answered so well, for your self, and Sex, as I can say no more in the behalf of my friend.
Daughter, your tongue is so sharp, as it is not only pointed, but edged on both sides.
Use, Mother, will blunt the point, and flat the edges.
No, Daughter, the more it is used, the sharper it will be, for words and passions, are the whetstones to that Razor.
As long as that Razor shaves no reputation, let it raze, or shave, what it will.
Madamosel Solid, what say you to Monsieur Ralleries wit?
I say of him, as I would of a wild or skittish jade, who hath only strength to kick and fling, but not to travel, or to bear any weight; so Raillery, is antic postures, and laughing reproaches, not solid and judicious discourses, or continued speeches, the truth is, a ralleying wit, is like obe∣structed, or corrupted lungs, which causes difficult, and short breathing; So that wit, is short and pussing, spurting out words, questions and replies; it is squib wit, or boys sport
Madamosel Doltche, what say you of Monsieur Satericals wit?
As I would of frosty weather; his wit is sharp, but wholesome, and though he hath a frowning brow, yet he hath a clear soul.
Madamosel Volante, What say you of Monsieur Pedants wit.
As I would of Leeches; for as Leeches sucks blood from the back parts of men, and spues it forth, when rubbed with salt; so Monsieur Pedant sucks wit from other men's pens, and mouths, and then spues it sorth again; being rubbed with the itch of praise; But all the learned knows, the wit was no more his own, than the blood that was sucked, was the Lee∣ches.
What say you of Monsieur Lyricks wit?
As I would of a Bird, that chirps more than sings.
Madamosel Doltche, What say you of Monsieur Tragedians wit?
As I would of Winter, wherein is more rain than Sun-shines, more storms than calms, more night than day; so his wit, hath more melan∣cholly than mirth, causing, or producing tears, sighs and sadness; the truth is, his wit dwells in the shades of death.
Madamosel Solid, what say you to Monsieur Comicals wit?
As I would of the Spring, which revives, and refreshes the life of every thing, it is lightsom and gay; So Monsieur Comicals wit is cheerful, pleasant, lively, natural and profitable, as being edifying.
Daughter, let me tell you, you have brought your Hogs to a fair Market.
That is better, than to keep them in a foul sty, Mother.
You cannot speak without crossing.
Nor readily cross without speaking.
I am sure, your bitter discourses, and cross answers, hath caused the Lady, namely, the Lady Hercules, to send a railing message, by a Mizzen∣ger, to declare her anger for your abusive discourses against her.
I never mentioned her in my discourse, in my life.
But you speak against big, and tall women.
I gave but my opinion of the size, and Sex, not of any particular, and I may speak freely, my opinion of the generalities.
You may chance, by your opinion of the generalities, to be gene∣rally talked of.
Why, then I shall live in discourse, although discourse were dead in me, and who had not rather live, although an ill life, than dye?
But you might live so, as to gain every bodies good opinion, if you would palliate your humour, and sweeten your discourse, and endeavour to please in conversation.
Which do you mean, Mother! either to please my self, or the company?
Why, the company.
That is impossible, for in all company, there is diversities, and contrarieties of humours, passions, appetites, delights, pleasures, opinions, judgements, wits, understandings, and the like, and for talking, speaking and discoursing, they are inter-changing, inter-mixing, reasoning, arguing dispu∣ting, which causes contradictions, wherefore to agree in, and to every hue∣more, passion, opinion, and discourse, is impossible; indeed one may seem∣lie, or truly agree, and approve of any one opinion or discourse; but not a diversity of discourses, opinions; also one may flatteringly applaud, or sooth any particular persons humour, but not diverse persons, diverse hue∣morse, but to flatter, is base, as to approve in their words, and disapprove in their thoughts, as to commend, or applaud that, or those, that is not praise-worthy: But howsoever, for the soothing of any bodies humour, I will no∣ver take the pains, for why should I make my self a slave to the several hue∣morse of mankind, who is never in one humour two minutes, and why may not I think, or desire to be flattered, and humoured, as well as others, and when I am not flattered, and humoured, to be as much displeased at others, as others at me: Wherefore, good Mother, be not you displeased, that I chose rather to displease my self, than any body else, besides your self.
You will follow your own ways, Daughter.
I cannot walk safer, than in my own ground, Mother.
Dear Mistress, I fear my absence hath made you forget me.
No certainly, I cannot forget you, by reason my brain is hung about with the memory of your worthy nature, and meritorious actions; which my love doth admire, and takes delight for to view each several piece and part.
Do you love me?
How can I chose but love, when in my infancy, such a number of words, in your praise, was thrown into my ears, like seeds into the Earth, which took root in my heart, from which love sprouted forth, and grew up with my years.
And will you be constant?
As day is to the Sun!
Do you speak truth?
Truly, I have been bred up so much, and so long, in the ways of truth, as I know no tract of dissembling; and therefore, certainly, my words will ever keep within the compass of Truth, and my actions will always turn, and run with that bias, but why do you seem to doubt, in making such questions.
I will truly confess, I have heard, that since I have been in the Country, you had entertained another Lover.
It's false, but false reports, is like breathing upon a pure and clear Glass, it dimns it for a time; but that malicious breath, soon vanishes, and leaves no stain behind it; so I hope your jealousy will do the like, it will vanish, and leave no doubt behind it.
I hope you are not angry with me, for telling you, or for being my self troubled, at what was reported.
No, for innocence is never concerned, it always lives in peace and quiet, having a satisfaction in it self, wherefore reports only seizes on the guilty, arresting them with an angry turbulence.
But, perchance you may be angry for my jealousy.
No, for jealousy expresses love, as being afraid to lose, what it desires to keep.
Then, I hope you do not repent the love you have placed on me.
Heaven may sooner repent of doing good, than I repent my love and choice.
Dear Mistress, my mind is so full of joy, since it is cleared of suspicion, and assured of your love, as my thoughts doth fly about my brain, like birds in Sun-shine weather.
Sweet Lady, will you give me leave to be your Servant!
I wish I were a Mistress worthy of your service.
There is no man shall admire more your beauty, and wit, nor be more diligent to your youth, nor shall honour your merits, and love your virtue more than I.
Indeed, I had rather be honoured for my merit, than for my birth, for my breeding, than for my wealth, and I had rather be beloved for my virtue, than admired for my beauty; and I had rather be commended for my silence, than for my wit.
It were pity you should bury your great wit in silence.
My wit is according to my years, tender and young.
Your wit, Lady, may entertain the silver haired Sages.
No surely, for neither my years, nor my wit, are arrived to that degree, as to make a good companion, having had neither the experience of time, nor practice of speech; for I have been almost a mute hitherto, and a stranger to the World.
The World is wide, and to travel in it, is both dangerous and difficult; wherefore, you being young, should take a guide, to protect and direct you, and there is no Guide nor Protector so honourable, and safe, as a Husband; what think you of marriage.
Marriage, and my thoughts, live at that distance, as they seldom meet.
Why, I hope you have not made a vow, to live a single life.
No, for the Laws of Morality, and Divinity, are chains, which doth sufficiently restrain mankind, and ties him into a narrow compass; and though I will not break those chaining Laws, to get lose, and so become lawless; yet I will not tie nature harder with vain opinions, and unnecessary vows, than she is tied already.
You shall need no Tutor, for you cannot only instruct your self, but teach others.
Alas, my brain is like unplanted ground, and my words like wild fruits, or like unprofitable grain, that yields no nourishing food to the understanding; Wherefore, if I should offer to speak, my speech must be to ask questions, not to give instructions.
Certainly, Lady, nature did study the architectour of your form, and drew from herself the purest extractions, for your mind, and your soul, the essence or spirits of those extractions, or rather you appear to me, a miracle, something above nature, to be so young and beautiful, and yet so virtuous, witty and wise, graced with such civil behaviour; for many a grave beard, would have wagg'd with talking, less sense, with more words.
Youth and age, is subject to errors, one for want of time to get experience, the other through long time, wherein they lose their me∣mori.
Pray let me get your affections, and then I shall not lose my hopes of a virtuous Lady to my wife.
Lady, are you walking studiously alone? may I not be thought rude, if I should ask what your studies are?
I am studying, how some studies for pain, some pleasure, some dangers, some quarrels, some to be wicked, some to be learned, some to be ignorant, some to be foolish, some to be famous, but few to be wise.
Who studies to be wicked?
Thieves, Murderers, Adulterers, Liars, and Extortioners.
Who studies to be learned?
Linguists.
Who studies to be ignorant?
Divines.
Who studies quarrels?
Lawyers.
Who studies dangers?
Soldiers.
Who studies to be fools?
Buffoons.
Who studies fame?
Poets.
Who studies pleasure?
Epicures.
Who studies pain?
Epicures.
Do Epicures study both for pain, and pleasure?
Yes, for they that surfeit with pleasure, must endure pain; and Epicures studies the height of pleasure, which no sooner enjoyed, but pain follows.
Who studies to be wise?
They that study Temperance, Prudence, Fortitude and Ju∣stice.
And, what study you?
I study how I may avoid the company of mankind, also, to be quit of your Lordships presence.
She is so handsome, no humour can ill become her.
Thom. Give me leave to rejoice with thee, for the resurrecti∣on of thy heart, that was killed with thy Mistresses cruelty, and buried in her constancy.
Well, well? make your self merry.
But prithee, in what plight is thy heart? I doubt it is lean, weak and pale, and in a puling condition, lying in the Grave of thy Mistresses in∣constancy.
Faith, I cannot tell; the good Angel that brought into life, can give a better account of it, than I can.
Where shall I seek this good Angel? amongst the effeminate or masculine Sex: For I suppose, it is an Angel that is of one Sex, although I have heard, Angels are of neither Sex; but prithee, of which shall I in∣quire.
Of the divine Sex, and the divinest of her Sex.
You may as well bid me inquire of that which is not to be found, for every particular man that is a Servant to any particular of these an∣gelical creatures, will prefer his own Mistress, to be the divinest, and so the most absolutest.
All men that sees my Mistress, and doth not adore her, as the only She, is damned in ignorance, and condemned to perpetual blindness.
Say you so, then I will not see her, for fear I should be one of the damned, and therefore I will give over that design, as the search of her, and go to a Tavern, and drink the good health of thy heart, and leave the in∣quiry after it, and if you will go with me, so.
I cannot, without the breach of gratitude, deny thy kindness; wherefore, I will bear thee company.
O, you are welcome, Doctor Freedom.
If I be not welcome now, I shall never be welcome.
Why, Doctor? what Present have you brought us? that can make you so acceptable, is it perpetual youth, or undeniable beauty, or ever∣lasting life? But prithee, Doctor, what is it that will make thee so well∣come?
Why, my self; here being so many young Ladies together, and not a man amongst them.
Thy self, Doctor! why, thou art not worth the dregs of an Ur∣nal, of a sick water, if it were not for our charity, and generosity, more than thy merit, ability or service, you would have but a cold entertainment, and a rule welcome.
Well, my young, witty, satirical Patient, you will take a surfeit of fruit, milk, puddings, pies, or sweet-meats, one of these days, and then you will flatter me.
You say right, Doctor; but now I speak truth, and is not that better than to flatter, or dissemble; For there is none but sick, and depraved souls, that will deliver Truth with a quarter, half, or three quartred face, like Merchants, or mechanic, that would sell off their ill commodities, with a broken light, but a noble and healthful soul, shows the full face of Truth, in a clear light; wherefore, the sick and base, will flatter, but the noble and free, will speak truth.
Well, I am sure you think better of me in your thoughts, than your words expresses.
Let me tell you, my words and thoughts, are so well acquainted, as they never dissemble, and there is such a friendship betwixt them, as they never move several ways, but runs even together: But let me tell thee, Do∣ctor, I have such a spleen to thy Sex, as I desire to kill them, at least, to wound them with spiteful words; and I wish I had beauty enough for to damn them, causing them to be perjured, by forsaking other women, they were bound by sacred vows, and holy bonds.
It is well, Master Doctor, that you can be privileged amongst the young Ladies, at all times, when such as I, that have not your Profession, are oftentimes shut, and locked out.
Faith, if you have no better entertainment, than I have had since I came, it were better you were from them, than with them, for their tongues are as sharp as needles.
It is a sign we want work, when we are forced to stitch our wit upon you.
How dare you anger the Doctor, when your life lies upon his skill.
O! His skill lies upon chance, and it is a chance, whether he kills, or cures, is it not, Doctor?
No, for I can kill my Patients, when I will, although not cure them, when I will.
Well, then, Doctor, when I would dye, I will send for you, but not when I would live.
Your Servant, Ladies.
Good Lady Wit, follow Monsieur Discretion, he will make you a wise Lady, and make your wit discreet, as it should be.
O Doctor! how you mistake, for wit cannot be made, it is a Creator, and not a Creature; for wit was the first Master, or Mistress of Arts; the first Husband-man, Granger, Gardiner, Carver, Painter, Graver, Caster and Molder, Mason, Joiner Smith, Brasier, Glazier, the first Chand∣ler, Vintener, Brewer, Baker, Cook, Confectioner, the first Spinster, VVeaver, Knitter, Tailor, Shoo-maker, and millions the like; also wit was the first Navigator, Architector, Mathematician, Logitian, Geometrician, Cosmo∣grafir, Astronomer, Astrologer, Philosopher, Poet, Historian and Hearold; also wit made the first Common-wealth, invented Laws for Peace, Arms for VVars, Ceremonies for State and Religion; also music, dancing, dressing, masking, playing for delight and pleasure; wit divides time, employs time, prevents time, and provides for time; it makes Heavens, and Hells, Gods and Devils.
Well, go thy ways, for though thou hast a heavenly mind, and an angelical beauty, yet thou hast a devilish wit,
It shall be sure to torment thee, Doctor, but do you hear, Doctor? pray present my service to Monsieur Discretion, and tell him, it was a sign he liked not our company, he made so short a stay.
He perceived by your usage of me, that if he stayed, you would beat him out of your company, with your two edged tongues; but I will tell him what a Raillery you are.
I hope you will give me a good report, for I have fully charged you.
You have over-charged me, and therefore it is likely I shall break into exclamations.
Lady, if I may not be your Husband, pray let there be a friendship between us?
What kind of friendship would you make? for there are so many, and of such different natures, as I know not which you would be; as some friendship is made by beauty, some by flattery, some by luxury, some by factions, others by knavery, and all for interest.
None for love?
No, but some are made by lust, but they last not long.
And is there no friendship made by virtue?
O no, for virtue may walk all the World over, and meet never a friend, which is the cause she lives alone; for all the World thinks her too rigid for Society, which makes mankind adhere to her enemy vice.
Doth not marriage make a friendship?
Very seldom, for marriage is like a Common-wealth, which is a contract of bodies, or rather a contract of interest, not a friendship betwixt souls, and there is as much Faction, and oftener civil Wars in marriage, than in public Commonwealths.
I desire our friendship may be Platonic.
That is too dangerous, for it oftimes proves a Traitor to Cha∣steady.
Sir, you must give me leave to chide you, for staying so long with my Nurse-child, as you keep her from her dinner, either go away, or stay and dine with her.
Good Nurse, be patient, for though I am engaged to dine with other company; yet her discourse is such charming music, as I have not power to go from her, as yet.
If my discourse sounds musical, it is only when you are by, but when you are absent, the strings of my voice, or speech, is as if they were bro∣ken, for then my tongue is out of Tune, and my wit is out of humour.
My dearest and sweetest Mistress, may your merits be rewar∣ded
by Fame, your virtue by Heaven, your life by Nature, and all your earthly desires by Fortune.
And my love by the return of yours:
When I forsake you, may Hell take my soul, and Devils tor∣meant it for ingratitude and perjury.
Madamosel Doltche seems to be a very fine, sweet Lady, well-behav'd, sober, modest, discreet, and of a gentle nature.
Most commonly, every one seems best at the first sight, by reason they put on their civilised demeanours, gracefullest garbs, modestest count∣nonce, and speaks their most choicest phrases, or words, when they meet strangers; all which, makes them appear to their advantage, when after ac∣quantaince, they will seem but vulgar, as when they are used to their ordina∣rye garbs, countenances and phrases, and that their natures and dispositions were known, they will appear to be no better than their Neighbours; nay, perchance not so good; the like will Madamosel Doltche appear to you.
I do suppose she looks more familiar on her acquaintance, than strangers, and it is likely, she looks more grave, and sober on strangers, than on her known friends, and familiars; yet those several looks and countenan∣ces, may be as pleasing, and obliging, the one, as the other; for though the one may be more kind, the other may be more respectful; for every ones countenance and behaviour, is to be ordered according to the several degrees or relations of several persons, and to several persons, and to several sexes, or according to their condition, state, life and fortune, and according to the times and occasions; for women are, or should be, more free and confident to, and in the company of women, than men; and men are more respect∣full in their discourse and behaviour to women, than to their own Sex, and a merry countenance in a sad condition or state of life or fortunes, would not be seemly; mirth in the house of mourning, would be inhumane, or to dance or sing over the Graves of their Parents, Children, Husbands, Wives or Friends, would be unnatural, or to be merry in the time of a general calami∣tie, as in timate of VVars, Plagues, or Pamine, or Deluges, or to be sad or froward in a general rejoicing; but a sad countenance, and a grave behaviour, is as sitting, and seems comely and handsome in a time of calamity, as a merry countenance, and a dancing behaviour, in a time of rejoicing; for tears becomes the face, sometimes, as well as smiles, and blushing may ap∣pear and express a modest nature to strangers, when to familiar acquaintance∣tenses, blushing might be thought an accuser, or witness of some crime, yet bashful eyes at all times, becomes modest Virgins.
I hate bashful eyes, for they are like to troubled waters, thick and unsteady, rolling from place to place, without an assurance; for modest Virgins may look upon the World with a confident brow, if they have no guilt to stain their cheeks with blushes, and surely amongst well-brod persons,
there is none so rude, injurious, or uncivil, to force the blood to rise, or stop the light, in causing bashful eyes, but such as condemns a confident count∣nonce in Virgins faces; my eye of understanding will cast a despising glance on such ridiculous fools, and the tongue of reason condemns them.
I wonder, Daughter, you should be so rudely uncivil to Monsieur Generosity, to use him so unkindly, as to entertain him with scornful words, and disrespectful behaviour.
Why did he come to visit me?
To offer his service, and to profess his affection to your person and virtue.
I care not for his service, or affection.
But he is a person of an honourable Title, and can make you a great Lady.
Give me leave to tell you, Mother, that nature hath given me Ti∣tles of Honour, Wit and Beauty, to which all men will bow to, with re∣spect; Titles from Kings, poor petty things to those.
But Daughter, let me tell you, that wit and beauty, without mo∣desty, civility and virtuous curtsy, may ensnare facile fools, and allure fond persons, but not persuade the judicious to esteem you, nor the constant to sue to you, nor true love to desire you; you may have vain Boasters, and amotous Flatterers to court you; but none that is wise, or honourable, will marry you, and to use this Noble Lord so disrespectfully, who is endued with virtue, and adorned with the graces, and beloved of the Muses, is a crime unpardonable.
Mother, the Muses and the Graces are Witches, which enchants the soul, and charms the Spirits, and makes the Senses extravagant, and the actions desperate.
Methinks they should charm you; if they have such power.
My humour is a Spell against all such charms.
You are well met, for I was going to your lodging to see you.
And I am now going home, and therefore let us go toge∣there.
Where have you been?
At a house you often resort to.
What, at a Bawdy-house?
Yes.
Why, how durst you venture?
Why?
Why! why if your angelical Mistress should come to hear of it; Faith, she would bury your heart again.
Yes, is it were not out of her power.
Why, hath she not the Possession?
No saith.
How comes that to pass?
I know not how, but upon some dislike, it grew weary, and by some opportunity, it found it stole home, and since it hath promised never to leave me again; for it hath confessed to me, it hath been most miserably tor∣mented with doubts, fears, jealousies and despairs.
Prithee let me tell thee, as a friend, that thy heart, is a false lie∣ing heart, for there inhabits no torments amongst angelical bodies.
By your favour, in Plutoes Court, there be Angels as well, and as many as in Ioves; But let me tell you, that if I did not love you very well, I would call you to an account, for calling my heart, a false lying heart.
Prithee pacify thy self, for I am sure I have had but a heartless friend of thee, all the time of thy hearts absence, and if I should rail of thy heart, thou hast no reason to condemn me; but prithee, tell me, had not thy heart some pleasure sometimes to mitigate the torments?
No saith, for my heart tells me, that what with rigid virtue, cruel scorn, and insulting pride, it never had a minutes pleasure, nor so much as a moment of ease; and if that there were no more hopes of happiness amongst the Gods in Heaven, than there is amongst the Goddesses on Earth, it would never desire to go to them, or dwell amongst them: Nay, my heart says, it should be as much afraid to go to Heaven, and to be with the Gods, as mortals are to go to Hell, to be with Devils.
But if pleasure, and happiness, is not to be found with virtue, nor with the Gods, where shall we seek for it.
I will tell you what my heart saith, and doth assure me; that is, that pleasure lives always with vice, and that good fellowship is amongst the damned, and it doth swear, it is a most melancholy life, to live with those that are called the blessed, which are the Goddesses on Earth.
Why, then let us return to the house from whence you came.
No faith, I am dry, wherefore I will go to a Tavern.
Content.
Which shall I complain of? Nature or Education; I am compassionate by nature; for though I am froward, I am not crew∣el, I am pious by education; for though I am froward, I am not wicked, I am virtuous by nature, and education; for though I am froward, I am neither dishonest, unchaste, base, or unworthy: Why then, it is Fortune I must complain of, for Fortune hath given me plenty, and plenty hath made me proud, and pride hath made me self-conceited, self-conceit hath bred disdain, and disdain scorn; So pride, disdain, and scorn, makes me disap∣prove all other creatures actions, or opinions, but my own; and this disap∣proving is that which men calls cross, peevish, and froward disposition, being most commonly, accompanied with sharp satirical words, and angry frowns.
These faults i'll conquer, whereresoere they lye;
I'll rule my froward humour, or i'll dye.
Lord! Lord! I wonder men and women should spend their time so idly, and wast their lives so vainly, in talking so ignorantly, and acting so foolishly upon the great Stage, or the Stage of the great World.
Why, how would you have them spend their time, or talk, or act?
I would have them spend their time, to gain time, as to prevent or hinder times oblivion, and to speak and act to that design,
—That when their bodies dye,
Their Names and Fems, may live eternally.
But it is not in every mans, or women's power, to get same, for some are made incapable by nature, others are hindered by fortune, some are obstructed by chance, others want time and opportunity, wealth, birth and education, and many that are pulled back by envy, spite and malice.
What man or woman soever, that nature is liberal to, may eter∣nalize themselves; as for fortune, she may hinder the active, the like may chance, envy, spite and malice, but cannot hinder the contemplative; the like may time and opportunity; but poor poverty and birth, can be no hen∣drance to natural wit, for natural wit, in a poor Cottage, may spin an after∣life, enter-weaving several coloured fancies, and threads of opinions, making fine and curious Tapestries to hang in the Chambers of fame, or wit may
and carve Images of imaginations, to place and set forth the Gardens of fame, making fountains of Poetry, that may run in smooth streams of verse, or wit may paint and pencil out some Copies, and various Pictures of Na∣ture, with the pencils of Rhetoric on the grounds of Philosophy, to hang in the Galleries of fame; Thus the Palacesses of fame may be furnished and adorned by the wit of a poor Cottager.
Item, I am to be courteous, but not familiar; to be merry, but not wild; to be kind, but not wanton, to be friendly, but not intimate; to be sociable, but not troublesome; to be conversable, but not talkative; to look soberly, but not frowningly; to return answers civilly, to ask questions wisely, to demand rights honestly, to argue rationally, and to maintain open∣nions probably: These rules I will strictly observe, and constantly practice.
Sir, I cry peccavi, and ask your pardon, for speaking so unhand∣somely of the effeminate Sex, when I was last in your company; for my in∣discretion made me forget, so as not to remember, that all men hath either VVives, Sisters, Daughters or Mothers: But truly, my discourse proceeded neither from spite or malice, but from the consideration of my own faults, which being so many, did bury the good graces of other women, for though I am virtuously honest, yet I am but rudely fashioned, and untoward for conversation; but though my discourse had a triangular countenance, for it seemed foolish, spy•efull and wicked; yet pray, Sir, believe, the natural face, was a perfect, round, honest face.
Lady, what faults soever, your Sex is guilty of, your virtues will get their pardon, and your beauty will cover their blemishes.
I wish my indiscretion had not discovered my froward imperfect∣once, but I am sorry, and shall hereafter endeavour to rectify my errors.
Good Nurse, where is my virtuous, sweet Mistress?
In her chamber, Sir.
What is she doing?
She is reading.
What Books doth she read? are they Divinity, Morality, Philosophy, History or Poetry?
Sometimes her study is of one, and then of another; But now I think, her chief study, is you, wherein she may read humanity.
Lord child! what makes you blush?
Not crimes, but my blushing, is caused by a sudden assault, or surprise meeting him; I did not expect to meet at this time, which raised up blushes in my face; for blushing is like the full and falling tide; for the blood flows to the face, and from thence ebbes to the heart, as passions moves the mind;
And thoughts as waves, in curling folds do rise,
And lashfull eyes, are like the troubled skies.
Sweet Mistress, crimes cannot stain your cheeks with blushes, but modesty hath penseld Roses there, which seems as sweet, as they look fair.
I desire my looks and countenance, may always appear so, as they may never falsely accuse me; and as I would not have my looks, or count∣nonce, wrong my innocence, or deceive the Spectators, so I would not have my heart be ungrateful to bury your presence in silence; Wherefore, I give you thanks, Sir, for the noble Present you sent me to day.
I was afraid you would not have accepted of it.
Truly, I shall refuse no Present you shall send me, although it were ushered with scorn, and attended with death.
My kind Mistress, I shall never send you any Present, but what is ushered by my love, attended by my service, and presented with the offer of my life.
Child, you are very free of kind words.
And my deeds shall answer my words, is need requires; yet I am sorry if my speaking over-much, should offend; but I chose rather, to set bosses of words on the sense of my discourse, although it obscures the gloss of my speech, than my love should be buried in my silence.
Sweet Mistress, your loving expressions gives such joy unto my heart, and such delight unto my hearing, as my soul is enthroned in hap∣pines, and crowned with tranquillity.
Pray Heaven, you both may be as full of Love, Joy and Peace, when you are married, as you express to have now; But let me tell you, young Lovers, that Hymen is a very temperate, and discreet Gentleman in love, I will assure you; neither doth he express himself in such high poe∣tical Raptures, for his discourse is plain, and ordinary.
Nay, sometimes his discourse is extraordinary, as when he hath Wars; but Nurse, thou art old, and the fire of love, if ever thou had any, is put out by old Father Times extinguisher.
True love never dyes, nor can time put it out.
It is true, but Nurse seems by her speech, as if she had never known true love; for true love, as it always burns clear, so it always flames high, far infinite is the fuel that feeds it.
Well, well? young Lovers, be not so confident, but let me advise
you to balance reason on both sides, with hopes, and doubts, and then the judgement will be steady.
But in the scales of love, Nurse, nothing must be but confi∣dence.
Yes, there must be temperance, or love will surfeit, and dye with excess.
Love cannot surfeit, no more than souls with grace, or Saints of Heaven.
My smiles shall be as Baits, my eyes as Angels, where every look shall be a hook to catch a heart; I'll teach my tongue such art, to plant words on each heart, as they shall take deep root, from whence pure love shall spring; my lips shall be as flowery banks, whereon sweet Rhetoric grows, and cipherous fancy blows; from which banks, love shall wish to gather Posies of kisses, where every single kiss shall differ as Roses, Pinks, Violets, Primroses, and Daffidillies, and the breath therefrom, shall be as fragant as the touch, soft thereon, and as the Sun doth heat the Earth, so shall my embraces heat my Lovers thoughts with self-conceit, which were before like water, frozen with a dejected and despairing cold. Hay ho!
Dear Mistress, you are the only She that is fit to be crowned; the sole Empress of the World.
Let me tell you, Sir? I had rather be a single Shepherdess, than the sole Empress of the World; for I would not be a Mistress of so much power, to be as a Servant to so much trouble.
But, put the case Alexander were alive, and would crown you Empress of the World, you would not refuse that honour, but accept of it, for the sake of renown.
Yes, I should refuse it, for if I could not get renown by my own merits, I should wish to dye in Oblivion, for I care not; Nay, I despise such
honours and renowns, as comes by derivations, as being derived from another, and not inherent in my self, and it is a poor, and mean renown, that is gained or got, only by receiving a gift from a fellow-creature, who gives out of pas∣zion, appetite, partiality, vain-glory, or fear, and not for merit or worth∣sake; wherefore, no gifts but those that comes from the Gods, or Nature, are to be esteemed, or received with thanks, but were to be refused, had man the power to chose, or to deny.
Sweet Mistress, nature hath crowned you with beauty and wit, and the Gods hath given you a noble soul.
I wish they had, for the Gods gifts are not like to mans, and natures crown is beyond the golden crown of Art, which are greater glories, than Power, Wealth, Title or Birth, or all the outward honours gained on Earth; but I desire the Gods may crown my soul with reason and understanding; Heaven crown my mind with Temperance and Fortitude; Nature crown my body with Health and Strength, time crown my life with comely and discreet age; Death crown my separation with peace and rest; and Fame crown my memory with an everlasting renown; thus may my creation be to a happy end.
Gods, Fortune and Fates hath joined to make me happy in your love, and that which will make me absolutely happy, is, that I shall marry you, and embrace you as my wife.
The absolute happiness is, when the Gods embraces man with mer∣cy, and kisses him with love.
Hay, ho! who can love, and be wise? but why do I say so? For reason loves wisely; it is only the mistaken senses that loves foolishly; indeed, the sense doth not love, but sondly, and foolishly affects, for it, it is an humoursome and inconstant appetite that proceeds from the body, and not that noble passion of true love which proceeds from the soul: But O! what a ridiculous humour am I fallen into, from a choleric humour, into an amorous humour; Oh! I could tear my soul from my body, for having such whining thoughts, and such a mean, submissive, croaching, feigning, flattering humour, and idle mind; a choleric humour, is noble to this, for it is commanding, and seems of an heroic spirit, but to be amorous, is base, beastly, and of an inconstant nature.
Oh! How apt is busy life to go amiss,
What foolish humours in mans mind there is:
But O! The soul is far beyond the mind,
As much as man is from the beastly kind.
Are you weary of, your life? that you send me; for you said, you would not send for me, until you had a desire to dye.
True, Doctor, and if you cannot cure me, kill me.
In my conscience, you have sent for me to play the wanton.
Why, Doctor? If I do not infringe the rules and laws of mo∣desty, or civility, I cannot commit wanton faults,
Yes faith, your tongue may play the wanton,
Indeed, Doctor, I had rather tell a wanton truth, than a mo∣dest lye.
Well, what is your disease?
Nay, that you must guess, I can only tell my pains.
Where is your pain?
In my heart and head.
Those be dangerous parts, but after what manner are your pains?
On my heart there lies a weight, as heavy as the World on Atlas shoulders; and from my melancholy mind, arises such damps of doubts, as almost quenches out the fire of life, did not some hope, though weak, which blows with fainting breath, keep it alive, or rather puffs than blows, which intermitting motions, makes my pulse unequal, and my blood to ebb and flow, as from my heart, unto my face; and from my face, unto my heart again; as for my head, it feels drowsy, and my spirits are dull; my thoughts uneasily doth run, crossing, and striving to throw each other down; this causes broken sleeps, and frightful dreams, and when I awake at every noise, I start with fears, my limbs doth shake.
Why, this disease is love, wherefore I cannot cure you; for love no more than wit, can neither be tempered, nor yet be ruled, for love and wit, keeps neither moderate bounds, nor spares diet, but dyes most commonly of a surfeit.
O yes, discretion can cure both.
Then send for Monsieur Discretion, and hear what he says to you, for your disease is past my skill.
By your industry, Doctor, help may be found, in giving direct∣once, and ordering the cordial.
So I understand you would have my counsel what you should do, and my industry to order, and get a meeting between Monsieur Discretion and you, and to make the match betwixt you.
You understand me right.
Well, I will study the means, and try if I can procure thee a man.
Good fortune be your guide.
And Monsieur Discretion, your Husband,
Thoughts be at rest, for since my love is honest, and the person I love worthy, I may love honourably, for he is not only learned with study, experienced with time and practice, but he is natures favourite, she hath endued his soul with uncontrolled reason, his mind with noble thoughts, his heart with heroic generosity, and his brain with a supreme wit; Besides, she hath presented his judgement and understanding, with such a clear Pro∣spective-glasse of speculations, and such a Multiplying-glass of conception, as he sees farther, and discerns more into natures works, than any man she hath made before him.
But let me consider? I have used this worthy Gentleman uncivilly, nay rudely, I have despised him; wherefore he cannot love me, for nature ab∣horse neglect, and if he cannot love me in honesty, he ought not to marry me, and if I be not his wife, for certain I shall dye for love, or live a most un∣happy life, which is far worse than death. Hay ho!
What, Daughter, sick with love?
O, Mother? love is a Tyrant, which never lets the mind be at rest, and the thoughts are the torments, and when the mind is tormented, the by∣die is seldom in health.
Well, to ease you, I will go to this Lord Generosity, and pray him to give you a visit.
By no means, Mother, for I had rather dye with love, than live to be despised with scorn, for he will refuse your desires, or if he should come, it would be but to express his hate, or proudly triumph on my unhappy state.
She is most desperately in love, but I will endeavour to settle her mind.
Am not I a good Doctor now, that hath got you a good Hus∣band?
Nay, Doctor, he is but a Suitor, as yet.
Why do not you woe upon the Stage, as the rest of your Como∣rades doth?
O fie, Doctor Discretion never whines our love in public.
So you love to be in private?
Why, Doctor, the purest love is most concealed, it lies in the heart; and it warms it self by its own fire.
Take heed, for if you keep it too tenderly, and close, it may chance to catch cold when it comes abroad.
True love ought to keep home, and not to gossip abroad.
Madam Monsieur Discretion is come to visit you.
Come, Doctor, be a witness of our contract?
I had rather stay with your maid.
She hath not wit to entertain you.
Nor none to anger me.
Pray come away, for no wise man is angry with wit.
I perceive, if I do not go with you, that you will call me fool.
Comorade, what cause makes you so fine to day?
I am going to two weddings to day.
Faith, one had been enough; but how can you divide yourself betwixt two Bridals?
I shall not need to divide my self, since the Bridals keeps toge∣there; for they are married both in one Church, and by one Priest, and they feast in one house.
And will they lye in one bed?
No surely, they will have two beds, for fear each Bride-groom should mistake his Bride.
Well, I wish the Bride-grooms, and their Brides joy, and their Guests, good cheer.
Will not you be one of the Guests?
No, for a Bon Compaignon shuns Hymens Court, neither will Hymen entertain him: But who are the Brides and Bride-grooms?
Monsieur Nobilissimo, and Madamosel Doltche, and Monsieur Perfection; and Madamosel Solid.
Is Monsieur Profession a Guest there.
No, for he swears now, that he hates marriage, as he hates death.
But he loves a Mistress, as he loves life.
Lady, why do you shun my company, in going from me, praystay, and give my visit a civil entertainment; for though I am not worthy of your affection, yet my love deserves you civility.
I know you are come to laugh at me, which is ignobly done; for heroic, generous spirits, doth not triumph on the weak effeminate Sex.
Pray believe I am a Gentleman, for if I loved you not, yet I would never be rude, to be uncivil to you, or your Sex; But I love you so well, as when I leave to serve you with my life, may nature leave to nourish me, fortune leave to favour me, and Heaven leave to bless me, and then let death cast me into Hell, there to be tormented.
I am more obliged to your generous affections, than to my own merits.
The ill opinion of your self doth not lessen your virtues, and if you think me worthy to be your Husband, and will agree, we will go strait to Church, and be married.
I shall not refuse you.

THE Poetress says, that if the Play be bad,
She's very sorry, and could wish she had
A better plot, more wit and skill to make
A Play that might each several humour take;
But she says, if your humours are not fixed,
Or that they are extravagantly mixed;
Impossible a Play for to present
With such variety, and temperiment;
But some will think it tedious, or find fault,
Say the Design or Language is stark nought;
Besides, the loose unsettled brains, she fears
Sees with squint eyes, and hears with Asses ears;
But she is confident all in this round,
Their understandings clear, and judgements sound;
And if her Play deserves not praise, she knows
They'll neither scoff in words, nor preposterous shows:
Without disturbance, you will let it dye,
And in the Grave of silence let it lye.
Husband, you have a strange nature, that ha∣avenge but one child, and never like to have more, and this your child a daughter; that you should breed her so strictly, as to give her no time for recreation, nor no li∣bertie for company, nor freedom for conversation, but keeps her as a Prisoner, and makes her a slave to her book, and your tedious moral discourses, when other children have Play-fellows, and toys to sport and pass their time withal.
Good wife be content, doth not she play when she reads books of Poetry, and can there be nobler, amiabler, finer, usefuller, and wi∣ser companions than the Sciences, or pleasanter Play-fellows than the Muses; can she have freer conversation, than with wit, or more various recreations than Scenes, Sonnets and Poems; Tragical, Comical, and Musical, and the like; Or have prettier toys to sport withal, than fancy, and hath not the liberty so many hours in the day, as children have to play in.
Do you call this playing? which sets her brain a worcester∣king to find out the conceits, when perchance there is none to find out, but are cheats, and cozens the Readers with empty words, at best, it sills her head but with strange phantasms, disturbs her sleep with frightful dreams of transformed bodies of Monsters, and ugly shaped vices of Hells and Furies, and terrifying Gods of Wars and Battles, of long travels, and dangerous escapes, and the pleasantest is but dark groves, gloomy fields, and the hap∣piest condition; but to walk idly about the Elizium fields; and thus you breed your daughter, as if your Posterity were to be raised from a Poets fantastical brain.
I wish my Posterity may last but as long as Homers lines.
Truly, it will be a fine airey brood! No no, I will have her bred, as to make a good housewife, as to know how to order her Family, breed her Children, govern her Servants, entertain her Neighbours, and to fashion herself to all companies, times and places, and not to be mewed and moped up, as she is from all the World, insomuch, as she never saw twen∣tie persons in one company in all her life, unless it be in pictures, which you set her to stare on above an hour everyday: Besides, what Father doth adieu∣cate their Daughters, that office belongs to me; but because you have no∣ver a Son to tutor, therefore you will turn Cotqucan, and teach your daugh∣la, which is my work.
Let me tell you, Wife, that is the reason all women are fools; for women breeding up women, one fool breeding up another, and as long as that custom lasts there is no hopes of amendment, and ancient cu∣stoms
being a second nature, makes folly hereditary in that Sex, by reason their education is effeminate, and their times spent in pins, points and laces, their study only vain fashions, which breeds prodigality, pride and en∣vie.
What? would you have women bred up to swear, swag∣ger, gaming, drinking, Whoring, as most men are?
No, Wife, I would have them bred in learned Schools, to noble Arts and Sciences, as wise men are.
What Arts? to ride Horses, and fight Dewels.
Yes, if it be to defend their Honour, Country and Reli∣gion; For noble Arts makes not base Vices, nor is the cause of lewd actions, nor is unseemly for any Sex; but baseness, vice and lewdness, invents un∣handsome and indecent Arts, which dishonours by the practice either Sex.
Come, come, Husband, I will have her bred, as usually our Sex is, and not after a new fashioned way, created out of a self-opiniated, that you can alter nature by education: No, no, let me tell you, a woman will be a woman, do what you can, and you may as soon create a new World, as change a women's nature and disposition.
O, Father! I have been in search of you, to ask you a que∣stion concerning the Sun.
What have you to do with the Sun, and lives in the shade of the Worlds obscurity.
Why, Madam? where would you have me live? can I live in a more serene air, than in my Fathers house, or in a purer, or clearer light, than in my Parents eyes, or more splendrous, than in my Parents com∣pany.
I would have you live at Court there, to have honour, favour and grace; and not to lose your time ignorantly, knowing nothing of the World, nor the World of you.
Can I live with more honour, than with my Father, and You, or have more favour than your loves; or is there a greater grace, than to be Daughter of virtuous Parents; can I use, or employ my time better, than to obey my Parents commands? need I know more than honesty, modesty, ci∣vility and duty: As for the World, mankind is so partial to each self, as they have no faith on the worth of their Neighbour, neither doth they take no∣tice of a Stranger, but to be taken notice of.
Yes, yes, your beauty will attract eyes and ears, which are the doors to let in good opinion, and admiration.
Had I a tongue like a Cerces-wand to charm all ears that heard me, it would staight transform men from civil Obligers, to spiteful Detractors, or false Slanderers; my beauty may only serve but as a bribe to tempt men, to entrap my youth, and to betray my innocence.
To betray a fools-head of your own! Lord! Lord! how the
dispositions of Youth is changed since I was young! for before I came to your Age, I thought my Parents unnatural, because they did not provide me a Husband.
If all youth were of my humour, their dispositions are change∣ed indeed; for Heaven knows, it is the only curse I fear, a Husband.
Why? then you think me cursed in Marrying your Fa∣there.
No Madam, you are blessed, not only in being a Wife, (a condition you desired) but being married to such a man that wishes could not hope for.
Why then, my good Fortune may encourage you, and raise a hope to get the like.
O no! It rather drives me to despair, believing there is no se∣cond.
Come, come, you are an unnatural Child to flatter your Father so much, and not me, when I endured great pains to breed, bear, and nurse you up.
I do not flatter, Madam, for I speak nothing but my thoughts, and that which Love and duty doth allow, and truth approve of.
Come, come Wife, the Jeerals wit will out-argue both ours.
Have I left my Husband, who was rich, and used me well? and all for love of you! and with you live as a Wanton! by which I have lost my esteem, and my honest reputation, and now to be for∣saken, and cast aside, despised and scorned! O, most base! for what can be more unworthy, than for a man to profess friendship to a Lady, and then forsake her?
Madam, you do me wrong, for my heart is as firmly yours, as ever it was, and burns with as clear a flame, as ever it did.
It is not like it will continue so, since you now are recall∣ved to marry.
The reasons are so powerful, that persuades me, by rea∣son there is none lest of my Family besides my self; and my Fathers com∣mands so terrifying, and my vows so binding, as I know not how to avoid it.
But since your Father is dead, what need you fear his commands, and for your vows, those may be dispensed with, for a sum of money to the Church for the poor.
But would you have me cut off the line of my Post∣rity by never marrying?
Perchance, if you marry, you may have no children, or your wife may prove barren, or if you have children, they may prove fools; for she you are affianced to, is none of the wisest.
That is none of my fault.
But why will you marry so soon?
I will not marry yet, for my affianced is young, and well may stay two or three years.
But if you will not marry her this two or three years, why must she come to live with you in your house.
By reason her Father is newly dead, and hath left her to my protection, as having right to her, and by her, to her estate.
And when she comes, I must deliver up the rule and government of your house and Family to her; for I suppose you will make her the Mistress to command, dispose and order as she pleases.
By no means, for you that are the Mistress of my heart, shall also be Mistress of my Estate.
Then pray give her to my charge and education; for I hear she is of a high spirit, and a proud heart, being spoiled with self-will, given her by the fondness of her Father.
Pray order her as you think good, she shall be your hand-maid.
Here flows a Sea, and there a sire doth flame,
Yet water and fire still is but the same:
Here the sixth earth, and there the air streams out,
All of one matter moving round about;
And thus the earth, and water, sire and air,
Out of each others shapes transformed are.
I am sure you are transformed from what you should be, from a sober, young maid, to a Stage-player, as to act Parts, speak Speeches, rehearse Verses, sing Sonnets, and the like,
Why, Madam; Stages and public Theaters, were first ordained and built, for the education of noble youth, where they might meet to pra∣ctise how to behave themselves civilly, modestly, gently, comely, gracefully, manly, and majestically; to speak properly, timely, fitly, eloquently, eel∣gently, tunably, tonably, readily, sagely, wittily. Besides, Theators were not only Schools to learn or practise in, but public patterns to take example from; Thus Theaters were profitable, both to the Actors and Spectators; for as these Theaters were public Schools, where noble principles were taught, so it was the dressing rooms of virtue, where the Actors, as her Ser∣vents did help to set her forth. Also these Theaters were as Scaffolds, where∣on vices were publicly executed; and, Madam, if you please but to consi∣der,
you will perceive, that Thrones are but glorious Theaters, where Kings and Princes, and their Courtiers acts their parts; likewise places of Judica∣ture, are but places where Judges and Lawyers acts their parts; Nay, even Churches are but holy Theaters, where the Priest and People acts their de∣vote parts. But, Madam, you mistake, making no difference betwixt the noble and base, the generous and mercenary; for, shall all noble persons that fights dewels of honour, be called Fencers; or shall a King, when he runs at the Ring, or Tilt, shall he be called a Jockey, or Post, when he rides whore∣ses of Manage, shall he be a Quirry, or a Rider; or shall Kings, Princes or noble Persons, that dances, sings, or plays on Music, or presents themselves in Masks, be thought, or called Dancers, or Fiddlers, Morris-dancers, Stage-players, or the like, as in their masking attire: No those are Riders, Fencers, Dancers, Fiddlers, Stage-players, and the like, that are mercenary, setting Ver∣tuosus to sale, making a mercenary profit, and living thereof; but if such open∣nions should be held, then no Vertuosus should be learned of noble Persons, because there are mercenary Tutors and Teachers, nor no arts understood, because of Mechanics, nor no Sciences understood, because of Pedants, nor no manners, nor graceful behaviours practised because of Players, nor none must write, because of Clerks, nor none must pray because of beneficed Priests, nor there must none understand the Laws, or plead their own causes, because of feed Lawyers; if these opinions or rules were followed, all the nobler and better sort, would be boars, clowns and fools, nor no civility, good manners, nor virtues would be known amongst them.
Well, well, I will have you show your self, and be known, and I known by you; for why should not I be as ambitious to be praised in your beauty, as your Father in your wit; but by that time you have gotten a suffi∣cient stock of wit to divulge to the World, your beauty will be dead and buried, and so my ruins will have no restoration, or resurrection.
Madam, I do humbly and dutifully acknowledge, that what beau∣tie or wit I have, it was derived from my Parents.
Wherefore you ought to do, as your Parents will have you, and I say, I will have you be a Courtier.
Would you have me go to live at the Court, Madam?
Yes marry would I.
And to do as Courtiers do?
Yes marry would I.
Alas, Madam, I am unpractised in their arts, and shall be lost in their subtle and strange ways.
Therefore I would have you go to learn them, that you may be as expert as the best of them, for I would have you shoot such sharp darts thorough your eyes, as may wound the hardest and obduratest hearts.
Amorous affections, Madam, and wanton glances are strangers to my eyes and heart; neither can I persuade nor command them to be other∣wise than they are.
Why, I would not have you either wanton, or amorous, but to be kind and civil, to invite a rich, noble Husband.
Why, say I had the power to pick and choose amongst the noblest and the richest men, a Husband out, you cannot promise me a happy life, fortune may set a Crown of Diamonds on my head, yet prick my heart with thorns, bind up my spirits with strong chained fears, my thoughts imprisoned in dark melancholy, and thus my mind may prove
a Hell unto my life, and my Husbands actions devils to torment it.
No disputing, but let my will be obeyed.
It is fit it should be by me, although it brings my ruin.
Joy gave me wings, and made my spirits fly,
Hope gave me strength to set ambition high;
Fear makes me old, as palsy shakes each limb,
My body weak, and both my eyes are dimb:
Like to a Ball, which rackets beats about,
So is my heart stricken twixt hope and doubt.
I observe, the Lord de L'amour uses the Lady Inno∣cence with more respect than he was used to do; and I observe his eyes meets her when she comes in place where he is, and follows her whereso∣ever she goes, and when she stands still, they are sixth upon her.
Truly she hath power, if she will put it in force to command a heart, at least to persuade a heart to love her; for certainly, she is very beau∣tifull, if it were not obscured under a sad countenance, as the Sun behind a dark cloud; but sometimes, do what she can in despite of her sadness, it will keep out, and the other day when you were gone abroad, I saw her dance, sing and play on a Gittur•, all at one time.
And how did it become her?
Truly, she sung so sweetly, played so harmoniously, danced so gracefully, and looked so beautifully, that if I had been a man, I should have been in love with her.
I charge you break her Gittar, tell her she sings not well, and that her dancing doth ill-become her.
Perchance she will not believe me.
Oh yes, for youth are credulous, even against them∣selves.
Ambitious thoughts flies high, yet never tires,
Winged with the swiftest thoughts of desires;
Then thoughts of hopes runs busily about,
Yet oft are stopped with thoughts of fear and doubt,
And thoughts of mirth and melancholy strives,
