I have been taught, none can be devirginated that suffers not immodest action, if so, I am a pure Virgin, and my thoughts are so in∣nocent, and my life so honest, as I wish the Chambers of my mind or soul, (which is the brain and the heart) were set open to your view; there should you see the pictures in the one, and read the letters in the other, for truth re∣cords all in the heart, and memory pencils all that the imaginations or Sen∣ses brings into the brain.
I cannot but believe what is so confidently reported; but your words are such charms, as they enchant my angry passions, and makes my will a prisoner.
Let reason, as a Knight of Chivalry, and truth as his E∣squire, set him free, and open the gates of understanding, then you might see virtue clothed with white Innocence, and truth free from the bonds of falsehood.
So you were as wife as witty.
Wisdom is built upon the Foundation of Experience; wherefore none can be wise but those that are old; but though I am too young to be wise, yet not to be vertously honest.
Pray Heaven you prove so.
This Lady Sanspareile hath a strange spreading wit, for she can plead causes at the Bar, decide causes in the Court of Jute∣cature, make Orations on public Theaters; act parts, and speak speeches on the Stage, argue in the Schools, preach in the Pulpits, either in Theology, Philosophy, moral and natural, and also physic and Metaphysick.
The truth is, she is ushered by the Muses, led by the Sciences, and attended by the Arts.
I do perceive my shiftless youth is round beset with enemies.
Suspicions round about me placed,
With slandring words my same disgraced:
My innocence, as crast is thought,
My harmless life to ruin brought;
Who will adore the Gods, if they
Vice, virtue, in one balance lay?
This Noble assembly may chance to think it a vanity in me, never to receive any particular visit or address from any particular or sin∣glee person, but I do so, by reason life is lost in particular acquaintance, as small Rivers are in running through the earth. But in the public, life swims as in a full Sea, having a fair gale of observation, and Sails of opportune time to swim withal, marking the Card of actions, and the Needle of dispositions
drawn or turned by the Loadstone of affection, to the North-pole of Expire∣ence, to guide me safe from the Rocks of slander, and quick-sands of scandal, till I come to the Port of death, there to unload my Lifes Merchandise; and I hope my Voyage may be so prosperous, as I may be enriched with the praises of After-Ages.
Likewise, the reason why I choose to speak in public, is, that I would not speak idly, for in public I shall take care of what I speak, and to whom I speak, when in private visitations to single persons, my speech may be care∣less with negligence, in which I may throw away my time with my words; For, to speak to no purpose, is to make words useless, and words is the marks to distinguish things, and Figures to number merits with, and Notes to record the noble Acts of men.
But at this time I am to speak by my Fathers command, upon a Subject which my contemplation hath no acquaintance with, which is marriage, and I hear by my Father, that you have all treated with him, or rather entreated him to bestow me in marriage, which is to make me unhappy, not but that I believe what I hear, which is, that you are all persons of Quality, Birth, Breed∣ing, and Merit, far beyond my desert, yet with the best, if any best there be, being all worthy; yet were I a wife to any one, I might be unhappy, by rea∣son marriage is an encumbered life, although the Husband and the Wife were fitly matched for years, Births, Fortunes, Dispositions, Humours, Capacities, Wits, Conversations, Constancies, Virtues, and affections; and first, by your leave, I will discourse of men's marriage, by reason Man being accounted the Supremer Creature, and always bearing Rule, he shall be first placed. As for marriage, to men it is a great hinderance to a speculative life, it cuts off Fancies Wings, and quenches out the Poetical Fire, it breaks the Engine of invention, disturbs sweet contemplation, corrupts honest Counsels, obe∣structs all Heroic actions, obscures fame, and often times causes infamy by the wives inconstancies, and many times by her indiscretion; for a man is dis∣honoured if his wife is but thought wanton, or but inclining to be amorous, and though she be as sober in her Nature, and as constant as any woman can be, yet the very suspicion is a disgrace, and if the suspicion is a disgrace, what is a visible truth? His very Neighbours makes Horns as he passes by their doors, whilst he sadly and shamefully hangs down his head with a dejected countenance, which makes him seem a Coward and a Fool, although it be unjust that the faults of the wife should be a blemish to the Husbands honour; yet so it is, this being the greatest cause why Husbands are jealous, which jealousy is more for their Honours sake, than for their Wives affections; thus you see how dangerous a thing it is for man to marry, who must trust his honour to the management of a Foolish Woman, and women naturally like children, inconstant, unless education doth rectify their frail natures, pee∣vish humours, various appetites, and inconstant affection: Likewise mar∣riage is not only apt to corrupt the mind with jealousy, but with Covetous∣ness; for the extreme fondness and natural love of Parents to their I will∣drone, makes them strive by all their endeavours to enrich them; this makes them gripe their Tenants, pinch and half starve their servants, quarrel and dispute with their neighbours, corrupt Judges take Bribes, besides it makes men apt to rebel, and turn Traitorus, murmuring at their Taxes and impositions, it also makes them timorous and fearful in wars, by reason their wife and i will∣drone may be ruined by their death. Also it makes them dull in their Con∣versations,
by reason they are always plodding for their worldly affairs; and for the Muses, had a husband time to entertain them, yet the wife would right them, or drive them from him, with their quarrelling disputes, or senseless prizes; besides most women are as jealous of the Muses, as of their Maids; but to treat or discourse of married women, is to discourse of a most unhappy life, for all the time of their lives is ensnared with troubles, what in breeding and bearing children, what in taking and turning away Ser∣vents, directing and ordering their Family, counting their expenses, and dis∣bursing their revenues, besides the vexations with their servants, for their quarrelling and combining, for their sloth and sluttery, for their spoils and carlessnesse, for their treachery and cousinage, and if they have Children, what troubles and griefs do unsue? Troubled with their frowardness and un∣towardness, the care for their well being, the fear for their ill doing, their grief for their sickness, and their unsufferable sorrow for their death; Yet this is the best part, and not to be avoided: But if these troubles be joined with an ill Husband, it heightens their torments; for if he be a Drunkard, she had better be married to a Beast, her nostrils is stencht with the Lees of wine, her eyes are offended with his rude behaviour, and her ears are struck with a cursed noise of cursing and Oaths; and if he be a Gamester, she lives in an unsettled condition, she knows not how soon she may want; for if she have plenty one day, she may be in a condition to beg the next. And if her Hus∣band be inconstant, and loves variety of women: O how jealousy torments her, besides the wrongs she suffers from him! what affronts she receives from his Mistress! How is she despised amongst her neighbours? slighted by her servant, suspected by the world for having some defect? as either to be in∣continent, sluttish, foolish, froward, cross, unkind, ill natured, sickly, or dis∣eased, when perchance the woman may be worthy to be marched with a tem∣pirate, wise, valiant, honest, rich and honourable man; and if women go fine, and take pleasure in themselves, and Garments, their Husbands are jea∣louse; and if they regard not themselves or Garments, their Husbands dislikes them; For though men will swear to their wives they like them better in their old clothes, than other women in their glorious Apparel; because they would not have them expensive, yet if their wives neglect themselves, regarding not their dressing, but sleights all outward Adornments, and change of Garments as prodigal spend-thrifts, they starve their Husbands esteem in their thrifty plainness, Consumes their affections in their peiced Petti∣coats, and buries their Husbands love in their dirty rags; And from the Dunghill of dirty rags, and grave of soul Linen, is their Husbands transfor∣med to beastly Adulteries, stealing by degrees out of one Form into another, as from a doting Husband, to a fond Husband, form a fond to a discreet Hus∣band, from a discreet, to a careful Husband, from a careful, to a careless, from a careless, to a disliking, from a disliking, to a hating, and then they be∣gin to wander; As first, an eye glances, from an eye glance, to an admirer; from an admirer, to a professor, from a professor, to a dissembler; from a dissembler, to an Adulterer; then for the dresses and garments of his Mistress, First, from clean, to new; from new, to fine; from fine, to brave; from brave, to glorious; from glorious to fantastical; from fantastical to profusely vari∣os from profusely, various to any dirty Slut. But his wife (on the other side, if his wife desires) appears handsome, and practises civil behaviour, and endeavours to be sine, takes care to be cleanly, observes to be fashionable, her
Husband straight becomes jealous, although she doth this for his sake, and to keep his affection, yet he thinks it is for the affection and sake of some other man, which causes private discontents, from private discontents to quarrelling disputes; from quarrelling disputes, to public exclamations, from public exclamations, to open defiance; from open defiance, to devorcement; and though I cannot say this by, or from experience, having it only from re∣lotion, yet I do as faithfully believe it, as if I were experienced therein: On which faith, I made a vow never to marry, since I hear men are so hard to please, and apt to change; wherefore if I were married, instead of discoursing of several arguments, I should be groaning and sighing, and weep∣ing, with several pains and vexations; and instead of a silent solitary contem∣plation, a clamorous quarrelsome conversation; instead of a peaceable life, I should be always in civil wars; and instead of being happy, I should be mi∣serable; for marriage is like a ship, which always lies on the roughest Belows of the Sea, rolling from side to side with discontents, sailing uncertainly, with inconstancy, and various winds, But noble, civil, kind and affectionate Gentle∣men, as I have told you, I have made a vow never to marry, and surely mar∣riage is not so happy an estate, or so pleasing a condition of life, as to persuade me to break my vow, neither can flattering Rhetoric, nor enticing beauty, nor adoring, admiring, deploring, praying, weeping Suitors persuade me, no, not a bleeding Suitor, were I sure he would dye, did he not enjoy me; for I will never be so dishonourable, perjurious, and impious, to break the holy Laws, and pull the Virgin Altars down, built in the conscience, on which are vows offered to Gods on high: Should I blow out that with faint inconstan∣cy, that pure bright Vestal Fire of innocence, from whence the Essence of chaste thoughts ascends to Heaven high; But rather than I would break my vow, I wish my ears as deaf as death, that hears no flattering sounds, nor sad complaints, nor terrifying threats, my eyes as dark as night, least light should bring some false deluding object in, for to deceive me; my heart like Ada∣mant, so hard love cannot enter, nor pity nor compassion wound; but how∣soever, I connote be wife to you all; wherefore since I cannot be every mans wife, I will dye every mans Maid. But I must tell this Noble Assembly, their meeting hath occasioned a quarrel here; for bashfulness, and confi∣dence hath fought a Duel in my Cheeks, and left the staines of blood there.
WHilst I was in his favour, my mind was like a pleasant Garden, where seve∣ral Fancies like several Birds, did make sweet melody; and in this Gar∣den a large, high Tree of Noble ambition grew; whereon hung fruits of hopes, but low misfortunes now hath cut it down, and therewithal have built a house, where melancholy dwells, darkened with Clouds of discontents, and winds of sighs, and show∣ers of tears, doth blow and power thereon.
Faith you will be well wived, for your assianced is known to be a Liar, and feared she will be a Whore, and proved a Thief.
How, a Thief?
Why, she hath stolen my Pearl Chain worth a thousand Pounds.
Tic impossible.
It is not impossible to prove a Thief.
No, for there is too many to miss; but sure it is impose∣sible she should prove one, she is so honourably born, and I never heard but she was Virtuously bred.
By your favour, Covetousness or Necessity, may tempt Honourable Births, and corrupt minds, that with plenty would be honest e∣nough.
I grant, misery may prove some Noble souls sprung from Honourable stocks, yet not to be so wickedly base as to steal, although so un∣worthy as to shark.
Why, sharking is next Neighbour to stealing, or as near Kindred as an Equivocation is to a Lye.
But she was never so necessitated, as to make her either a shark, or a Thief, having always plenty.
But she is covetous, and youth that is fond of all things they see, desires to enjoy all things they have not, and will endeavour by any means or ways to compass their desires.
I never found my Youth prompt to any such Acts.
Without more discourse, she hath stole my Chain, and I can prove it.
Tic strange, I know not what to think, or how to judge, which of the two Ladies is a Devil; for surely one of them is.
The Lady Sanspareile is the miracle of this age, the world doth not parrallel her with the like; for her behaviour is graceful and becoming, her Countenance modest and wife, her speech Majestic and witty, yet grave and learned, and her Oratory is after a New way.
It is reported, that there are many men come from all parts of the world to hear her, and those that cannot understand this Language, comes only to see her, so famous is she to all the world.
She is a great Honour to our Nation.
I hear she doth intend to plead in the behalf of poor Suitors, and hath asked leave of the Queen to be a pleader at the Barr, for all such as suf∣feared wrong as injustices, and for such Clients as hath just causes, but hath not means to follow the Law, as to see the Lawyers, &amp; she will plead for them gratis.
It is a pious and Noble Act.
Also her Father hath challenged all the eloquent Orators of our Nation, to make Orations extemporately; likewise he hath challenged the most famous Scholars and learned men to dispute with her.
Her Father is most dotingly fond of her.
He hath reason, and out of love to her he is building a very fine Library, to lay in all her Works; for they say she writes much, and hath writ many excellent Works.
She deserves a Statue for her self, as well as a Library for her Works.
Madam, my Lord and the Lady Incontinent hath sent me to tell you, you must come to be examined about the Chain.
I am so shrunk up with fear, that methinks I could thrus• my self into a Nut-shell to hide myself.
Faith if you could, it would not conceal you; for they would crack the Nut-shell and find you out.
The Lady Incontinent hath brought a Justice, who hath power to make you confess.
You may perceive her guilty, she trembles and shakes &amp; looks so pale.
Pray judge me not guilty by my countenance, bring it not as a witness against me, for the childish fears in my heart, causes a trem∣bling, which like an Earthquake, shakes my body, and makes my breath as pent up Air, that pants for passage, striving to get forth, and my innocent bash∣fullness, or my bashful innocence, makes my eyes like perturbed lights, that see nothing clearly; my words to flow like rough and broken streams; for my mind is so troubled, and my passions in such a storm, as my words can nei∣there flow easy, nor free.
Here be two that will witness that she stole the Chhain.
I will swear she took the Chain of Pearl, and put it in her pose∣ket, and so went out of the room with it.
Why did not you follow her, and take it from her.
I thought she would bring it again, for I never suspected she would deny it.
And will you witness the same Informer?
I will witness I saw it in her hand, looking on it.
What say you for your self Lady Innocence?
I say my accusements doth not make me guilty of a crime; but I confess I took the Chain in my hand, out of a curiosity, and trial of my judgment or skill, to see whether I could find any defect, in so much valued, esteemed, and high-prized a thing as Pearl; but not any ways out of a cove∣ton; Appetite, as to steal it, nor had I any tempting thoughts thereto, nor wished I that or the like should be lawfully given me.
What did you with it, when you had done viewing it?
I laid it on the Table from whence I took it off.
But here are those that will swear you carried it away with you.
Yes that we will.
I cannot always avoid a false accusation.
Will you swear you did not?
Yes, If my Oath will be taken.
Well, you did take it that is certain, wherefore you were best confess it, or you shall be wrecked to make you confess it.
I will never bear false-witness against my self; I will dye first.
My Lord, pray let her be carried away, and be whipped, until the be forced to confess it.
Let me killed first: for to be whipped is base, and is only fit for Gally-slaves, or those that are born from Slaves; but to be killed is Noble, and gives an Honourable triumph.
Young Lady, you are heer accused by two Witnesses, and unless you can bring Evidence to clear you, you are liable to punishment.
Truly Sir, I have but two invisible Witnesses, Conscience and Innocence, to plead for me, and Truth my Judge, who cannot be bribed, although it may be over-powr'd, by false and slanderous reports.
But it is imagined by your best friends, you are guilty.
Neither my friends, nor enemies, can create me a Crime∣nal, with their Imaginations.
But speak, are you guilty?
To what purpose should I speak? for what can I say to those that make it their delight to accuse, condemn, and execute? or what justice can I expect to have, where there is no equity? wherefore, to plead were a folly, when all hopes are cut off; to desire life, a double misery, if I must endure Torments; but silence, and patience, shall be my two Comp∣nions, the one to help me in my suffering, the other to cut of impertinen∣cies.
What think you Justice, is she guilty?
Why should you make a question, when it hath been proved by Witnesses? Come Justice, Come, and drink a Cup of Sack, and give your opinion then.
I am so confidently accused of this Theft, as I am half per∣swaded I did take the Chain, but that Honour and Honesty says I did not.
Where is your Mistress? the people do flock about the house to see her, as I think they will pull it upon my head if she shows not her self to them, wherefore call her.
Come, Come Child, there are such expectations without for thee; but what makes thee to look so heavy?
Truly Sir, I am not well.
Not well? Heaven bless thee; where art thou Sick?
I cannot say I am very sick, or in any great pain; but I find a general alteration in me, as it were a fainting of spirits.
Prithee say not so, thou dost so affright me; but thou art not very sick, art thou?
I hope I shall be better Sir.
My dear Child go to bed, whilst I send for some Doctors to thee.
TO whom shall I power out my sad complaint? for all do them a Melan∣choly mind. O Gods! how willingly would I be buried in the grave with dust, and feast the worms, rather than live amongst mankind! Oh! Oh! that these Melancholy damps arising from my afflicted Soul could extinguish the Lamp of life, or that my sad and grieved thoughts that feed upon my troubled Spirits, could bite with sorrows teeth, the thread of life asunder.
My sweet Mistress, why do you weep?
The spring of grief doth send forth streams of tears to wash off my disgrace, and the foul spots which slandring tongues have stained, or rather slain my reputation; for which my eyes, did they not weep, would seem unnaturally unkind; but my dead reputation is embalmed with salt tears, bitter groans, shrouded in sorrows, and entombed in misery.
My dear Lady, you are embalmed with the precious gums of
Virtue, and sweet spices of wit wrapped up in youth and beauty, and are entomb∣ed, or rather enthroned in honest hearts; wherefore waste not your self with grief; for certainly the world will condemn your Accusers, and not you.
Those feeble hopes cannot my spirits uphold, they give no light of comfort to my mind; for black despair, like Melancholy night, mustles my thoughts, and makes my Soul as blind. O but why do I thus mourn in sad complaints, and do not curse Fortune, Fates, and destiny, their Wheels, there spindel, threads, and Chains?
May Nature great, turn all again to nought,
That nothing may with joy receive a thought.
She is deeply Melancholy, Heavens ease her mind.
The Lady Sanspareile cannot live, for the hath no pulse.
No, she is descending to the grave.
But had we best tell her Father so?
No, by no means as yet.
Why not? he will know when she is dead.
Mr. Doctors, What, do you mean to let my Daugh∣la dye? will you not prescribe something to give her?
Madam, we shall do our best, you may be confident.
What if you prescribed a Glister, or a Purge?
I shall not need Madam.
Why, if any one be sick, they ought to have some re∣medies applied to them:
We shall consider what course is best to be taken.
For Gods sake do not neglect her.
Mr. Doctors, what is your opinion of my Daughter?
Truly Sir, she is very dangerous sick.
I can find no pulse she hath.
Nor we Sir, that makes us doubt her.
Pray consult about her what is best to be done.
We shall Sir.
What makes you look so ghastly pale?
I am so ashamed of my accusation, as my bashfulness is beyond all blushing, as greatest griefs are beyond all tears, it causes my limbs to tremble, face look pale, like Death's assault, making my courage fail.
Perchance you are ashamed to confess so base a crime; you may confess to me, for I shall strive to hide your faults, and cover them with some excuse; wherefore confess; for though it be a fault to steal, yet it is a double fault to hide it with a Lye, and by these crimes you do offend the Gods; nor will their anger be removed, unless you confess and ask pardon.
Your Doctrine is very good, and Application well apply∣ed, had I been Guilty; but being Innocent, they are vainly uttered.
I hope you will agree to resign the interest you have to me, if I should desire you.
Saints never offred up their Souls to God more willingly, than I all interest to you; not but that I love you, yet I should be loath to be bound to one that hath so ill an opinion of me, as you have.
The World would condemn me, if I should marry you, to stain my Posterity with your Crimes.
O Heavens, is my scandal of so deep a dye, as to stain Pre∣decessors and Posterity! yours may avoid it, but my Predecessors are spot∣ted all over.
I cannot choose but love her, although I fear she is guilty; but I perceive she is resolved not to confess, as being ashamed of it.
Let spotless Virgins bear me to my grave, and holy An∣thems sing before my Hearse, and soft-toucht Instruments to play the while, and keep just time with tears, that trickling fall from the sad eyes of my most sorrowful friends; and one my Coffin spread upon a covering of smooth Satin, white, to signify here how I lived a Virgin, pure I lived and die∣ed; and let my works which I have wrought, and spun out of my brain, be given to times Library, to keep alive my name.
And set a Lilly-Garland on my Hearse,
On every leaf therein, stick on a verse;
And when my Coffin to the grave you bring,
Let Poets on my Hearse some verses fling.
For whilst I lived I worshipped Nature great,
And Poets are by Nature savoured.
I in the Muses Arms desire to Dye,
For I was bred up in their Company:
And my requesl's to them, when I am dead,
I may amongst them be remembered.
But death draws near, my destiny is come; Father farewell: may time take up my years, which death cuts off, and add them to your life: Peace keep your mind, and Comfort give you rest.
But why do you weep dear Father? my life's not worth your tears; yet Heavens doe weep, and mingle with dull earth their Crystal streams, and earth's refreshed thereby; so is not death, for death is ever dry.
O Child! O Child! my heart will break.
Sir, why do you sigh and groan, and grieve, that I must dye? life is perpetual, and death is but a change of shape.
Only I wish that Death may order it so,
That from your roots I may your flower grow.
I fear not Death, nor am I loath to dye:
Yet I am loath to leave your Company.
But O the Muses stay my dying lips to close. Farewell
What art thou sted? dear Soul wheredost thou go? stay and I will bear thee Company.
Where art thou Soul? why make thou such great haste? I pray thee stay, and take thy aged Fathers Soul along with thee, left it should wander in the dark and gloomy shades to find thee out. O! O death! quick dispatch, Let me unprisoned be, my body is old, decayed and worn, times ruins shows it. Oh! Oh! let life fall, for pity pull it down.  Am I not dead? you cruel powers above, to lengthen out an old mans life in misery and pain; why did not Time put out the sight of both my eyes, and also deaf my ears, that I might neither hear, nor see, the death of my lifes joy? O Luxurious Death, how greedily thou feedst on youth and beauty, and lie old Age hang withering on lifes tree? O shake me off, let me no longer grow, if not, grief shall by force snip off my tender stalk, and pity lay me in the silent grave. Hark, Hark, I hear her call me? I come, I come Child.
O no, she is gone, she is gone, I saw her dead; her head hung down, like as a Lily, whose stalk was broke by some rude blusterous wind.
There, there I see her on her duteous knee; Her humble eyes cast to the ground; Her spotless hands held up for blessings crave, asking forgiveness for faults not done. O no, She is dead! She is dead! I saw her eye-lids close
like watery Clouds, which join to shut out the bright Sun; and felt her hands which Death made cold and numb, like as to Crystal balls; She is gone, she is gone, and restless grows my mind; thoughts strive with thoughts, &amp; struggle in my brain, passions with passions in my heart make War.
My Spirits run like suries all about;
Help help for Heavens sake, and let life out.
O my daughter! my daughter is dead, she is dead. Oh that ever I was born to bear a Child to dye before me. Oh she was the Comfort of my Heart, the pleasure of my Eyes, the delight of my life. Oh she was Good, she was Sweet, she was Fair. O what shall I do, what shall I do?
Mercury lend me thy winged feet, that I may fly to Heaven, there to observe, how all the Gods and Goddesses doe gaze upon my Beautiful Child; for she is fairer than the light that great Apollo gives; and her discourse more ravishing than the Music of the Spheres; but as soon as she sees me, she will leave them all, and run unto me, as she used to do, kneeling will kiss my hands, which she must not do, being a Goddess, and I a Mortal, wherefore, I must kneel to her, and carry her an offering; but what shall the offering be? Let me think. Why I will kneel and offer up my Aged life unto her Memory; but now I think of it better, I cannot dye in Heaven; wherefore, let me Study, let me Study, what she did love best when she lived upon the Earth; O I now remember, when I did ask her what she loved best, she would Answer, her Father and her Fame; but I believe, if she were here it would be a hard Question for her to resolve, which she preferred; and being not to be separated in Affection, we will not part in our Resurrection; wherefore Mercury farewell: for I will fly up with the Wings of her good Fame.
And carry up her Wit, and there will strew
It on Heavens floor, as bright as Stars will show;
Her Innocence shall make new Milky ways,
Her Virtue shall Create new Worlds to praise
Her never-dying Name.
Ha, Ho! It shall be so, it shall be so.
I am not so much in love with the World, as to desire to live, nor have I offended Heaven so much, as to be afraid to dye; then way should I prolong my life, when Honour bids me dye? for what Noble Soul had not rather part with the Body, than live in Infamy? Then tic not Death that affrights me, and yet I find my Soul is loath to leave its bodily Mansion; but O to be buried in Oblivions grave is all I fear; no Monumental Fame, nor famous Monument, my Soul displeases, that makes it loath to leave the body in forgotten dust, whilst it doth sadly wander in the Air.
Soul be at ease, for the Memory of the dead is but like a dying Beauty, vades by degrees, or like a Flower whithered, hath neither Sent, Colour, nor Taste, but molders into dust: so hath the mind no form of what is past.
But like as formless heaps those Objects lye,
And are entombed in the dark Memory.
O Foolish Vanity, to be so much a slave to Fame, since those that Fame doth love the best, and favours most, are not Eternal. Wherefore
Nature persuades me to release my woe,
Though foolish Superstition Natures foe
Forbids it, yet Reason aloud says dye;
Since Ease, Peace, Rest, doth in the grave still lye.
I am resolved, then Come sweet Death, thou friend that never fails, give me my liberty. But stay my hasty resolution; for I would not willingly go to the grave as beasts doe, without Ceremony; for I being friendless, those hue∣mane Funeral rites will be neglected, none will take the pains, nor be at the charge to see them performed; but some base vulgar person will throw me into the Earth without respect or regard; wherefore I will Living perform the Ceremonies, and as a guess or friend be at my own Funeral; it shall be so, and I will prepare it.
Multitudes of Melancholy thoughts crowd in my brain,
And run to pull down Reason from his Throne;
Fury as Captain leads the way,
Patience and Hope is trod upon:
O these distracted thoughts burrie my Soul about,
Seeking a place to get a passage out.
But all the Ports are stopped. O Cursed Death, for to prolong a life that is so weary of its Mansion.
Sir, will you give order for your Daughters Funeral, and direct how you will have her interred?
How say you? why I will have you rip my body open, and make it as a Coffin to lay her in, then heave us gently on sighs fetched deep, and lay us on a Hearse of sorrowful groans, then cover us with a Dark, Black, Pitchy, Spungy Cloud, made of thick Vapour, drawn from bleeding hearts; from whence may tears of showers run pouring down, making a Sea to drown remembrance in.
But O remembrance, is a fury grown,
Torments my Soul, now she is gone.
Sir, where there is no remedy, you must have patience.
Patience, out upon her, she is an Idle lazy Gossip, and keep; none Company but Cowards and Fools, and slothful conscientious Persons; neither is she useful but for indifferent employments: for what is of extraordi∣nary worth, Patience doth but disgrace it, not set it forth; for that which is transcendent and Supreme, Patience cannot reach. Wherefore give me Fury, for what it cannot raise to Heaven, it throws it straight to Hell; were you no∣ver there?
No, nor I hope shall never come there.
Why Sir, I was there all the last Night, and there I was tor∣tured for chiding my Daughter two or three times whilst she lived; once because she went in the Sun without her Mask; another time because her Gloves were in her Pocket, when they should have been on her Hands; and another time, because she slep'd when she should have studied, and then I remember she wept. O! O! those precious tears! Devil that I was to grieve her sweet Nature, harmless Thoughts, and Innocent Soul. O how I hate my self, for being so unnaturally kind. O kill me, and rid be of my painful life.
He is much distracted, Heaven cure him.
The Miracle is deceased, the Lady Sanspareile I hear i• dead.
Yes, and it's reported her Statue shall be set up in every College, and in the most public places in the City, at the public charge; and the Queen will build a Sumptuous and Glorious Tomb on her sleeping Ashes.
She deserves more than can be given her.
I hear her death hath made her Father mad.
Though her death hath not made every one mad like her Father, yet it hath made every one melancholy; for I never saw so general a sadness in my life.
There is nothing moves the mind to sadness, more than when Death divots Youth, Beauty, Wit, and Virtue all at once.
There is a Hearse placed upon the Stage, covered with black, a Garland of Cyprus at the head of the Hearse, and a Garland of Myrtle at one side, and a Basket of Flowers on the other.
O Nature, thou hast created bodies and minds subject to pains &amp; torments, yet thou hast made death to release them! for though Death hath power over Life, yet Life can command Death when it will; for Death dares not stay, when Life would pass away; Death is the Ferry∣man, and Life the Wastage.
But here great Nature, I do pray to thee,
Though I call Death, let him not cruel be:
Great Jove I pray, when in cold earth I lye,
Let it be known how innocent I die.
Here in the midst my sadder Hearse I see;
Covered with black, though my chief Mourners be,
Yet I am white, as innocent as day,
As pure as spotless Lilies born in May;
My loose and flowing hair with Ribbons tied,
To make Death Amorous of me, now his Bride;
Watchet for truth, hair-colour for despair,
And white as innocent as purest Ayre;
Scarlet for cruelty to stop my breath,
Darkening of Nature, black, a type of death.
Roses and Lilies about my Coffin strew,
Primroses, Pinks, Violets fresh and new:
And though in deaths cold arms anon I lye 
I'll weep a shower of tears these may not dye,
A Cyprus Garland here is for my head,
To crown me Queen of Innocence, when dead;
A Myrtle Garland on the left side placed,
To show I was a Lover; pure &amp; chaste;
Now all my saddest Rites being thus about me,
And I have not one wish that is without me.
Here on this Hearse I mount the Throne of death,
Peace crown my soul, my body rest on earth:
Yet before I dye,
Like to a Swan I will sing my Elegy.
Life is a trouble at the best,
And in it we can find no rest;
Joys still with sorrows they are Crowned,
No quietness till in the ground.
Man vexes man, still we do find,
He is the torture of his kind:
False man I scorn thee in my grave
Death come, I call thee as my slave.
Here ends my Lords Writing.
I will observe how she passes away her time, when she is alone.
Great Jove grant that the light of Truth may not be put out, with the extinguisher of Malice.
How she feeds her melancholy!
What are you acting a melancholy Playby your self alone?
My part is almost done.
By Heaven she hath stabbed her self.
Call not for help, life is gone so far tic past recovery; wherefore stay and hear my last words; I die, as judging it unworthy to out-live my honest Name, and honourable Reputation. As for my accusers, I can easily forgive them, because they are below my Hate or Anger, neither are worthy my revenge; But you, for whom I had not only a devout, but an Idolatrous Affection, which offered with a zealous Piety and pure Flame the sincerity of my heart; But you, instead of rewarding my Love, was cruel to my life and Honour, for which my soul did mourn under a Veil of sad∣ness, and my thoughts covered with discontent sate weeping by: But those mourning Thoughts I have cast off, clothing my self with Deaths pale Gar∣mints; As for my pure Reputation, and white Simplicity, that is spotted with black Infamy by Hellish slander, I have laid them at Heavens Gates, just Gods to scour them clean, that all the World may know how innocent I have been: But Oh! farewell, my fleeting Spirits pure Angels bear a∣way.
O speak at the last! Are you guilty or not?
I am no more guilty of those crimes laid to my charge, than Heaven is of sin.
O Gods receive me. Oh! Oh!
Great Patience assist me; Heart hold life in,
Till I can find who is guilty of this sin.
How are you now?
O Friend! I shall now be well, Heaven hath pity on me, and will release me soon; and if my Daughter be not buried, I would have her kept as long out of the Grave as she can be kept, that I might bear her company.
She cannot be kept longer, because she was not unbowelled.
Who speaks her Funeral Oration?
Why Sir, your distemper hath so disordered all your Family, as it was not thought of.
She shall not go to the Grave without due Praises, if I have life to speak them: Wherefore raise me up, and carry me to the Holy place before her Hearse, thus in my Chair, sick as I am; For I will speak her Few∣neral Oration, although with my last words, Thus will I be carried living to my Grave.
When I do think of her, my mind is like a tempestu∣os Sea, which foams and roars, and roles in Billows high; My brain like to a Ship is wrecked, and in it's ravenous Waves my heart is drowned; And as several winds do blow, so several thoughts do move; some like the North with cold and chilly Fears, others as from the South of hot Re∣avenge do blow;
As from the East despairing storms do rise,
A Western grief blows tears into mine eyes.
My Lord, why are you so melancholy for that which is past, and cannot be helped?
Oh! the remembrance of her death, her cruel death, is like the Infernal Furies, torments my soul, gives it no case nor rest; For some∣times my soul is flung into a Fire of Rage,
That burns with furious pain,
And then with frozen despair it rips it up again.
But I unjust and credulous, I was the cause of her untimely death.
O my Lord, forgive me, for I have murdered the innocent La∣die you grieve for; for my false Accusation was the hand that guided the dag∣ger to her heart; but my Ladies command was the Thief that stole the Chain, for she commanded me to take the Chain, and accuse the Lady of the Theft, for which she gave me the Chain for a reward; This I will wit∣ness by oath unto you and all the World; For it is heavier than a world up∣on my Conscience.
Why did your Lady so wicked an act?
Through Jealousy, which bred Envy, Envy Malice, Malice Slander, and this Slander hath produce Murder.
Oh my Lady! My Lady hath hanged her self; for when she heard Falsehood was gone to tell your Lordship the truth of the Chain, she went into a base place and hung her self; and upon her breast I found this written Paper.
It is the Lady Incontinents Hand-writing.
I have been false to my Marriage-bed, lived impudently in the sin of Adultery,
in the public face of the World; I have betrayed the trust imposed to my charge, standered the Innocent, poisoned the Instrument I employed, Falsehood. All which being summed up, was worthy of hanging.
She hath saved me a labour, and kept my Heroic Ho∣nor free from the stains of having laid violent hands on the Effeminate Sex.
What shall be done with this dead Body?
Let her Ladies body, with hers, be thrown into the Fields, to be devoured of Beasts.

The whilst her Father is carried as sick in a Chair, the Chair covered with black, and born black by Mourners, he himself also in close Mourning; when they have gone about the Stage.
Then the Father is placed in his Chair, upon a raised place for that purpose, the raised place also covered with Black; he being placed, speaks her Few∣neral Sermon.
Most Charitable and Noble Friends, that accompany the Dead Corps to the Grave, I must tell you, I am come here, although I am as a Dead Man to the World, yet my desire is to make a living Speech, before I go out of the world, not only to divulge the Affections I had for my Daugh∣la, but to divulge her Virtue, Worth, and good Graces; And as it is the cu∣stome for the nearest Kindred, or best and constantest Friends, or longest ac∣quaintance, to speak their Funeral Oration, wherein I take my self to be all,
wherefore most fit to speak her Funeral Oration; For I being her Father, am her longest acquaintance, and constantest Friend, and nearest in Relation, wherefore the, fittest to declare unto the world my natural and Fatherly Love, Death will be a sufficient witness; For though I am old, yet I was health∣full when she lived, but now I cannot live many hours, neither would I, for Heaven knows, my affections struggle with Death, to hold Life so long as to pay the last Rites due to her dead Corps, struck by Death's cruel Dart: But most Noble and Charitable Friends, I come not here with eye filed with sal• tears; for sorrows thirsty Jaws hath drunk them up, sucked out my blood, &amp; left my Veins quite dry, &amp; luxuriously hath eat my Marow out; my sighs are spe•t in blowing out Life's Fire, only some little heat there doth remain, which my affections strive to keep alive to pay the last Rites due to my dead Child, which is, to set her praises forth, for living Virtuously; But had I Nestors years, it would prove too few, to tell the living Stories of her Youth, for Nature in her had packed up many Piles of Experience, of Aged times, be∣sides, Nature had made her Youth sweet, fresh and temperate, as the Spring; and in her brain, Flowers of Fancies grew, Wits Garden set by Natures hand, wherein the Muses took delight, and entertained themselves therein, Singing like Nightingales, late at Night; or like the Larks ere the day begin; Her thoughts were as the Celestial Orbs, still moving circular without back ends, surrounding the Center of her Noble mind, which as the Sun gave light to all about it; her Virtues twinkled like the fixed Stars, whose mo∣tion stirs them not from their fixed place; and all her Passions were as other stars, which seemed as only made to beautify her Form; But Death hath turned a Chaos of her Form, which life with Art and Care had made, and Gods had given to me: O cursed death, to rob and make me poor! Her life to me was like a delightful Mask, presenting several interchanging Scenes, de∣scribing Nature in her several Dresses, and every Dress put in a several wa•• Also her life was like a Monarchy, where Reason as sole King, did govern al her actions; which actions, like as Loyal Subjects did obey those Laws which Reason decreed; Also her life was like Ioves Mansions high, as being placed above this worldly Globe; from whence her Soul looked down on duller earth, mixed not, but viewed poor mortals here below; thus was her life a∣bove the world, because her life prized not the Trifles here; Perchance this Noble Company will think I have said too much, and vainly, thus to speak.
That Fathers should not praise their Children so,
Because that from their Root and Stock did grow;
Why may not Roots boast if their Fruits be good?
As hindering worth in their own Flesh and blood,
Shall they dissemble, to say they are nought,
Because they are their own? sure that's a fault
Unpardonable, as being a lye that's told,
Detracting lies, the baser lies I hold.
Neither can strangers tell their life and worth,
Nor such affections have to set them forth,
As Parents have, or those thats near of Kin,
Virtuous Partiality, sure that's no sin,
And virtue, though she be lovliest when undressed
Yet she is pleased, when well she is expressed.
But Oh! my words have spent my stock of breath,
And Life's commanded forth by powerful Death;
When I am dead, this company I pray,
The last rites done, me by my daughter lay;
And as her soul did with the Muses fly,
To imitate her in her a verse, I dye.
Noble Friends, you heard his request, which was; to be bu∣riot in his daughters grave; and whilst you show your charity, in laying the Corps of his daughter in the grave, I will carry out his body, and put it into a Coffin, and then lay him in the same grave.
The whilst the Virgins take up the Lady Sanspareiles Hearse, and whilst they are putting it into the grave, this Song following was sung.
Tender Virgins, as your Birth,
Put her gently in the earth,
What of Moral, or Divine,
Here is lapped up in this shrine;
Rhetoric dumb Philosophy,
Both those arts with her did dye.
And grieved Poets cannot choose,
But lament for her their Muse.
When she was putting into the Grave, this Song following was sung.
Her Tomb, her Monument, her Name,
Beyond an Epitaph her Fame;
Death be not proud, embracing more
Now, than in all thy reign before;
Boasting thy Triumphs, since thou must
But justly glory in her dust,
Let thy Dart rust, and lay it by,
For after her none's sit to dye.
Now I am free, no hinderance to my own Tragedy.
This Tomb her sacred Body doth contain.

Sweet gentle Spirit•, fly me not, but stay,
And let my Spirits walk thy Spirits way;
You loved me once, your Love in death renew,
And may our souls be as two Lovers true;
Our Blood's the Bonds, our wounds the Seals to Print
Our new Contract, and Death a witness in it.
Had I as many lives as Poors in skin,
He sacrifice them for my ignorant sin.

Friend, lay me in this Tomb, by my affianced Wife; for though I did not usher her to the grave, I will wait after her.
Noble Spectators, now you have seen this Play,
And heard it speak, let's hear what now you say;
But various judgements, various sentences give,
Yet we do hope you'll sentence it may live.
But not in Prison be condemned to lye,
Nor whipped with censure, rather let it dye
Here on this Stage, and see the Funeral Rites,
Which is, to put out all the Candle lights.
And in the grave of darkness let it rest,
In peace and quiet, and not molest
The harmless soul, which hopes Mercury may
Unto the Elizium fields it safe convey.
But if you sentence life, the Muses will
Attend it up unto Parnassus Hill.
If so, pray let your hands, here in this place,
Clap it, as an applause, the triumph grace.

What Lady Contemplation, musing by your self alone?

Why, are you so godly, to be so serious at your Devo∣tion?
No faith, they were Contemplations that pleased me better than Devotion could have done; for those that contemplate of Heaven, must have death in their mind.
O no, for there is no Death in Heaven to disturb the joys thereof.
But we must dye before we come to receive those joys; and the terrifying thoughts of Death, take away the pleasing thoughts of Hey∣ven.
Prithee let me know those pleasing thoughts.
I did imagine my self such a Beauty, as Nature never made the like, both for Person, Favour, and Colour, and a Wit answerable to my Beauty, and my Breeding and Behaviour answerable to both, my Wisdom excelling all: And if I were not thus as I say, yet that every one should think I were so; for opinion creates more, and perfecter Beauties, than Nature doth. And then that a great powerful Monarch, such a one as Alexander, or Caesar, fell desperately in love with me, seeing but my Picture, which was sent all about the world; yet my Picture (I did imagine) was to my disad∣vantage, not flattering me any ways; yet this Prince to be enamoured with this shadow for the substance sake: Then Love persuaded him to send me his Picture, which represented him to the life, being extremely handsome, yet had a manly and wise countenance. This Picture being brought by Em∣bassadours, which Ambassadors when they came, treated with me about marriage with this sole Emperor, all other Kings and Princes being but Tri∣butteries; receiving these Ambassadors with great civility and respect, yet behaving my self with a reserved and Majestic behaviour, which the Em∣bassadours observing, said, I was the only Lady that was fit to be the only Emperors wife, both for my Beauty, Carriage, and Wit: When after a modest Fear, and seeming Humility, I had reasoned against the marriage, at last by their persuasion I consented; then was there Post after Post, and Mes∣senger after Messenger, sent with letters from the Emperor to me, and from me to the Emperor; he admiring my letters, for the elegance of the stile, and eloquence of the wit, and admiring my Picture for the beauty; one while
reading my letters, and another while viewing my Picture, made him imp∣tient for my Company, which made him send to his Ambassadors, that with all speed they should bring me away, sending to all the Princes whose King∣domes I was to pass thorough, that they should guard me with Armies, but not retard me with Olimpias, or the like, but to convey me safe and speedily: Whereupon I took my Journey (most of the Kingdom where I was born petitioning to wait on me); but by reason I could not take them all, unless I should depopulate the Kingdom, I would carry none, lest I should displease those that were to be left behind; but as I went out of the City where I dwelt, all the streets were strewed with dead Lovers, which had lived only on hopes, so long as I lived amongst them: But when they knew for certain I was to depart, their hopes vanished, and they dyed with despair. The Em∣bassadours seeing such a Mortality, caused the Army that was my guard to march apace, and my Coaches to trundle away, thinking it was the Plague; but at last, after my Beauty had killed millions in the Kingdoms I passed thorough, I arrived at that part of the world where the Emperor was, who was a joyed man to hear of my coming, and had made great preparations a∣against my arrival; but some few days before my arrival, he sent a Chariot which was made of the thinnest plated gold, because it should be light in the Carriage, but the body of the Chariot was enamelled and set with pre∣cious stones, the Horses trappings were only great Chains of pearls, but the horses reigns were Chains of gold, that might be strong enough to check their hot Spirits, and swift speed; as for my self, I was only clothed in white Sa∣tin, and a Crown of Diamonds on my head, like a Bride, for I was to be married as soon as I met the Emperor; but as I past along, all the High∣ways were beset with Crowds of people, which thronged to see me, and when they saw me, they cried out I was an Angel sent from the Gods; but your coming spoiled the Triumph, and brake the Marriage.
No. no it is retarded for a time, the next musing Contemplation the marriage Nuptial will be.
If you had not come and hindered me, I should have go∣ver'nd all the world before I had left off Contemplating.
But if you make such hast to be at the Government of the whole world, you would want a Theme for your thoughts to work upon, for you can aim at no more than all the world.
O yes, rather than fail I would make new worlds, but this will last me a long time in showing you what wise Laws I make, what upright Justice I give, ordering so, as the whole world should be as one united Fami∣lie; and when I had showed my wisdom in Peace, then my thoughts should have raised Wars, wherein I would have showed my valour and con∣duct.
Prithee be not so imprudent to cast away precious time, and to bury thy life in fantasms.
Why prithee, they manage time best, that please life most; For it were better not to be, than to be displeased; for there is none that true∣lie lives, but those that live in pleasure, &amp; the greatest pleasure is in the imagine∣tion not in fruition; for it is more pleasure for any person to imagine themselves Emperor of the whole world, than to be so; for in imagination they reign &amp; Rule, without the troublesome and weighty cares belonging thereto; neither have they those fears of being betrayed or usurped as real Emperors have;
Besides, the whole general Race of Man-kind, may this way be the particular Emperor of the whole World, if they will; but those that desire to be Emperors any other ways, have but sick judgements, for the mind is all, for is that be pleased, man is happy.
Well, well, I had rather have the Material world, than you Airy Fictions.— But confess really to me, if you should not think your self ac∣cursed if you were to have no other Lovers, but what your Fancy cre∣ates.
No truly, for I finding none so exact as my Fancy creates, makes all men appear worse than they are: For imagination doth like Pain∣ters, which takes all the gracefullest lines, and exactest Features from two or three good faces, and draws them into one: this is the reason that there may be handsomer Pictures drawn, than any Creature born; because, Nature di∣stributes and divides her Favours, as to the generality, when Painter contract them into particulars; for there was never any, unless born as a wonder, that hath no exceptions; besides, my Lovers which my Fancy cre∣ates, never make me jealous, nor never disturb me; come to me, and go from me; speak or are silent as I will have them, and they are behaved, qual∣fied, and adorned to my humour, also of what Birth, Age, Complexion, or Stature I like best; thus their persons and souls are created in my brain, live in my Contemplation, and are dead and buried in my forgetfulness, but have a Resurrection in my remembrance,
Prithee do not lose the pleasure of the World, for the sake of dull Contemplation.
Why, the greatest pleasures that can be in Fruition, I take in Imagination: for whatsoever the sense enjoys from outward objects, they may enjoy in inward thoughts. For the mind takes as much pleasure in cre∣ating of Fancies, as Nature to create and dissolve, and create Creatures anew: For Fancy is the Minds creature, &amp; imaginations are as several worlds, where∣in those Creatures are bred and born, live and dye; thus the mind is like infinite Nature.
Prithee leave thy infinite folly.
It is my infinite delight.
Madam, why do you weep, and grieve your self almost to death?
Have I not reason? my Father being killed, and I left friendless all alone, my Mother dying as soon as I was born.
There is no reason you should grieve for your Father, since he dyed in the defence of his King and Country.
Tic true, and I glory in his valiant loyal Actions, yet I cannot choose but mourn for the loss of his life, and weep upon his death.
Methinks the greatest cause you have to weep, is, for the loss of your Estate, which the Enemy hath seized on, and you left only to live on Charity.
I cannot mourn for any thing that is in Fortunes power to take away.
Why? Fortune hath power on all things in the World.
O no, she hath power on nothing but base dross, and outward forms, things moveable; but she hath neither power on honest hearts, nor noble Souls; for it is the Gods infuse grace, and virtue; nor hath she power or Reason, or Understanding, for Nature creates, and disposes those; nor doth she govern Wisdom, for Wisdom governs her; nor hath she power on Life and Death, they are decreed by Heaven.
And will you weep at Heavens decree?
The Heavens decrees hinder not humanity, nor natural af∣fection.
Well, ever since your Mother dyed, I have governed your Fa∣theirs House, and pleased him well; but since he is killed, and that there is nothing for me to govern, I will take my leave of you and seek another place; and I hope fortune will favour me so as to direct me to some Widower, or old Bachelor, which desires a comely huswifly woman to order their pri∣vate affairs.
I wish you all happiness, and if I were in a condition, I would make you a present.
Sir, My Lord is so busy since his Fathers Death, with Stewards, Attorneys, and such like, about ordering his Estate, as I am loath to disturb him; but as soon as he hath done speaking to them, I will wait upon you to my Lord.
Sir, I shall wait my Lords leisure.
Sir, what pretty young Lady is that which passes by?
She is a great Heiress, and was Ward to my old Lord, and he upon his Death-bed charged his Son my young Lord to marry her.
Surely small persuasions might serve turn; for her Virtue is Rhetoric enough to persuade, nay to force affection.
Yet my Lord is discontented, he would rather choose for him∣self, than that his Father should have chosen for him; for it is the Nature of Mankind to reject that which is offered, though never so good; and to prize that they cannot get, although not worth the having.
Of what Quality, of Birth, and Nature, and disposition is she of?
She is Honourably Born, and seems to be of a sweet disposition; but of a Melancholy Nature.
Sir, my Lord desires the Gentleman would be pleased to walk in.
Lady, what makes you so silently sad?
Pardon me Sir, I am not sad at this time, for my thoughts are merry, and my spirits lively.
There is no appearance of mirth in you, for mirth hath always a dancing heel, a singing voice, a talking tongue, and a laughing face.
I have such merry Companions sometimes; but I seldom dance, sing, talk, or laugh my self.
Where are those Companions? I desire to be acquainted with them, and keep them Company.
You cannot keep them Company, for the place they inhabit in, is too little for your Corporal body to enter; besides, they are so curious, choice, and nice Creatures, as they will vanish at the very sight of you.
Why Lady, I am none of the biggest sized Men, nor am I of a terrible aspect; I have seen very fine and delicate Creatures.
But you never saw any of these Creatures.
Pray where do they dwell, and what are their Names? I long to visit them.
They dwell in my head, and their Surnames are called thoughts; but how you will visit them I cannot tell, but they may visit you.
Faith Lady, your relation hath made me despair of an enter∣view, but not a friendly entertainment, if you please to think well of me.
Thoughts are free, and for the most part they censure according to fancy.
Then fancy me such a one, as you could like best, and love most.
That I cannot doe, for I love those best which I create my self, and Nature hath taught me to prize whatsoever is my own most, although of smaller value, than what's another, although of greater worth.
Then make me yours, by creating me anew.
That is past my skill; but if you will leave me alone, I will think of you when you are gone; for I had rather of the two entertain you in my thoughts, than keep you Company in discourse; for I am better pleased with a solitary silence, or a silent solitariness, than with a talking conversation, or
an entertaining talking, for words for the most part are rather useless spent, than profitably spoke, and time is lost in listening to them, for few tongues make Music, wanting the Cords of Sense, or sound of Reason, or singers of Fancy, to play thereon.
But you will injure your wit, to bury your wit in solitary silence.
Wit lives not on the tongue, as language doth, but in the brain, which power hath, as Nature, to create.
But those are aerie not material Creatures.
It is true, but what they want in substance, they have in variety; for the brain can create Millions of several Worlds filled full of several Cry∣tures, and though they last not long, yet are they quickly made, they need not length of time to give them form and shape.
But there is required Speech to express them, or they are made in vain, if not divulged.
Speech is an enemy to Fancy; for they that talk much, cannot have time to think much; and Fancies are produced from thoughts, as thoughts are from the mind, and the mind which doth create the thoughts, and the thoughts the fancies, is as a Deity; for it entertains it self with it self, and only takes pleasure in its own works, although none other should par∣take, or know thereof; but I shall talk a World out of my head, wherefore farewell.
Now your Estate is seized on, you have not means to keep a Servant, as to pay them for their service.
No truly Nan, but that which grieves me most, is, that I have not wherewithal to reward thee for thy past service.
I have served you these seven years, and have had nothing but my bare wages, unless it were some of the worst of your cast Clothes; for Mrs. Governess took order I should have none of the best; but I hope you will pay me my half years wages that is due to me.
Truly Nan I am not able, for not only my Estate, but all the Money, Jewels, Plate, and other goods you know was seized on, all that my Father left, or had a right to, unless it were my single self; and if you will take my service for half a year for payment, I will be very honest, dutiful, and diligent.
No by my troth, for you have been bred with so much at∣tendance, curiosity, and plenty, as you will rather prove a charge than a pay∣meant; but if you can get means by your youth, and beauty, I shall come and claim what is owing me.
When I am able you shall not need to challenge it; for I will pay you before you ask.
Why weepst thou old Humanity?
For the ruin of your noble family. I came a boy to your Grandmother the great and rich Lady Natures service, she being then newly married to your Grandfather the Lord Propriety; from whence sprung your Father the Lord Morality; your Grandfather, and Grandmother dying, I ser∣ved your Father, who soon after married your Mother the Lady Piety, they living, whilst she lived, with Peace and Tranquillity; but she dying, left you only to your Father, as a pledge of their loves; and indeed, you are so like them both, as all must confess they were your Parents, although they knew not your Birth; and yet none can tell which you resembled most: thus have I lived to see your Grandfather, and Grandmother, and Father, and Mother dead, and Peace, and Tranquillity fled; and you sweet Virtue left desolate and forlorn, both of friends and fortune; but sweet Lady comfort your self, for I have a little fortune, which I got honestly in your Fathers service; and as long as that lasts you shall not want.
I thank you, but you are old Humanity, and ready to go upon Crutches, and age and infirmities are shiftless; wherefore keep it for thy own use.
Why, so is unexperienced youth, both shiftless, and strength∣less.
Tic true, yet youth hath an increasing advantage; for time carries youth up, but time pulls Age down; wherefore I will not take that from thee, that will cause thee to be the poorer, or hazard you to want; I shall only desire your advise, what I shall do, and what course I shall follow.
Alas sweet Lady, necessity will drive you into many ex∣tremities.
I shall have fortitude to arm me; but what Counsel will you give me?
The best way for you will be to get into some great Ladies ser∣vice, and in such a place or office as to attend upon her Person, there you may live with honour and respect.
I had rather shrow'd my honest Poverty in a thatched house, than live in a Palace to be pointed at for my misfortunes; for in this Age, misfortunes are accounted crimes, and poverty is condemned as a thief, and hanged in the Chains of scorn; wherefore if I could get a service in an ho∣nest poor Farmers house, I might live happy, as being most obscure from the World, and the Worlds Vices; for vice increases more in Palaces than in Cottages; for in Palaces Pride Plows, Faction Sows, Riot Reaps, Extortion Threshes, Covetousness Whoords up the grain or gain; there youth is corrup∣ted with Vanity, Beauty caught with Flattery, Chastity endangered with Pow∣er, and Virtue slandered by Envy; besides, great Persons use their Servants too unequally, making them either Masters, or Slaves; where in an humble Cottage the industrious, and laborious Masters command their Servants friendly and kindly, and are obeyed with love; wherefore good Humanity, seek me out such a Place to live in, to serve.
I will, for I will never forsake you as long as I live, or at least so long as I have legs to go.
When you cannot visit me, I will visit you, for I shall never be ungrateful.
Sir Experience Traveller, you that have been so great a tra∣veller, pray tell me what Nations have the rarest Beauties, and which the greatest Wits?
In all my travels, the rarest Beauty that I have seen, and the greatest Wit that I have heard of, is your self, sweet Lady Con∣versation.
Then you have lost your labour; for you might have seen my Beauty, and have heard my Wit, at less Charges, and more ease.
Tic true Madam, had I only travelled to see a fair Lady, and hear a witty discourse.
Why, many travel to less purpose.
Tic true Madam, for some travel merely to learn to make a leg or congy with a good grace, and to wear their clothes, or acouster themselves fashionably. But I have observed in my travels, that very cold Countries, and very hot Countries, have neither so many Beauties, nor so much Wit, at lest not so much as more temperate Countries have.
What is the reason of that?
I cannot conceive the reason, unless the extreme coldness of the Climate should congeal their Spirits, and stupefy their Brains, making the Spirits unactive to get, and the Brain too barren to breed and bear Wit.
So then you make the Spirits and the Brain the Parents to Wit.
Yes Madam.
And what reason give you for the scarcity of Beauties in very cold Climates?
Beauty, Madam, is as tender and fading in the growth, as a Flower, although it be fresh and sweet; and the more delicate it is, the more subject to be nipped with the hard Frost, and to be withered with raw colds.
Then hot Countries should produce good store.
No Madam, for extreme heat dries up Wit, as water in a Spring, and Sun-burns beauty.
But hot Brains are thought to produce the greatest VVits.
Yes, if they be equally tempered with moisture; for as heat in moisture are Generators of all Creatures, so of Wit; but if the moisture exceed the heat, the Brain, or Mind becomes stupid, if the heat exceeds the moisture, the Brain or Mind becomes mad.
What Nation hath the best Language?
There are but three commendable things in Language, those
are to be significant, copious, and smooth, and the English tongue hath the perfection of all, there being an oil, or butter made of the cream of all o∣there Languages. Thus, what with the Temperature of the Climate, and the soft, smooth, spreading Language, England produces rarer Beauties, and eloquenter Orators, and finer Poets, than any other Nation in the world; and the Nobility and Gentry live not only in greater grandeur, than in other Na∣tions, but naturally appear or look with a more splendid Great∣ness.
Tic true, they did so in former times, when the Crown kept up Ceremony, and Ceremony the Crown; but since that Ceremony is down, their grandeur is lost, and their splendour put out; and no light thereof re∣mains: But they are covered with a dark rudeness, wherein the Clown ju∣stles the Lord, and the Lord gives the way to the Clown; the Man takes the wall of his Master, and the Master scrapes legs with Cap in hand to the Ser∣vant, and waits upon him, not out of a generous and noble Nature, but out of a base servile fear, and through fear hath given the Power away.
I am sorry to hear the Nobility is so degenerated.
I wonder your Lordship should be so troubled at your Fathers commands, which was to marry the Lady Ward, unless she had been ill-favoured and old.
O that's the misery! that she is so young, For I had rather my Father had commanded me to marry one that had been very old, than one that is so young; for if she had been very old, there might have been some hopes of her death; but this young Filly will grow upon me, not from me; besides, those that are young give me no delight, their Company is dull.
Why, she is not so very young, she is fifteen years of Age.
Give me a Lady to embrace about the years of twenty, rather than fifteen; then is her Beauty like a full-blown Rose in June, her Wit like fruit is ripe and sweet, and pleasant to the ear; when those of fifteen are like to green sharp Fruit, not ripened by the Sun of Time. Yet that's not all that troubles me; but I cannot endure to be bound in VVedlocks shackles, for I love variety, and hate to be tied to one.
Why, you may have the more variety by marrying.
No faith, it is a Bar; for if I should but kiss my wives Maid• which a thousand to one but I shall, my wife, if she doth not beat her Maid, making a hideous noise, with scoldings, yet she will pour, and cry, and feign her self sick, or else she would Cuckold me, and then I am paid for all.
Faith my Lord, it is a hundred to one but a man when he is mar∣yed
shall be Cuckolded, were he as wife as Solomon, as valiant as David, as fortunate as Caesar, as witty as Homer, or as handsome as Absalom; for Wo∣men are of the same Nature as men, for not one man amongst a thousand makes a good Husband, nor one woman amongst a thousand makes an honest Wife.
No saith, you might well have put another Cipher and made it ten thousand.
Well my Lord, since you must marry, pray let me counsel you: This Lady Ward being very young, you may have her bred to your own Humour.
How is that?
Why, accustom her to your ways before you marry her; let her see your several Courtships to several Mistresses, and keep wenches in your house; and when she is bred up to the acquaintance of your customs, it will be as natural to her.
What, to be a whore?
No, to know your humours, and to be contented there∣at.
Well, I will take your advice, although it is dange∣rous: And as the old saying is, the Medicine may prove worse than the disease.
Why, the worst come to the worst, it is but parting.
You say true; but yet a divorce will not clearly take off the disgrace of a Cuckold.
I have found out a service, a Farmer which hath the report of an honest labouring man, and his wife a good huswifely woman; they have only one daughter about your years, a pretty Maid truly she is, and seems a modest one; but how you will endure such rough and rude work, which perchance they will employ you in, I cannot tell, I doubt you will tire in it.
Do not fear, for what I want in strength, my industry shall supply.
But you must be fitted with clothes according, and proper to your service.
That you must help me to.
That I will.
Sweet Lady Contemplation, although your thoughts be ex∣cellent, yet there are fine curiosities and sweet pleasures to be enjoyed in the use of the world.
Perchance so, but would not you think that man a Fool that hath a great estate, a large convenient house, well situated, in sweet and healthful Air, pleasant and delightful, having all about for the eyes to view Landscapes, and Prospects; beside, all the inside richly furnished, and the Master plentifully served, and much company to pass his time with, as a re∣sort of men of all Nations, of all Ages, of all qualities or degrees, and pro∣fessions, of all humours, of all breedings, of all shapes, of all complexions: Likewise a recourse for all Wits, for all Scholars, for all Arts, for all Sci∣ences; Also Lovers of all sorts Servants of all use, and employments; Thus living luxuriously with all rarities and varieties, and yet shall go a begging, debasing himself with humble crouching, enslaving himself to Obligations, living upon cold Charity, and is denied often times unkindly, or kicked out scornfully, when he may be honoured at home, and served in state, would not you think that this man had an inbred baseness, that had rather serve un∣worthily, than command honourably; that had rather be enslaved, than free? Besides, that mind is a fool that cannot entertain it self with it's own thoughts; a wandering Vagabond, that is never, of seldom at home in Contemplation; A Prodigal to cast out his thoughts vainly in idle words, base to enslave it self to the Body, which is full of corruption, when it can create bodiless Creatures like it self in Corporalities; with which self Creatures, it may nobly, honestly, freely, and delightfully entertain it self. With which, the mind may not only delight it self, but improve it self; for the thoughts, which are the actions of the mind, make the soul more healthful and strong by ex∣ercises; for the mind is the souls body, and the thoughts are the actions thereof.
After what manner will you form this Body?
Thus, Understanding is the Brain, Reason the Liver, Love is the heart, Hate the Spleen, Knowledge the Stomach, Judgement the Sinews, Open∣nions the Bones, Will the Veins, Imaginations the Blood, Fancy the Spirits, the Thoughts are the Life, and Motion, or the Motions of the Life, the out∣ward Form is the Mind it self, which sometimes is like a Beast, sometimes like a Man, and sometimes like a God.
And you my fair Goddess.
My Lord, you are too covetous to take a wife merely for her riches.
Believe me Madam, I do esteem of such Riches as Money, as I do of Marriage, and in my nature I do hate them both; for a man is en∣slaved by either: wherefore I would shun them if I could, and turn them out of doors, but that some sorts of necessity and convenience enforce me to en∣tertain them; the one for Posterity sake, the other for subsistence of present life, besides convenient pleasures.
The Lady Ward, who is to be your wife, seems of a very dull disposition.
She is so, but I like her the better for that, for I would have a deadly dull Wife, and a lively Mistress, such a sprightly Lady as you are.
In truth my Lord, I am of a melancholy Nature.
Certainly Madam, you only know the Name, not the Nature, for your Nature is always fresh, and sweet, and pleasant, as the Spring.
O no, my mind is like to Winter, and my thoughts are numb and cold.
If your thoughts were so cold, your words would be as if they were frozen between your lips, all your discourse would melt by drops, not flow so smoothly and swiftly into men's ears, as they at all times do.
Tic true, I am merry when I am in your company, but in your absence I am as dull as a cloudy day, and as melancholy as dark night.
I cannot believe so well of my self, as that my company can be the light of your mirth, but I know that your company is the Sun of my life, nor could I live without it.
This is a barren Country, for in all this progress I have not seen a pretty Country wench.
Nor I.
Nor I.
If an person can tell, it is Tom Purveyor.
Now Tom Purveyor, are there no pretty wenches in this part of the Coun∣trey?
Yes that there are, an it please your Lordship, and not far off, two as pretty wenches as are in the Kingdom, and no dispraise to the rest.
Where? where?
Hard by here, at a Farmers House, the one is his Daught∣er, the other is his Servant-Maid.
Prithee Tom show us the house.
Not all at once; but one after another.
Nay faith Tom, let us all see them at once; but we will Court them apart.
Content.
What is the reason that Mercury is feigned to be the patron of Thieves?
That is to be the patron of Scholars, for Scholars are the greatest Thieves, stealing from the Authors they read, to their own use.
And why are Scholars counted the greatest Thieves?
Because that they steal the Spirits, or life of renown, out of the treasury of Fame; when all other sorts of Thieves steal but the goods of Fortune, which is nothing but a Corporal dross.
And why is he feigned the talkative God?
Because Scholars talk more than other men, and most com∣monly so much, as they will let none speak but themselves; and when there is a Company of Scholars together, they will be so fierce in disputes, as they will be ready to go to cuffs for the Prerogative of their opinion.
The Prerogative of the tongue you mean; but why are Scholars apt to talk most?
Because they overcharge their heads with several Authors, as Epicures do their Stomachs with variety of meats, and being overcharged, they are forced to vent it forth through the mouth, as the other through the gut; for the tongue, as a Feather, tickles the throat of Vainglory, vomiting out the slime of Learning, into the ears of the hearers; but some heads, as Stomachs which are naturally weak, are so grip'd, by reason it doth not dis∣gest well, as they vent nothing but windy Phrases; and other brains which are hot and moist, by reason of a facile memory, digest so fast, as they do nothing but purge loose Sentences; and other brains that are too dry and Insipid, are so costive, as their restringency strains out nothing but strong lines.
What is that, Non-sense?
Indeed they are hard words without sense.
What makes a good Poet?
A quick Fancy.
What makes a good Orator?
A ready Tongue.
What makes a good Physician?
Much Practice.
What makes a good Divine?
A Holy Life.
What makes a good States-Man?
Long experience, great observance, prudent industry, in∣genuous wit, and distinguishing judgment.
What makes a good Soldier?
Change of Fortune, Courage, Prudence, and Patience.
What makes a good Courtier?
Diligence, Flattery, and time-serving.
What makes a good Prince, or Governor?
Justice, Clemency, Generosity, Courage, and Prudence mixed together.
What makes a good Woman?
A Poet.
Why a Poet?
By reason the Poetical wits convert their natural defects into sweet graces, their follies to pure innocencies, and their Vices into He∣roick Virtues.
By these descriptions, you make as if women were more obliged to Poets than to Nature.
They are so; for where Nature, or Education, makes one good, or beautiful Woman, Poets make ten; besides, Poets have not only made greater numbers of beautiful women, but perfecter beauties than ever Nature made.
Then let me tell you, that women make Poets; for women kindle the masculine brains with the fire of Love, from whence arises a Poetical flame; and their Beauty is the fuel that feeds it.
I confess, were there no women, there would be no Poets; for the Muses are of that Sex.
Truly Husband our Maid Poor Virtue is a very in∣industrious Servant as ever I had in my life.
Yes wife, but you were angry with me at first because I per∣swaded you to take her.
Why, she seemed to be so fine a feat, as I thought she would never have settled to her work.
Truly Wife, she does forecast her business so prudently, and doth every thing so orderly, and behaves her self so handsomely, car∣rios her self so modestly, as she may be a Pattern to our Daughter.
I am a better Pattern my self.
Fair Maid, may I be your Shepherd to attend you.
I am but a single Sheep that needs no great attendance, and a harmless one, that strays not forth the ground I am put to feed.
Mistake me not fair Maid, I desire to be your Shepherd, and you my fair Shepherdess, attending loving thoughts, that feed on kisses sweet, folded in amorous arms.
My mind never harbors wanton thoughts, nor sends immodest glances forth, nor will enfold unlawful love, for chastity sticks as fast unto my Soul, as light unto the Sun, or heat unto the fire, or motion unto life, or ab∣sense unto death, or time unto eternity, and I glory more in being chaste, than Helen of her beauty, or Athens of their learning and eloquence, or the Lace∣demonions of their Laws, or the Persians of their Riches, or Greece of their Fa∣bless, or the Romans of their Conquests; and Chastity is more delightful to my mind, than Fancy is to Poets, or Music to the Ears, or Beauty to the Eyes, and I am as constant to Chastity, as truth to Unity, and Death to life; for I am as free, and pure from all unchastity as Angels are of sin.
I wonder not so much at Fortunes gifts, as Natures curiosities, not so much at Riches, Tittle and power, as Beauty, Wit, and Virtue, joined
in one; besides, she doth amaze me by expressing so much learning, as if she had been taught in some famous Schools, and had read many histories, and yet a Cottager, and a young Cottager, tic strange.
My Lord, doth my Counsel take good effect?
Yes faith, for she seems to take it very patiently, or else she is so dull a Creature as she is not sensible of any injury that's done her.
How doth she look when you address, and salute your Mi∣stress?
She seems to regard us not; but is as if she were in a deep contemplation of another world.
