I think she is one of the fewest words, for I never heard her speak.
Faith so few, as I am in good hope she is tongue-tied, or will grow dumb.
That would be such a happiness, as all married men would en∣vi you for.
They will have cause, for there is nothing so tedious as talking women, they speak so constraintly, and utter their Nonsense with such formality, and ask impertinent questions so gravely, or else their dis∣course is snip snap, or so loud and shrill, as deafs a mans ears, so as a man would never keep them Company, if it were not for other reasons.
Your Lordship speaks as if you were a woman-hater.
O Pardon me, for there is no man loves the Sex better than I; yet I had rather discourse with their beauty than their wits; besides, I only speak of generalities, not particularities.
Lady, pray make me partaker of some of your conceptions.
My conceptions are like the tongue of an extemporary Orator, that after he hath spoke, if he were to speak upon the same subject he could hardly do it, if it were not impossible just to speak as he did, as to express the same subjects in the same expressions, and way of his natural Rhetoric; for the sense may be the same, but the expressions, &amp; way of Rhetoric will hard∣lie be the same; but it is likely will be very different, and so differing, as not to be like the same, but the same premeditated Rhetoric, will many times
serve to many several designs, or preaching, pleading, or speaking, the Theme or cause being altered; This is the difference betwixt extemporary Orato∣rye, and premeditated Oratory, the one may be spoke, as many times as an O∣rotor will, and make the same Oratory serve to many several Subjects; the o∣there being not fixed, but voluntary, vanishes out of the remembrance, the same many times do my conceptions.
But I hope all are not vanished, some remain; wherefore pray express or present any one of your conceptions after what manner of way you please.
Why then I will tell you, I had a conception of a Monster, as a Creature that had a rational soul, yet was a Fool: It had had a beautiful and perfect shape, yet was deformed and ill-favoured; It had clear distinguish∣ing senses, and yet was senseless; It was produced from the Gods, but had the nature of a Devil; It had an eternal life, yet dyed as a Beast, It had a body, and no body.
What Monster call you this?
I call him Man.
This is a Man of your own conception.
A man of Natures creating is as monstrous for though man hath a rational soul, yet most men are fools, making no use of their reason; and though Man hath a beautiful and perfect shape, yet for the most part, they make themselves deformed and ill-favoured with antic postures, violent passions, or brutish vices; and man hath clear distinguishing Senses, yet in his sleep, or with sumes, or drink, he is senseless: Man was produced immediately from the Gods, yet man being wicked, and prone to evil, hath by evil wick∣oddness the nature of a Devil; Man it is said, shall live for ever, as having an eternal life, yet betwixt this life and the other, he dyes like a Beast, and turns to dust as other Creatures do; but the only difference between the man Na∣ture creates, and the man my Conceptions create is, that Natures man hath a real substance as a real body; whereas my conceptive man is only an Idea, which is an incorporal man, so as the body of my concepted man, is as the soul of Natures created man, an incorporality.
Well, I have lost my first Course in Love, and now like an angry bloody Gray-hound, I will down with the first I meet, were she as innocent as a Dove, or as wise as a Serpent, down she goes.
But soft, here's Loves game, and Isle fly at her. Fair One, for so you are.
Truly Sir I am but a Blouse.
Think better of your self, and believe me.
My Father hath told me, I must not believe a Gentleman in such matters.
Why sweetest? I am a Lord.
A Lord; Lord bless your Worship then, but my Father gave me warning of a Lord, he said they might nay, say and swear too, and do any thing, for they were Peers of the Realm, there was no meddling with them he said, without a Rebellion, bless me from a Lord, for it is a naughty thing, as they say, I know not.
Do you value me so little, when I can make you an Apocryphal Lady?
The Apocrypha forsooth is out of my Book, I have been bred purer than to meddle with the Apocrypha, the Gods bless us from it, and from all such ill things.
Well, in short, will you love me?
I am so ashamed to love a Lord forsooth that I know not how to behave my self.
I will teach you.
If your Honour will take the pains to teach a poor ignorant Country Maid, I will do the best I can to learn forsooth; but will it not be too much pains for your Honour, do you think?
No no, it will be both for my Honour, and my pleasure, and for the pleasure of my Honour.
Bless us, how the Lords doe. It backward and forward at their pleasure, the finest that ever was; but what would your Honour have of me?
By this kiss Isle tell you.
O fie, fie, good your Honour, do not scandalise your lips to kiss mine, and make me so proud as never to kiss our Shepherd again.
No fie.
I will and must kiss you.
Nay, good your Honour, good your Honour.
What are you the better now? But I see there is no denying a Lord, for∣sooth it is not civil, and they are so peremptory too, the Gods bless them, and make them their Servants.
This kiss hath so inflamed me, therefore for Loves sake, meet me in the Evening, in the Broom close here.
I know the Close forsooth, I have been there before now.
Well, and when we meet I will discover more than yet I have done.
So you had need forsooth, for nothing is discovered yet, either on your side, or mine, but I will keep my promise.
There spoke my better Angel; so adieu.
An Angel, I will not break my word for two angels, and I hope there will be no dew neither, God shield you forsooth.
Fair Maid, stay and look upon my person.
Why, so I do.
And how do you like it?
As I like a curious built house, wherein lives a vain and self-con∣ceited owner.
And are not you in love with it?
No truly, no more than with a pencilled Picture.
Why, I am not painted.
You are by Nature, though not by Art.
And do you despise the best and curiousest Works of Na∣ture?
No, I admire them.
If you admire them, you will admire me, and if you admire me, you will yield to my desires.
There may be admiration without love, but to yield to your de∣sires, were to abuse Natures Works.
No, It were to enjoy them.
Nature hath made Reason in man, as well as Sense, and we ought not to abuse the one, to please the other; otherwise man would be like Beasts, following their sensualities, which Nature never made man to be; for she created Virtues in the Soul, to govern the Senses and Appetites of the Body, as Prudence, Justice, Temperance, and Conscience.
Conscience? What is that, natural fear?
No, it is the tenderest part of the Soul, bathed in a holy dew, from whence repentant tears do flow.
I find no such tender Constitution, nor moist Complexion in my Soul.
That is, by reason the Fire of unlawful Love hath drunk all up, &amp; seared the Conscience dry.
You may call it what Fire you will, but I am certain it is your Beauty that kindles it, and your Wit that makes it flame, burning with hot desires.
Pray Heaven my Virtue may quench it out again.
I am sure Nature requires a self-satisfaction, as well as a self-preservation, and cannot, nor will not be quiet without it, esteeming it beyond life.
I wonder my Lord Courtship, he being counted a wise man; should make me his Baud, if he intends to make me his Wife, and by my troth Nurse, I am too young for that grave Office.
How ignorantly you speak Child? it is a sign you have been bred obscurely, and know little of the world; or rather it proves your Mother dyed before you could speak, or go, otherwise you would be better experien∣ced in these businesses.
My Mother, Nurse, Heaven rest her soul, she would never have made me a Baud.
No, why then she would not do as most Mothers do now a days; for in this age Mothers bring up their daughters to carry Letters, and to receive messages, or at lest to watch at the door left their Fathers should come unawares, and when they come to make some excuse, and then the Mother laughs, and says her daughter is a notable witty Girl.
What, for telling a lye?
Yes, when it is told so, as to appear like a truth.
But it is a double fault, as to deceive the Father, and be a Baud to the Mother.
Why, the Mother will execute the same Office for the daugh∣la when she is married, and her self grown into years; for from the age of seven or eight years old, to the time they are married, the Daughter is a Baud to the Mother; and from the time of their marriage, to the time of their Mothers death, the Mother is a Baud to the Daughter; but if the Mother be indifferently young, and hath a young tooth in her head, as the old saying is, they Baud for each other.
But why doth not the Mother Baud for her Daughter, before she is married.
O there is reason for that, for that may spoil her fortune, by hindering her marriage: for marriage is a Veil to cover the wanton face of adultery, the like Veil is Baud-mothers, and Baud-daughters; for who would suspect any lewdness, when the Mother and the Daughter is toge∣there?
And are not Sons Pimps for their Fathers, as Daughters are for their Mothers?
No saith, Boys have facility, or ingenuity as Girls have; besides, they are kept most commonly so strictly to their Books, when Girls have nothing else to do; but when they have cast away their Books, and come to be married men, then they may chance to Pimp for their Wives.
O fie Nurse, surely a man will never play the Pimp to Cuckold himself.
O yes, if they be poor, or covetous, or ambitious; and then if they have a handsome woman to their wife, they will set her as a bait to catch their designs in the trap of Adultery; or patient, quiet, simple, fearful
men will, if they have a Sprightly wise, they will play the Pimp, either for fear, or quiet; for such men to such wives, will do any thing to please them, although it be to Cuckold themselves.
But surely Nurse no Gentleman will do so.
I know not who you call Gentleman, but those that bear up high and look big, and vant loud, and walk proud, and carry the out-side of a Gentleman, will do so.
Certainly Nurse they are but Bastard Gentry, or else they are degenerated.
An insipid Branch may spring from a sound Root, ma∣ny a withered and rotten Plum may hang on a good Tree.
And do Wives play the Bawds for their Husbands, as the Hus∣bands play the Pimps for their Wives?
Most often; for they will make Gossiping meetings, on purpose for their Husbands to Court other women; for they know when their Hus∣bands minds are filled with amorous love, they will not muse upon their act∣once, nor examine their ways; besides, when as the Husband would take his liberty without disturbance, he will wink at the liberty his wife takes, and so will be procures for each other, and the Ladies acquaintance are Confi∣dents.
Confidants, what is that, Nurse?
Why it is thus, two Ladies make friendship, or at least call Friends, and if any man desires to be a Courtly Servant to one of them, he addresses himself to the other, and expresses what Passions and Affections he hath for her friend, and so makes his complaints and affections known to her; whereupon she recommends his addresses and service to her Friend; thus doing a friendly Office by carrying and declaring his professions, and re∣turning her Friends civil answers, appointing places for each others love-meetings, the other will do as much for her.
Why this is a Baud.
O peace Child, for if any body heard you say so, they would laugh at you for a Fool, but it is a sign you never was a Courtier, for I knew a young Lady that went to Court to be a Maid of Honour; and there were two young Ladies that were Confidants to each other, and a great Prince made love to one of them, but adddrest himself to the other, as being her Friend; this young Maid asked why he did so, it was answered, she was the Princes Mistress Confident; and just as you ask me, what said she, is a confi∣dent a Baud; whereupon the whole Court laughed at her, and for that only question condemned her to be a very Fool, nay, a mere Changeling.
Well Nurse, say what you will, Confident is but a Courtly name for a Baud.
Those wandering Stars that shine like brightest day, are fixed on me, the Center of your love.
O Heavens!
Happy to touch those Lilies in your cheeks mingled with Roses, loves perfumed bath.
They grow forsooth in our Garden.
You are the Garden of all sweets for love, your blush∣ing lips of the Vermilion die, and those twin cherries,give me leave to taste.
Truly Sir, I understand no Latin, but I will call our Vi∣car to you, and he shall expound.
No dearest Dear, my lovely Dear, my dearest Love, my loveliest Dear.
I never cost you any thing as yet, Sir.
Why, then no Lady of Arcade bred.
Truly Sir, this is as our Vicar saith, like Hebrew without points, to be read backwards; say any thing forward in Notthingham-shire; speak, that I may guess at, and I will answer your Worship, though truly, it is as fine as ever I understood not.
Why then sweet heart I love you, and would gladly enjoy you.
O sie, enjoy is a naughty word forsooth, if it please you.
It would please me, your thoughts of what you mince.
Thoughts are free forsooth, and I love whole joints with∣out mincing.
Why then in plain English, I would have your Maiden-head.
O dear, how will you get it, can you tell? Truly, true∣lie, I did not think such naughty words would come forth of so fine a Gentle∣mans mouth.
But tell me truly, do you think me fine?
You will make me blush now, and discover all; so fine clothes, the Taylor of Norton never made such, and so finely made, unbotton∣ed and untrust doth so become you; but I do hang down my head for shame; and those Linen Boot-hose (as if you did long to ride,) do so become you, and your short Coat to hang on your left arm; O sweet, O sweet, and then your Hat hid with so fine a Feather, our Peacocks tails are not like it; and then your hair so long, so finely curled, and powdered in sweets, a sweeter Gentleman I never saw. My love's beyond dissembling, so young, so fresh, so every thing, I warrant you; O Sir, you will ravish me, but yet you can∣not.
O how you have made me thankfulness all over for this
your bounty to me; wherefore my earthly Paradise, let us meet in the next Close, there under some sweet Hedge to taste Loves aromatic Banquet at your Table.
O Sir, you blushes I consent; farewell; do not betray me then, you must not tell.
Farewell my sweetest, granting of my suit,
Shall still enslave me, and be ever mute.
Stay lovely Maid, and receive a Fortune.
I am Fortune proof Sir, she cannot tempt me.
But she may persuade you to reason.
That she seldom doth, for she is always in extremes, and
Extremes are out of Reason's Schools,
That makes all those that follow Fortune Fools.
What do you Rime, my pretty Maid?
Yes Rich Sir, to end my discourse.
I will make you Rich, if you will receive my gifts.
I love not gifts Sir, because they often prove bribes to cor∣rupt.
Why, what do you love then?
I love Truth, Fidelity, Justice, Chastity; and I love obedience to lawful Authority, which rather than I would willingly and knowingly infringe, I would suffer death.
Are you so wilful?
No, I am so constant.
But young Maid, you ought not to deny all gifts, for there are gifts of pure affection, Love-gifts of Charity, gifts of Humanity, and gifts of Generosity.
They are due debts, and not gifts; For those you call gifts of pure Love, are payments to dear deserving friends; and those of Charity are payments to Heaven; and those of Humanity are payments to Nature, and those Generosity, are payments to Merit, but there are vain-glorious gifts, covetous gifts, gifts of fear, and gifts that serve as Bawds to corrupt foolish young Virgins.
Are you so wise to refuse them?
I am so virtuous as not to take them.
What still musing, O thou idle creature?
I am not idle, for I busy my self with my own fancies.
Fancies are like dust, soon raised, and suddenly blown away.
No, they are as fire-works that sparkling fly about; or ra∣there stars, set thick upon the brain, which gives a twinkling delight unto the mind.
Prithee delight thy friends with thy conversation, and spend not thy time with dull thoughts.
Pray give me leave to delight my self with my own thoughts, since I have no discourse to entertain a hearer.
Why, your thoughts speak in your mind, although your tongue keeps silence.
It is true; but they disturb not the mind with noise, for noise is the greatest enemy the mind hath: and as for my part, I think the most useless sense that Nature hath made, is hearing: the truth is, that hear∣ing and smelling might well have been spared, for those two senses bring no materials into the brain; for sound and scent are incorporal.
Then put out all the senses.
There is no reason for that, for the eyes bring in pictures which serve the mind for patterns to draw new fancies by, and to cut, or carve out figurative thoughts, and the last serves towards the nourishment of the by∣die, and touches the life.
But wisdom comes through the ear by instruction.
Wisdom comes through the eye by experience; for we shall doubt of what we only hear, but never doubt of what we see perfectly: But the ground of wisdom is Reason, and Reason is born with the soul, where∣fore the ear serves only for reproof, and reproof displeases the mind, and seldom doth the life any good; nay many times it makes it worse, for the mind being displeased, grows angry, and being angry, malicious, and being malicious, revengeful, and revenge is war, and war is destruction.
But if you were deaf, you would lose the sweet harmony of music.
Harmony becomes discord by often repetition, and at the best it doth but rock the thoughts asleep; whereas the mind takes more plea∣sure in the harmony of thoughts, and the music of fancy, than in any that the senses can bring into it.
Prithee let this harmonious music cease for a time, and let us go and visit the Lady Conversation.
It seems a strange humour to me, that all mankind in general should have an itching tongue to talk, and take more pleasure in the wag∣ging thereof, than a beggar in scratching where a louse hath bit.
Why, every part of the body was made for some use, and the tongue to express the sense of the mind.
Pardon me, tongues were made for taste, not for words, for words wa an art which man invented: you may as well say, the hands were made to shuffle cards, or to do juggling tricks, when they were made to de∣fend and assist the body; or you may as well say, the leg were made to cut capers, when they were made to carry the body, and to move, as to go from place to place; for, though the hands can shuffle cards, or juggle, and the legs can cut capers, yet they were not made by Nature for that use, nor to that purpose; but howsoever, for the most part, the sense and reason of the mind is lost in the number of words; for there are millions of words for a single figure of sense, and many times a cyphre of nonsense stands instead of a figure of sense: Besides, there are more spirits spent, and flesh wasted with speaking, than is got or kept with eating, as witness Preachers, Pleaders, Players, and the like, who most commonly die with Consumptions; and I believe, many of our effeminate Sex do hurt the lungs with over-exercising of their tongues, not only with licking and tasting of Sweet-meats, but with chatting and prating, twitling and twatling; for I cannot say speaking, or discoursing, which are significant words, placed in a methodical order, then march in a regular body upon the ground of Reason, where sometimes the colour of Fancy is flying.
Now the Flag of your wit is flying, is the fittest time to encoun∣la the Lady Conversation; and I make no question but you will be Victory∣os, and then you shall be Crowned the Queen of Wit.
I had rather bury my self in a Monument of Thoughts, than sit in the Throne of Applause for Talking.
Sweet, why sit you so silently here?
My speech is buried in my thoughts.
This silent place begets melancholy thoughts.
And I love melancholy so well, as I would have all as silent without me, as my thoughts are within me; and I am so well pleased with thoughts, as noise begets a grief, when it disturbs them.
But most commonly Shepherds and Shepherdesses sit and sing to pass away the time.
Misfortunes have untuned my voice, and broke the strings of mirth.
Misfortunes? what misfortunes art thou capable of? Thou hast all thou were born to.
I was born to die, and it is misfortune enough I live, since my life can do no good: I am but useless here.
You were born to help increase the world.
The world needs no increase, there are too many creatures al∣ready, especially mankind; for there are more than can live quietly in the world; for I perceive, the more populous, the more vicious.
It is strange you should be so young, so fair, so witty as you are, and yet so melancholy; thy poverty cannot make it, for thou never knew the pleasure of riches.
Melancholy is the only hopes I do rely upon, that though I am poor, yet that may make me wise; for fools are most commonly mer∣riest, because they understand not the follies that dwell therein, nor have e∣nough considerations of the unhappiness of man, who hath endless desires, unprofitable travels, hard labours, restless hours, short pleasures, tedious pains, little delights, blasted joys, uncertain lives, and decreed deaths; and what is mirth good for? it cannot save a dying friend, nor help a ruined Kingdom, nor bring in plenty to a famished Land; nor quench out ma∣lignant Plagues; nor is it a ward to keep misfortunes off, though it may tri∣umph on them.
But you a young Maid, should do as young Maids do, seek out the company of young Men.
Young Maids may save themselves that labour, for Men will seek out them, or else you would not be sitting here with me.
And are you not pleased with my company?
What pleasure can there be in fears?
Are you afraid of me?
Yes truly; for the ill example of men, corrupts the good principles in women: But I fear not the perverting of my Virtue, but men's incivilities.
They must be very rudely bred, that give you not respect, you being so very modest.
It is not enough to be chastely modest and honest, but as a ser∣vant to my Mr. and Mrs. I must be dutiful, and careful to their commands, and on their employments they have put to me: wherefore I must leave you Sir, and go fold my sheep.
I will help you.
Sweet-heart, I have no Sonnets,  Songs, or stronger Lines, with softer Poesy to melt your Soul, nor Rhetoric to charm your Ears, or Logic for to force, or ravish you, nor lopped in richer clothes embalmed in Sweets, nor Courtly Language; but am an Ancient Squire, by name Sir Golden Riches, which hath force in all things, and then in Love; for Cupped being blind, he is for feeling, and look here my We•ch, this purse is stuffed with Gold, a hundred pounds.
Let me see, pour it on the ground.
I will obey thee: Look here my Girl.
O dear, how it doth shine for∣sooth! it almost blinds mine eyes; take it away, yet pray let it stay: truly I know not what to do with it.
No? why it will buy you rich Gowns, aped in the Silk-worms toils, with stockings of the softer silk, to draw on your finer legs, with rich lace shoes, with roses that seem sweet, and garters laced with spangles like twinkling Stars, embalm your hair with Gessimond Pomaetums, and rain Odoriferous Powders of proud Rome.
O Heaven! what a Wench shall I be, could I get them! But shall we have fine things of the Peddler too?
Buy all their packs, and send them empty home.
O mighty! I shall put down all the Wenches at the May-pole; then what will the Bag-piper say, do you think? Pray tell me, for he is a jeering knave.
Despise the Rural company, and that windy bag, change it for Balls with greatest Lords to dance, and bring the Jerkin Fiddles out of frame.
Then I shall have a Mail-Pillion, and ride behind our Thomas to the dancing.
No, you shall ride in rich gilt Coaches, Pages and Lackeys in rich Liveries, with Gentlemen well clothed, to wait upon you.
And be a Lady; then I will be proud, and will not know Thomas any more, nor any Maid that was acquainted with me.
You must forget all those of your Fathers house too; for I'll get a Pedigree shall fit you, and bring you Lineally descended from Great Charlemain.
No, I will have it from Charls wain my Fathers Carter; but I would so fain be a Lady, and it might be: I will be stately, laugh with∣out a cause, and then I am witty, and jeer sometimes, and speak nonsense aloud. But this Gold will not serve for all these fine things.
Why then we will have hundreds and thousands of pounds, until you be pleased, so I may but enjoy you in my Arms.
No Maid alive can hold our these Assaults, Gold is the Peter that breaks the Virgins gates, a Soldier told me so. Well then, my Lord Title, farewell, for you are an empty name; and Sir Effeminate Lovely, go you to your Taylor, make more fine clothes in vain.
I'll stick to Riches, do then what you will,
The nearest way to pleasure buy it still.
Why should Lord Courtship dislike me? Time hath not ploughed wrinkles in my face, nor dug hollows in my cheeks, nor hath he set mine eyes deep in my head, nor shrunk my sinews up, nor sucked my veins dry, nor fed upon my flesh, making my body insipid and bate; nei∣there hath he quenched out my wit, nor decayed my memory, nor ruined my understanding; but perchance Lord Courtship likes nothing but what is in perfection; and I am like a house which Time hath not fully finished, nor Education thoroughly furnished.
Sweet-heart, refuse not Riches, it will buy thee friends, pacify thy enemies; it will guard thee from those dangers that throng upon the life of every creature.
Heavenly Providence is the Marshal which makes way for the life to pass through the crowd of dangers, and my Virtue will gain me honest friends, which will never forsake me, and my humble submission will pacify my enemies, were they never so cruel.
But Riches will give thee delight, and place thee in the midst of pleasures.
No, it is a peaceable habitation, a quiet and sound sleep, and a healthful body, that gives delight and pleasure, and it is not riches; but riches many times destroy the life of the body, or the reason in the soul, or, at least, bring infirmities thereto through luxury; for luxury slackens the Nerves, quenches the Spirits, and drowns the Brain, and slackened Nerves make weak Bodies, quenched Spirits, timorous Minds, a drowned Brain, a watery Understanding, which causes Sloth, Effeminacy, and Simon∣plicity.
How come you to know so much of the world, and yet know so few passages in it, living obscurely in a Farmers house?
The Astronomers can measure the distance of the Planets, and take the compass of the Globe, yet never travel to them; nor have they Ambassadors from them, nor Liegers to lie therein to give Intelligence.
How come you to be so learnedly judicious, being so young, poor, and meanly born and bred?
Why, Fire, Air, Water, and Earth, Animals, Vegetables, and Minerals, are Volumes large enough to express Nature, and make a Scholar learn to know the course of her works, and to understand many of∣fects
produced therefrom. And as for Judgment and Wit, they are brother and sister; and although they do not always, and at all times agree, yet are they always the children of the Brain, being begot by Nature. Thus what Wit or Knowledge I have, may come immediately from Nature, not from my Birth or Breeding; but howsoever, I am not what I seem.
What makes you look so sad?
Why Monsieur Amorous's visit hath been the cause of the death of one of the finest Gentlemen of this Age.
How, pray?
Why thus; my Imagination (for Imagination can Create both Masculine and Feminine Lovers) had Created a Gentleman that was handsomer and more beautiful than Lender, Atones, or Narcissus; vali∣anter than Tamberlain, Scanderbeg, Hannibal, Caesar, or Alexander; sweeter-natur'd than Titus, the delight of mankind; better-spoken, and more e∣loquent than Tully, or Demosthenes; wittier than Ovid, and a better Poet than Homer. This man to fall desperately in love with me, as loving my Virtues, honouring my Merits, admiring my Beauty, wondering at my Wit, doting on my Person, adoring me as an Angel, worshipping me as a God∣dess; I was his Life, his Soul, his Heaven. This Lover courted my affe∣ction: with all the industry of Life, gifts of Fortune, and actions of Ho∣nor; sued for my favour, as if he had sued to Heaven for mercy; but I, as many cruel goddesses do, would neither receive his obligations, nor regard his vows, nor pity his tears, nor hearken to his complaints, but rejected his Suit, and gave him an absolute denial; whereupon he was resolved to dye, as believing no torments could be compared to those of my disdain; and since I would not love him living, he hoped by dying, his death might move my pity, and so beget a compassionate remembrance from me; where∣upon he got secretly near my chamber-door, and hung himself just where I must go out, which when I saw, I starred back in a great fright, but at last running forth to call for help to cut him down, in came Monsieur Amorous, which hinderance made me leave him hanging there, as being ashamed to own my cruelty; and he hath been talking, or rather prating here so long, as by this time my kind Love is dead.
O no, for Lovers will hang a long time before they dye; for their necks are tuff, and their hearts are large and hot.
Well, pray leave me alone, that I may cut him down, and give him Cordials to restore life.
Faith you must let him hang a little time longer; for I have un∣dertaken to make you a sociable Lady this day; wherefore you must go a∣broad to a friends house with me.
Who I? what do you think I will go abroad, and leave my Lover in a twisted string? his legs hanging daugling down, his face all black and swelled, and his eyes almost started out of his head; no, no, pray go alone by your self, and leave me to my Contemplation.
Well, if you will not go, I will never see you, nor be friends with you again.
Pray be not angry, for I will go, if you will have me, although I shall be but a dull companion; for I shall not speak one word; for where∣soever I am, my thoughts will use all their Industry to cut the string, and take him down, and rub and chafe him against a hot fire.
Come, come, you shall heat your self with dancing, and let your Lover hang.
That I cannot; for active bodies and active brains are never at once, the one disturbs the other.
Then it seems you had rather have an active brain, than an active body.
Yes; for when the brain doth work, the understanding is in∣riched, and knowledge is gained thereby: whereas the body doth oft-times waste the life with too much exercise.
Take heed you do not distemper your brain with too much exer∣cising your thoughts.
All distempers proceed from the body, and not from the mind; for the mind would be well, did not the humours and appetites of the body force it into a distemper.
Well, upon the condition you will go, you shall sit still, and your wit shall be the Music.
Prithee let me rest at home; for to day the strings of my wit are broken, and my tongue, like a fiddle, is out of tune: Besides, Contem∣plative persons are at all times dull speakers, although they are pleasant thinkers.

Sweet-heart, you are a most Heavenly Cry∣ture.
Beauty is created and placed oftner in the fan∣cy, than in the face.
It is said there is a Sympathy in likeness; if so, you and I should love each other, for we are both beautiful.
But it is a question whether our Souls be answerable to our Persons.
There is no question or doubt to be made, but that loving souls live in beautiful persons.
And do those loving souls dye, when their beauties are de∣cayed and withered?
The subject pleads it self, without the help of Rhetoric, for Love and Beauty lives and dies together.
It is Amorous Love that dies when Beauty is gone, not Ver∣tuous Love; for as Amorous Love is bred, born, lives, and dies with the ap∣petite: so Virtuous Love is Created, and shall live with the Soul for¦ever.
You may call it what love you please.
It is no love, but a disease.
Why did you leave the Lady Amorous company so un∣civilly, as to go out of the room, leaving her all alone?
I heard your Lordship was coming, then I thought it was fit for me to withdraw; for I have heard Lovers desire to be alone.
Do you desire to be alone with a man?
I am no such Lover, for I am too young as yet, but I know not what I shall or may be wrought or brought to, but time and good ex∣ample may instruct and lead me into the way of amorous love.
May it so?
Why not? for I am docible, and youth is apt to learn.
But before I marry you, I would have you learn to know how to be an obedient wife, as to be content, and not murmur at my actions, al∣so to please my humour, but not to imitate my practice.
If I might advise your Lordship, I would advise you to take such a Portion out of my Estate, as you shall think just or fit, and then quit me, and choose such a one as you shall like, for I shall never please you; for though I may be apt to learn what will please my self, yet I am dull and intractable to learn obedience to another will, nor can I flatter their delights.
I find you have learned, and now begin to practice how to talk; for now your sober silence seems as dead and buried in the rubbish of foolish words; But let me tell you, a talking wife will never please me; wherefore practise patience, and keep silence, if you would enjoy the hap∣pines of peace.
There can be no peace, when the mind is discontented.
Why do you follow me so much, as never to let me rest in peace and quiet alone? Is it that you think I have beauty? and is it that you are in love with? why, to cure your disease, I will deform it; or do you think I have wit to cure that Imagination? I will put my tongue to silence. I am sure it cannot be my Virtue that inflames you to an intem∣perance; for Virtue is an Antidote against it: But had you all the beauty in Nature squeezed into your form, and all the wit in Nature pressed into your brain, and all the prosperities of good fortune at your command, and all the power of Fate and Destiny at your disposal, you could not persuade me to yield to your unlawful desires; for know, I am honest without self-ends; my virtue, like to Time, still running forward, my chastity sexed as E∣ternity, without circumference lines; besides, it is built on the foundation of Morality, and roofed and cicl'd with the faith of Religion, and the materi∣else thereof are Honour, which no subtle Arguments can shake the one, nor no false Doctrine can corrupt or rot the other; neither is the building sub∣jest to the fire of unlawful love, nor the tempestuous storms of torments, nor the deluge of poverty, nor the earthquakes of fear, nor the ruins of death; for so long as my Soul hath a being, my Chastity will live. But were you as poor as I, even to move pity, or so lowly and meanly born, at might bring contempt and scorn from the proud, yet if your mind and soul were endued with noble qualities, and heroical virtues, I should sooner em∣brace your love, than to be Mistress of the whole World; for my affecti∣on to merit hath been ingrafted into the root of my Infancy, which hath grown up with my years, so that the longer I live, the more it in∣creases.
You cannot think I would marry you, although I would lie with you.
I cannot but think it more possible that you should marry me, than I to be dishonest.
Thou art a mean poor wench, and I nobly descended.
What though I am poor, yet I am honest, and poverty is no crime; nor have my Ancestors left marks of infamy to shame me to the world.
Thy Ancestors? what were they but poor peasants? where∣fore thou wilt dignify thy Race, by yielding to my love.
Heaven keep them from that dignity that must be gained by my dishonesty: no, my chastity shall raise a Monumental Tomb over their cold dead ashes.
What pity it is Nature should put so noble a soul into a mean∣born body.
Pray go visit the Lady Amorous, and if her husband be ab∣sent, deliver her this letter.
Excuse me my Lord.
Wherefore?
I am no Carrier of Love-letters.
But you shall carry this.
But I will not.
Will you not?
No, I will rather endure all the torments that can be in∣vented.
And you shall; for I will torture you if you do not; for I will have you drawn up high by the two thumbs, which is a pain will force you to submit.
Do so if you will; nay scrue me up into the middle-Region, there will I take a Thunderbolt, and strike you dead, and with such strength I'll fling it on you, as it shall press your soul down to the everlasting shades of death.
Sure you will be more merciful.
No more than Devils are to sinful souls; there will I be your Bawd, to procure you variety of torments; for I had rather be one in Pluto's black Court, caused by my own revenge, than to be a Bawd on earth, which is a humane Devil.
You are mad.
Might every word I speak prove like a mad dogs bite, not only to transform your shape, and turn your speech to barks and howl∣ings, but that your soul may be no other than the souls of beasts are.
You are transformed from a silent young Maid to a raging Fury.
May all the Furies that Hell inhabits, and those that live
on earth, torment your mind, as racks do torture bodies, and may the ve∣nom of all malice, spleen, and spite, be squeezed into your soul, and poi∣son all content, your thoughts flame like burning oil, and never quench, but be eternally a siery Animal; and may the fire feed only on your self, and as it burns, your torments may increase.
She is mad, very mad, and I have only been the cause.
Fairest, will not you speak?
My words have betrayed my heart, as discovering the se∣crets therein: wherefore I will banish them, and shut the doors of my lips against them.
What, for saying you love me. Sweet, why do you weep?
Tears are the best Cordials for a heart oppressed with grief.
I should hate my self, if I could think I were the cause. But pray forbear to weep.
Pray give my grief a liberty, my tears are no disturbance, they shower down without a rattling noise, and silent fall without a murmuring voice; but you disturb me: Wherefore for pity-sake leave me, and I will pray you may enjoy as much prosperity as good fortune can present you with, and as much health as Nature can give you, and as much tranquillity as Hey∣ven can infuse into a mortal creature.
Neither Fortune, Nature, nor Heaven can please me, or make me happy in this world without you.
O you torment me.
Surely Lady Contemplation your thoughts must needs be very excellent, that they take no delight but with themselves.
My thoughts, although they are not material, as being pro∣fitable, yet they are innocent, as being harmless.
Yet your thoughts do the world an injury, in burying your words in the grave of silence.
Let me inform you, that sometimes they creep out of
their graves as Ghosts do, and as Ghosts walk in solitary places, so I speak to my solitary self, which words offend no ears, because I speak to no ears but my own; and as they have no flatterers to applaud them, so they have no censurers to condemn them.
But you bury your life, whilst you live retired from company.
O no, for otherwise my life would be buried in company; for my life never enjoys it self, but when it is alone; and for the most part, all public societies are like a discord in Music, every one playing several contrary parts in their actions, speaking in several contrary notes, striking on several contrary subjects, which makes a confusion; and a confused noise is like a disordered multitude, only the one offends the ear, as the other of∣fends the eyes; and there can be no pleasure but in harmony, which harmo∣ny is Quantity, Quality, Symmetry, and Unity; and though quality, quantity, and symmetry are brought by the Senses, yet Unity is made in the mind. Thus Harmony lives in the mind; for without the mind, the senses could take no delight.
How do you Lady?
Why very well Doctor, how do you?
Why I was sent, as being believed you are mad.
Troth Doctor that's no wonder; for all the world is mad, more or less.
Do you find any distemper in your head?
My head will ache sometimes.
I mean a distemper in your mind.
My mind is troubled sometimes.
That is not well: let me feel your pulse.
Why Doctor, can you know the temper of my mind, by the feeling of my pulse?
There is a great Sympathy between the Mind and the Body.
But I doubt, Doctor, your learned skill is many times de∣ceived by the pulse; you will sooner find a mad distemper in the tongue or actions, than in the wrists.
In troth Lady, you speak reason, which those that are mad do not do.
O yes, Doctor, but they doe, as you cure Diseases, by chance.
O Love, dissembling love, that seem to be the best of passi∣once, and yet torments the soul!
What makes your Lordship so melancholy, as to shun all your friends, to walk alone?
I am in Love.
There are many remedies for love.
I would you could tell me one.
May I know the Lady you are in love with?
The Lady say you? she is a poor Lady•
Your Lordship is so rich, as you may marry without a pore∣tion,
O I could curse my fate, and rail at my destiny.
For what?
To make me fall in love with one I am ashamed to make her known.
Is she so mean, and yet so beautiful?
O she hath all the Beauties and Graces that can attract a soul to love; for surely Nature sate in Council to make her body, and the Gods sate in Council to compose her mind.
May not I see her?
Yes.
Where may I find her?
Upon the next Plain, under a bush that bends much like a bower, there she most commonly sits to watch her sheep; but I will go with you.
Your Lordship is not jealous?
All Lovers think their Beloved is never secure enough.
O my Child, I am told that on a sudden you turned mad!
Surely Nurse your fear, or what else it may be, you seem to me to be more mad than I can find in my self to be.
That shows you are mad.
If I am mad, I sucked the madness from your breast.
I do confess, Child, I have not had those mad vagaries since I gave suck, as I had before.
It is a sign you are grown old, Nurse.
I confess, Youth is oftner mad than Age; but dear Child tell me, art thou mad?
Prithee Nurse, lest thou should become mad, go sleep to settle thy thoughts, and quiet thy mind, for I remember a witty Poet, one Doctor Don, saith,
Sleep is pains easy salve, and doth fulfil
All Offices, unless i•'t• to kill.
O Heaven, what shall I do, what shall I do!
What is the matter Nurse, what is the matter you shriek out so?
O Doctor, my Child is mad, my Child is mad; for she re∣peats Verses.
That's an ill sign indeed.
Doctor, did you never repeat Latin Sentences when you have read Lectures, nor Latin Verses, when you did Dispute in Schools?
Yes, Sweet Lady, a hundred times.
Lord, Doctor, have you been mad a hundred times, and re∣covered so often!
Those were Latin Verses, those were Latin Verses Child.
Faith Lady you pose me.
Then Doctor go to School again, or at least return again to the University and study again, and then practise not to be posed.
Nurse, she is not well, she must be put to a diet.
But why, Doctor, should you think me mad? I have done no outrageous action; and if all those that speak extravagantly should be put to a diet, as being thought mad, many a fat waste would shrink in the doub∣let, and many a Poetical vein would be dried up, and the flame quenched out for want of radical oil to prolong it; Thus Wit would be starved, for want of vapour to feed it; The truth is, a spare diet may make room in a Scholars head for old dead Authors to lie in; for the emptier their heads are of wit, the fuller they may be filled with learning; for I do imagine, old dead Au∣thors lie in a Scholars head, as they say souls do, none knows where, for a million of souls to lie in as small a compass as the point of a needle.
Her brain is hotly distempered, and moves with an extraordi∣nary quick motion, as may be perceived by her strange fancy: wherefore Nurse you had best get her to bed; if you can, and I will prescribe some me∣dicine and rules for her.
Come sweet child, let me put thee to bed.
I will go to bed, if you would have me, but good Nurse believe me, I am not mad; it's true, the force of my passion hath made my Reason to err; and though my Reason hath gone astray, yet it is not lost: But consider well Nurse, and tell me what noble mind can suffer a base ser∣vitude without rebellious passions? But howsoever, since they are of this o∣pinion, I am content to cherish it, if you approve of it; for if I seem mad,
the next of my kindred will beg the keeping of me for the sake of my E∣state; and I had rather lose my Estate, and be thought mad, than lose my honour in base offices, and my free-born liberty to be enslaved to whores; and though I do not fear my honest youth can be corrupted by ill example, yet I will not have my youth a witness to wicked and base vice.
By no means, I do not approve of these strange ways; be∣sides, you are a Ward to a gallant man, and may be Marriage will alter his humour; for most commonly those back-holders that are the greatest Li∣bertines, make the best Husbands.
It is true, he is of a noble nature, valiant and generous, pru∣dent, and just, and temperate in all delights, and free from all other vices but Incontinence, civil and obliging to all the world, but to me, and I could love him better than life, could he be constant, and only love me as he ought to do a Wife; otherwise, Death were more pleasing to me.
You were born to do me a mischief.
Why how?
Why you have routed an Army.
Which way?
I did imagine my self Married, my Husband being a Ge∣neral of an Army, who had fought many Battles, and had won many Vi∣ctories, conquered many Nations, at last an unfortunate day of Battle be∣ing fought, my Husband being too active and venturous, making lanes of slain bodies as he went, and his horse riding thorough Rivers of blood, those Ri∣verse rising so high, as his horse was forced to swim; but the blood growing thick to a jelly, obstructed his way, which made his horse furious, which fury added to his strength, forced a passage over a hill, or heap of slain by∣dies; but the horses spirits being spent with fury and labour, fell strength∣less to the ground, with my Husband upon his back; and being in the midst of his Enemies Army, his Enemies seeing him fall, ran about him in great numbers, and so took him prisoner: whereupon his Soldiers soon missing him, thought he was killed; upon which belief, their courages grew cold, their limbs unactive, and their spirits so benumbed, as they all seemed like to a number of stone-statues; which unactive dullness gave their Enemies the Day without any after-blows. I being in the Camp, hearing of my Husbands misfortunes, ran with a distracted fear towards the Enemies Camp; I being espied by some of my Husbands scattered Troops, was stopped in the way, and so brought back to my Tent again; where, when I was there, some of my Husbands Officers of the Army told me, That though the Day was lost, yet there was a considerable Body left; which I no sooner heard, but my spirits took new life, and then excusing my fear, told those Comman∣ders it was not through fear that made me run out of my Tent; for I did
not fly from my Enemies, but to them, and that I sought death, and not life; and to express my courage, I told them, That if they would give me leave, I would take my Husbands Office, and lead the Army: They told me, that if the rest of the Commanders would agree to it, they were well contented: So when all the Commanders met together, I spake thus un∣to them.
Noble Friends, and valiant Soldiers, you may think it a vain ambition for me to desire to lead your Army, especially against so potent an Enemy, and being a woman, which female Sex are usually unexperienced in Mar••∣al Affairs, as also by nature fearful, which fears may ruin an Army, by go∣avenge wrong direction, causing a confusion through distraction; and truly an Army were not to be trusted unto a woman; management and ordering, if that Records had not given us Precedents, which is, that Woman have led Armies, have fought valiantly themselves, and have had good success, and not so much by fortunes favour, as by their own wise Conduct: And to show that Pallas is a friend unto her own Sex, is, that in all History, there are very few women than can be found, that have lost Battles in the field of Wars, but many that have won Battles; and in all public Affairs it is to be observed, the Gods do generally assist our Sex, whereby to show their own power, and to abate the haughty pride of men. But to induce you more; for men trust not so much unto the Gods, as to their own strength, is, that you are present in all Councels and Actions, to assist and direct me; besides, I am Wife unto your General, who was and is an expert Soldier, and a valiant man, although he now had ill fortune; but ill fortune neither lessens valour nor experience, but rather increases them. This gallant and wise man, my Husband and your General, his Discourses have been my Tutors, and his Example hath and shall be my Guide; and if you dare trust me, I dare venture; otherwise I shall stay in my Tent, and pray for your good success. After I had left off speaking, an old Commander which had served long in the Wars, and was much esteemed, answered me as thus.
Noble Lady, although your youth doth dissuade us, yet your beauty and wit doth encourage us; for what man, although he were possessed with fear itself, can run away when a fair Lady sights? for beauty triumphs in all hearts, and commands the whole world: wherefore that man that shall or will deny to follow your Command, is of a bastard-kind, although a lawful Issue. With that all the rest of the Commanders cried or called out, that none was so fit to Lead and Command them as I. Thus being chosen, I called a general Muster of my Soldiers, and then gave order that some of the broken Regiments should be mended and made up with other broken Regiments, also I made new Officers in the room of those that were slain or taken prisoners, and after, I surveyed my Artillery and Ammunition; which done, I drew my Army into a Body, and after I had given Orders and Directions for the Soldiers to march towards the Enemies Camp, which when the Enemy heard of a new Army coming towards them, they drew out the Body of their Army in Battle Array: But I shunned to fight so soon as appeared, by reason my Army was tyred with marching; wherefore I gave order to Entrench: Besides, I thought it might give my soldiers more courage, when accustomed to the fight and neighbourhood of the Enemies: But withal, I made some of them give intelligence to the En∣my that a woman led the Army, by which they might despise us, and so be∣come
more negligent, by which negligence we might have an advantage: In the mean time I sent to Treat of a Peace, and to have my Husband set at liberty; but the Enemy was so averse to a peace, as they returned me both jesting and scornful Answers: So when I saw no peace could be made, I drew out my Army into Battle Array; which when the Enemy perceived, they did the like; but it will be too tedious at this time to tell the Form and Figures I put my Army into, as also what Commanders led, or who omman∣ded the Horse, or who commanded the Foot that day; only let me tell you, I led the Van my self, and was Accoutred after this manner: I had a Mas∣culine Suit, and over that a cloth of silver Coat, made close to my waste, which reached to the ankles of my legs; and those Arms I wore being all gilt, were Back, Breast, Gorget, Pot and Gantlet, all being made light accor∣ding as my strength would bear: In my hand I carried my Sword; for be∣ing not accustomed, I could not wear a sword by my side, as men do, but whenever rested, I tied it to my Saddle-bow, and on my Head-piece I wore a great Plume of Feathers: As for my Horse, he was cole-black, on∣lie a white star on his fore-head, and three white feet; my Saddle was crime∣son Velvet, but so embroidered with silver and gold, as the ground could not be seen: But when I was mounted, I spoke as following unto the com∣mon soldiers.
Worthy Friends, and laborous, and valiant Soldiers, you may justly won∣der to see a Woman thus Accoutred like a man, and being one of the ten∣der female Sex to be armed as a soldier, and in a posture to fight a Bat∣tel: Also you may fear the success of my Command, by reason I am young, and unexperienced, as also unpractised in the Wars: But fear not, the gods are with me, and will assist me, and have promised to give you victory by my Conduct; for they will conduct me: But the Gods suffered the other Battle to be lost, because many Victories had made you proud, and conceit∣ed of your selves, and your own valours, trusting more to your own strength, than to their favours or powers, whereupon the Gods destroyed many of you; but since they have taken pity of you, drawn to it by your humility: whereupon the Gods have commanded me to Lead and Conduct you; and they have also commanded me to tell you, That if you trust in them, and fight courageously, that you shall have Victory, and rich Spoils; for I heard the common people, of which common soldiers were of, were apt to be su∣perstitious, and to believe in any new reports, as also to believe in Miracles, Prophecies, and the like, and withal, very covetous; all which, made me feign my self to be commanded immediately from the Gods, and to be sent as from the Gods to command them, and to declare such promises to them; for all the common soldiers sight for Spoils, not for Honour.
O but it is not good to dissemble.
Pardon me; for without policy (which is deceit) there can be neither government in peace or war: wherefore it is a virtue in a States-man, or a Commander, to be a dissembler, although it be a vice in a∣ny other man; but you have put me out as you always do, and therefore I will tell you no more.
Nay, pray make an end.
I will not; but I could have told you how I killed the Ge∣neral of the Enemy with my own hand, and how I released my Husband, and of such gallant Acts as you never heard the like of.
O pray tel me.
Which if I do, let me never contemplate more, which would be worse than death to me, by reason it is the only pleasure of my life.
O Love, though thou art bred within the Soul, yet by the Senses thou art begotten, or else by some Opinions; for Virtue is but the Tutor, or Guide, for to instruct or lead thee in a perfect way• bur though I lead Love right, yet may it meet Opposers.
How do you find my Ward?
Truly she is somewhat distempered; for her wit is ve∣rye quick.
That's it; for she being naturally of a dull disposition, and of a mild humour, and her brain slow of conceits, as also unpractised in speaking, should of a sudden fall into high raptures.
You say true, my Lord; and it is to be feared this distem∣per will increase.
Pray Doctor have a regard and care to her distemper; for I would not willingly have a Wife that is more mad than natural wo∣men are.
She is not here.
O yonder she comes.
She hath a garb not like a Farmers Maid, but rather one
that's nobly born, and her garments, though mean, sit nearly on her body.
Fair Shepherdess, it is a melancholy life you lead.
It is a course of life suits best to my condition.
You may change this condition if you please.
I had rather lie honoured in death, than by dishonour raised to glorious state of life.
But here you live like a creature not produced by mankind, amongst beasts, having no conversation by discourse.
Want of Speech makes not beasts beasts, but want of Reason, &amp; want of Reason makes a man a beast; and speech rather disturbs than been∣fits the life, when silence and pure thoughts make men like Angels, whereas speech sometimes expresses men like Devils, blaspheming Heaven and God, fomenting factions amongst their kind, betraying trust &amp; friendship, cozening innocence, slattering vice, reproaching virtue, and with distractions strives to pull down honour from its feat; where silence refines the thoughts, eel∣vates the fancy, quickens wit, strengthens judgment, allays anger, sweetens melancholy, and collects the Reason.
Thou art a wonder, and for this one Speech I doe adores thee.
I should be sorry so worthy a person, and so noble a Gentleman as you seem to be, should adore my Speech, when it might be chance that did produce it, and not wit or judgment.
Thy speech is like to Orpheus Harp, it charms all ears that hear it.
I wish my Speech were like a Loadstone, to draw the iron hearts of men to pity and compassion, to charity and devotion.
Pray stay and choose me for your Love, and let me go along with you.
An Amorous Lovers, as I believe your Lordship is, never walks in sober pace, nor hath a constant and assured mind; for Amorous Lovers run with might and main, as if desires were caught with haste.
I perceive Farmers breed pretty Maids, and honest, as well as Lambs and Doves, and witty and well-behav'd Maids, as well as Courts and Cities do. O that I were unmatied, that I might wed this Sweet, Fair Country-maid!
But stay, here comes another by my troth, a very pretty Lass, but yet her garments sit not so neat, nor becoming, nor is her behavi∣our so graceful as the other Maids was. Sweet Mistress!
Pray keep your jeers to your self, I am no Mistress.
You may be my Mistress, if you please, and I will be your servant.
What to do?
What you please.
I am seldom pleased, and an idle fellow will anger me more.
I will be very industrious, if you please to set me to work.
You idle slut, do you stand loitering here, when it is more than time the Cows were milked?
Go milk them your self with a murrain, since you are so light-finger'd.
I will milk your sides first.
I marry Sir, this is right as a Farmers daughter should be; but in my Conscience the other Maid that was here before her is a bastard, begot by some Gentleman.
Let me tell you, Sir Iohn Argument, Love delivers up the whole Soul to the thing beloved; and the truth is, none but one soul can love another.
But Justice, Madam, must be the rule of Love; wherefore those souls which Love must give the bodies leave to join.
O no; pure souls may converse without gross bodies.
Were it not for the Senses, Madam, souls could have no ac∣quaintance, and without an acquaintance, there can be no reciprocal affecti∣on; and will you make the Senses, which are the souls chief confidence, to be strangers or enemies?
I would have them converse, but not interrupt.
The bodies must have mutual friendship and correspondence with each other, or otherwise they may dissemble, or betray the souls; or abuse the trust, loose appetites or wandering senses or contrary humours; and what can interrupt Love more than the disagreement of bodies?
The Senses and Appetites of the Body, are but as subject to the Soul.
But it is impossible for Foreign Princes, as I will compare two loving souls unto, can live in peace and mutual amity, if their subjects disagree.
O Mistress Troublesome, you are welcome; for you shall end the dispute between Sir Iohn Argument and I.
If you cannot decide the Dispute your selves, I shall never do it. But what is the Dispute Madam?
Whether there can be a perfect friendship of Souls without a reciprocal and mutual conversation and conjunctions of Bodies?
Faith, Madam, I think it would be a very faint friendship betwixt the Souls, without the Bodies.
I perceive Sir Iohn Argument and you would never make Ply∣tonick Lovers.
Faith, Madam, I think Platonic is a word without sense.
You say right, Mistress Troublesome, it is an insensible love.
It is the Soul of Love.
What's that, Madam, a Ghost, or Spirit?
Indeed it hath no material body.
No, for it is an incorporal thing.
What is an incorporal thing, Sir Iohn?
Why, nothing.
Pray leave this discourse, or else you will talk nonsense.
That's usual in Conversation.
Setting aside this discourse at Mistress Troublesomes request, Pray tell me how the Lady Contemplation doth?
Faith Madam, by the course of her life one might think she were an incorporal thing.
Why?
Because she makes but little use of her Body, living always within her Mind.
Then her Body stands but as a Cipher amongst the Figures of her thoughts.
Just so, by my Troth.
Pray bring me acquainted with the Lady Contemplation.
If it be possible, I will; but the Lady Visitant can do it bet∣la than I.
I am resolved I will visit her.
What, is your passion over?
My passion will strive to maintain my honour, and you may take my life; but as long as I live, my passion will fight in the quarrel. But what man of honour will make a Bawd of her he intends to make his Wife? and what man of honour will be cruel to those that are weak, helpless, and shiftless? and what man of honour will be uncivil to the meanest of our Sex? It is more noble to flatter us, than to quarrel with us;
but that I have heard you are valiant, I should think you were a base cow∣art, and such a one that would quarrel in a Brothel-house, rather than fight in a Battle: But I perceive you are one that loves Pleasure more than Ho∣nor, and Life more than Fame; and I hate to be in that mans company, or to make a Husband, whose courage lies in Volupmousness, and his life in Infamy: I will sooner marry Death, than such a man.
Her words have shot through my soul, and have made a sen∣sible wound therein. How wisely she did speak! how beautiful appeared! Her mind is full of honour, and the actions of her life are built upon noble principles; so young, so wise, so fair, so chaste, and I to use her so basely as I have done! O how I hate my self for doing so unworthily!
The more ground is trodden on, the easier the path to walk in.
It seems so, that you visit me so often.
Why, thou art such sweet company, and behav'st thy self so prettily, as I cannot choose but visit thee.
I would, if I could, behave my self so to the world, as my indiscretion might not defame me.
Why do you think of a Fame?
Why not? since fame many times arises from poor Cottages, as well as from great Palaces; witness the Country labouring-man, that was taken from the plough, and made an Emperor, as being thought sit to rule, both for Justice and Wisdom, and he was more famous than those that were born of an Heroic Line, and were of Royal dignity; and David a shepherd, became a King. It is Merit that deserves a fame, not Birth; and sometimes Merit hath its desert, though but seldom.
Thy discourse would tempt any man.
Mistake not my discourse, it hath no such devilish design; for to tempt, is to pervert: It is true, my Nature takes delight to delight and please others, and not to cross or displease any, yet not to tempt, or to de∣lude with counterfeit demeanours, or fair insinuating words, smooth speech, or oiled tongue, to draw from Virtues side, but to persuade and plead in Virtues cause.
Thy very looks would gain a cause, before thy tongue could plead.
Alas! mans countenance is like the Sea, which ebbs and flows as passion moves the mind.
I am sure Love moves my mind, and makes it in a fiery heat.
If it be noble Love, it is like the Sun, which runs about to give both light and heat to all the world, that else would sit in darkness, and be both cold and sterile; so doth a noble mind run with industry to help those in distress, his bounty heats, his counsel and advice gives light.
I love you so much, Sweet-heart, that since you will not be my Mistress, you shall be my Wife.
Indeed I will not.
Will you refuse me?
Yes.
Wherefore?
Because I know, though you may use me well at first, after a time you'll be divorced.
I will never part from thee.
O yes but you will, for youth and beauty most commonly are inconstant; for vain ambition, and flattering praises, corrupt that mind that lives therein, and is pleased therewith.
Well, I will become a new man, and cast off all vanity, and study Moral Philosophy, to gain this Maid; for then perchance she will love me.
Complements are the worst sort of Conversation, for they are not sociable; besides, Truth holds no intelligence nor corre∣spondence with them.
Truth is no Complement as flattery, and I speak nothing but what truth hath dictated to my tongue.
Those praises you gave me were writ by speech, in so fine a style of Eloquence, with such flourishing Letters of words, as I cannot believe but that custom of self-conceited wit or passion, hath given the Scribe, which is the Tongue, a bribe to slatter me.
This is a wonder to see you, Lady Contemplation, abroad, I doubt it doth Prognosticate some change of Fortune, pray Jove it be good.
All the ill will fall on me, Madam.
Nay, faith Madam, she accounts company a worse for∣tune than the ruin of a Kingdom, and you cannot conceive with what dif∣ficulty I have got her abroad; for at first I did persuade her with all the
Rhetoric I had, and pleaded with as powerful arguments as I could find, any promised more than I was able to perform, and nothing of this could get her forth, until I told her I would bring your Ladyship to visit her, and that forced her out; for she said, she would rather trouble you, than you should trouble her.
Faith, Contemplation, thou art only sit to keep beasts com∣pany; for what difference is there betwixt beasts and men, but Conver∣sation.
Indeed beasts want that folly of idle Conversation, and the error of speaking, as much as the vanity of dressing, and the custom of dissembling; for they spend their time more prudently, quietly, easily, ho∣nestly, so more happily; and if it were for no other reason than speaking, I had rather be a beast, than of mankind.
O fie, O fie, you are a beastly Lady.
No, Madam, beasts have no false Titles of Honour, their honour lives in their natures, not in their names.
Who that may choose, or have their liberty, would spend their time in idle thoughts?
All that are wise, and would be happy; for should not we think that man were mad, that leaves a peaceful habitation, and thrusts him∣self in foreign broils? or should not we think a King were most unjust, that makes his peaceful and obedient subjects slaves to strange Princes? The Mind's a Common-wealth, and the Thoughts are the Citizens therein, and Reason rules as King, or ought to doe: But there is no reason we should vex our Thoughts with outward things, or make them slaves unto the world.
But thoughts would want employment, were it not for the world, and idleness were worse than slavish toils.
The thoughts, without the worlds materials, can Create millions of worlds, only with the help of Imagination.
Then your Mind and the World are mere strangers.
I say not so; for though the World draws not my Mind to wander up and down, yet my Mind draws the World to it, then pencils out each several part and piece, and hangs that Landscape in my Brain, on which my thoughts do view with Judgments eyes. Thus the world is in my Mind; although my Mind is not in the world.
Then you enchant the world?
I had rather enchant the world, than the world should in∣chant me.
If the Mind be a Common-wealth, as you said even now it was, Pray tell me of what degree the Passions are of?
They are the Nobles thereof, and Magistrates therein; each several Passion still governs in its turn and office.
And what are the Appetites?
The Appetites are none of the Mind's Citizens, but they are an unruly Rout that dwell in the Senses, which are the Suburbs of the Body: Indeed the Appetites are the Out-Lawries, and doe oft-times much hurt with their disorders, insomuch as they, many times, disturb the minds tranquillity, and peace. But, Madam, lest the appetite of talking should di∣sturb the Mind, I shall kiss your Ladyships hand, and leave you to those that are more delightful and pleasanter company than I am.
Lady Conversation, I perceive you and Sir Vain Complement are grown dull with the Lady Contemplations company.
Mercury defend me from her; for I would not keep her company for Ioves Mansion.
And Cupped defend me from her; for I would not be bound to Court her for the Favours Venus gives to Mars.
Lord what a dull piece of gravity she is!
She looks as if she conversed with none but Ghosts and Spirits, walking in Moon-shine, and solitary and dismal places.
Let us talk of her no more; for I am so far from keeping her acquaintance, as I hate to hear her named.
My Sweet, Fair Maid, I cannot hope thy Pardon, for my crimes are not only great, but many; for I have not only used you un∣kindly, uncivilly, ungentlemanly, which are vices and crimes that Canker∣fret the Fame of Honour, and bury all noble qualities; but I have used you barbarously, cruelly, and inhumanly, which are sins sufficient to annihi∣late all the Masculine Race; and surely, if there be that we call Justice in Nature, it will, unless thy virtue redeem them, and save them with thy pity: wherefore, for the sake of the generality, though not for my particular, par∣don me. Thus will you become a Deity to your whole Sex and ours.
I am sure your Lordship is a particular punishment to me, which Heaven send me quit of.
Lady, you smother your thoughts, and stifle your cons∣ption in the close Closet of Study.
No Sir, I only keep them warm, being tender and weak.
They will grow stronger in the Air of Conversation; but when continually kept close in the Chamber of Contemplation, they will be apt to fall into many several diseases, as melancholy Opinions, and extrava∣gent Fancies, which may over-heat the mind, and sire the thoughts: where∣fore Lady let me give you Counsel.
What Counsel would you give me? as a Lawyer, or Phy∣cian?
As a Physician.
For the Body, or the Mind?
For the Mind.
The Physicians for the Mind are Divine:
No, the best physicians for the Mind are Poets.
How will you prove that?
By Example and Skill; for when the Mind is raging mad; Poets, with gentle persuasions, in smooth numbers, and soft music, cure it; and when the Mind is despairing, Poets draw hopes into numbers, which beats out the doubtful Foe: And for Example.
David with his Poetical Inspirations, and Harpsical harmonious Music, allayed the ill Spirit, and raging passion of Saul; for Poets take from the sweet Spring of Nature, an Oil of Love, and from Heaven, the Balsam of Mercy, and pour them through golden numbers, and pipes of wit, into the festered wounds of despair, when oft-times Divines, in stead of suppling Oil, pour in corroding Vitriol, and in stead of healing Balsoms, pour in burning Sulphur, which are terrifying threats, and fearful menaces: where∣fore Lady, let me advise you as a Poetical Physician, to keep your mind cool, and your thoughts in equal temper; wherefore in order thereto, when the mind is wrapped in the mantle of Imagination, if it finds it self very hot therewith, let it lay that mantle by, and bathe it self in the fresh, clear, pure Rivers of Discourse.
By your favour, Sir, for the most part, the Mind becomes hotter with the motion of the tongue, than the mantle of Imagination; for when the tongue hath liberty, it runs wildly about, and draggs the mind af∣la it; and rather than I will have my minded dragged and hurried about by my unruly tongue, which will neither endure the bit of Reason, nor the bri∣dl of Discretion, but runs beyond all sense, I will tie up my tongue with the cords of silence, in the stable of the mouth, and pull down the Portcullis of the teeth before it, and shut the doors of my lips upon it. Thus shall it be treble locked, and kept with the Key of Judgment, and the Authority of Prudence.
Did you hear him say he had lain with me?
Yes, Madam.
O the wicked, base vain-glory of men, to belly the pure chastity of a woman! But surely he did not plainly express so much in clear words, as by nods, winks, shrugs, dark sentences, or broken discourses?
He said plainly, he had lain with you in an unlawful manner.
Fates assist me in revenge; for it is no dishonour to be re∣veng'd of a base person, that hath maliciously slandered me, or vainglory∣ously injured me.
Revenge is against the Laws of Honour, Madam.
It may be against the Tenets of some particular Reli∣gion,
or religious Opinions. But a noble revenge is the ground or foundati∣on of Heroic Honour.
But what do you call a Noble Revenge?
First, to be an open Enemy, as to declare the enmity; next, to declare their endeavour to prosecute to the utmost of their power, either their Enemies Estate, Liberty, and Life; whereas a base Revenger is to dissemble, in professing they have forgotten and forgiven their injury, and pardoned their Enemy, yet under-hand and disguisedly endeavour to do their Enemy a mischief. Not but an honourable Revenger may choose their time for executing their revenge; but they must declare they will be revenged be∣fore they execute their revenge, and let their Enemies stand upon their Guard.
But a revengeful woman is not good.
Why not, as well as a revengeful man? For why may not a woman revenge her scandalised honour as well as a man? Is there any reason why it should be a dishonour for a man to pass by a disgrace, and for a woman to revenge her disgrace? Is it not as great a blemish to the honour of a woman, to be said to be unchaste, as for a man to be said to be a Cow∣art? And shall a woman only sit and weep over her lost honour, whilst a man fights to regain his? And shall it be thought no dishonour for a man to pistol, or at least bastonade another man for an injury, or an affront re∣ceiv'd, and a fault for a woman to do, or cause to be done the like? Must women only sit down with foolish patience, and endure wrong, when men may execute revenge with fury? These were both injustice, and an unjust act of Education to our Sex; as also it would be an unjust sentence, not on∣lie from men, but from the Gods, since neither Gods nor men will suffer in∣jury, wrong, or dishonour, without revenge: But if Gods, Men, and Adieu∣cation should be so unjust to our Sex, yet there is no Reason in Nature we should be so unjust to our selves: But for my part, as I am constant to an honest friend, and can easily forgive an honourable Enemy, so I can never forgive a malicious Foe, nor forget a vain-glorious bragging fool, or false slandring knave, but will persecute them to the utmost of my power, and the weight of my revenge should be according to the pressure of my injury, or dishonour.
But let me tell you, Madam, those that brag are seldom be∣leaved, and there is none that believe these vain bragging Renters; for it's well known, that all Renters are idle deboyst persons, and do usually belie the most Honourable and Chaste Ladies, for which all worthy persons hate them, and account them so base, as they will shun their companies; no man of honour will come near them, unless it be to beat them. But if you appear to the world as concerned, you may raise those doubts which would never have been raised, had you took no notice thereof.
Indeed Disputes raise doubts; wherefore I will not bring it into a Dispute, but take your Counsel, and take no notice of it.
You will do wisely, Lady.
I wish my tongue as smooth as oil, to make my words as soft as Air, that they may spread about your heart, there intermixed with your affection.
Words cannot win my love, no more than wealth, nor is my heart subject to those infections.
I will build thee Palaces of burnished gold, where thou shalt be worshipped whilst thou livest, and when thou die, I will erect a Mo∣nument more famous than Mausolus's was.
My Virtue shall build me a Monument far richer, and more lasting; for the materials with which it shall be built, shall be tried Chasti∣tie, as pure Gold, and Innocence, as Marble white, and Constancy, as undis∣solving Diamonds, and Modesty, as Rubies red, Love shall the Altar be, and Piety, as Incense sweet, ascend to Heaven, Truth, as the Oil, shall feed the Lamp of Memory, whereby the flame of Fame shall never go out.
And is She gone? are Riches of no force? Then I will bu∣rye my self within the bowels of the Earth, so deep, that men shall never reach me, nor Light shall find me out.
My Lord, my Lady, the Lady Amorous, remembers her Service to you, and sent me to tell you her Husband is gone out of Town, and She desires to have the happiness of your company.
Pray present my Service in the humblest manner to your Lady, and pray her to excuse me; for though I cannot say I am sick, yet I am far from being well.
I shall, my Lord.
My Lord, there is an old man without desires to speak with you.
Direct him hither.
Old man, what have you to say to me?
I am come to desire your Lordship not to persecute a poor young Maid, one that is friendless, and your Lordship is powerful, and therefore dangerous.
What poor Maid do you mean?
A Maid called Poor Virtue.
Do you know her?
Yes.
Are you her Father?
No, I am her servant, and have been maintained by her Noble Family these threescore years, and upwards.
Ha, her Noble Family! what, or who is She?
She is a Lady, born from a Noble Stock, and hath been choisely bred, but ruined by misfortunes, which makes her poorly serve.
Alas he weeps! Who were her Parents?
The Lord Morality, and the Lady Piety.
Sure it cannot be: But why should I doubt? her Beauty, Wit, and sweet Demeanour, declares her Noble Pedigree: The Lord Morality was a Famous man, and was a great Commander, and wise in making Laws, and prudent for the Common Good: He was a Staff and Prop un∣to the Common-wealth, till Civil Wars did throw it down, where he fell under it. But honest friend, how shall I know this for a truth?
Did not your Lordship hear he had a Child?
Yes that I did, an only Daughter.
This is She I mention, and if Times mend, will have her Fa∣theirs Estate, as being her Fathers Heir; but to prove it, and her Birth, I will bring all those servants that lived with her, and with her Father, and all his Tenants, that will witness the truth.
When I consider, and bring her and her Actions to my mind, I cannot doubt the truth, and for the news, thou shalt be my Adopted Father, and my Bosome-friend; I'll be a staff for thy Old Age to lean upon, my shoulders shall give strength unto thy feeble limbs, and on my neck shalt lay thy restless head,
Heaven bless you, and I shall serve you as my Old Age will give me leave.
Thou Celestial Creature, do not believe that I am so pre∣sumptuous to ask thy love, I only beg thy pardon, that when my body lies in the silent grave, you give my restless soul a pass, and leave to walk a∣amongst sad Lovers in dark and gloomy shades; and though I cannot weep to show my penitence, yet I can bleed.
Here, take this Instrument of Death, for only by your hands I wish to die.
Give me as many Wounds as Pores in skin,
That I may bleed sufficient for my sin.
It seems strange to me, that you, a wise man, or at least ac∣counted so, should fall into such extremes, as one while to hate me to death, and now to profess to love me beyond life!
My Debaucheries blinded my Judgment, nor did I know thy worth, or my own error, until thy wise wit gave the light to my dark understanding, and you have drawn my bad life, and all my unworthy act∣once therein, so naturally in your discourse, as now I view them, I do hate my self as much as you have cause to hate me.
