I only hate your Crimes, but for those excellent Qualities, and true Virtues that dwell in your Soul, I love and honour; and if you think me worthy to make me your Wife, and will love me according as my honest life will deserve your affections, I shall be proud of the Honour, and thank Fortune or Heaven for the Gift.
Sure you cannot love me, and the World would condemn you if you should, and all your Sex will hate you.
The World many times condemns even Justice her self, and women, for the most part, hate that they should love and honour.
But can you love me?
I can, and do love you.
How happy am I, to enjoy a world of Beauty, Wit, Virtue, and sweet Graces.
Honest Roger and Maudlin, I present you with a kind Good-morrow.
Present me? Bless your Lordship, I should present you with a couple of Capons.
It is a salutation when you salute; but how do you then?
Very well, I thank your Honour: How do you?
Well, enough of Complements, I am come with a Petition to you.
What is that, is it please your Honour?
A Suit.
Byrlaken I have need of one, for I have but poor and bare cloth∣ing on.
No, Roger, it is a request and desire I have you should grant.
Grant, or to Farm let, no Sir, I will not part with my Lease.
Roger, you understand me not, therefore let me speak with Maudlin your Wife.
There she is Sir, spare her not, for she is good metal I'll warrant your Honour; wipe your lips Maudlin, and answer him every time that he moves thee, and give him as good as he brings: Maudlin, were he twenty Lords, hold up your head, Maudlin, be not hollow.
I'll warrant you Husband, I'll satisfy him.
Honest Maudlin.
That's more than your Lordship knows.
Why then Maudlin.
That's my name indeed.
You have a maid here in your house.
I hope so forsooth; but I will not answer for no Virgin in this wicked world.
Well said Maudlin; Nay your Honour will get nothing of my Maudlin, I'll warrant you.
Well, this supposed Maid is Poor Virtue, that's her name, I de∣sire you will let her live with me, this Poor Virtue.
God bless you Honour from her, it is not fit for a Lord, and a great Noble-man to meddle with Virtue, your Honour should not foul your fingers with her: Besides, she will never stay in a great mans house, neither is it fit she should; and your Honours servants will hate her like the Devil, for she will please no body as she should do, a very peevish, ill-natured girl forsooth she is.
Why how doth she agree then with you?
Alas forsooth, if it please your Honour, Virtue may live in a Cottage, when she will be whipped out of a Court, or a great Lords Palace; they may talk of her, but they will never give her leave to live and board with them: It may be they give their Chaplain leave to talk of her a Sun∣days, or so forsooth, but talk's but talk, for they forget her the six days after,
and never mind her; for indeed she is a very peevish girl, and not fit for Gentlefolks company, that's the truth of it, hardly for poor folks.
Why you agree well with her?
Nay by the faith of my body do I not; for I can hardly go to Market, and be merry, as I use to be, and all long of her peevishness: nay I cannot go to order one of our busy Thrashers, but she troubles me; or to speak with the Carter, but she whip, in presently, or discourse with the Plough-man about his plough-share, how he should order it for my advan∣tage, but she troubles me; or about our Husbandman, how and where he should sow his Seed, but she vexes me still: Such a life, the Gods help me, as I am even weary of my self. Speak Roger, is it not true?
True Maudlin as steel, I never was merry since she was in my house, the May-pole is down since she came.
I Roger that it is, the more the pity.
And the Towns Green is a Meadow, and the poor Big-pipers cheeks are fallen into a Consumption, hardly wind to speak withal; the Morris-dan∣cers bells are silenced, and their cross garters held superstitious, idolatrous, and profane; the May-Lord and his Lady deposed, and the Hobby-horse is forgotten; nay the Whitson-Lord and Lady are banished, Merry Wakes oboe∣lish'd, and the poor Ale-wives beggared,
I, I, and all since this melancholy girl Virtue came into our house.
I cannot choose but cry.
Thou art true Maudlin then.
Yes, with small beer, that's the calamity of it; therefore bless every good subject from so melancholy a thing as this girl Virtue is: But we have a Daughter, and it please your Honours worship, that will give you good content, and please most of your Household; for she is a lusty Wench, though I say it that should not say it: Did you but see her swim like a Tench on our Town-green, encircling the May-pole, and at the end of a Horn-pipe, when she is to be kissed, how modestly the wries her head away, but so as to be civil; nay she hath been well Educated, my own natural Daughter, for in∣deed Roger, I was with Child with her before you married me.
Peace Maudlin, all Truths are not to be spoken of; for should that be, many a Worshipful Person would be very angry; but our Vicar made all well betwixt thee and me, Maudlin: But I beseech your Honour take my Daughter, for you will find her another manner of woman than Virtue is, for she is not like her in faith, nor any thing that belongs to her, she is better blessed than so.
No, I will have Poor Virtue, or none.
Faith if you have Virtue, you are sure to have her poor, for I never knew any of her Family rich, the Gods do not bless them, I think, in this world; but if you will have her, take her, shall he not, Maudlin?
Yes, Husband, and the house is well rid of her, and let us bless our selves for it; for now we shall be like our Neighbours again, we will not abate them an hair, the best in the Parish shall not live merrier than we will now for all Sports: Why, Vanity and Sin, Husband, is the Liberty of the Subject, and the seven Deadly Sins are the Fundamental Laws of the Kingdom, from the greatest to the least, if poor folks might have their right. Well, your Honour shall have her, but you will be as weary of her as we have been, the Gods bless your Honour, but alas you do not know what this
Girl Virtue is, Lords have no guess at her.
Well Maudlin, let me have her, I desire no more.
Nor we neither, if it pleases your Honour, and so the Gods give you good of her.
Let me speak to his Honour, Maudlin.
Do so Roger.
I give yourdship many thanks.
For what?
For ridding our house of this troublesome Girl.
And I thank you for it too.
When thanks on all sides happen, we are eased.
And I with your Poor Virtue am well pleased.
Mark the end of it, Roger.
Yes Maudlin, the End Crowns the Work.
What always musing? Shall I never find thee in a sociable humour?
I would you had come sooner, or stayed longer away.
Why prithee?
I will tell you: A while since, there came the Muses to visit me, being all either mad, or drunk, for they tossed and tumbled me, and rumbled me about, from one to the other, as I thought they would a dive∣ded me amongst them: At last came in the Sciences to visit me, with sober Faces, grave Countenances, stayed and formal Behaviours, and after they had Saluted me, they began to talk very seriously to me, their Discourse being Rational, Probable, Wise, Learned, and Experienced; but all the while the Muses would not let me alone, one pulled me to Dance, another to Sing, another to play on Music, others to recite Verses, speak Speeches, and Act parts of Plays, and the like• Whereupon I gravely turned the in∣corporal head of my rational Soul, nodding it to them to be quiet, and let me alone, but still they played with me: At last my Thoughts, which are the language of the Soul, spoke to them, and prayed them to forbear, until such time as the Sciences were gone; but they would not be quiet, nor silent, doe
what I could, but would interrupt the Sciences in the midst of their Dis∣course, with their idle Rimes, light Fancies, and odd Numbers, insomuch as the Sciences departed: Whereupon the Muses did rejoice, and skip, and run about, as if they had been wilde: And in this jocund humour, in came the Arts, even a whole Common-wealth; for there were not only Politic Arts, Civil and Combining Arts, Profitable and necessary Arts, Military Arts, and Ceremonious Arts; but there were Superstitious Arts, Idol∣trous Arts, false, factious, and mischievous Arts, destructive and wicked Arts, base and mean Art, foolish, childish, vain, superfluous and unprofita∣ble Arts: Upon all these Arts the Muses made good sport; for at some they flung jests, scorns, and scoffs, and some they stripped naked, but to others they were cruel, for some they stayed their skins off, and others they made very Skeletons of, dissecting them to the very bones; and the truth is, they spa∣red not the best of them, but they had one saying or other to them: But when all the Arts departed, they took me, and carried to the Well of Heli∣con, and there they threw me in over head and cares, and said they would Souse me in the Liquor of Poetry; but when I was in the Well, I thought verily I should have been drowned, for all my outward Senses were smo∣ther'd and choked, for the water did blind my eyes, stopped my ears and no∣strils, and filled my mouth so full, as I had not so much space as to spout it sorth; besides all my body was so numb, as I had no feeling, insomuch, as when they took me out of this Well of Helicon, into which they had flung me, I seemed as dead, being quite senseless: Whereupon they all agreed to take and carry me up on Parnassas Hill, and to lay me on the 〈◊〉 thereof, that the Poetical Flame, or Heat therein, might dry and warm me; after which agreement they took me up, every one bea•ing a part o• m•, or was industrious about me, for some carried my Head, others my Legs, some held my Hands, others embraced my Waste, another oiled my Tongue, and o∣theirs powered Spirits into my Mouth, but the worst-natur'd Muse pinched me, to try if I was sensible, or not, and the sweetest and tenderest natured Muse wept over me, and another was so kind as to kiss me; but when they had brought me up to the top of the Hill, and laid me thereupon, I felt such a heat, as if they had laid me on AEtna; but after I had lain some time, I felt it not so hot, and so less and less, until I felt it like as my natural heat; just like those that go into a hot Bathe, at first cry out it is insufferable and scalding hot, yet with a little use will sinde it cool enough: But whilst I lay on Parnassus Hill, I began to make a Lyric Verse, as thus.
Bright, Sparkling hot Poetic sire,
My duller Muse Inspire
Unto thy Sweeter Lyre:
My Fancies like as Notes all sit
To play a Tune of Wit
On well-strung Numbers fit.
But your unfortnnate Visit hath pulled me so hastily down from the Hill, that the force of the speed hath cracked my Imaginary Fiddle, broke the Strings of my Wit, blotted the Notes of Numbers, so spoiled my Song.
Prithee, there is none that would have taken the pains to have sung thy Song, unless some blind Fiddler in an Alehouse, and then not any one would have listened unto it, for the fume of the drink would stop the
sense of their ears: Besides, Drunkards love not, nor delight in nothing but beastly Nonsense; but howsoever I had done thee a friendly part, to fetch thee down from off that monstrous high Hill, whereby the vastness of the height might have made you so dizzy, as you might have fallen there-from on the sharp stones of Spite, or at least, on the hard ground of Censure, which might have bruised, if not wounded the Reputatio of thy Wit.
Let me tell you, you had done me a Curtsy to have let me remained there some time; for if you had let me alone, I might there have improved the Stature of my Wit, perfected the Health of my Judge∣meant, and had nourished the Life of my Muse.
Still I fear my fault is beyond a Pacification, yet the Gods are pacified with submissive Actions, as bended knees, repentant tear, im∣ploring words, sorrowful Sighs, and dejected Countenances, all which I gave to thee.
Though there is always in my mind an obedient respect to Merit, yet a scorn is a sufficient cause to make a rebelling of thoughts, words, and actions; for though I am poor, yet I am virtuous, and Virtue is to be pre∣ferr'd before Wealth or Birth, were I meanly born. But howsoever, true Love, like a great and powerful Monarch, soon disperses those rebellious passions, and quiets those factious thoughts, and all murmuring speeches, or words, are put to silence, banishing all frowning Countenance, returning humble looks into the eyes again.
Then you have pardoned me.
Yes.
And do you love me?
As Saints do Heaven.
Your Favours have raised my spirits from the grave of Melan∣choly, and your pure Love hath given me a new Life.
So truly I love you, as nothing but death can destroy it; my, I am of that belief, that were I dead, and turned to ashes, my dust, like firm and lasting steel, would fly unto you, as to the Loadstone, if you were at such distance as nothing might oppose.
Thus Souls, as well as Bodies, love.
Since I cannot have the happiness of your Lordships company at my House, I am come to wait upon you at your House.
Your Ladyship doth me too great an honour.
Your Lordship is grown very Courtly. Pray how comes our familiar friendship so estranged, and set at distance with Comple∣mints?
Madam, my wilde manners have been so rude to your Fair Sex, as I am become a scorn and shame unto my self.
I hate Civility and Manners in a man, it makes him ap∣pear sneakingly, poorly, and effeminate, and not a Cavalier: Bold and free Actions become your Sex.
It doth so in a Camp amongst rude and rough Soldiers, whose Breeding never knew Civility, nor will obey gentle Commands, sub∣meting only to rigorous Authority: But to the fair, tender, effeminate Sex, men should offer their service by their admiring Looks, civil Discourses, and humble Actions, bowing as to a Deity; and when they are pleased to fa∣four their servants, those Favours to be accounted beyond the Gifts of Jove.
Have I Cuckolded my Husband, dishonoured my Family, defamed my self for your sake, and am I thus rewarded and thrown aside with civil Complements? O basest of men!
I am sorry I have wronged your Husband, but more sorry I have dishonoured you, and what satisfaction a true repentance can make, I offer upon the Altar of a Reformed Life.
Do you repent? O false man! May you be cursed of all your Sex, and die the death of Orpheus.
It is beyond the power of Jove to please the various humours of Woman-kind.
There was never so many Noble Persons Married in one day, in one City, I think, before those that are to Marry to more∣row.
Who are they?
Why, do you not hear?
No.
Surely you have been either dead or deaf.
I have been in the Country.
That is some reason indeed; but the News of the City uses to travel in Letters on Post-horses into the Country.
No faith, for the most part they come in slow Waggons; but tell me who those are that are to be Married to morrow?
Why first there is the Lord Title and the Lady Virtue. Se∣condly, the Lord Courtship and the Lady VVard. Thirdly, there is Sir Famit Poet and the Lady Contemplation. Fourthly, the Lady Conversation and Sir Experienced Traveller. And fifthly, the Lady Visitant and Sir Humphrey In∣terruption.
I will do my endeavour to see them all; for I will go to each Bridal House.
How will you do so, being all married on a day?
Why I will bid Good-morrow to the one, and I will go to Church with another, and dine with the third, and dance the afternoon with the fourth, and see the fifth a bed.
That you may do.
Lord there are so many Weddings to be to morrow, as I know not which to go to! Besides, I shall displease those I go not to, being invited to them all.
If you would displease neither of them, you must seign your self sick, and go to none of them.
None of them, say you? that would be a cause to make me die; for I would not but be a guest to one of them for any thing could be given me: But I am resolved to go to the Lady Conversation and Sir Ex∣perienc'd Travellers Wedding, for there there will be the most company, and it is company that I love better than the Wedding-cheer; for much company is a Feast to me.
Truly Mistress, I wonder you should delight in company, you being in years.
Out you naughty Wench, do you say I am old?
No indeed, I did not name old.
Then let me tell you, that those women that are in years, seek company to divulge their Wit, as youth to divulge their Beauty; and we Aged Wits may chance to catch a Lover from a young Beauty: But I should applaud my own wit, if it could contrive to bring each Bride and Bridegroom into one Assembly, making Hymen's Monarchy a Republic, where all should be in common.
So Mistress you would prove a Traitor to Hymen, which is a Bawd.
Faith I will turn you away for your boldness.
I am come to tell you, that the five Bridals meet with their Guests and good Cheer at the City-Hall, and make their several Comp∣niece Joining as one, as one Body, and there will be such Revelling, as the like was never before.
Iuno be thanked, and Venus be praised for it; for I was much perplexed concerning their Divisions, till you came and brought me this good News of their Corporation.
Come Old Humanity, and be our Father, to join and give us in the Church; and then when we are Married, we will live a Country-life, I as a Shepherd, and this Lady as my Fair Shepherdess.
My dear Child, you appear as a sweet budding Rose this morning.
Roses are beset with thorns, Nurse, I hope I am not so.
By'r Lady your Husband may prove a thorn, if he be not a good man, and a kind Husband; but Oh my heart doth ache.
Wherefore doth it ache?
Come Sweet, are you ready? for it is time to go to Church, it is almost twelve a clock.
I am ready, but my Nurse doth affright me, by telling me her heart doth ache, as if she did fore-know by her experien'd age some ill for∣tune towards me, or that I shall be unhappy in my marriage.
Her heart doth not ache for you, but for her self, because she cannot be a young fair bride, as you are, as being past her youth; so that her heart doth ache out of a sad remembrance of her self, not for a present, or a future cause for you.
Well, well, I was young indeed, and a comely bride when I was married, though I say it, and had a loving bridegroom, Heaven rest his soul.
Come, I have brought all my bridal guests hither to join with yours, for we will go to Church together: Wherefore prithee come away, our Bridegrooms and our Guests stay for you.
I will go to them by and by.
Why, I hope you do not stay to muse upon Phantasms, saith Marriage will banish them out of your head, you must now employ your time with Realities.
If I thought Marriage would destroy or disturb my Con∣templations, I would not marry, although my Wedding-guests were come, and my Wedding-dinner ready dressed, and my Wedding-cloaths on; nay, were I at the holy Altar, I would return back.
That would be such an action, as all the Kingdom would say you were mad.
I had rather all the World should not only say I were mad, but think me so, rather than my self to be unhappy.
Can want of Contemplation make you unhappy?
Yes, as unhappy as a body can be without a soul; for Con∣templation is the life of the soul, and who can be happy that hath a dead soul?
By my troth I had rather be dead, than have such a dull life.
Madam, the Bridegroom is coming hither.
I will prevent him, and meet him.
Come away, come away, they'll be all married before we shall get to Church.
There will be enough Witnesses, we may well be spared; but so I share of the Feast, I care not whether they be married or not.
The truth is, the benefit to us will be only in eating of their meat, and drinking of their wine.
And I mean to be drunk, but not for joy of their Marriages, but for pleasure of my Gusto.
What Lines of Light doe from those Torches spin,
Which winds about those Ladies whiter skin?
But from their Eyes more Splend'rous Beams doe run,
As bright as those that issue from the Sun.
Wherein the lesser Lights wax dull and dim,
Or like as Minnes in an Ocean swim.
By your good leave Gentlefolks,  I am come here to complain of this Hog-grubber
Sir Golden Riches, who did tempt me with Gold till he had his desire, you know all what it is, and I like an honest woman, as it were, kept my word, and performed truly as any woman could do: Speak, can thou detect me either in word or deed? and like a false and covetous wretch as thou art, performed nothing with me as thou should have done, I am sure of that: Is it not a truth? speak coverous wretch, speak.
Why, what did I promise you?
Why thou did promise me an hundred pounds in gold, showed it me, and then took it away again; nay further, thou said I should be a Lady, and have a great parimanus Coach gilt, with neighing Horses, and a Coachman, with a Postilion to ride before: Nay, nay, I remember well e∣nough what you said, you talked of Gesemond, Pomatum, and Roman Gunpow∣der for my hair, and fine gowns and stockings, and sine laced silk garters, and roses shining like Stars, God bless us!
Did I, did I?
Yes, that you did, you know what you did, and how you did, and so do I; and Gentlefolks as I am a true woman, which he knows I am, I never had more than this white fustion waistcoat, and three pence to buy me three pennyworth of pins, for he would allow me no incle to tie it withal, and this old stamel petticoat, that was his great Grand∣mothers in Eighty eight, I am no two-legged creature else.
But I bought you velvet to guard it withal.
Yes, that's true, an old black velvet Jerkin without sleeves, that had belonged to one of Queen Elizabeth her learned Counsel in the Law of blessed Memory, primo of Her Reign, and you bought it of an old Broker at Nottingham; and as I am a true Christian woman, if our Neigh∣bore Botcher could almost few it on, it was so mortified.
I bought you shoes, and ribbons to tie them withal.
Look Gentlefolks, a pair of wet-leather shoes, that have given me a Cold, and two leather points that he calls ribbons, like a lying false man.
I am sure I bought you stockings and garters.
Old Doncaster-stockins, that I was sain to wash my self with a little borrowed soap, and they were footed with yellow fustion too, and the garters he talks of were lists of cloth, which a Taylor gave me for my New-years-gift, and I cannot choose but grieve to see his unkindness; I gave you satisfaction often, but you never satisfied me, I will take it upon my death.
Go Gill Flirt, pack away hence.
Nay that puts me in mind of the Peddlers pack you pro∣missed me, and I never had so much bought as that I might whissle for them; but I will follow thee to Hell, but I will have something more out of thee than I have had, or else I will make all the Town ring of me.
Here Beadles, take her to the Correction-house, Bridewell, and let her be punished.
Is it so, thou miscreant? well, I thought to be thy Bride, and not Bridewell, I never thought it in my conscience.
Pray stay.
Mall, although you deceived me, and broke your promise, you I will not only save you from the punishment you were to suffer at the Cor∣rection-house, but I will give thee a Husband here, lusty Thom. Purveyor, to whom, for taking thee to Wife, I will give him a lease of fifty pounds a year. Here Tom, take her and go marry her.
Heaven bless your Honour.
Come Mall, let us go Wed, for fifty pounds a year is better than thy Maiden-head.

I would my Parents had kept me up as birds in dark∣nos, when they are taught to sing Artificial Tunes, that my ears only might have been employed; and as those Teachers whistle to birds several times, so would I have had Tutors to have read to me several Authors, as the best Poets, the best Historians, the best Philosophers, Moral and Natural, the best Grammarians, Arithme∣ticians, Mathematicians, Logicians, and the like. Thus perchance I might have spoke as eloquently upon every subject, as Birds sing sweetly several tunes; but since my Education hath been so negligent, I wish I might do some no∣ble Action, such as might raise a monumental Fame on the dead Ashes of my Fore-fathers, that my Name might live everlastingly.
I hate to be compared to an inferior, or to have an inferior compared to me: wherefore if I were Jove, I would damn that creature that should compare me to any thing less than my self.
Your Ladyship is like a Goddess, above all comparison: where∣fore I think there is none worthy to match in Marriage with you, unless there were some Masculine Divine Creature on Earth to equal you, as surely there is none.
I shall not willingly marry, unless it were to have a command o∣ver my Husband.
But Husbands, Madam, command Wives.
Not those that are Divine Creatures.
Husbands, Madam, are Reprobates, and regard not Divinity, nor worship Earthly Deities.
Whilst they are Suitors, they worship, and women command their wooing servants.
The truth is, all Suitors do worship with an Idolatrous zeal, but their zeals tire at length, as most zeals do, and men are content to be com∣manded, whilst they are Courting servants, and do obey with an industry∣os
care, and with an humble and respectful Demeanour, a submissive and awful Countenance, with an admiring and listening Ear, pleasing and ap∣placing Speech, insomuch as their Mistress might think they commanded not only their Senses, but also their Souls; yet after they are married, they be∣come from being servants, to be Masters, and they are so far from obeying, as they command, and instead of an humble and respectful demeanour, and an awful countenance, they will be haughty and surly, and their faces will be clothed in frowns, and instead of an admiring eye and a listening ear, they will neither regard nor take notice of their Wives, unless it be to throw a scornful glance, and instead of a pleasing and applausing speech, they will reprove, discommend, or threaten. Thus, although they serve as Slaves when they are wooing Suitors, yet they rule as Tyrants when they are Husbands, as all Slaves do that come to rule, prove Tyrants, like as the most fierce zealous Supplicants oft-times prove Atheists, or Reprobates.
Then I must never marry; for I cannot endure to be command∣ed, but must be admired and adored.
It is fit you should, being a Divine Creature, Madam.
Women that love the Courtship of men, must change themselves into as many several humours as Protheus shapes; as sometimes gay and merry, sometimes grave and majestic, sometimes me∣lancholy, sometimes bashful and coy, sometimes free and confident, some∣times patient, and sometimes choleric, sometimes silent, and sometimes dis∣cursive, according as they find those humours they meet with.
Let me tell you, Wanton, they must love Courtship well, that will take such pains to transform themselves so often, to please, or rather to get Lovers.
You say well, Ease, but they rather lose than gain by the bar∣gain; for the charge of troublesome observance, is more than the profit they receive therefrom.
Truly, Mistress Temperance, there is no delight in pains-taking, ask my Lady Pleasure.
No truly Ease; but a sweet civility, a modest behaviour and countenance, and a pleasing speech, gains more Lovers than a metamor∣phos'd humour.
In truth a well-temper'd humour is easy to themselves, and delightful to others.
You speak for Lovers, but there is a difference betwixt Court∣ship and Love; for dull Love is contented to be entertained only with plain truth, and is constant to an honest heart, but sprightly Courtship delights in extravagances, lives in varieties, but dies in particulars or singularities.
True delight lives in true love.
And true Love lives in Temperance.
And Temperance lives in Ease.
And Ease lives in Idleness.
And Idleness lives in Wantonness, and Wantonness lives in Pleasure.
Let me tell you, Wanton, that Pleasure doth not live in Wan∣tonnes nor Idleness; for Pleasure lives in Peace, maintained by Plenty, instructed by Prudence, protected by Justice, and governed by Grave Tempe∣rance here.
All the Ladies in the City are in love with me, and that woman thinks her self happy that can receive a Courtship from me; but I mean to marry none but Mademoiselle Ambition, nor would I marry her but for my particular ends, for she is rich.
She is so, if they be rich that have vast desires. But are you sure you shall have her?
Yes, for her Friends and I am agreed, and I know she can∣not deny me; for what woman would not be proud to marry me?
It is said she is a Noble Lady.
Faith she will be but a trouble to me; but I will only keep her for breed, and entertain myself, and lead my life with Mademoiselle Pleasure, and she shall share of the riches that Mademoiselle Ambition brings.
Now you talk of riches Sir, what shall we do with the rich Ca∣binet you bought? must that be carried to Mademoiselle Pleasure?
Yes, but I have other presents to send along with it, which I will give order for.
Live under these laws? I will sooner live under the Turks.
What makes thee such an enemy to these laws, Monsieur Sensuality?
Why Monsieur Censure, I am fined a hundred pounds for kiss∣sing a Mistress, and getting a child.
Indeed the Turks government is the only government for such men as would have many Wives, Concubines, and Slaves.
Why, he is a slave that lives not under such government; for what greater slavery is there than to be tied to one woman? I am sure our Fore-fathers, who were godly men, were not tied to such slavery; they had
their liberty as the Turks, and such like wise governments, a to have as ma∣ny Wives and Mistresses as they please, or at least as many as they can maintain.
Although you may think that government wise, because it fits your Appetite, yet well-tempred men, it is likely, will be of another opine∣on, as to think the strict Canon-Laws of Europe are better for the good of Commonwealths, and every particular Family, by restraining one man to one woman, than to let them have more, or as many as they will.
If well-temperd men be of that opinion, they are fools, which I will soon prove them to be. As first for the Common-wealth, there is no∣thing more disadvantageous; for those Commonwealths flourish with great∣est glory, that are fullest populated, by reason populated Kingdoms are strongest, both for their own defence, and against Foreign Enemies, as being able to conquer others by Invasions, enlarging their Dominions with their numbers, increasing their numbers with their numerous issues, begot and born from their many Wives, Concubines, and Slaves: when by our niggardly laws Kingdoms become uninhabited and barren for want of men to till and manure the ground: And as for our Wars, they'd seem as private Chal∣lenges, and our Armies as particular Duellers, being met with their Se∣conds to decide their petty quarrels, and to show their valour by the ha∣zard of their lives, and our Battles seem slight Skirmishes, or like a Company or Rout that kill each other in an idle Fruy. Thus in comparison of other Em∣peers, all Europe is but as one Kingdom, for numbers of men, and Martial Forces, when by the Extent it may be accounted the fourth part of the known World. And as for particular Families, want of children breeds discontent, and not only destroys industry, but makes spoil and unthrifts; for those that have no children, they care not what becomes of their goods, lands, or livings, spending them through cluelesness, or through riot: And as for Women, it spoils them from being good wives; for being sole Mi∣stresses, having no Co-partners, nor Shares, neither of their Husbands, i will∣drone, or estates, and being the only She that is served or attended, embraced, loved, or maintained, grows proud, imperious, insults and domineers, and disputes with her Husband for pre-eminence, and the truth is, for the most part, obtains it. Thus men become slaves to the distaff for quietness sake, o∣therwise there is such quarrels and brawleries, that his house and home, that should be his Couch of Ease, his Bed of Rest, his peaceable Haven, or haven of Peace, is for the most part his couch of thorns, his bed of cares, his hell of torments, or tormenting hell, and his whole Family are like a tempestuous Sea, where Passions hurl into Factions, and rise in waves of discontent: But when men have an absolute power over their wives, they force them into quiet obedience; and where men have many Wives, Con∣cubines, and Slaves, the women are humbled into a submission, each woman striving which should be most serviceable, and who can get most love and favour; and as for Bastards, they are as much the Fathers children, as those that are got in Wedlock.
But it is likely that Concubines and slaves will be false, and fa∣there their children on those that never begot them.
Why so may Wives, and it is most probable they do so; but as other Nations do allow many Wives, Concubines, and slaves, so they give men power and rule to govern and restrain them; and the men are so wise in other Nations, as they suffer no other men but themselves to come
near them, hardly to look at the outside of their Seraglio's, as that part of the house they are lodged in.
Thou hast spoke so well, and hast made so learned a Speech for many Wives, Concubines, and slaves, as I am converted, and will, if thou wilt, travel into such Kingdoms as allow such numbers and varieties, that I may be naturalised to their liberties.
What is the reason, Monsieur Satirical, you do not marry?
The reason, Monsieur Inquisitive, is, that I cannot find a wife fit for me.
Why, there are women of all Ages, Births, Humours, Sty∣tures, Shapes, Complexions, Features, Behaviours, and Wits. But what think you of marrying the Lady Nobilissimo?
She is a Lady that out-reaches my Ambition.
What think you of the Lady Bellissimo?
She is a Lady for Admiration, and not for use.
What think you of marrying the Lady Piety?
She is a Lady to be prayed unto as a Saint, not to be embraced as wife.
What think you of the Lady Modesty?
She is a Lady that will not only quench amorous love, but the free matrimonial love.
What do you think of the Lady Sage?
She is a Lady to rule as a Husband, and not to be ruled as a Wife.
What think you of the Lady Politic?
She is a Lady fitter for Counsel than for Marriage.
What say you to the Lady Ceremony?
She is a Lady fitter for a Princely Throne, than the Mari∣age-bed.
What say you to the Lady Poetical?
She is a Lady fitter for Contemplation than Fruition.
What say you to the Lady Humility?
She is a Lady sooner won than enjoyed.
What say you to the Lady Sprightly?
She is a Lady that will disquiet my rest, being fitter for dancing than sleeping.
What say to the Lady Prodigal?
She is a Lady I might feast with, but could not thrive with.
What say you to the Lady Vanity?
She is a Lady too various and extravagant for my humour.
What say you to the Lady Victoria?
She is a Lady I had rather hear of, than be enslaved by.
What say you to the Lady Innocent Youth?
She is a Lady that may please with embracing, but not with con∣versing; she is fitter for love than for company, for Cupped than for Pallas, for sport than for counsel.
What say you to the Lady Wanton?
She is fitter for an hour than for an Age.
What say you to the Lady Poverty?
She is fitter for my Charity than my Family.
What say you to the Lady Ill-favoured?
She is a Lady fitter for a Nunnery than a Nursery; for Beads, than for Children.
What say you to the Lady Weakly?
She is fitter for Death than for Life; for Heaven, than the World.
By your Answers I perceive you will not Marry.
Have I not reason, when I can find such Answers from the Sex?
But the Gods have commanded Marriage?
But Saints doe choose a single life, and in case of Marriage, I will sooner follow the Example of the Saints, than the commands of the Gods.
Ladies, what think you of good Husbands?
I think well of good Husbands.
But it is a question whether good Husbands will think well of us.
I think good Husbands may be in our thoughts, but not actually in the World.
I am of your opinion, they may be mentioned in our words, but not found in our lives.
Faith we may hear of good husbands, and read of good wives, but they are but Romances.
You say right; for we may as soon find an Heroic Lover, and see all his impossible Actions out of a Romance Book, as a good Hus∣bands; but as for Wives, I will not declare my Opinion.
Nor I; but were there such men that would make good hus∣bands, it were as difficult to get them, as for a Romantic Lover to get his Mistress out of an Enchanted Castle.
For my part I had rather die a Maid, than take the pains to get a good Husband.
I wonder our Sex should desire to Marry; for when we are un∣married, we are sued and sought to, and not only Mistress of our selves, but our Suitors: But when we are married, we are so far from being Mistresses, as we become slaves.
The truth is, there is no Act shows us, or rather proves us to be so much fools as we are, as in marrying: for what greater folly can there be, than to put our selves to that condition which will sorce us to sue to pow∣er, when before that voluntary slavery we were in a condition to use power, and make men sue to us.
We must confess, when we well consider, it is very strange, since every Creature naturally desires and strives for pre-eminence, as to be supe∣riour, and not inferior; for all Creatures endeavour to command, and are unwilling to obey; for it is not only Man, but even the Beasts of the Field, the Birds of the Air, and the Fishes in the Sea; and not only Beasts, Birds, and Fish, but the Elements those creatures inhabit in, strive for superiori∣tie; only Women, who seem to have the meanest souls of all the Creatures Nature hath made; for women are so far from endeavouring to get power, as they voluntarily give away what they have.
Talk not of women's souls, for men say we have no souls, only beautiful bodies.
But beautiful bodies are a degree of souls, and in my Con∣science please men better than our souls could do.
If anything prove we have no souls, it is in letting men make such fools of us.
Come, come Ladies, by Women's Actions they prove to have more, or at least better souls than Men have, for the best parts of the Soul are Love and Generosity, and Women have more of either than Men have.
The truth is, that although Reason and Understand∣ing are the largest parts of the Soul, yet Love and Generosity are the delica∣test parts of the Soul.
Goodmorrow young Ladies, you appear this morning like sweet-smelling flowers, some as Roses, others as Lilies, others as Violets, Pinks, and Primroses, and your associating in a company together, is like as a Posy which Love hath bound up into one Bucket, which is a sit Present for the Gods.
If you would have us presented to the Gods, we must die; for we are never preferred to them but by Death: wherefore we must be go∣ven to Death, before the Gods can have us; they may hear us whilst we live, and we may hear of them, but partake of neither until we die.
O that were pity, Ladies; for there is nothing more sad in Na∣ture, than when Death parts a witty Soul from a young beautiful Body, be∣fore the one hath built Monuments of Memory, and the other gained Trow∣phies of Lovers: And as for the Gods, you will be as acceptable to them when you are old, as when you are young.
As nothing could make me so sad as untimely death of Youth, Wit, and Beauty, so there is nothing could anger me more, as for Fortune to frown upon Merit, or not to advance it according to its worth, or to bury it in Oblivion, hindering the passage into Fems Palace.
For my part, I believe Death will neither call nor come for you before his natural time, if you do not send Surfeit and Excess to call him to take you away.
Indeed Mankind seem as if they were Deaths Factors; for they
do strive to engross and destroy all other creatures, or at least as many as they can; and not only other creatures, but their own kind, as in Wars; and not only their own kind, but themselves, in idle and unprofitable Adven∣tures, and gluttonous Excess, thus as I said, they are Deaths Factors, buying sickness with health, hoping to gain pleasure, and to make delight their pro∣fit, but they are cozened, for they only get Diseases, Pains, and Aches.
Pray Ladies mark how far you are gone from the Text of your discourse, as from sweet-smelling flowers to stinking carrion, which are dead carcasses; from a lively good-morrow, to a dead farewell; from mirth to sadness.
You say right, Mother Matron; wherefore pray leave off this dis∣course, for I hate to hear off death; for the thoughts of death affright me so, as I can take no pleasure of life when he is in my mind.
Why Ladies, the thought of death is more than death himself; for thoughts are sensible or imaginable things, but Death himself is neither sensible nor imaginable.
Therefore I would not think of him; and when I am dead, I am past thinking.
Let us discourse of something that is more pleasing than Death.
Then by my consent, Ladies, your discourse shall be of Venus and Cupped, which are Themes more delightful to your Sex, and most country∣rye to death; for Love is hot, and Death is cold; Love illuminates life, and Death quenches life out.
Let me tell you Sir, Love is as apt to burn life out, as Death is to quench it out, and I had rather die with cold, than be burnt with heat; for cold kills with a dead numness, when heat kills with a raging mad∣ness.
But Lovers are tormented with fears and doubts, which cause cold sweats, fainting of spirits, trembling of limbs; it breaks the sweet re∣pose of sleep, disturbs the quiet peace of the mind, vades the colours of beau∣tie, nips or •lasts the blossom of youth, making Lovers look withered, be∣fore Time hath made them old.
It is a sign, Lady, you have been in love, you give so right a Character of a Lover.
No, there requires not a self-experience to find out a Lovers trouble, for the outward Actions will declare their inward grief and pas∣zion.
Certainly she is in love, but conceals it, she keeps it as a Secret.
Love cannot be secret, the passion divulges it self.
Confess, Are you not in love?
Nay she will never confess a Secret, unless you tell her one; for those that tell no secrets, shall hear none.
O yes, for a Secret is like a child in the womb; for though it be concealed for a time, it will come out at last, only some comes out easier than others, and some before their time.
Nay whenever a secret comes out, it's untimely.
Secrets are like Coy Ducks, when one is flown out, it draws out others, and returns with many.
Then like a Coy Duck I will try if I can draw all you after me.
She shall see she is like a Duck, which is like a Goose, and we like her, for we will follow her.
Have you been at Monsieur Busie's house, to tell him I desire to speak with him?
Yes, I have been at his house.
And will he come?
Faith Sir the house is too unwieldy to stir, and Monsieur Busy is too Active to stay at home: but the truth is, I went at four a clock this more∣ning, because I would be sure to find him and his servants, and their Master was flown out of his nest an hour before: Then I told his servants I would come about dinner-time, and they laughed, and asked me what time was that? I said I supposed at the usual time, about Noon, or an hour before or after, but they said their Master never kept any certain time of eating, be∣ing full of business. Then I asked them what time that would be when he would come home to bed: They answered, that his time of Resting was as uncertain as his time of Eating. Then I prayed them to tell me at what time they thought I might find him at home: They said it was impossible for them to guess, for that their Master did move from place to place, as swift as thoughts move in the Mind. Then I prayed them that they would tell him when he came home, that you would desire to speak with him: They told me they would, but they did verily believe he would forget to come to you, by reason his head was so full of busy thoughts, or thoughts of business, as there was no room more for a thought to stay in. So I went away in despair, but coming home, I chanced to see him at a little distance, so I made all the haste I could to overtake him, placing my Eyes fixedly upon him, because I would not lose him; but his pace was so swift, and his several turnings in se∣viral Lanes and Allies were so many, as it was impossible for me to keep my measure, pace, or sight, for like a Bird, he did not only fly out of my reach, but out of my view; but by a second good fortune, I met him just at your Gate, and I stopped his way until I had told him your Message, which was, you would speak with him: He answered me, he could not possibly stay, for his business called him another way. I told him, that if he did not come and speak with you, or stay until you did come and speak with him, his Law-sute, which was of great Importance, would be lost, for you could not do him any further service to your Friends, that should help him, until he had resolved you of some questions you were to ask him; besides that, you wanted a Writing that he had. He told me that he was very much obliged to you for your favour to him, but he could not possibly stay to speak with you, for he had some business to do for two or three other men, and he must of necessity go seek those men out whom the business concerned; so that I could not persuade him by any means, although for his own good, to come in, or to stay till you went to him.
Faith he is so busy, that he will neither do himself good
nor any other man; for he runs himself out of the Field of Business, being over-busy, neither holding the Reins of Time, nor sitting steady in the Seat of Judgment, nor stopping with the Bit of Discretion, nor taking the Advan∣tages of Opportunity; but totters with Inconstancy, and falls with Loss. Thus his busy thoughts do tire his Mind, so that his life hath a sorry, sore, and weary Journey.
I think he is a man that is full of Projects.
So full, as his head is stuffed with them, and he begins many designs, but never finishes any one of them; for his designs are built upon vain hopes, without a Foundation: But were his hopes solid with pro∣bability, yet his inconstancy, and unsteady doubts, and over-cautious care, would pull down, or ruin his designs before they were half built.
Monsieur Sensuality, let us examine you, What company have you met withal, that hath caused you to break your Word with us, when you had promised you would come, and carry us to a Play?
If he carry us all, he will carry a very heavy load.
Ladies should be heavy, and not light.
But Monsieur Sensuality, pray tell us where you have been, and with whom.
Why I have been with as proper a Lady as any is in this City.
What do you mean by a proper Lady?
He means a propped Lady.
I mean a Tall, Proportionable Lady, which is a comely sight.
Not to my Eyes; for I never see a tall big woman, but I think she rather proceeds from the race of Titan than Jove, for she seems to be more Body than Soul, more Earth than Flame.
For my part, I think there cannot be too much of a fair La∣die; and if I were to choose, I would choose her that had more body than soul, for her soul would be useless to me, by reason souls cannot be enjoyed as bodies are.
Yes, in a spiritual conversation they may.
I hate an incorporeal Conversation.
Why then you hate the Conversation of the Gods.
I love the Conversation and Society of fair young Ladies, such as you are.
That is not the Answer to my question.
Then let me tell you, Ladies, that most of our Sex do venture Heaven for your sakes, and will sooner disobey the Gods than you.
So you make as if Women commanded Men against the Gods.
No Lady, but we serve Women, when we should serve the Gods, and pray to your Sex, when the Gods would have us pray to them.
The more wicked creatures are men.
No, the more tempting creatures are women.
So you will make us Devils at last; for the original of temptation came from Pluto.
Temptation, Lady, was bred in Nature, born from Nature, and inhabits with all your Sex, as with Natures self, whom I have heard is a most beautiful Lady, and that is the reason, I suppose, she hath favoured women more than men, being her self of the Effeminate Sex: And the truth is, Nature hath been cruel to our Sex; for she hath not only made you so beautiful, as to be admired and desired, but so cruel, as to despise, reject and scorn us, taking pleasure in our torments.
If all Women were of my mind, we would torment you more than we do.
We have tormented him enough with talking, therefore let us leave him.
Nay Ladies, I will wait upon you.
Monsieur Satirical, I can tell you sad News.
Let sadness sit upon the grave of Death, for I defy it.
But that man is in danger that stands as a Centre in a Circumference from whence all the malignant passions shoot at him, as Suspicion, Spite, Envy, Hatred, Malice, and Revenge; and the more dangerous, by reason their Arrows are poisoned with Effeminate Rage.
Let them shoot, for I am armed with Carelessness, and have a Spell of Confidence, which will keep me safe. But who are they that are mine Enemies?
No less than a dozen Ladies.
If I can attain to fight with them apart, hand to hand, I make no question but to come off Conqueror; and if they assault me altogether, yet I make no doubt but I shall so skirmish amongst them, as I shall be on e∣qual terms. But what makes the breach of peace betwixt me and the La∣dies, and such a breach as to proclaim Open Wars?
The Cause is just, if it be true as it is reported.
Why what is reported?
It is reported you have divulged some secret favours those Ladies have given you.
It were ungrateful to conceal a favour: for favours proceed from generous and noble Souls, sweet and kind Natures.
But Ladies favours are to be concealed and locked up in the Closet of secrecy, being given with privacy, and promise not to divulge them; and it seems by report you have broke your promise, for which they swear to be revenged.
Faith all Women, especially Ladies, their natural humour is like the Sea, which will be neither quiet it self, always ebbing and flowing, nor let any thing be at rest on it: I know not what the Fishes are that are in it, but for any thing I can perceive to the contrary, they live in a perpetual motion: So doe Ladies; for their Passions and Affections ebb and flow from object to object; for one while they flow with love, then ebb with hate, sometimes they are rough with anger, and stormy with rage, then indifferent calm with patience, but that is seldom: But in the Spring-tide of Beauty they overflow all with pride, and their thoughts, like Fishes, are in a perpe∣tual motion, swimming from place to place, from company to company, from one meeting to another, and are never at rest.
Thou deserve to die the death of Orpheus.
It is likely I shall, by reason I am a Satirical Poet, and Women hate Satire in Poetry, although not Wood or Forest Satyrs; and the most extravagant and maddest Actions that ever were done, were done or acted by Women, and the truth is, Women are not only Batchelling some parts of the year, but all their life-long, for they drink vanity, and are mad-drunk with wantonness.
Let me tell you, that if I should be brought as a Witness, and should declare the truth, there were no hopes of mercy for thee.
I grant it, if Women were to be my Judges.
Where shall we go for pastime to day? for our Lady hath left us to our own: pleasures to day.
Let us go and swim in a Boat upon the River.
That is but a waterish Recreation; besides it is very dangerous, for many have been drowned in their idle pastimes.
If you will take my Counsel, let us go to the Lodge in the Park, and drink Sullybubs.
Yes, let us go, for the Lodge puts me into a good humour, and Sullybubs make me merry.
You have reason, for it is a cheerly Cup, and a Cup of good fellow∣ship, for we may all eat and drink together.
Yes by spoonfuls.
I love to be drunk by spoonfuls, for then I am drunk by degrees, and not at one draught, as a pint, or a quart at a draught, as men do; be∣sides, though it be allowable for the sobrest noblest Women to be drunk with Wine-caudles, Sullybubs, Sack-possets, and the like, so it be by spoon∣fuls, yet it were abominable and most dishonourable for Women to be
drunk with plain Wine, and great draught, as men are; besides, in great draughts there is not that pleasure of taste, as in a little at a time.
I believe that is the reason that Flemmings love to sip their Wine, be∣cause they would have the pleasure of Taste.
No question but they learned that of the Effeminate Sex, who love to taste of every thing.
I do believe it; for all women love spoon-meat.
It is true, and to drink in spoons.
Talk no more of eating and drinking, but eat and drink without talk∣ing, and afterwards talk to digest it.
And after it is digested, let's eat and drink again.
So we shall do nothing but eat, drink, and talk.
Women do nothing else all their life-long.
By your favour but we do.
Come, come, let us go.
O that I might enjoy those pleasures which Poets fancy, living in such delight as nature never knew; nor that all Poets did write of me, not only to express their Wit, but my Worth, and that I might be praised by all mankind, yet not vulgarly, as in a crowd of others praises, but my praises to be singularly enthroned above the rest, and that all others commendations might have no other light but what proceeds from the splendour of my Fame: Also I wish that Nature had made me such a Beauty, as might have drawn the Eyes of the whole World as a Loadstone to gaze at it, and the splendour thereof might have enlightened every blind eye, and the beams therefrom might have comforted every sad heart, and the pleasing Aspect therein might have turned all passions into love; then would I have had Nature, For∣tune, and the Fates, to have given me a free power of the whole World, and all that is therein, that I might have pressed and squeezed our the healing Bal∣somes, and sovereign Juices, and restoring Simples into every sick wounded and decayed body, and every disquieted or distempered mind: Likewise, that I might have been able to have relieved those that were poor and necessitous, with the hidden riches therein, and that by my power I might not only have obliged every particular creature and person, according to their worth and merit, but to have made so firm a peace amongst mankind, as never to be dissolved.
I wonder you should be an Enemy to Women.
I am so far from being an Enemy to the Effeminate Sex, as I am the best friend they have: for I do as a friend ought to do, which is, to tell them truth, when other men deceive them with flattery.
But they complain, and say you exclame and rail against them.
Their complaints proceed from their partial Self-love and Lu∣xury: for they love pleasing flattery, as they do Sweet-meats, and hate rigid truth, as they do a bitter potion, although the one destroys their health, the other prolongs their life.
But they are so angry, as they all swear, and have made a vow to be revenged on you.
Let them throw their spleens at me, I will stand their malice, or dart forth Amorous glances, they will not pierce my heart: for Pallas is my Shield, and Cupped hath no power.
If they cannot wound you with their Eyes, they will sting you with their Tongues, for Women are like Bees.
If they are like Bees, their stings lie not in their Tongues.
I can tell you News, Ladies.
What News, Mother Matron?
Why there is a rich young Heir come to Town.
Some foolish Son of a miserable Father, who hath spared from his back and belly, to make his Son vain and prodigal. But what shall we be the better for this rich Heir?
Why marry if you can get him, you will be so much the better as a rich Husband can make you.
He will first be got by the Cheats in the Town, which Cheats have more subtlety, and will be more industrious to get him, than the young∣est and beautifulest, and wittiest Lady of us all; so as there is no hopes of gaining him, until he is so poor, as he is not worth the having.
But if he could be had whilst he were rich, it were no great vi∣ctory; for I dare say his Mothers Landry-maid might be as soon a Conque∣ress, as a great Lady: But if we could conquer and imprison Monsieur Sa∣tyrical in Loves Fetters, that would be a Conquest worthy Fems Trum∣pet.
O that would be such an Exploit, as it would be an Honour to our Sex.
There is nothing I desire more, than to be she that might in∣fetter him.
I long to ensnare him.
So do I.
Faith I will lay an Ambuscado for him.
Fie Ladies, sie, I am ashamed to hear the Designs you have no catch Monsieur Satirical; such Fair, Young, Noble Ladies to be so wan∣ton, as none will content you but a wilde, rough, rude Satyr.
If I were sure there were no other ways to get him, I would become a Wood-nymph for his sake.
You have forgot the Nymph that was turned into a Bear.
O she was one of cruel Diana's Nymphs; but I will be none of her Order.
No, I dare swear you will not; for it is unlikely you should, when you desire to embrace a Satyr.
I do not desire to embrace him, but to enamour him.
Well, Ladies, your Parents gave you to my Care and Charge; but since you are so wilde, to talk of nothing but Nymphs, Woods, and Sa∣tiers, I will resign up the Trust which was imposed on me, to your Pa∣rents again; for I will not adventure my Reputation with such wanton young Ladies.
Mother Matron, let me tell thee, thy Reputation is worn out of thee, Time hath devoured it, and therefore thou hast no Reputation to lose.
Fath Tom. I have emptied thy pockets.
Thou hast picked my pockets with thy juggling Dice, for which, if thou were a woman, and in my power, I would be revenged for my loss.
Why, what would you do if I were a Woman?
I would condemn thee to a solitary silent life, which to a woman is worse than Hell; for company and talking is their Heaven, and their Tongues are more restless than the Sea, their Passions more stormy than the Winds, and their Appetites more unsatiable and devouring than fire; they are lighter than Air, more changing than the Moon.
What makes thee thus rail at the Effeminate Sex?
Have I not reason, when Fortune is of the same gender?
Faith Tom, I must tell.
What will you tell?
Why I will tell you, Lady, he hath railed most horribly against your Sex.
That is usual: for all those men which never received, nor hope to receive any favour from our Sex, will rail against it.
Those men have no reason, Lady, to commend you, if they no∣ver received neither profit nor pleasure from you; and those that have been cruelly used by your Sex, may lawfully rail against it.
The Laws of Honour forbid it.
But the Laws of Nature allow it, and Nature is the most pre∣veiling law.
Natures law is for Men to love Women, and Women Men, but in you and I there is not that Sympathy; for I dislike your Sex, as much as you do ours, and could rail with as free a will against it. The truth is, that although I do not hate men, yet I despise them; for all men appear to me either Beasts or Butter-flies, which are either sensual or vain: Indeed most men are worse than beasts; for beasts are but according to their kind, when men are degenerated by beastly Sensualies, from which they were made; for as most men are worse than beasts, so you are worse than most men.
It is a favour, Lady, from your Sex, to rail against ours; for it is a sign you have considered us, and that we live in your memory, although with your ill opinions; yet it is better to live with Enemies, than not to be; and of all men, I have received the greatest favour from the chiefest of your Sex, which is your self, in that you have considered me most, though you have found me worst, yet it proves you have thought of me.
If those thoughts and dispraises be favours, I will bind so many together, until they become as thick and hard as steel, of which you may make an Armour, to keep your Reputation from wounds of reproach.
There Tom. she hath paid thee both for thy Railings and Com∣plements.
She hath not paid me in current coin.
It will pass for disgrace, I'll warrant thee.
There are but three things a gallant man requires, which is, a Horse, a Sword, and a Mistress.
Yet a gallant man wants Generosity; for the greatest honour for a man, is to be generous; for Generosity comprises all Virtues, good Qualities, and sweet Graces; for a generous man will never spare his life, purse, nor labour, for the sake of just Right, plain Truth, Honest Poverty, Distress, Misery, or the like; for a generous man hath a courageous, yet compassionate Heart, a constant and noble Mind, a bountiful Hand, an active and industrious Life; and he is one that joys more to do good, than others to receive good.
There are few or none that have such noble Souls, as to prefer a∣nothers good before their own.
The truth is, men have more promising Tongues, than perform∣ing deeds.
For all I can perceive, mans life is composed of nothing but de∣ceit, treachery, and rapine.
Indeed mans mind is like a Forest, and his thoughts, like wilde beasts, inhabit therein.
Mans Mind is like a Sea, where his Thoughts, like Fishes, swim therein, where some Thought are like huge Leviathans, others like great Whales, but some are like Sprats, Shrimps, and Minus.
What is like a Minus?
A mans Soul.
It is better have a soul, although no bigger than a Minus, than none at all, as Women have; but if they have, I dare swear it is no bigger than a pins point.
Very like, which point pricks down thoughts into the Brain, and Passions in the heart, and writes in the Brain witty Conceits, if the point be sharp.
No, no, it serves only to raise their brains with Vanity, to engrave their hearts with Falsehood, and to scratch out their lives with Dis∣content.
We oftner scratch out men's lives than our own.
Nay, you oftner scratch out our honour than our lives.
For my part, I have an itch to be scratching.
I believe you, for you have a vexatious soul.
It hath cause to be vexatious, for the point of my soul is whetted with Aqua Fortis against your Sex.
I'm sure, Lady, your tongue is whetted with Aqua Fortis.
So is yours.
If it be, let us try which point is sharpest.
I will leave the Trial to Time and Occasion.
Madam, I am an humble Suitor to your Ladyship.
What is your suit?
That you will be pleased to take a young Maiden into your ser∣vice of my preferring.
In what place?
To wait and attend on your person.
Let me tell you, that those servants that attend on my person, do usually accompany me in all my Pastimes, Exercises, and sometimes in Con∣versation:
Wherefore they must be such as are well born, well bred, well behaved, modest, and of sweet dispositions, virtuous, and of strict life, other∣wise they are not for me; and if I find them not so, I shall soon turn them away.
Why Madam, even Diana her self, as severe and strict as she was, had some wanton Nymphs, that would commit errors; although they seem∣ed all sober and modest, and professed chastity, yet they would slip out of the way and her presence sometimes.
But she never failed to turn them out of her service, and some she cruelly punished; so that what her severity could not prevent, yet her severity did punish; for Diana's practice was not to watch her wanton Nymphs, nor to hunt out their evil haunts, or lurking-places, to see their evil actions, but her practice was to hunt the more modest and temperate creatures, which were the beasts of the Fields and Forests: So, like as Diana, I shall not watch my Maids, nor pardon their rude or dishonourable actions.
Pray Madam try this Maid, for she is very honourably born, and well bred, but poor.
I shall not refuse her for poverty: But as I will have some bound for the truth and trust of my vulgar servants, so I will have some bound for the behaviour, virtue, and modesty of my honourable servants, or else I will not take them.
Monsieur Frisk, you are well met, for I was even now sending a Footman for you.
For what, good Mother Matron?
Marry to come to a company of young Ladies, who do half long for you.
They shall not lose their longing, if I can help them.
Now by my Troth, and that is spoke like a Gentleman; but let me tell you, there is a great many of them.
Why then there is the more choice.
But there is no choosing amongst Ladies, you must take better for worse.
There is no worst amongst Ladies, they are all fair and good.
In faith I perceive now why the Ladies desire your company so much as they do.
Why my dear Mother Matron?
Because you speak well of them behind their backs, and pro∣mise them much to their faces; and I will assure you, they have as pro∣mising
faces as you can promise them; but great Promisers are not good.
Will you say the Ladies faces are not good?
I say men's promises are not good. But you are very quick with me, Monsieur Frisk, to take me upon the hip so suddenly; but, beshrew me, your sudden frisking Answer hath put me into a Passion, which hath percur∣bed the sense of my Discourse. Lord, Lord, what power a villainous word hath over the passions!
If you please, Mother Matron, a kiss shall ask pardon for your vile∣lanous word.
And now, by my troth, I have not been kissed by a young Gentle∣man above this twenty years; but now I am in haste, and cannot stay to re∣ceive your gift, wherefore I will refer it until another time.
But I may forget to give it.
Never fear that, for I shall remember you of it, when time shall serve: But come away, for the Ladies will be horrible angry I have stayed so long, for they were all going to dance, for the Fiddles were tuned, Tables and Stools removed, room made, and they in a dancing posture, only they stay for you to Frisk them about.
Madam, you behaved your self more familiar to day, than your Ladyship was wont to do.
It is true, because those I conversed with to day were but inferior persons, and I speak more familiar to such persons as are below my quality, than those that are equal to me, to do them grace and favour; and if they take it not so, I can only say my Civility was ignorantly placed on foolish and ignorant persons.
Some say Poems are not good, unless they be gloriously At∣tired.
What do they mean by glorious Attire?
Rhetoric.
Why gay words are not Wit, no more than a fair Face is a good Soul; and it is Wit which makes Poems good, not words.
Indeed Rhetoric is no part of the Body of Wit, no more than of the Soul, only it is the outward garment, which is Taylors work.
Then it seems, as if the Grammarians, Logicians, and The∣toricians, are the Taylors for Oratory, who cut shapes, sit places, seam and
few words together to make several Eloquent Garments, or Garments of E∣loquence, as Orations, Declarations, Expressions, and the like worditive work, as they please, or at least according to the fashion.
They are so.
Why then those that say Verse is not good, unless gloriously At∣tired, do as much as to say a man is a fool that hath not a fine Suit of Clothes on, or, that a Curled Hair, sweetly powdered, is a wise, or witty Brain, powdered with Fancies. This surely is an unpardonable mistake, or rather an incurable madness, for there is neither Sense nor Reason in it.
It is not so much a madness, nor that we call Natural Fools, but Amorous Fools, or Finical Fools, or such as are Opinionated Fools, or Self-conceited Fools, or High-bound Fools.
High-bound Fools? What doe you mean by High-bound Fools?
Strong-lin'd Fools.
Those are Learned Fools.
No, they are Conceited Fools; for their strength of Wit lies in a Conceit.
Those, for the most part, their Wit is buried in Oblivion.
If there be any Wit to bury.
Who is so foolish to bury Wit?
You, in the rubbish of words.
The only Grave to Wit is a foolish Ear.
Let me tell you, Ladies, that Wit is so far from lying in a Grave, as it hardly settles any where; for it is so Agile, and flies so swiftly, and yet extends in breadth so far, as it spreads the wings of Fancy, not only over all the World, and every particular thing in the World, but one In∣finite and Eternal Nature, and with the Bill of Conception picks a hole, whereby the Eyes of Imagination spy out the dark Dungeons of Pluto, and the glorious Mansions of Jove.
Then Poems need not the garments of Rhetoric.
No more than a Fair Lady: And as for my part, I like Po∣ems as I like a Woman, best uncloathed, for then I am sure they cannot de∣ceive or delude me with false and feigned Shows.
Madam, will you please to go abroad, and take the cool re∣freshing Air to day?
Yes, Temperance, if you will; but I had rather stay and entertain Monsieur Serious Contemplations company.
Indeed Madam I will forbid his frequent Visits; for other∣wise you will bury your self in his melancholy Conversation.
Pray do not, for he is the greatest delight in life.
And then he brings such a numerous Train of Fancies and O∣pinions, as fills up your Head, which is the largest room in your bodily house; insomuch, as none of your domestic Thoughts, which are the Minds usefullest servants, can stir about your lifes ordinary affairs.
Why Temperance, Fancies are pretty youths, which make harm∣less and innocent sport, to pass the time away.
We have so little time, as we shall not need to pass it idly away.
As much as we complain of want of time, we have more than we can tell well how to spend.
Then pray forbid Monsieur Serious Contemplation not to bring his wilde, stubborn, and useless Opinions; for they make more disorder, and louder noise, and greater Factions, than if all the Dogs and Bears in the Town were set together by the ears, and more mischief comes thereby, than I can rectify.
Now Liberty, you are a Fore-runner of Visitants.
Yes Madam, for there are the five Sistres, the five Senses, come to visit you.
They are the troublesomest Visitants that are; they are so extra∣vagant, so impertinent, so various, and so humoursome, as I know not how to entertain them: But pray Liberty usher them into the Gallery where my pi∣ctures hang, drawn by the Rarest and most Famous Masters; and let the Room be sweetly perfumed, and bring a Banquet of the most delicious and choicest Drinks and Meats, and let there be sine linen Napkins, and spread all the Floor over with downy Carpets, and set soft Cushions on the Couch∣es, and whilst they are there, let the Music sound harmoniously, with soft strokes, pleasing notes, and gentle strains: And Temperance, I desire you to Order the rest of the Entertainment, and let Ease wait upon you: As for you, Wanton and Surfeit, I forbid you, as not to come into their Com∣pany.
Always when my Lady makes a great Entertainment, we are forbid to appear.
Although my Lady forbids me, yet the Company never leaves un∣till they have found me out, so that I am still at the end of the Entertainment, like an Epilogue to a Play.
And I sometimes come in like a Chorus.
O that I might have my wish!
What would you wish?
I would wish to be the only Beauty.
And if I might have my wish, I would wish to conquer all the World, and then to divide it to the Meritorious, and not to rule it my self: for I desire not the Power, but the Fame.
And if I might have my wish, I would wish to be the Su∣premised Wit in Nature.
You three are sympathetical in Ambition; for one desires to in∣captive all Hearts with her Beauty; the other desires to conquer all the World with his Valour; the third desires to confute all Mankind with her Wit.
And what do you wish, Mademoiselle Ambition?
I wish I were Destiny, to link you all three together.
Come leave your wishing, and let us go to see the Monster that is to be seen.
The most mostrous Creature I imagine, is a headless Maid.
What is that, a devirginated Maid?
Yes.
When she is devirginated, she is no Maid.
O yes; for as a Wife is one that is married, a Widow one that hath been married, so a Maid is one that was never married, and a Virgin is one that never knew man, and a headless Maid is one that hath lost her Fire∣ginity, and yet was never married.
If a devirginated Maid be a headless Monster, in the World there are many headless Monsters.
But the best of it is, Lady, their Monstrosity is invisible.
You say true; but they are not monstrous in Nature, but in Vice, for they are transformed by their Crimes.
So are Drunkards.
They are so; for all Courtesans and Drunkards are beasts: For though a Drunkard is not a headless beast, yet he is a brainless beast.
But what Monster is that you would have us to see?
Why a woman with a Hogs face.
Then it is likely she hath a Sows disposition. But howsoever let us go.
One witty word, or saying from a fool, is, for the most part remembered, and often repeated, when from a Wit it would be hardly taken notice of.
There is reason for that: for wit is more remarkable from fools, than those that have natural wits.
Monsieur Satirical, I am come with a Message from a company of fair young Ladies; the Message is this: They desire that you would do them the favour to come to them, to judge of a Poem which they have made amongst themselves.
Women make Poems? burn them, burn them; let them make bone-lace, let them make bone-lace.
You are an unjust Judge, to condemn their Poems to the fire, before you have examined them.
The best trial of a Ladies wit is the fire; besides, the fire will supply that want of Poetical heat which should make Poems, which heat women's brains cannot suffer.
You are mistaken Sir, and mis-inform'd: for we women have as hot brains as any of the Masculine Sex of you all have.
I grant your Sex have an unnatural heat, which makes them all mad.
I think the Ladies were mad when they sent me for you.
No doubt of it, and you are mad for coming.
Your words will make me mad before I go away, although I came well-temper'd hither: beshrew me my very bones do quiver in my flesh to hear you.
If thy bones quiver so much as to shake, they will soon powder into dust: for Age hath almost dissolved thee into ashes already, and Time hath eaten off thy flesh, as Crows do carrion.
Out upon thee Satyr, a beastly man you are by my Troth, and so I will deliver you to the Ladies.
You shall not deliver me to the Ladies, I will deliver my self to Death first.
Thou art so bad, Death will refuse thee: but I will do your Er∣rand I'll warrant you, I'll set a mark upon you that shall disgrace you.
Thou can not set a fouler mark than thy self upon me, there∣fore come not near me.
Worse and worse, worse and worse. O that I were so young and fair, as my Beauty might get me a Champion to revenge my quarrel! But I will go back to the Ladies, they are fair and young enough, as being in the Spring of Beauty, although I am in my Autumnal years.
Thou art in the midst of the Winter of thine Age, and the Snow of Time is fallen on thy head, and lies upon thy hair.
They that will not live until they are old, the Proverb says, They must be hanged when they are young, and I hope it is your Destiny.
I am come to tell you, Wanton and Surset, that my Lady is gone to receive the Visit of Monsieur Tranquillities Peace, who is come to see her, and old Matron Temperance is gone to wait upon her; wherefore you may go, for there is none left with the five Senses but Excess.
I wonder Mother Matron should stay so long.
I cannot guess at the reason.
She might have delivered her Message twice in this time.
Mother Matron, Welcome, welcome, welcome: What News? what News?
What says Monsieur Satirical?
Will he come?
Or will he not come? pray speak.
Are you dumb, Mother Matron?
Pray Ladies give me some time to temper my passion; for if a house be set on fire, there is required sometime to quench it.
But some fires cannot be quenched.
Indeed my fire of Anger is something of the nature of the un∣quenchable fire of Hell, which endeavours to afflict the Soul, as well as to torment the Body.
Jove bless us, Mother Matron! Are you inflamed with Hell∣fire?
How should I be otherwise, when I have been tormented with a Devil?
Jupiter keep us! What have you done, and with whom have you been?
Marry I have been with a cloven-tongu'd Satyr, who is worse, far worse, than a cloven-footed Devil.
Is all this rage against Monsieur Satirical?
Yes marry is it, and all too little, by reason it cannot hurt him.
How hath he offended you?
As he hath offended you all, railed against you, most horribly railed against you: He says you are all mad, and hath condemned your Po∣ems to the fire, and your employment to the making of bone-lace.
Why these sayings of his do not offend me.
Nor me.
Nor me.
Nor me.
But if he had said you had been old, and ill-favour'd, carrion for Crows, dust and ashes for the grave, as he said to me, then you would have been as angry as I.
No truly, I should have only laughed at it.
By your favour, I should have been as angry as Mother Matron, if I had been as old as she; so I should have been concerned in the behalf of my Age.
Marry come up, are you turned Lady Satirical, to upbraid me with my Age? Is this my reward for my jaunting and trotting up and down with your idle Message to more idle persons, men that are mere Jack∣straws, flouting companions, railing detractors, such as are good for nothing but to put people together by the cars?
By the Effects it proves so, for you and I are very near falling out: But I thought you would have given me thanks for what I said, as taking your part, and not inveterates your spleen.
Can you expect I should give you thanks for calling me old? Can the report of Age be acceptable to the Effeminate Sex? But Lady, let me tell you, if you live you will be as old as I, and yet desire to be thought young: For although you were threescore, yet you would be very angry, nay in a furious rage, and take those to be your mortal Enemies that should reckon you to be above one and twenty, for you will think your self as beau∣tiful as one of fifteen.
I do not think so, although I believe our Sex have good opinions of themselves, even to the last gasp; yet not so partial, as to imagine themselves as one of fifteen at threescore.
It is proved by all Experience, that all Mankind is self-conceited, especially the Effeminate Sex; and self-conceit doth cast a fair shadow on a foul face, and fills up the wrinkles of Time with the paint of Imagine∣tion.
But the Eyes must be blind with Age, or else they would see the wrinkles Time hath made, in the despite of the paint of Imagination.
By your favour, Self-conceit doth cause the Eyes of Sense to be like false glasses, that cast a youthful gloss, and a fair light, on a withered skin: For though the deep lines in the face cannot be smoothed, yet the lines, or species, in, or of the sight, may be drawn by self-conceit so small as not to be perceived: And were it not for the Eyes of Self-conceit, and the Paint of Imagination, as Mother Matron says, which preserves a good Open∣neon
of our selves, even to the time of our Death, wherein all remembrance is buried, we should grow mad, as we grow old, for the loss of our Youth and Beauty.
I by my faith you would grow mad, did not Conceit keep you in your right wits.
The truth is, our Sex grow melancholy, when our Beauty de∣cayes.
I grow melancholy at the talking of it.
Let us speak of some other subject that is more pleasing than Age, Ruin, and Death.
Let us talk of Monsieur Satirical again.
He is a worse subject to talk of than Death.
As bad as he is, you shall carry another Message to him.
I will sooner carry a Message to Pluto; for in my Conscience he will use me more civilly, and will send you a more respectful Answer than Monsieur Satirical.
Indeed I have heard that the Devil would flatter; but I never heard that a Satirical Poet would flatter.
