Prudently, say you? why Prudence and Temperance are the Executioners of Pleasure, and Murderers of Delight: wherefore I hate them, as also this covetous humour of yours.
I marry Sir, here is a Lady indeed: for she talks of pulling down this House before she hath thoroughly seen it, and of building up a∣another.
If you will have my opinion, the old servants must go down as well as the old house.
I believe so: for she looked very scornfully upon us, nor spoke not one word either good or bad to us.
Well, come let us go about our employments, and please as long as we can, and when we can please no longer, we must seek other Ser∣vices.
Do not pursue such horrid Acts, as to Whore your Si∣ster, Cuckold your Brother-in-Law, dishonour your Father, and brand your life and memory with black infamy. Good Brother consider what a world of misery you strive to bring upon your self and me.
Dear Sister pity me, and let a Brothers pleading move your heart, and bury not my youth in Death before the natural time.
It is better you should die, and in the grave be laid, than live to damn your soul.
To kill my self will be as bad a crime.
O no: for Death any way is more honourable than such a life as you would live.
FRiend, prithee tell me why you do not marry.
Because I can find no woman so exact as I would have a Wife to be: for first I would not have a very tall woman, for the ap∣pears as if her soul and body were mis-match'd, as to have a pygmy soul, and a gyantly body.
Perchance her soul is answerable to her body.
O no: for it is a question whether women have souls or no; but for certain, if they have, they are of a dwarfish kind: Neither would I have a wife with a masculine strength; for it seems pra•posterous to the softness and tenderness of their Sex: neither would I have lean wife; for she will appear always to me like the picture of Death, had she but a since and hour-glass in her hand: for though we are taught to have always Death in our Mind, to remember our End, yet I would not have Death always before my Eyes, to be afraid of my End: But to have a very lean wife, were to have Death in my Arms, as much as in my Eyes, and my Bed would be as my Grave.
Your Bed would be a warm Grave.
Why man, though Death is cold, the Grave is hot: for the Earth hath heat, though Death hath none.
What say you to a fat woman?
I say a fat woman is a bed-fellow only for the Winter, and not for the Summer; and I would have such a woman for my Wife, as might be a nightly companion all the year.
I hope you would not make your Wife such a constant bed-fel∣low, as to lie always together in one bed.
Why not?
Because a mans stomach or belly may ache, which will make wind work, and the rumbling wind may decrease love, and so your wife may dis∣like you, and dislike in time may make a Cuckold.
By your favour it increases Matrimonial Love: it is true, it may decrease Amorous Love; and the more Amorous Love increases, the more danger a man is in: for Amorous Love, even to Husbands, is dangerous; for that kind of Love takes delight to progress about, when Matrimonial Love is constant, and considers Nature as it is: Besides, a good Wife will not dislike that in her Husband, which she is subject to her self; but howso∣ever I will never marry, unless I can get such a Wife as is attended by Virtue, directed by Truth, instructed by Age, on honest grounds, and honourable principles, which Wife will neither dislike me, nor I her, but the more we are together, the better we shall love, and live as a married pair ought to live, and not as dissembling Lovers, as most married couples do.
What think you of choosing a Wife amongst the Sociable Virgins?
No, no, I will choose none of them; for they are too full of dis∣course: for I would have a Wife rather to have a listening Ear, than a talking Tongue; for by the Ear she may receive wise instructions, and so learn to practise that which is noble and good; also to know my desires, as to obey my will; when by speaking muck, she may express her self a fool: for great Talkers are not the wisest Practisers: Besides, her restless Tongue will disturb my Contemplations, the Tranquillity of my Mind, and the peace, quiet, and rest of my Life.
Are you she that takes upon you to govern, and to be Mistress in this House?
Why I do but that I did in the other Ladies time.
Let me tell you, you shall not do so in my time; nay you shall have no doings, wherefore get you out of the House.
I will not go.
No? but you shall.
Go you and call one of those servants I brought with me.
Here take this wench, and put her out of the Gates.
You Rogue, touch me and you dare, I shall have one to de∣fend me.
I desie your Champion.
What you Villain, will you force her? set her down.
I did no more than what I was commanded.
Who commanded you?
My Lady, Sir, commanded me to carry her out of the gates.
Pray let her alone until I have spoke with my wife.
I shall Sir.
VVhat's the matter Nan?
Only my Ladies dislikes of my person: for it could not be through any neglect of my service, or faithful diligence, or humble duty, but through a passionate humour, because she hath heard you were pleased heretofore to favour me.
But now we are very honest Nan.
Yes, the more unkind man you, to win a young Maid to love, and then to turn her away in disgrace.
I do not turn you away.
Yes but you do, if you suffer my Lady to turn me away.
How should I help that? for she hath such a strong spirit, as not to be controlled.
O Sir, if you bridle her, you may guide her as you will.
How should I bridle her?
Why put her to her allowance, and take the government of your Family out of her hands, as you did to your former Lady.
My other wife was born with a quiet obedient nature, and this with a high and turbulent nature; and if I should cross her high working spy¦rit, she would grow mad.
Why then you would have a good excuse to tie her up.
Her Friends would never suffer me; besides, the world would condemn me, and account me a Tyrant.
Why it is better to be accounted a Tyrant than a Fool.
O no; for men ought to be sweet and gentle-natur'd to the Effeminate Sex.
I see by you; that the worse that men are used, the better Husbands they make: for you were both unkind and cruel to your other Lady, nei∣there could you find, or at least would not give such Arguments for her.
Will you rebuke me for that which you persuaded me unto, by dispraising your Lady unto me?
Alas Sir, I was so fond of your company, that I was jealous even of my Lady, and love is to be pardoned: wherefore, Dear Sir, turn me not away; for Heaven knows I desire to live no longer than when I can have your favour, and I wish I were blind, if I might not be where I may see you, and my heart leaps for joy, whenever I hear your voice: wherefore good Sir, for loves sake pity me.
Well, I will speak to my wife for you.
Well, if I can but get my Master but dance once, to kiss me again,
which I will be industrious for, I will be revenged of this domineering Lady: I hope I shall be too crafty for her.
Brother, speak no more upon so bad a subject, for fear I wish you dumb: for the very breath that's sent forth with your words, will blister both my ears: I would willingly hide your faults, nay I am ashamed to make them known; but if you do persist, by Heaven I will discover your wicked desires, both to my Father and Husband.
Will you so?
Yes that I will.
Well, I will leave you, and try if Reason can conquer your evil de∣sires, or else I'll die.
Heaven pour some holy Balsam into your festered soul.
Wife, I am come an humble Petitioner to you in the be∣half of Nan, she hath been a servant here ever since I was first married to my other Wife.
No, no, Husband, I will have none of your whores in the house where I live; if you must have whores, go seek them abroad.
Pray let not your jealous Passion turn away a good servant.
Had you rather please your servant, a whore, or me?
Why you.
Then turn her away.
But surely Wife you will let me have so much power, as to keep an old servant.
No Husband, if your old servant be a young lusty wench.
But I have passed my word that she shall stay.
And I have sworn an Oath that she shall go away.
But my promise must be kept: wherefore she shall not go away.
I say she shall go away; nay more, I will have her whipped at the end of a Cart, and then sent out of doors.
As I am Master, I will command none shall touch her; and let me see who dares touch her.
Who dares touch her? why I can hire poor fellows for money, not only to whip her, but murder you.
Are you so free with my Estate? I will discharge you of that Of∣fice of keeping my money.
If you do, I have Youth and Beauty, that will hite me Revengers, and get me Champions.
Will you so?
Yes, or any thing rather than want my will; and know, I per∣fectly hate you, for taking my Maids part against me.
Nay prithee Wife be not so choleric: for I said all this but to try thee.
You shall prove me, Husband, before I have done.
Shall I divulge my Brothers Crimes, which are such Crimes as will set a mark of Infamy upon my Family and Race for ever? or shall I let Vice run without restraint? or shall I prove false to my Husbands bed, to save my brothers life? or shall I damn my Soul and his, to satisfy his wilde desires? O no, we both will die, to save our Souls, and keep our Honours clear.
The more I struggle with my Affections, the weaker do I grow for to resist. If Gods had power, they sure would give me strength, or were they just, they would exact no more than I could pay; and if they cannot help, or will not help me, Furies rise up from the infernal deep, and give my Actions aid; Devils assist me, and I will learn you to be more evil than you are; and when my black horrid designs are fully finished, then take my soul, which is the quintessence of wickedness, and squeeze some venom forth up∣on the World, that may infect mankind with plagues of sins
There multitudes will bury mine,
Or count me as a Saint, and offer at my Shrine.
Nan, you must be contented, for you must be gone: for your Lady will not suffer you to be in the house.
Will you visit me, if I should live near your House, at the next Town?
No: for that will cause a parting betwixt my Wife and me, which I would not have for all the World: wherefore Nan, God be with you.
May your House be your Hell, and your Wife be your Devil.
What will your Ladyship have for your Supper?
Whatsoever is rare and costly
Did your Ladyship send for me?
Yes: for you having been an old servant in my Fathers House, will be more diligent to observe and obey my commands: where∣fore go to the Metropolitan City, and there try all those that trade in vani∣ties, and see if they will give me credit, in case my Husband should restrain his purse from me, and tell them that they may may make my Husband pay my debts. The next is, I would have you take me a fine house in the City: for I intend to live there, and not in this dull place, where I see no body but my Husband, who spends his time in sneaking after his Maids tails, having no other employment; besides, solitariness begets melancholy, and melan∣choly begets suspicion, and suspicion jealousy; so that my Husband grows amorous with idleness, and jealous with melancholy. Thus he hath the plea∣sure of variety, and I the pain of jealousy: wherefore be you industrious to obey my command.
I shall Madam.
Good Sir conceal my Passion, left it become a scorn, when once it is known: for all rejected Lovers are despised, and those that have some small returns of Love; yet do those saint Affections triumph vaingloriously upon those that are strong, and make them as their slaves.
Surely Child thy Affections shall not be divulged by me, I only wish thy Passions were as silent in thy breast, as on my tongue, as that he thou love so much may lie as dead and buried in thy memory.
There's no way to bury Love, unless it buries me.
I hear Wife that you are going to the Metropolitan City.
Yes Husband: for I find my self much troubled with the Spleen, and therefore I go to try if I can be cured.
Why, will the City cure the Spleen?
Yes, for it is the only remedy: for melancholy must be diverted with divertisements; besides, there are the best Physicians.
I will send for some of the best and most famous Physicians from thence, if you will stay.
By mo means: for they will exact so much upon your impor∣tance, as they will cost more money than their journey is worth.
But Wife, it is my delight and profit to live in the Country; besides, I hate the City.
And I hate the Country.
But every good Wife ought to conform her self to her Hus∣bands humours and will.
But Husband, I profess my self no good Wife: wherefore I will follow my own humour.
I find there is no crossing her, she will have her Will.
Wife, I am come to rob your Cabinet of all the Ri∣bands that are in it: for I have made a running match betwixt Monsieur la Whips Nag, and your Brothers Barb; and he faith that he shall not run, unless you give him Ribands: for he is persuaded your Favours will make him win.
Those Ribands I have, you shall have, Husband: But what will my Brother say if his Barb should lose the match?
I asked him that question, and he answered, that if he lost, he would knock his Barbs brains out of his head.
Where is my Brother?
Why he is with your Father, and such a good companion he is to day, and so merry, as your Father is so fond of his company, insomuch as he hangs about his neck as a new-maried wife: But I conceive the chief reason is, that your Brother seems to consent to marry the Lady Amor.
I am glad of that with all my soul.
But he says, if he doth marry her, It must be by your pursue∣sons.
He shall not want persuading, if I can persuade him.
Come Wife, will you give me some Ribands?
Yes Husband, I will go fetch them.
Nay Wife, I will go along with you.
Thoughts, cease to move, and let my Soul take rest, or let the damps of grief quench out lifes flame.
My dear Child, do not pine away for Love: for I will get thee a handsomer man than Monsieur Frere.
Sir, I am not so much in love with his person, as to dote so sondly thereon.
What makes you so in love with him then? for you have no great acquaintance with him.
Lovers can seldom give a Reason for their Passion; yet mine grew from your superlative praises; those praises drew my Soul out at my Ears to entertain his love: But since my Soul misles of what it seeks, will not return, but leave my body empty to wander like a ghost, in gloomy sadness, and midnight melancholy.
I did mistake the subject I spoke of, the substance being false, those praises were not current: wherefore lay them aside, and fling them from thee.
I cannot: for they are minted, and have Loves stamp, and being out, increases like to Interest-money, and is become so vast a sum, as I be∣lieve all praises past, present, or what's to come, or can be, are too few for his merits, and too short of his worth.
Rather than praise him, I wish my Tongue had been for ever dumb.
O wish not so, but rather I had been for ever deaf.
My Child is undone.
My Master looks so lean and pale, as I doubt he is in a Con∣sumption.
Faith he takes something to heart, whatsoever it is.
I doubt he is jealous.
He hath reason: for if my Lady doth not cuckold him, yet she gives the World cause to think she doth: for she is never without her Gal∣lants.
There is a great difference betwixt our Lady that is dead, and this.
Is my Wife come home yet?
No Sir.
I think it be about twelve of the Clock.
It is past one Sir.
If it be so late, I will sit up no longer watching for my Wives coming home, but I will go to bed; for I am not very well.
You do not look well, Sir.
Indeed I am sick.
Lord Brother, what is the reason you are come back so soon? Hath not your Barb run the Race?
No.
What makes you here then?
To see you.
To see me? why I shall give you no thanks, because you left my Husband behind you.
I do not come for your thanks, I come to please my self.
Prithee Brother get thee gone: for thy face doth not appear so honest as it uses to do.
I do not know how my Face doth appear; but my Heart is as it was, your faithful Lover.
Heaven forbid you should relapse into your old disease.
Let me tell you, Sister, I am as I was, and was as I am, that is, from the first time I saw you, since I came from Travel, I have been in love with you, and must enjoy you; and if you will embrace my love with a free consent, so, if not, I'll force you to it.
Heaven will never suffer it, but cleave the Earth, and swallow you alive.
I care not, so you be in my Arms; but I will first try Heavens pow∣er, and struggle with the Deities.
Wife, Is this the way to cure melancholy? to sit up all night at Cards, and to lose five hundred pounds at a sitting? or to stay all night abroad a Dancing and Revelling.
O yes; for the Doctors say there is nothing better than good company, to employ the Thoughts with (outward Objects) otherwise the Thoughts feed too much upon the Body; besides, they say that Exercise is excellent good to open Obstructions, and to disperse melancholy Vapour; and the Doctors say, there is no Exercise better than Dancing, because there are a great Company meet together, which adds Pleasure to the La∣bore.
My other Wife did not do thus.
Wherefore she died in her youth with melancholy; but I mean to live while I am old, if mirth and good company will keep me alive; and know I am not so kind-hearted to kill my self, to spare your Purse, or to please your Humour.
Who will call unto the Gods for aid, since they assist not Innocence, nor give protection to a Virtuous Life? Is Piery of no use? or is Hey∣ven so obdurate, no holy prayers can enter Heaven-gates, or penitential tears can move the Gods to pity? But O my sorrows are too big for words, and all actions too little for his punishment.
Sister, I must die, wherefore you must not live: for I cannot be without your company, although in death, and in the silent grave, where no Love's made, nor Passion known.
It's welcome News: for if death comes not by your hand, my hand shall give a passage unto life.
There is none so sit to act that part as I, who am so full of sin, want nothing now but murder to make up measure.
Death, thou are my griefs Reprieve, and wilt unlade my Soul from heavy thoughts that miserable life throws on, and sinks me to the Earth. Brother farewell, may all your crimes be buried in my grave, and may my shame and yours be never known.
Now she is dead, my Mind is at rest, since I know none can enjoy her after me; but I will follow thee: I come, my Mistress, Wife, and Si∣ster all in one.
You Gods of Love, if any Gods there be, O hear my prayer! And as we came both from one Womb, so join our Souls in the Elizium, out Bodies in one Tomb.
Wife, you are very unkind, that you will not come to see me now I am sick, nor so much as send to know how I do.
I am loath to trouble you with unnecessary visits, or impertinent questions.
Is it unnecessary or impertinent to see a Husband when he is sick? or to ask how he doth?
Yes, when their visits and questions can do them no good: But God be with you, for I must be gone.
What, already?
Yes; for I doubt I have staid too long: for I have appointed a meeting, and it will be a dishonour for me to break my word.
But it will be more dishonour to be dancing when your Husband is dying, Lady.
What, will you teach me? go tutor Girls and Boys, and not me.
Let her go, friend: for her anger will disturb me.
I know not what her anger doth you; but her neglect of you doth disturb me: And for my part, I wonder how you can suffer her.
Alas how shall I help, or remedy it? But Heaven is just, and punishes me for the neglect I used towards my first Wife, who was virtuous and kind.
She was a sweet Lady indeed.
O she was! But I Devil as I was, to use her as I did, making her a slave unto my whore and frowns, conjecturing all her Virtues to a con∣trary sense: for I mistook her patience for simplicity, her kindness for wan∣tonness, her thrist for covetousness, her obedience for flattery, her retired life for dull stupidity; and what with the grief to think how ill I used her, and grieving to see how ill this Wife uses me, wasting my Honour and Estate, she hath brought me into a Consumption, as you see: But when I am dead, as I cannot live long, I desire you, who are my Executor, to let me buried in the same Tomb wherein my Wife is laid: for it is a joy to me, to think my dust shall be mixed with her pure ashes: for I had rather be in the grave with my first Wife, than live in a Throne with my second. But I grow very sick, even to death: wherefore let me be removed.
Son-in-law, did your Brother say he was very ill?
He said he had such a pain on his left side, as he could not sit on his horse, but must be forced to return home again.
Heaven bless him: for my heart is so full of fears and doubts, as if it did Prognosticate some great misfortune to me.
Pray Sir be not so dejected, nor look so pale; I dare warrant you the News that his Barb hath won the Race, will be a sufficient Cataplasm to take away his Stitch.
How doth my Son and daughter?
I think they are both well, Sir.
Why, do not you know, and yet dwell in the same House?
No indeed not I: for I only saw my young Master go towards my Ladies lodging, but I did not follow to inquire of their healths, for feat they should be angry, and think me bold.
Where is you Lady?
In her Chamber I think, Sir.
Do you but think so? do you not know? It is a sign you wait not very diligently.
Why Sir, I met my young Master going to his Sisters Chamber, and he sent me on an Errand, and when I came back, the outward doors were locked, so as I could not get in any ways.
The doors locked, say you?
Yes Sir.
Let them be broken open.
O my doubts foretell à miserable Tragedy.
Villains let go, she shall not wander in the silent shades without my company; besides, my soul will crowd through multitudes of souls, that flock to Charons Boat, to make an easy passage for her pure soul: wherefore let go, I command you as being your Master, let go.
This is so strange an Accident, that hardly Story can mention the like.
I wonder how they came murdered, the door being locked, and none but themselves; if it had been thieves, they would have robbed them, as well as murdered them.
I believe my young Master was the Thief that did both rob and murder.
Well, I could tell a story that I heard, listening one day at my Ladies Chamber-door; but I will not.
Prithee tell it us.
No, I will not, you shall excuse me for this time.
Daughter, I am come to bring you a Medicine to take out the sting of Love.
What is it Sir?
Why, Monsieur Frere hath most wickedly killed himself.
Although I cannot usher him to the Grave, I'll follow him.
Help, help, for Heavens sake, help.
O my Child is dead! O she is dead, she is dead! Carry her to her Bed.
O my Lady is quite dead, and past all cure, and her Father, I think, will die also.
I am sure there is a sad, a sad House to day.
IF subtle Air, the Conduit to each ear,
Hearts passion moved to draw a sadder tear
From your squeezed brains, on your pale cheeks to lie,
Distilled from every Fountain of each eye;
Our Poetress hath done her part, and you
To make it sadder, know this Story's true;
A plaudity you'll give, if think it fit,
For none but will say this Play is well writ.

OUr Auth'ress says to make a Play is hard,
To censure freely men are not afraid;
Opinions easily do pass upon
The wit of others, though themselves have none;
And envy rounds the sense, and words about,
Hoping some errors it may soon find out.
But streams of wit do not so often flow,
As salt rough censures, which to billows grow;
And swell so big, till they in pieces fall,
In their own ruins they are buried all.
But if our Authors Play deserves a praise,
She will not thank you, though you give her bays;
Because she knows it is her right and due,
And justice to receive the same from you.
Wherefore she says, if you do take delight
To read her Play, or acted to your sight,
The bounty doth proceed from her alone;
Her wit doth pleasure give to every one.
The Play, if bad, she doth desire no praise,
The Cypress will receive instead of bays.
It is reported that the great Mogul hath War with the Parthians, and a man of our Nation is General of all his Forces.
Me thinks it is too great an Honour and Trust to give to a stranger.
But it is reported he hath behaved himself so wisely, honestly, nobly, and valiantly, as he hath gained the favour of the Emperor, and love of the Soldiers, and also respect from all the infer∣our Princes.
Who should this man be?
I cannot learn: for the Merchants from whom I had this report, know not what his right name is; for they think he goes by a covered name.
Surely he is of a very mean Birth, that he is ashamed to own his name.
It seems so; but let his Birth be poor or great, he hath a Gene∣rous Soul: for they say he is very bountiful, and lives in great magnificence, and carries himself as if he were Princely born: He is the whole discourse upon the Exchange, and the Merchants do cry him up like to another Iuli∣us Caesar.
It seems they fare the better for his being their Countryman, and he to be the Emperors Favourite.
It is like enough.
Nay you may be assured they have a Fee of Obligation, if they praise him so much. Of what Age do they say he may be?
They say is in the prime of his years, a very handsome man, well-behav'd, and of a ready wit.
It is strange it should not be known of what Parentage he is of.
It is not known as yet.
Sir, were not you a servant to the Lord of Sage?
Yes Sir.
He was a Wise, and a Noble Person.
He was so, Heaven rest his Soul.
It is said he hath left but one only Child, and she a Daughter, which Daughter is sole Heir to all his Estate.
She is so.
And it is also reported she will be wooed in public, or else she'll never wed.
The Report is true, Sir: for I am now going to invite all her Friends and acquaintance, to whom she desires to publish her resolutions.
Is she resolved of it?
She hath vowed it.
Pray favour me so much, as to give me a Character of her.
She is Virtuous, Young, Beautiful, Graceful, and hath a superna∣tural Wit; and she hath been bred and brought up to all Virtuosus, which a∣dorns her Natural Gifts; she lives magnificently, yet orders her Estate pru∣dently.
This Lady may be a sample to all her Sex.
Mistress Simple is the very'st Fool that ever I tutored or in∣structed.
Do you mean a fool by imprudence, or a fool that speaks im∣properly?
I do not know what her imprudence may be; but in her words there is no coherence.
Alas she is young; and youth is a Cage of Ignorance, and boys and girls are like birds, which learn from their tutors and tutoresses artifice∣al tunes, which are several Languages, Sciences, Arts, and the like: But the truth is, of all sorts of Birds, the Cocks are more apt to learn than the Hens.
If she can be taught sense, I am much mistaken: for she hath not a reasonable capacity to learn.
Why then she hath a defect in Nature, as a Changeling.
I think so.
Why should you think so, since youths capacity cannot be measured by their Educators? for Time is the only measure of the rational capacity: And to prove it, some boys and girls will be so dull, as to seem stu∣bid to Learning, and yet in their strength of years may prove very rational un∣derstanding,
and wise men or women; besides, the Brain is like to the Air, it is sometimes thick with misty Errors, sometimes dark with clouds of Eg∣norance, and sometimes clear with Understanding, when as the Sun of Know∣ledge shines; and perchance you heard her speak when her Brain was cloud∣die and dark.
So dark, as her words could not find the right way to sense.
Perchance if you hear her speak some other times, when her Brain is clear, you may hear her speak wisely.
It is so unlikely she should ever speak wisely, as it is near to impossible.
Indeed unlikely and impossible do some way resemble each o∣there: But let me tell you, the Brain is like the Face, it hath its good days and its bad: for Beauty and Wit have not only their times and seasons, but their foul and fair days.
You say true: for the choicest Beauties that ever were, or are, will sometimes look worse than at other times; nay so ill they will look some∣times, as they might be thought they were not Beauties.
The like for Wit: for certainly, the greatest Wit that ever was, or is, may sometimes be so dull and unactive, as it might be thought they were so far from being Wits, as they might be judged Fools: And cer∣tainly, the most Eloquent Orators that ever were, have spoke at some times less Eloquently than at other times; insomuch, that at some times, although the subject of their Discourse is so full of Matter and Reason, as might have oiled their Tongues, smoothed their Words, and enlightened their Fancy, yet they will speak as if their Wits had caught cold, and their Tongues had the numb Palsy, on which their words run stumbling out of their mouths as insensible; when as at other times, although the subject of their discourse be barren or boggy, woody or rocky, yet their Wit will run a Race without stop or stay, and is decked and adorned with flowery Rhetoric: And certain∣lie, the wisest men that ever were, have given both themselves and others worse counsel sometimes, than at other times; and certainly the valiantest man that ever was, had sometimes more courage than at other times: But yet although a valiant man may have more courage at one time than another, yet he is at no time a coward, nor a wise man a fool.
But Orators may chance to speak non-sense.
They may so, and many times do.
Why then may not a Valiant man be at some times a Coward, and a Wise man a Fool, as well as Orators to speak non-sense?
Because Valour, Judgment, and Prudence are created in the Soul, and is part of its Essence; I do not mean every soul, but the souls of Valiant and Wise men: for souls differ as much as bodies, some are cry∣ted defective, others perfect; but words are only created in the mouth, and are born through the lips, before the soul of sense is entered or inbodied therein.
An Orators tongue is powerful.
An Orators tongue doth rather play on Passions, than compose the Judgment, or set notes to the Reason; like as a Fiddler, that can play tunes on musical Instruments, but is no Musician, to compose and set tunes: But there are many men that have eloquent tongues, but not witty souls; they have the Art of words, but not the Spirit of wit.
Kind Friends, and worthy Acquaintance, you may think it strange, and perchance take it ill, I invite you only to a simple Dis∣course, for to declare a vain Vow, as you may judge it so to be, which Vow I made since my Father the Lord Sage's death. The Vow is, never to receive a Lovers Address, or to answer a Lovers Suit but in a public Assembly; and it is likely the World will laugh at this as ridiculous, or condemn it for pride, or scorn it as self-conceit: But if they will be pleased to weigh it in Judge∣mints Scales, they will find it poised with a good Intention, and make a just weight of Convenience against unaccustomariness: for though it is not usu∣al, yet it is very requisite, especially to such young women which are Or∣phans, who like small and weak Vessels, that are destitute of Guide or Pilot, are left on the wide Sea-faring World to ruinous waves, and incon∣stant weather; even so young women are to the Appetites of greedy men, and their own inconstant and changing Natures, and want of Experience to guide them, run on Rocks, Shelves, and Quick-sands of Troubles, Misery, and Disgrace, not knowing what safe Port or Home to sail to; whereupon, and in which danger, I considering with my self, at last I thought it the safest way to swim in the full Ocean, and not in the narrow Channels, Creeks, or obscure Corners, lest I should be crushed to pieces, or drowned for want of Sea-room; and surely were there a Law to forbid all private meetings of young men and women, and that no women should marry, unless they be wooed in public, there would not be so many unequal matches, so many perjured Consciences, so many devirginate and forsaken Maids; neither would there be such floods of tears from sorrowful Parents Eyes, for their unduti∣full childrens Actions that will choose without their good liking, and marry against their good wills: But they will be ashamed in public to choose dishonourably or indiscreetly: for the Ears and Eyes of a public Assembly will be as Reigns, to curb their unruly Passions, and their Applause and Com∣mendation will be as spurs to force them to a wise, choice, when in private Wooings their Passions become wilde, and run loosely about, without bridle or check: Wherefore I desire my Friends and Acquaintance to be as wit∣noses of my behaviour and words to my loving and Matrimonial Suitors; and in this you will be as Parents to the Fatherless, as Judges to Pleaders, and Gods to Men.
We approve of your discreet and honest Resolutions, and shall wish you happy days.
Mistress, there is a Woman at the door that can tell Fortunes.
O let her come in, let her come in.
God bless you young Ladies.
Can you tell Fortunes?
Yes that I can Lady.
Tell me mine.
Tell me mine first.
No, tell me mine first.
Nay, tell me mine first.
Have patience Ladies, and let her tell your Fortunes by degrees, one after another: for she cannot tell them all at once.
I must look in your hand, Lady.
By your hand you should marry richly, and keep Open-House; you will have many Children, and your Husband will love you dearly.
But will no body love me but my Husband?
Yes, you will be well beloved, if you be kind and loving to others.
Now tell me my Fortune.
You, Lady, will have two Husbands.
You did not tell me I should have two Husbands.
No Lady, your Fortune is to have but one.
How long will it be ere I shall have one of my Husbands?
Not long, Lady.
Will my Husbands be handsome men?
Your first Husband will be a tall men, with a brown hair and complexion.
That complexion and stature I like very well.
Your second Husband will be of a middle stature, and of a fair hair and complexion.
O I like that stature and complexion better.
Tell me mine, tell me mine.
You will have many courting Servants, and two will fight for you.
And which shall have me?
He that out-lives the other.
Why, shall one of them be killed?
Yes.
I am sorry for that: for I could please them both. But look again, perchance he may be only sore wounded, and not killed out-right.
Your hand doth portend death to one.
And will he live long that I shall marry?
I do not perceive his death in your hand.
I am sorry for that; for I shall not love him, by reason he killed one that loved me so well as to die for my sake.
It is only his fortune to live; but he ventures as much for your sake as the other.
That's all one: for I shall love him that's killed, more than he that lives, especially after I am married: for I shall love a dead servant be∣la than a living Husband.
You are so long a talking to the woman, as you hinder her from tel∣ling me my fortune. Come woman, read the fortune in my hand.
You, Lady, will die a Maid.
Out upon the Witch, what Devil told you that lye?
I do not say you will die a Virgin.
I hope you do not see any children in my hand.
There are many lines that do foretell children; but some are so small, and others so crossed and broke, as I cannot find a strait or perfect line: But here are lines that do foretell many Suitors.
That's some amends: for it had been a hard case, and very ill for∣tune, if I should have neither Husband nor Suitors.
Come, come, Ladies, pay the poor woman, and let her go.
Give her a crown for me.
And one for me.
And one for me.
Heaven bless you Ladies: for you will make me rich.
Give her half a crown for me.
Will not you give her a whole crown?
There is no reason I should: for she hath given me never a Hus∣band.
Well, good woman, let this be a warning to you, that when you come to tell young Ladies their Fortunes, that you be sure to give them all one Husband a piece, if not two or three: for the more Husbands you give them, the more money they will give you.
I shall take your counsel, Mistress.
To die a Maid, it cannot be, it must not be, it shall not be.
Madam, I am come here to offer you a Man, a Gentleman, and a Soldier, three Titles in me, the Person that loves you, honours you, and will serve and obey you, and think it no disgrace thus to alter the Care∣chism of our old written Matrimony: If you command the breeches, you shall not only have them, but the coat too; and when you are pleased to change the name of the Sex, the gray Mare shall be the better Horse: for it is ashame for a man to control a woman, but always to obey and please them from the least to the greatest of their commands: for man never seems so much man, nor masculinely enthroned under the cloth of State, in his Royal Chair of Courage, as when he is taken prisoner, and led captive by the Fe∣male Sex. Thus, fair Divine Lady, conquered, thus I beg, thus I yield, thus submit: Wherefore Lady, take me, and make your self happy and me.
No Musk nor Civet courtly words I use,
Nor Frenchez-pan promises to abuse
Your softer Sex, nor Spanish sweets to tell,
And bribe your quicker nostrils with the smell,
Or let a false tear down my cheek to fall,
And with dissembling kneeling therewithal,
Sigh my self into Air: these fools disdain,
These quarter-wits, O kick them back again:
Nor am I like a Justice of the Peace,
That woo's you just as he would buy a lease;
Nor like an Heir, whose Tutor for his sake
So many lies of Joynter-houses make;
Nor like a Lawyer that would fain entail,
And when he's tried, doth make a Jeofail;
Nay thousands more, that always do dissemble
For your sake, make my loving heart to tremble,
Lest you should be deceived.
Admired Lady, fear not my Profession,
All my Drum-heads, I'll beat them to soft silence,
And every warlike Trumpet shall be dumb:
Our feared Colours now shall be torn off,
And all our Armour be condemned to rust,
Only my Sword I'll wear, the badge of man,
Pore to defend you and your Honour-still.
Then Madam take me thus your loving Vassal,
When lying bragging Castrils will forsake you.
Oh take a man, and joy in him for life,
A Sword-man knows the virtue of a Wife.
Gallant Sir, should I accept of your Suit, I should be ei∣there an Enemy to my self, or you, or my Country: As for my self, should I marry a Soldier, I should be tormented with the cruelest passions: for if I love my Husband, as sure I shall, I shall be perpetually frightened with his dangers, grieved for his absence, despair of his life: Every little misfortune will be as his Passing-Bell; I shall never be at rest asleep nor awake; my Dreams will present him to my view, with bleeding wounds, mangled by∣die, and pale visage; I shall be widowed every minute of an hour, in my own thoughts: for as the Senses are to the Body, so the thoughts are to the Mind, and Imaginations in these, or the like cases, are as strong as a visible presence: for passions live in the Soul, not in the senses; for a man is as much grieve∣ed when he hears his friend is dead or killed, as if he saw him dead or slain: for the dead friend lives in the mind, not the mind in the dead friend: But with these Dreams and Imaginations I shall grow blind with weeping, weak with sighing, sick with sorrowing, and deaf with listening after reports: And should you desist from that noble Profession for my sake, I should prove as a Traitor to my Country, by taking away part of the strength and support, lea∣avenge the weakness to the force of the Enemy: for a good Soldier is a strong Fort and Bulwark of Defence: Indeed a skilful Commander is to be pre∣fer'd before a numerous Army: for a number of men without Order, are like dust, which the least puff of wind blows about; so an Army, not being well commanded, is quickly dispersed, and suddenly routed upon the least error; besides, should you desist, you would bury your name in Oblivion, when by your valiant Actions, and prudent Conduct, your memory will be placed in Fems high Tower, and writ in large Characters of praise. It is true, should I marry, I should prefer my Husbands honour before his life, yet would I not willingly marry a man, whose life shall be set at the stake, and Fortune still throwing at it, for that would make me live miserably: And who would wilfully make themselves miserable, when Nature forbids it, and God commands it not?
Shall we go and visit the Lady Gravity?
No, she lives so solitary a life, as we shall meet no company there: for none go to visit her.
Then let us go to the Lady Liberty, there we shall meet
company enough: for all the Ladies in the Town go to visit her.
If she hath no men-visiters, I will not add to the number of her Lady visitors.
You may be sure she hath Masculine Visitors, or else the Ladies would never go to see her: for it is to meet the men the Ladies go to see her, and not for her own sake.
And the men go to see the Ladies.
I believe some do; yet men are better company in the company of their own Sex, than in the company of women.
By your favour, the contrary Sex agree best, and are better plea∣sed together, than men with men, or women with women: But if the Lady Liberties House be the General Rendezvous for Men and Women, let us go.
Content.
O my dear Heart!
O my dear Joy, how glad am I to see thee! But where have you been, that you came later than you promised? for if you had not sent me word you would come to me to day, I had gone to you.
Why, where do you think I have been?
I know not where to think.
I have been at a Silk-mans shop to buy me a new Gown; but I would not choose it before I had shown thee my patterns.
Let me see them.
What do you think of this stuff?
This is out of Fashion; besides, it is not a Mode-colour.
What think you of this Tabby?
The colour is good, but it is not of a good water.
What think you of this Satin?
The Satin is a good glossy Satin, but the colour is too pale.
But pale colours, it is said, are Allamode in France.
Who says so?
A Gentleman told me so which is newly come out of France.
Then he perchance could have told you all the French Fashions.
So he did most particularly: for he said he went into France for no other purpose but to see and observe Fashions.
I believe he only observed men's Fashions, being a man, and not women's Fashions.
Nay, he swore he observed the women's Fashion more than the men's, by reason he knew it would make him more acceptable to our Sex at his return, not only for Discourse-sake, but for the kind rewards he should have for his Intelligence; which rewards he hath found so full and plentiful, as he hath made such a beneficial Journey, as he will go once every year, and stay a month or two, and then return.
For Ioves sake send him to me.
I will; but prithee choose my Gown.
Let the Gentleman that came out of France choose your Gown: for he can put you into the French Fashion.
Sweet Lady, your Beauty hath wounded my heart, im∣prisoned my senses, and hath enslaved my soul, so as I am wholly in your power.
I will mask my beauty, and set you free.
A mask may shadow your beauty, but cannot extinguish it, no more than a dark cloud can the bright Sun: And as the Sun begets life, and gives light; so your beauty begets love, and gives delight to all that do be∣hold it.
And as Time brings Death, Darkness, and Obscurity; so Age brings wrinkles, and Absence forgetfulness, burying love in the ruins of Beauty.
My love can never die, nor hath time power to vade your beauty.
Nothing escapes Times tyranny, but what the soul possesses.
You are the soul of beauty, and beauty the soul of love.
Such souls have no Eternity, but die as bodies do.
O save my soul, and love me.
It is not in my power: for love is free and resolute; it can nei∣there be commanded nor entreated.
Ladies, you are become melancholy of a sudden: I hope you are not tired with dancing?
Yes saith, we want divertisements: wherefore prethy Sir Tho∣mas Letgo, send for thy affianced Mistress to make sport.
I am ashamed she should be seen, or made known to this noble company.
O divulge her by all means, that the World may know you do despise her, and that you will marry her only because she is rich, and to o∣bay your Fathers commands.
I will obey your commands, and send for her.
Sir Thomas Letgo, your wise Mistress is come to welcome your Guests.
She wants words to express her self, and Wit to entertain them.
Your Father knew you wanted not Wit so much as Wealth.
Many Fathers leave their sons nothing but their follies and vices for their Inheritance: But my Father not having Vices or Follies enough of his own, hath left me another mans Fool for an Annuity.
Is she a fool?
O yes: for she seldom speaks.
That's a great sign of simplicity indeed.
She is a mere Changeling: for when she doth speak, it is but, when she is questioned, and then for the most part she gives but one answer to all sorts of questions.
What Answer is that?
Her Answer is, she cannot tell.
Lady, there may be such questions asked, as are beyond a wise mans understanding to resolve: But perchance she is sceptic, that doubts all things.
What do you judge the scepticks fools?
A man may judge all those to be fools that are not scepticks.
I judge all those that think her not a fool, are fools.
Then Lady I am condemned: for I cannot give sentence against any of your Sex, neither in thoughts or words.
Country Gentleman, Madam, though I no Courtier am by Education,
Yet I more truth may speak, and here declare,
Your charming Eyes turn wanton thoughts to virtue;
Each modest smile converts the sinfull'st soul
To holy Matrimony, and each Grace and Motion,
Takes more than the fairest Face.
I am not young, not yet condemned to age,
Not handsome, nor yet (I think) ill-favour'd;
I do not swell with riches, nor am poor,
No Palaces, yet have Conveniences.
What though Poetic Raptures I do want,
My Judgment's clearer than those hotter brains,
To make a Jointure out of verse and songs,
Or thirds in Oratory to endow you;
The Mean betwixt Extremes is Virtue still:
If so, then make me happy, and your self.
Courtiers may tell you that you may enjoy,
And marry pleasure, there each minutes time,
There is all freedom for the female Sex,
Though you are bound, yet feel not, you are tied,
For liberty begins when you're a Bride:
Your Husband, your Protection, and the Court,
Doth cure all jealousy, and fonder doubts,
Which there are laughed at as the greatest follies,
If not by most, yet they are thought mortal sins:
It is Heaven on Earth for Ladies that seem wise.
But you are virtuous, and those ways despise,
Therefore take me, that honour you for that.
Worthy Sir, could I persuade my Affection to listen to your sure, you should not be denied; but it is deaf or obstinate; it will neither take your counsel, nor be entreated. But since you woo so worthily, I shall esteem you honourable, as well you deserve.
Sweet Madam, I could not pass by your house for my life, but I must enter to see you, although I was here but yesterday.
Dear Madam, I am very much joyed to see you: for I am never well but in your company.
When did you see the Lady Gravity?
I have not seen her these two days.
Lord, she is the strangest Lady that ever I knew in my life, her company is so uneasy, and let me tell you as a secret, she hath a very ill Reputation.
If I thought that, I would not keep her company.
Since I heard that Report, I have shunned her company as much as I could.
Even so will I: for I would not keep any body company that I thought were not chaste for a World. But who is her servant, can you tell?
It is commonly reported Sir Henry Courtly is her servant.
Out upon him, he is the veriest Whoremaster in all the Town; nay, if she keeps him company, I will not come near her, I'll warrant you.
Nor I, although she would fain be dear with me, and seeks all the ways she can to be great with me, sending her Gentleman-Usher every day to me with a How do you.
No, pray do not be dear nor great with her, but let you and I be dear and great, and that will anger her to the heart.
That it will faith, therefore let us go to morrow together and visit her, to let her see how dear and great friends we are.
Content.
Agreed.
Lord, Sir Henry Courtly, I have not seen you these three days.
I was here yesterday, Madam, to wait upon you, but you were abroad, then I went to wait upon you my Lady Parrot, but you were also from home.
So then I had but the reversions of the Lady Minions Visit.
I can be but in one place at one time, Madam.
Why should you take it ill, Madam, that he should visit me first?
Because I know no reason but that he should visit me before you.
Why, my place is before yours.
But the love and esteem I have for him, is to be preferred before your place.
How do you know but that I have as much Affection for him as you have? And I am sure I have, and more.
Don't you believe her, Sir Henry Courtly: for faith she said but even now, that you were the veriest Whoremaster in all the Town, and cried, Out upon you.
And she said she would forbear the Lady Gravitie's company, by reason you did visit her, which was scandalou•.
What, do you betray me in your own house, when you said the same, and if I be not mistaken, before me?
If you tell what I say, I will tell what you say.
Ladies, whatsoever you have said, or will say of me, I shall take it well: for it is an honour to be mentioned by fair Ladies, although in the severest sense or manner, or sharpest words.
What, do you take her part against me?
No, no, I perceive well enough that he takes your part against me, for which he is a most unworthy man.
No, he partially takes your part, which is base.
I will assure you, Ladies, it is not my nature or disposition to de∣light in your displeasures; but my desire is to please all your Sex, and I in∣devour in my practice and behaviour to that end: wherefore, if I cannot please, it is not my fault.
So you make us Women strange creatures, as not to be pleased.
No, Madam, men want those excellent Abilities, or good For∣tunes, which should or could please you.
Faith Madam, he will have much to do to desend himself against us both.
Nay if you will join with me, we shall be too hard for him.
That I will, and help to beat him with Arguments.
For fear I should argue my self more out of your favours than I am already, I will take my leave of your Ladyships for this time.
Lady, you are the Sun of Beauty, from whence all your Sex receive a light, which without that would sit in darkness; you only give them lustre; you are the only Godess men adore, and those men which do not so, if any such men be, they are damned to censure: As for my self, La∣dies have judged me handsome, and for my persons sake have given me fa∣vours; nay, they have wooed my love with great Expenses, maintained my Vanities, and paid my Debts, ruined their own and Husbands Honour and E∣state, and all for love of me; yet do I sue to you with great Humility, though many of your Sex have courted me; and let me tell you, fair Lady, that Courtiers Wives have freer Access to Masks, Plays, Balls, and Courtly Pleasures, than other Ladies have, who beg and strive, and often are beat∣en back in rude disgrace.
All which, fair Lady, if you sum up right,
You'll find a Courtiers Wife hath most delight.
Fair Sir, could Person, Courtship, Garb, or Habit win my love, you should nor could not be denied: But since my Affection is not to be won by any outward Form, or Courtly Grace, I cannot grant your suit; be∣sides, the lives that Courtiers live, agree not with my humour: for I had rather travel to my Grave with ease, than inconveniently Progress about, ti∣ring my body out, lying in nasty lodgings, feeding on ill dressed meat that's got by scrambling; but at the best, a Courtiers life to me is most unpleasant, to sit up late at Masks and Plays, to dance my time away in Balls, to watch for Grace and favour, and receive none; to gape for Preferments, Offices, and Honours, but get none; to waste my Estate with Fees, Gifts, and Braveries, to run in debt prodigally, to receive Courtships privately, to talk loud foo∣lishly, to betray friendship secretly, to profess friendship commonly, to pro∣mise readily, to perform slowly, to slatter grossly, to be affected apishly; no Prudent Brain, or Noble Heart, would interweave the thread of life with such vain Follies, and unnecessary Troubles; besides, I had rather be Mistress of my own House, were it a Cottage poor, than serve the Gods, if Gods were like to men.
My dear Comrade, what think thou? will the Gentleman we met at Madam Gravities lodging marry me, think you?
I know not.
I verily believe he will.
What reason have you to believe he will?
A very good reason, which is, he looked upon me two or three times, and at one time very steadfastly.
If a man should marry all the women he looks on, he will have more Wives than Solomon and the great Turk, adding the number of their Concubines. But the more earnestly the Gentleman looked on you, the gre∣la sign he thought not of you: for thoughts are buried in fixed eyes.
You speak out of spite, because I am thought handsomer than you.
I had rather your Beauty should lie in your own &amp; others thoughts, than it should be visible to the view of the World, or to be inthrown on a multitude of Praises; but howoever, I am not spiteful, and therefore pray think not so for telling you my opinion of your no-lover.
You love your Jest better than your Friend.
That's an old saying; but I love a plain truth better than a flatter∣ing lye.
Madam, Madam, Madam.
Speak Sir, what is it you would say?
Madam, his Love and Modesty doth check his speech.
Then speak you for him.
Madam, your Presence, with you sparkling Eyes,
Hath dazzled him, and struck him dumb with Love;
Like to a bottle too much filled, I doubt,
Though's mouth's turned downward, nothing will come out.
Or like a Bag-pudding in love he's cursed,
So stuffed, so swelled, and yet he cannot burst:
Or like a glass with Spirits of high price,
No drop can fall when it is congealed to Ice.
Sweet Lady thaw him then, take him apart,
And then his Tongue will tell you all his Heart,
And gush it forth with more force far than those
Who dribble all their love away in Prose.
I'm all for Public Wooing, so no stain
Upon my Reputation will remain.
With a dumb Husbands curse I'll ne'er be caught,
But a dumb Wife a blessing may be thought.
And so farewell.
Sir Thomas Letgo's Mistress, that he is to marry, is a pretty Lady.
But I do not perceive he is very hasty to marry her.
If she were mine, I would not prolong my Wedding-day.
For fear she should die, and you should lose her Estate.
No, I am not covetous: for my Estate will maintain a Wife according to my quality, although she bring no Portion; and upon that condition I might have her, I would give a Portion for her, so much I like and fancy her.
And would you marry her if you might have her?
Yes.
Pray tell me, what would you do with a Fool? she would be neither good for Breed nor Conversation: for she might bring you a Race of Fools, and vex you with ignorant Follies.
Why should you think her a Fool? she neither appears fro∣ward, peevish, or spiteful; she hath a sober Face, a bashful Countenance, a natural Garb; she is silent and pensive, which shows she is no Fool; but if she were always laughing, or toying, or singing, or dancing, or simpering, or prating, or had an affected countenance, or affected garbs or postures, I should conclude her to be a Fool. But certainly she must needs have a wise Wit: for she seems melancholy and contemplative, which no fool is; she hears much, and speaks little, which no fool doth: wherefore I judge she hath Wit, but either she is careless, and cares not to express it, or thinks the company fools, and therefore will not express it, or is so bashful, as she can∣not express it; and there is nothing shows, or discovers Wit so much as Bashfulness, which shows the Mind and Thoughts so sensible, as they appre∣hend beyond another perceivance, and so fearful lest they should commit Errors in their Actions and Expressions, as they obscure their Virtues and na∣tural Excellencies, for want of a confident Assurance, and a good Opinion of their own Abilities; besides, Bashfulness thinks the least natural defect
a Crime, and every little error a Disgrace, never to be rubbed out; they will blush at their own thoughts, and will pine almost into a Consumption, if two or three idle words should slip out of their mouths, or that they should mistake an Argument, or that their Behaviour was not so or so: The truth is, they never think their Actions or their Words well enough done or spo∣ken; they are the first that shall condemn themselves, and the last that shall give themselves a pardon: But prithee Ned, as thou art my Friend, see if you can procure me, or watch for an opportunity, that I might speak with her alone.
I think that were not difficult to be done; but I will enquire a way.
Do not forget it.
No, it is so remarkable you should be in love with so simple a creature, as I shall remember it.
Madam, I should not thus presume, did not my Profession dig∣knife me to a Spiritual Office, wherefore a fit Suitor to a Divine Lady: And since my Suit is holy, by reason Marriage is sacred, despise me not.
Worthy Sir, all of your Profession require a solitary Habitati∣on for studious Contemplation to a holy life, wherein their Thoughts are Consecrated to Devotion, that their Doctrine may flow from a pure Mind, in Eloquent words, to the ears of their Flock, to instruct them with the light of Knowledge, and to lead them into the ways of Truth; whereas Marriage, although it be sacred in it self, yet it is rather apt to disturb than unite, espe∣cially a double Marriage, which are of different Natures: for there are two sorts of Marriages, as a Spiritual, and a Corporal: The first is betwixt the Gods and Mankind; the other is betwixt Man and Woman: The one is by a Consecration and Communion of Spirits, the other is by a Com∣bination and Communication of Persons; wherefore those that are married to Jove, ought to keep themselves pure in that Unity: As for the marriage of Combination and Communication of Persons, although it is requisite for the continuance of Mankind, and civil Commonwealths, yet to spiritual Eel∣vations is is a great hinderance: for though a woman, especially a Wife, be accounted as a Helper and Comfort to man by her diligent attendance, and loving service, yet women are accounted not only unprofitable in learned Schools, but obstructers to a studious life, for which women are not suffered to inhabit in Universities, Schools, or Colleges; indeed we are in a manner banished from the sight or entrance thereinto, and men have reason so to do; since learning, especially Divine learning, requires study, and study requires a quiet, solitary, and silent life; and certainly there can be neither solitariness
nor silence where women and children are: for Nature hath made women and children to have restless spirits, unquiet minds, busiless active, and such voluble tongues, as it is impossible they should be silent, whilst life gives them motion; so that a woman is a very unfit companion for Contempla∣tions, wherein there should be no other company but thoughts, which thoughts in a Divine, should be only such as are the Inquirers and Searchers of Ioves divine Mysteries, and Scholars to Ioves divine Schools, and Orators to explain &amp; plead in Ioves divine Laws, and servants to Ioves divine Or∣ders, that they may be Instructors and Intelligencers of Ioves divine Com∣mands: And though women ought to be instructed in Divinity, yet for the most part, women are obstructers and disturbers of Divinity and Divines; besides, the Original Woman was a Tempter to Sin, which all her Effemi∣nate Posterity inherit as a Natural Right and Gift from their great Grand∣mother: And though Divines ought to be industrious to cut off the Entail of that Original Inheritance with their holy Doctrine, quenching the fire of Temptation with the spiritual dew of Divine Instructions, yet ought they not to run themselves into that fire they should quench, serving as fuel to in∣crease it: Wherefore those that dedicate themselves to Ioves Church, ought to live separated from Natures daughters, lest they should yield to hue∣mane frailties, and become slaves to the Effeminate Temptations.
Friend, I am come to ask thy counsel.
Concerning what?
Concerning Marriage.
I will give you the best I can; but it is both difficult and dangerous to give counsel in so weighty a Concernment as Marriage.
You say very true; and being so weighty a Concernment as you say, I am come for thy Advice, not trusting to my own judgment, and thus it is: There is a Gentleman that hath come two or three times thorough out street, and the last time he came, he looked up to my Chamber-window; wherefore I conceive he will come a wooing to me, therefore I desire thee to instruct me how I shall receive his Addresses.
Do you know who he is?
No.
Nor where he dwells?
No.
Nor from whence he came, nor whither he will go?
No.
What makes you think he will be a Suitor to you then?
Because he comes so often thorough our street, and by our door, and hath looked up to my Chamber-window; and these are sufficient Rea∣sons to believe it: for you may be sure he comes thorough our street for my sake.
Truly I know not what counsel to give you; but as occasion shall offer it self, I shall think of you.
Prithee do; but I am in haste, and therefore cannot stay with you any longer: wherefore farewell.
O my sweet Parley, I was told thou were •ot at Home, and I have been at all my Acquaintances Louses to seek thee out, to tell thee a secret.
What secret?
Why there hath been a Gentleman this day at my Fathers house, to Treat with my Father about marrying me; and when I marry, I'll bid thee to my Wedding.
You must bid me before you are married, if you will invite me to your Wedding.
Yes so I will, I'll warrant thee: for I will not forget thee of all my Acquaintance: But prithee tell me what my Wedding-Gown shall be of.
Of white Satin, or cloth of Silver. But of what quality is the per∣son whom you shall marry?
I cannot tell.
What Estate hath he?
I know not.
How often hath he been with your Father?
He never was with my Father before this morning.
Hath your Father concluded the match with him?
I cannot tell.
Hath your Father spoke to you of him?
No.
Then how came you to know he came to Treat of Marriage?
My Fathers man told me he thought the Gentleman came about such a business, because my Father and he were very earnest in their Dis∣course, and in private.
If you know no more, perchance it is about some other bu∣siness.
It cannot be about any thing else, because they were earnest and private.
Perchance it was about borrowing of money, and borrowers use to be earnest, and desire their desires may not be known: wherefore they draw aside, and whisper out their wants.
No, no, I am confident it was about me.
I wish you may do well.
I thank thee for thy good wishes, and I hope he will prove a good Husband.
Madam, although there is a certain and set Form of making Deeds, Wills, and Leafes, and a Form of Marriage, yet I know no cer∣tain nor set form of VVooing, but every one woos after what manner or form he pleases or thinks best, having no set rules to woo by: But I am come here to woo, and so to plead my own cause at the Bar of Affection, and you, as the Judge, are to give the Sentence, and to determine the Suit: But as all other Judges are to be free from partiality, or self-interest, as neither to be oversw•yd with either fear, pity, love, or covetousness, or the like; yet such a Judge as you, and in the like Causes as mine, may have the freedom of partiality or self-interest: wherefore, if no other plea can persuade you, take me for pity: for I am miserably in Love, manacled in Cupids Fetters, bound with his Bow-strings, and wounded with his golden Arrows, from which nothing but your favour and compassionate sentence can release me, otherwise I must lie under the Arrest of a wretched life, till such time as Death set me free, or cast me into Oblivion.
Worthy Sir, as there is no certain nor set form of wooing, so there is no certain nor set form for the wooed to give a direct Answer: And though pity may move a Judge to give a favourable sentence, yet there is no Judge will, or ought to make himself a slave, to set a prisoner free; but if such a chance should be, it must be by a stronger motive or passion than pi∣tie, to make them yield up their liberty: And Marriage is a bondage, especi∣ally when as Sympathy doth not match the pair; and if Cupped hath won∣ded you with his golden Arrows, he hath shot me with those that are head∣ed with lead, from which wounds proceed nothing but cold denials: But howsoever I shall give you part of your desires, which is, I shall pity you, although I cannot persuade my Affections to love you so much as to consent to marry you.
Husband I hear you have a Mistress, but I do not wonder at it, for you have taught me (although not by the former, yet by your present practice) to foresee the future event. First, our loves have grown to their full maturity, and therefore in Nature, as Vegetables, must shed their leaves, or like Animals, at such a growth their strength decays, and in old age dyes; thus we may guess by Natures Revolution, the revolution of our love, though at first we could not dream, but we must discover our dreams to each other, and whatsoever we had heard or seen in each others
absence, when we met, we recounted to each other each object, and repeat∣ed each subject and discourses that our Senses had presented to our know∣ledge; and not only what our Senses had presented, but what our Cons∣caption had conceived, or our Imaginations had created: Also we took de∣light to confer in our Household Affairs, and we were unquiet, uneasy, and restless, until we met, and had discoursed thus unto each other; and if ei∣there of us had been sick, or had perceived the least distemper in each others health, our grief was expressed by our tears, and by our sighs, which from our Hearts did rise, and flowed with grief, which poured through our eyes. But now we begin to cast shadows of dissimulation, which shows our love is in an Eclipse, and from a pretence of the confidence and assurance we have of each other, we begin to be careless of each others discourse or action, giving our selves freedom and liberty to wander, not only from our Home-affairs, but from our professed Affections, to seek for pleasures and delights a∣broad, and only a seeming affection and delight remains at home: And thus by a juggling deceit, and false-glac'd love, we shall in the discovery become enemies, and by a seeming wisdom, we shall become fools, and our follies, as well as our crimes, will destroy the unity of Love, and the peace of Ma∣trimonial Government; And though we should not break out into open War, yet we shall live factious, and our servants will be as Commoners, si∣ding with each Party: But it seems your Mistress hath learned your mind so perfectly, and knows your humour so exactly, and can match your appetites with pleasure so justly, as she hath worked out her designs skilfully, which is, to displace me, and to place her self in your Affections, by which she can make a subtle advantage of your Estate and Fortune, I mean good Fortune: for in bad Fortune she may chance; nay, it is most likely she will desert you for those that will and do forsake Virtue, Chastity, and Honour, are not likely to stick to misfortunes, as to follow Banishment, or to live with Pover∣tie, to bear injury, to endure Scorn, and to die in Misery. True Love may do it; but for those Affections that are produced by Incontinence, and not bound to Honesty, and settled by Constancy, will change more often than the wind, wavering from person to person.
Wife, I confess the Amorous Addresses I have made to other Women; but though I have strayed in my Actions, yet not in my Affecti∣once: for my love is unalterably constant to you, as believing you are unat∣terribly virtuous, and I do not only love your Chastity, prize your Virtue, honour your noble Soul and sweet Disposition, but I take delight in your Wit, am pleased with your Humours, admire your Beauty, and esteem and be∣lieve you to be the most perfect and best of your Sex. But Wife, know, that my Appetites, and not my Affections, seek after variety: for the kissing of a Mistress lessens not the Love to a Wife, but rather increases it, comp∣ring the falseness and beastliness of the one, to the Virtue and Purity of the other.
And shall my Virtue and Chastity be only rewarded with your good Opinion?
Virtue, Wife, is a sufficient Reward in it self, and the Chastity of your Sex is crowned with Honour; but the Reward I give you, is the free use as a Co-partner of my Estate, and the Mistress of my Family: Besides, I make you the chief care of my Industry, the chief subject or object of my Valour, the Treasure of my Life, the only Possessor of my Heart, and for your sake I shall neither refuse Death or Torment. Thus you are the Soul of
my Soul; and since you have my whole soul to you self, you may be well contented to lend my person to your Neighbours Wife, Daughter, Sister, Niece, or Maid.
And will you be contented that I shall likewise borrow of your Neighbour?
No Wife: for you can neither lend nor borrow without the loss of Honour.
Nay, rather than lose so great a loss as Honour, I'll strive to be content, Husband.
Do you so, Wife, and I will strive and endeavour to be contented with my own Wife.
Madam, although I cannot Woo in Eloquent Orations, or Courtly Solicitations, or Learned Definitions, being only bred to In∣industrious actions, thrifty savings, gainful gettings, to enrich me with worldly wealth, and not to studious Contemplations, Poetical Fictions, Divine Eel∣vations, Philosophical Observations, State-Politicians, School-contradicti∣once, Laws Intrications, by which (perchance) I might have gained Fame, but not Wealth: But Fame neither clothes the naked, nor feeds the hungry, nor helps the distressed, neither doth it maintain a Wife in Brave∣rye, where, if you will be mine, you shall sit in a shop all furnished with gold, and great sums shall be brought you for exchange of my Wares; and while you sit in my shop, all street-passengers will stand and gaze on your Beauty, and Customers will increase, and be prodigal to buy, whilst you sell, not for the use of what they buy, but for the delight to buy what you sell; besides, of all saleable curiosities &amp; varieties that are brought to the City, you shall have the first offer, and the first fruits and meats each Season doth pro∣duce, shall be served to your taste; your clothes, though of the City-fashion, yet they shall rich and costly be; besides, to every Feast the City and each Citizen doth make, they will invite you, and place you as their chiefest guest; and when you by your Neighbours doors do pass, their Prentice-boys and Journey-men will leave their shop-boards, and run to view you as you go. Thus shall you live, if you will be mine, in Plenty, Luxury, Pride, and Ease.
Rich Sir, I may sit in your shop, and draw Customers, but shall get no honour by them; I may sell your Wares, but lose my Reputation; I may be adored, worshipped, sought and prayed to, as for and to a Mistress,
but shall never be counted as a Saint; I may be rich in wealth, but poor of the Worlds good Opinion; I may be adorned with silver and gold, but ble∣meshed with censure and slander; I may feed on luxurious Plenty, yet my good name starve for want of a good Fame: for a Citizens Wife is seldom thought chaste, and the men for the most part accounted Cuckolds. I know not whether it be a Judgment from Heaven for their Cozening, or decreed by the Fates for their Covetousness, or bred by a natural Effect of their Lu∣xury, which begets an Appetite to Wantonness; but from what cause so∣ver it comes, so it is: wherefore I will never be a Citizens Wife, though truly I do verily believe there are as many virtuous and chaste women, and understanding men that belong to the City, as in the Country; and were it not for the Citizens wealth, more Ancient Families would be buried in poverty than there hath been, where many times a rich City-widow, or daughter, gives a dead Family a new Resurrection: wherefore, it is more prudent for men to marry into the City, than it is advantageous for women, especially such women that esteem a pure Reputation before wealth, and had rather live in poverty, than be mistrusted for dishonesty.
Madam, although I cannot draw a Line of Pedigree from Gen∣tility, yet I can draw a Line of Peasantry five hundred years in length; and if Antiquity is to be esteemed, my Birth is not to be despised: As for my wealth, I am not poor, but rich for my degree and quality; and though it is not sit I should maintain my Wife in silver and gold, yet I may maintain her with plenty and with store, cloth her in fine smooth soft cloth, spun from the fleeces of my Flocks: But if you will be mine, you shall be crowned with Garlands made of Lilies, Roses, Violets, Pinks, and Daffidillies, and be as Queen of all these Downs, where all the Shepherds and Shepherdesses shall give you homage, and worship you as Godess of the Plains, bringing you Offerings of their mornings Milk, their Butter, Curds, and soft pressed Cheese, and various Fruits fresh gathered off their Trees; also my Kids and Lambs shall sport and play, and taught to know your voice, and to obey, and every Holiday you shall in Arbors sit, shadowed from hot Sun-beams, whilst Country Maids and Country Men which Lovers are, shall dance up∣on the grassy Green to the sound of the Horn-pipe, Bag-pipe, and such brea∣thing Music, whose pleasant Strains, and plain-set Notes, rebound in Echoes from the high-cast Banks, the lofty Hills, hollow Woods, and murmuring Streams, besides other Rural sports, to entertain your Eyes and Ears, and recreate your Mind with Mirth and harmless Plays, to pass your Time withal.
No life so pleasant as the Country Life,
No woman so happy as the Farmers Wife.
Honest Friend, could I as easily persuade my Affections to your Person, as I could to the condition of a Shepherdesses life, or Farmers wife, you should be the only man I would choose; but since I cannot, I must on∣lie return you thanks for your good liking, in that you have preferred me in your choice, for which, may neither nipping Frost, nor burning Sun, nor bla∣sting winds, nor weeds, nor snails, nor worms destroy your Labours, nor ra∣venous
Wolves, nor crafty Foxes nor Polcats, Weasels, Kites, or any such like Vermin, fright or rob you of your young &amp; tender breed; may all your grounds and flocks increase a treble-fold, your fleeces long and thick, your corn firm and full-car'd, your grass sweet and broad-bladed, your trees so full of fruits, that every branch may bow under its load; and may your plen∣tie store all the Kingdom, that neither want nor famine may be feared or felt; may all your Country Neighbours, and labouring Swains, respect you as their Chief, obey you as their Lord, and worship you as their God Pan.
Lady, you are in a serious Contemplation. Pray what are you thinking of?
I have heard that thoughts are free; but I perceive they cannot pass without questioning.
I would not boldly intrude upon them, my humble desire is I might partake of the Excellence of them.
I suppose you think my Contemplation is of Heaven, and not of the World: for there is no subject which can make Thought excellent, but what is Divine: for the World corrupts them, Nature deceives them, and Speech betrays them.
If your speech never betrays more than it doth now, which only expresses your Wit, you may well pardon it; but I now find you are not so ignorantly simple as you are thought to be through your si∣lence.
I confess I have practised silence: for I am of years fitter to learn than to talk; and I had rather be thought ignorantly simple for being silent, than to express folly by too much speaking.
But I wonder you will suffer you self to be laughed at for a Natu∣ral Fool, when your wit is able to defend you from scorns and scoffs, and is able to maintain its own Arguments.
If I had Wit, there would be no Honour in the Arguing, no more than for a Valiant man to fight with Cowards; so wit to dispute with fools: But I had rather they should laugh at me, than I should weep for my self; yet there were none in that company that laughed at me, but were older than I, and the older they are, the more faults they have committed; and if they laugh at me for my little wit, I will scorn them for their many faults, and hate them for their vices.
The truth is, it is only fools that commit many faults, and take de∣light in their own follies, and do themselves hurt with their own errors; and not those that have Wit: for they have Ingenuity and Prudence to foresee, and so escape errors, and the mischiefs that may follow: But you appear,
by not expressing your self, to your disadvantage, and your silence doth you wrong.
I care not how I appear in my outward Aspect, so my Life be ho∣nest, my Actions just, my Behaviour modest, my Thoughts pure, and that I obey to the utmost of my power the Laws and Customs of Duty, Morality, Divinity, and Civility. But it is a sign of a foolish Age, when silence is thought ignorant simplicicitie, and modesty accounted a crime; when in Ancient Times Youth was taught sober Attention, and it was imposed upon Scholars to keep silence five years before they were suffered to speak, that they might afterwards be able to Teach, and not always live to learn as School-boys, which they would always be, if they spent their time in words, and not stu∣die and observe: And silence is a discretion that few women practise, being more apt to talk than men; for women are fuller of words than thoughts: but words should be weighed by Judgment, in the balance or scales of Sense, and delivered by the tongue through the lips by Retail, which cannot be if they throw them out so fast: for there is required Reason, Time, and Understanding, besides unstopped Ears to hear them: But though mine En∣mies laugh at me for a Fool, yet I have so much Honesty, Innocence, and Modesty, to guard and defend my Reputation, as they cannot wound that with their sharp words, nor laughing faces.
