Lady, I come not now to plead with flourishing Rhetoric, to make that which is false to appear like truth, or paint a foul cause with fair smooth words: But my cause of request is honest, and what I shall speak is truth; nor do I strive to hide my Deformities or Vices: As for my outward deformities, they are visible to your Eyes; but Vices live in the Appetites, Passions, and Affections, which are only expressed by the Actions, and therefore the easier may be dissembled from the most part of the World, yet not from Heaven, to whom I am to make a just account: And since my sins are only to the Gods, and not you, fair Godess, I shall not at this time make a public confession of them; but I am come here to present you with my love, which love is as pure as unspotted Angels, it hath no by-respects unto your Wealth, Beauty, or Birth, but barely and merely to your Virtue: in truth I come a wooing to your Soul, not to your Body, but yet mi∣stake me not, I would not have them parted. I cannot say my Estate or Birth deserves you, nor have I merits equal to your worth; but since my love is as pure as your virtue, it will be an equal Match: And though you see my body a deformed bulk, yet I am not ashamed of it, because the owner, which
is my Mind, is honest: for I never betrayed my King, or Country, Mistress, or Friend, nor any Trust that was imposed unto me by any, although a Foe; I never shut my purse, nor sheathed my sword from helping the distressed, nor turned my back upon my assaulting Enemy; I never stole good Fame, nor robed good Names, nor stabbed Innocence with slander; I never scorned those below my self, nor envied those above me; I never infringed the Laws of Honour, nor disturbed civil Society; and though I cannot suffer an injury patiently, yet I never did omit a duty willingly: As for the truth of what I say, I have none to witness for me, as being a stranger, but my own words, from which this company (perchance) may think self-love and great desire hath bribed my Tongue; but if they do, their thoughts make Truth no less, no more than Eyes that are blind, Ears that are deaf, can rob you of your Wit and Beauty: for though your Wit they do not hear, nor Beauty see, yet you passess them no less, their want only robs you of their Admiration, not of the Possession; and say I am blind of one eye, my other eye doth see, and I have Hearing perfectly, which doth inform my Knowledge and Under∣standing, with that which makes my Admirations and Adorations perfect and sound within my Heart, wherein your Picture is printed on, which my Soul doth view, and gazing, kneels with wonder and astonishment, that so much Wit, Wisdom, and Virtue should be in one so young &amp; fair: And if you cannot love me, despise me not; for my pure Love is Divine, as being divinely placed on you; and it would grieve my Soul, to have the zealous fire and immaculate flame of my Affection extinguished with your neglect∣ing Thoughts, and raked up in the ashes of your Forgetfulness: But if any of my Sex shall seem to jest, or scorn me for my outward form or shape,
My Courage and my Sword shall take my bodies part,
To cut their Limbs, or thrust them through their Heart.
Worthy Sir, you must excuse me from answering you at this time: for I am taken on the sudden very sick.
I wish you health, although it were to be only purchased by my death.
What is the cause you weep?
Because my Father will not get me a Husband, and Mistress Fondly will have a Husband before I shall have one: for I hear she is to be married, she is happier in her Parents than I am: for my Parents are unnatu∣ral, and take no care how to get me a Husband, and to see me married.
You may marry soon enough to repent.
I am sure I shall not repent: for to be a Wife, is a condition I am most desirous of, and cannot be happy any other way.
And Wives think Maids only happy, because they are not vexed nor troubled with a Husband.
Such women deserve no Husbands: for certainly a Husband is a joy and a comfort, as being a companion and a friend.
But Husbands seldom keep in the company of their Wives, and many times, instead of a friend, prove an enemy.
What, have you been at Mistress Fondly's House?
Yes.
And have you inquired of her Maid as I bid you, whether the Re∣port is true, that her Mistress is to be married?
Yes.
And what said she?
She said that a Gentleman did Treat with her Mistresses Father, but they could not agree: for the Gentleman would have more portion than her Father would give, whereupon the Match is broke off.
I am glad of that: for I would not have her married before me for all the World. But did you not see mistress Fondly?
No: for her Maid said her Mistress, at the breaking off her Mari∣age, almost broke her heart: for she hath so afflicted her self, and hath so wept and sighed, as she is fallen sick, and keeps her Chamber.
Alas good Friend, I pity her extremely, but I will go with her, and try if I can comfort her.
Noble Sir, the Wit wherewith Nature, Time, and Education hath endued my tender brains, is like new kindled fire, that sparkling flies about, the fuel being green, and newly laid to burn, there is more smoke than flame: But since the time I heard you speak, a newer fire is kindled in my Heart, which equally doth burn with your professed Affections; and though your Person is none of Natures exactest Pieces, yet your Mind doth seem to be composed with all her best Ingredients; and sure your Thoughts set notes of Honour, Honestly, and Love, by which your Tongue plays Harmony. It is not the satin Skin, that's painted white and red, nor near-carv'd Bodies, can win my Love, nor Wealth, Titles, Birth, nor crowned Power; but Truth, Sincerity, Constancy, Justice, Prudence, Courage, and Temperance, by which, as Magistrates, your life seems to be governed, which life I wish the Gods may Crown with happy days, and in Fems Tower long live your praise. I will not ask you from whence you came, nor what you are: For though you seem but poor and mean, Your Soul appears to me sublime.
And will you choose me for your Husband, Lady?
I shall be proud to be your Wife, Sir.
The Gods are just to my pure Love, rewarding it with your ac∣ceptance; but I must beg your leave for some short time of Absence, and then I shall return, and claim your Promise.
You have the liberty, Sir.
Lady, surely you are in a High Fever.
Why, Madam?
As to do so extravagant an Action, as to marry a man you know not what he is, nor from whence he came, and may prove as deformed in Mind as in Body, as mean of Birth, as poor in Parse, as beggars that live on cold dry Charity.
If he be poor, my Estate will make him rich; if humbly born, his Merits make him Honourable; from whence he comes I do not care, and where he will have me go, I will wait upon him, never questioning to what place.
Her Courage is beyond her Wit.
For the Example of this Lady, I would have a Law made, that there should be no more Public Wooing.
She hath cast away her self.
Who can help it?
Lady, why seem you so melancholy?
My melancholy disposition is apt to catch hold on my e∣vile Fortunes, and both joining together, help to multiply my sad thoughts.
Why should you be sad?
How can I be merry, when I am left destitute of Friends, and unac∣quainted with Experience.
Nature hath furnished you with all store, you need none.
If she had, yet all the good seeds that Nature and Education hath sown in me, and sprouted forth in bud, are nipped with Misfortunes, withered with Sorrows, blasted with Sighs, and drowned in Tears.
For what?
For being enslaved unto an unworthy person, who neither loves Fire∣tu, nor values Honour, but laughs at my youth, and flings scorns on my In∣nocency, which makes me almost murmur at Heaven, and apt to think the
Gods unjust, to let Fortune betray me to Power and Tyranny.
Trouble not your self: for certainly your bondage may be taken off, if it be discreetly handled: for he seems willing to part with you upon easy terms; for you heard him offer to sell you.
I wish I were worth your Purchase.
Would you willingly change him for me?
I cannot be worse; and you seem so noble a person, as persuades me to hope I may be happy.
And if I had the whole World, I would give it for you, rather than not have you; and I should think my self more enriched by the enjoy∣meant, than if the Gods made new Worlds to present me.
I have heard Heaven protects the Innocent, defends the Harm∣less, and provides for the Helpless; which if it doth, the Gods will give me you.
Ha, ha, ha, Is this the young wife Lady that all the World ad∣mired for her Prudence and Judgment?
Faith her Judgment hath erred in her choice.
I am glad: for now I may marry to whom I will, for I cannot choose worse; and my Father and Mother did bid me, nay charged me to imitate her.
So did mine.
And mine.
Well, for my part I rejoice: for now we shall have the old way of Wooing again, to embrace and kiss in corners, to hear amorous and wan∣son discourse.
That way of wooing is best.
You say true: for I hate this way of wooing, there is no plea∣sure in it:
No 'saith, to stand gazing and prating a mile asunder.
You make short miles.
Why, two inches is a Lovers mile, and three a long league.
It was not likely she should choose well, or ever be happily mar∣ried.
Why so?
By reason she was cursed by all the maids, back-holders, widows and widowers in the Town.
But she had the prayers of all the married women.
But she had the curses of all the married men: for they crowd in amongst the back-holders sometimes.
Sweet Madam, you are the Godess which my Thoughts adore,
You flatter.
Love cannot flatter: for Lovers think all their praises truth.
The Lady Mute is your Godess.
If there were no other Godess of your Sex but she, I should become an Insidel to love, nay an Atheist, believing there were no such De∣ity as Love.
Madam, all the Town condemns you.
And do you condemn me too?
No, Madam: for I am bound, as being your servant, to submit to your will, liking, and pleasure.
Why, the choice is honest: for they may swear I am not ena∣mored with his Person: But had he been a fair Youth, or known to be a debanch'd Man, they might have justly condemned me, either for my fond Affection and amorous Love, or wilde Choice.
Faith they may thiak your Choice is wilde, by reason you have chosen out of a Labyrinth, not knowing where his beginning or end is.
Why Virtue is the Beginning, and Happiness, I hope, will be the End.
I wish it may prove so Madam.
But pray tell me, Did you ever hear me speak worse than I did to him?
How do you mean, Madam, in that you gave your self away?
No, in that I did not present my self more Eloquently.
Methought your Speech did not flow so smooth as it was used to do, as if your Tongue did know you did commit a fault in granting to his Suit.
No truly; for my desire did out-run my speech: for desiring to speak best to him I loved most, obstructed my Tongue, which made my words run unevenly.
That's a common misfortune: for when any one strives to speak wisely, they most often speak foolishly.
It is true; for strife is an enemy to speech: for those that speak not free and easy, never speak well.
For when as Passion wrestles with the Tongue,
The Sense is weak, and down the words are slung,
It is strange the Lady Prudence, that is so beautiful, rich, and nobly born, and hath so great a wit, should choose a man so poor and mean, and so ill-favour'd.
In my opinion it is not strange: for certainly there is a sympathy between the spirits of virtuous souls, which begets love, although in de∣formed persons: And this is the true Love; for that which proceeds from Covetousness, or Ambition, or is produced by the Senses, is rather an Ap∣petite, which is apt to surfeit, or dies as soon as enjoyed, or turns with For∣tunes wheel.
Well, I wish for the Ladies sake, who is known to be Virtue∣os, her Husband may prove as Virtuous as she.
Ladies, do you hear the News?
What News?
Why Mistress Simple is gone very early this morning out of Town with Sir Anthony Gosling; and it is said they will be married before they return.
I cannot believe it: for she was the most unlikely to be married of any of us all.
I perceive that Maid that can have Fortune to be her friend, shall not want a Husband.
You say true; and Fortune is a better friend than our Parents are: for our Parents are contented we should live Maids all the time of our lives, when Fortune (most commonly) gives Maids Husbands at one time or other.
Ladies, why do you complain of your Parents for their wary care? who would not have you marry, but to such Husbands as you may be happy withal, and therefore are cautious how to choose, when Fortune makes Matches at Random.
I had rather marry at Random, than not marry at all.
Why then (perchance) in stead of a worthy person, you may marry a base fellow; and in stead of a rich husband, a beggar.
Those women that are curious in their Choice, may chance to die old Maids.
It is better to die an old Maid, than to live a miserable life, which will be, if an unhappy Wife.
There is no misery like being an old Maid.
O that I were so happy once to be a wedded Wife,
I would fulfil my Husbands will all the days of my life.
I doubt I may sing the Song that says,
O pity take upon me now some gentle Body,
And give me the Willow-Branch, for no man will have me.
And I may sing this old Song.
I wander up and down,
And no body cares for me:
Although I be but poor and brown,
Yet constant will I be.
And I may sing this old Ballad.
Every Bird can choose his Mate,
The Wren can do the same,
The Fish and Fowl their pleasures take,
They follow after Game.
But I, poor I, poor silly I,
Do sigh and sorrow still,
Yea night and day I wear away,
Wanting my wished will.
Come, come, Ladies, you are all so desirous to marry, and so impatient because you are not married, as I doubt when you are married, your Husbands may sing the Song of Cuckolds all a row.
It were better for us that our Husbands should be Cuckolds, than we lead Apes in Hell.
Why do you weep, Madam?
Have I not reason, when one I chose for Honesty proves false, and publicly strives for to disgrace me, by breaking of his Promise, and Ap∣pointed day of Marriage?
Perchance he could not come, some Accident hath hindered him.
He might have sent me word the reason of his stay.
It is likely he is not so rich, as to hire a Messenger.
Some would have done it for Charity.
Faith Charity is lazy, and will not go without Reward.
If he had loved Me or Honour, he would have found some means or ways.
My Virtuous sweet Mistress, what makes such showrs of Tears in Sun-shine Eyes?
O Sir, I thought you had forsaken me, and left me to the Worlds wilde scorn.
I should sooner forsake Life, Fame, and Heaven, than forsake you.
Will you have your Friends to your Wedding, Mistress?
If you please, Sir: for I am not ashamed of my Choice, nor shall I be ashamed of my Marriage.
Nor I, of my self; and for you, the Gods may envy me.
Shall we go to visit Mistress Simple? she that is now my Lady Gos∣ling, and bid her joy.
Yes, if you will: for I long to see how she looks, now she is a Wife.
So do I, and to see how she behaves her self, since she is married.
She is now, Ladies, for the conversation of Wives, and not for the society of Maids; her discourse will be now of Household Affairs, as of Housewifery, and of her Husband, and of Children, and hired servants, and not Suitors and Courtiers, not Fashions, nor Dressings; neither will she re∣turn your Visits: for her Visitings will be to other married Wives, and her time will be spent at Labours, Christenings, Churchings, and other Matri∣monial Gossippings and Meetings.
Howsoever we will go visit her.
I wish we may see her Husband with her, to see if he be kind to her, or not.
If he be not kind to her, and hath been married but two or three days, he will never be kind.
I wonder whether he will kiss her when we are by.
Yes certainly: for new-maried men and their wives take a pleasure to kiss before company.
Hey ho, that married Wives should have such pleasures, when Maids have none.
O unfortunate villain! that I should be such a Coxcomb, such a Fool, to lose five thousand pounds at Dice! Those bones spotted with the small Pox, the great Pox take them for me, and the Plague to boot: for they have plagued me, and yet I have not a token left about me.
You may borrow more.
Borrow, you Puppy, you, my land's entailed, a perpetuity, I have nothing but for life, like a Serving-mans Annuity, or an old Ladies Jointure, no body will lend me any thing; and now I must eat grass and hay: for we are all mortal they say, and they choke me with that. Pox of my Grand∣fathers and Fathers provident Wisdoms, with their learned Counsels in the Law; but I hope all their souls fry in Hell for it, that's my com∣fort.
It is a hard case, that a young Gentleman cannot undo himself for those Fetters and Bonds of Parchment; truly it is cruel.
I, is it not Jack, to be tied thus, like a dog to a cup-board, and in chains too, that he cannot gnaw or bite them asunder?
Faith Sir, it is a strange thing, that a man should venture to play his money, whether it should be his or another mans.
No Dick, you are deceived, I play whether his money should be mine or his. O unfortunate Rogue that I am! and that foolish Star-gazer, the Astrologer, never to see it in my Nativity neither when he cast it! Those Knaves and Fools, to talk of things that they have no guess at what they are, as if the seven Planets, or the twelve Houses, had to do with a cast of Dice, a sine nimble Cheater is worth a thousand of them. Rogue that I am! And now comes in such a consideration into my brain upon my Re∣pentance.
As how pray?
As how? why if I had this current running money, nay rather, it hath wings, and flies beyond the Fiction of Pegasus: why, if I had it, how I would bestow it for the good of the Common-wealth, as thus: What rich Apparel, with Embroideries of gold, and silver, and silk? what Feathers and Mistresses? what gilt Paris Coaches, Pages, and Lackeys, sa•s number, in rich liveries? what Coachmen, Pos•ilions, with six Flanders Horses, to strike with amazement the whole street as I pass? what running Horses, Hounds, Hawks, Cocks, Greyhounds? what delicious Banquets, Spanish Perfumes, most odoriferous, soft Music, that should lull the soul asleep, sumptuous Furnitures, so as I would surfeit the Senses, and make the seven Deadly Sins live like Princes?
And set up Sin and Vanity to the hight,
Since those are still the Gentlemen's delight.
But O my money is gone, which cuts off all my hopes of exercising all those virtuous ways! well, let me cogitate, and boy, give me a melancholy Pipe to cloud all hopes of joys with sadder thoughts.
Truly it is pity he hath lost his money: for you hear how Religi∣ously he would have spent it.
Most like a Gentleman, I must needs say that for him.
Most piously indeed; but prithee let us walk for a while, lest we should disturb his Thoughts: no more Discourse, but let us tie our Tongues.
Content, till his be loose.
What Contemplation now?
Pious and charitable ones. But this damned money, this runnagado, this vagabond money!
But if you had a statute to whip her home to her own Parish, it would do well.
I Jack, but there is no such law, the more the pity; but this oboe∣minable money disorders all the World. What work makes it betwixt Pa∣rents and Children, Husbands and Wives, Brothers and Sisters, Masters and Servants, Landlords and Tenants, Citizens and their Prentices, Mistresses and their Maids, and between Kings and their subject? Corrupts all the World, breaks Friendship, betrays Friends, raises Rebellions, commits Treason, and corrupts Virgins: It is the Pander and Bawd to all business; the States-man is fed by this damned Lady Pecunia, the Lawyer serves her, the Merchants her slave, the Shop-keeper her vassal, and the Countryman her Tenant, Lords and Ladies her pensioners, and greatest Monarchs pay tribute to her; the Logician argues for her, the Orator pleads for her, and many Ecclesiasticals preach for her, the Vicar General and his Conclave are ruled by her, and the poor Poet, she draws his copperas from his ink, and makes him flatter her. This horrid Lady Sorceress, so to bewitch the World! Is there no law a∣against this Enchantress, that thus doth still abuse the World, and all that's in it? The very Soldiers sword is charmed by her, and all his guns are si∣lent at her presence. This she-devil!
But I would you had your she-devil again for all that: But what Pious and Charitable Consideration had you, if you had your money again?
Marry Sir, First I would build an Hospital for decayed Ladies that were maimed in Venus's wars, losing a nose, or so, never yet any care taken of them, the more is the pity.
Very good: and what next?
Next I would buy such a piece of ground, and build a Bedlam, and then put in all such Divines as preach themselves out of their power and riches; and I would put all such Lawyers in, as pleaded themselves out of pra∣ctice; and all such Citizens as petitioned themselves out of trade.
These are good and pious Acts: But would not you provide a place or means for such as were undone by playing at Dice and Cards, and the like.
No, they should have only Fools Coats to be known by, and I would be the Master of them.
How doth your Husband, Madam?
I hope he's well, he's gone abroad.
You look pale since you were married.
I was not very well this morning: for I could not eat my Break∣fast; truly I have lost my stomach since I have been married.
Perchance you are breeding.
Oh sie, no surely; but yet my Maid laughs, and tells me I am.
I hope, Lady, you are not breeding already? for you have not been married above three days.
I have heard that some have been with Child as soon as they were married; and my Maid told me she served a Mistress, who, the next day she was married was with Child.
By my Faith that was very soon.
Me thinks it is strange to see you have a Wedding-ring on your Thumb.
You will come to wear a Wedding-ring on your Thumb one of these days.
What is the Posy?
I like too well to change.
It is well you do: for if you did not, you could hardly change, un∣less your Husband dies.
Heaven forbid: for I would not have him die for all the World; for he is one of the lovingest and fondest Husbands that ever was.
The first Month is a fond Month, Lady.
And are you fond of him?
Yes truly: for I hang about his neck when he is at home.
But you will weary your Husband, Lady, if you hang a long time.
I would very sain you did see my Husband.
We much desire so to do.
Is your Master, Sir Anthony Gossing, come home yet?
No, Madam.
In truth he is too blame to stay out so long, knowing I am not well when he is away.
Are you sick in his absence?
I am best pleased when he is with me.
New-maried Wives are always so; but after they have been married some time, they are worst pleased when their Husbands are with them.
Me thinks it is a strange sight to see such a Bride, and such a Bridegroom. I do imagine them to be like Pluto and Proserpine.
Nay rather, they are like Venus and Vulcan.
But she is too chaste to entertain a Mars to Cuckold him.
It is to be hoped she will take her liberty with variety: for extra∣vagant love is seldom constant.
If that rule prove true, he may be a Cuckold indeed.
It is likely he will: for women choose to marry such deformed men a purpose; first to excuse their fault, thinking the World will never con∣damn them, their Husbands being ill-favour'dly misshapen, or thinking their Husbands will be well content, knowing their own infirmities, to be a sharer.
But I wonder she did not new-cloath him: for though he is not so rich to buy himself a Wedding-Suit, yet she hath means enough to buy him many several suits, and rich.
There was no time to make him Wedding-cloaths, because he came not till his Wedding-day.
Well, let us go see them married, and wish them joy.
Since my losses, I have such a desire of Revenge, as my fingers itch to be at it, and the Palsy is in my eldow with the imagination of throw∣ing those partial bones, called by the Vulgar, Dice; they say they are square fellows, but I doubt it: Well, have at them, whatsoever comes on it; for I long more for them, than the great Belly that longed to bite her Husbands Nose, or to give him a box on the Ear; or she that threw her loas into a barrel of Tar; and if I have not my longings, in my Conscience I shall mis∣carry.
Take heed Sir, that you do not miscarry, if you have the Dice.
How can he do that? for he hath nothing to miscarry withal, not a farthing, his pockets swell not; it is but an imaginary Child, a windy or watery Mole, or a Moon-calf; he needs no Dice to be his Midwife for the La∣die Pecunia, a mere Timpani of the Fancy, and nothing else.
O Jack, thou art cruel! there is nothing so horrid as truth to a Gen∣tleman, and such truths too. I know not what to do with my self: for I can∣not be alone, those are such foolish fellows that have parts, as they call them, and I hate both them and their parts.
Look here is my foolish Mistress, by the Gods I'll play her, I'll set her you, Sir William Holdfast, what will you stake against her?
Sir, a Lady, and such a Lady, is beyond price unvaluable.
Come, come, leave your Courtship to Ladies, and throw, and have at her.
Why Sir, with the Ladies leave, I will set you five thousand pound.
Five thousand pound? why she hath two thousand pound land a year man, and is an Heir.
But I consider a Wife is chargeable: for I shall maintain her ac∣cording to her Birth, and my own Honour; besides, children will come on, and they are chargeable.
For her charge, I will maintain her as cheap as a Changeling, a Dairy-maid, or a Kitchin-wench: why, she is a fool, and for children, you will not have them the first day certainly; but her Estate will maintain her, and make thee rich; besides, a witty Wife is a curse, and a fool but a Trouble.
But I consider there are two Jointures go out of her Estate.
Why, they are so old, they will both pick over the Perch the next Fall, and die of the Frownsies; or if not, I will present thee with a little Rats∣banc for them, to put in their Caudles.
Well Sir, I honour the Lady so much, as I will set ten thousand pound against her.
By the Gods, make it but fifreen thousand, and here I set her.
Content, and we will take one another words, and these Noble Gentlemen shall be the witnesses.
With all my Soul. Give me the Dice, they that throw most at three throws with three dice, let them win: for three is the Ladies number But first let me invoke them.
Thou Lady Fortune, here I do implore thee,
Now metamorphosed into Dice that's three
My better Fate with Sixes to be crowned,
Thy Favourite winning fifteen thousand pound.
Throw Sir, without any more Invocation of this various Godess.
Come, you Fool, stand here on my side, and now have at your mo∣ney Sir. Two fives and a six? it is well; again, two fixes and a five? I thank thee Lady Fortune, if I win, thou shalt never be called a whore again, but a virtuous and pious Lady; once again, three sixes? Sweet Lady Fortune, how have they wronged thee heretofore, in laying their own follies to thy charge! Malicious lying Detractors, that defame Ladies thus.
Here take the Dice, which are so square and new,
And bid your fifteen thousand pound adieu.
You will give me leave to throw Sir (Throws) what is that, three sixes?
Well, again.
Three sixes again? I vow I believe she is a Virtuous Lady in∣deed.
I cannot tell yet, I will not take upon me for the noblest Lady in the World, throw again, and I will tell you.
Why then have at your Mistress; three sixes again? O Virtuous Lady Fortune!
By the Gods, Jack, the Lady Fortune is a whore, a pocky whore.
Why did you meddle with her then? I knew you would get a Clap.
Nay I have got two; but now I shall have a strict Diet that will cure me.
Are you pleased with my Fortune?
Yes.
It is an injury to Nature to whisper out your words, but rather they should be blown abroad by Fems loud Trumpet.
Had I Rhetoric, as I have none, the loudness of the voice would take away the Elegance of the Speech, and drown the sense of the Subject: But I desire you, and all the rest of this Company may know, I am so well pleased with the Change, as for this Act of Fortunes savour, I shall become a Votaress to Her Deity, for whom I will build an Altar more famous than Mausolus's Tomb; it shall be built with Rhetoric, polished with Eloquence, carved with Allegories, pencilled with Fancies, and gilded with Praise; the Materials shall be wise Brains, honest Hearts, and eloquent Tongues; on this Altar shall burn the Fire of Life, and all the Actions of Industry shall be of∣feared thereon.
What, can you speak?
I am not dumb, although my name is Mute.
You were almost as silent as if you were dumb, all the time you were mine.
It is true; but now I am set at liberty, my Tongue can run freely.
Why, you are as much bound to him now, as you were to me before.
I account this bondage a freedom: for none can be a slave that is bound to a worthy person, who hath a noble nature.
Pray Sir Thomas Letgo do not Court my fortunate Mistress: for though you thought her a fool, I know her to be both wise, and also to have a great Wit.
I fear my wit is but an Infant-wit, and lies in swathling-clouts a∣sleep in the cradle of obscurity: But Time may give it growth, and practice strength, and experience may bring it into the light of knowledge.
If you had no Affection for me, yet you might have had so much civility, as to have expressed your self sociable.
Civility doth not bind any one to divulge their own infirmities, as to express their ignorance by their discourse; besides, for my part, I was so bashful and fearful, lest I should cause errors, and make such defects as were not naturally in me, but only produced by innocent ignorance, which made me choose silence to shun scorns; but I found it was not a sufficient defence.
Here is a Miracle, not only that the dumb speaks, but she that was thought a natural Fool, proves a great Wit.
That word, Wit, that those Ladies return in scorn, I with Industry will make it like a reflection, to cause a double light, and give a greater heat of Sense, Reason, and Judgment, Fancy and Phrase.
Sir, if I behave my self indiscreetly, impute it to an over-flowing joy; and those follies I commit, are not by Nature born, nor yet by Education bred in me.
Sweet Mistress, you can no more be guilty of a fault, than Angels
in Ioves Mansion. Fare you well, Sir Thomas Letgo, the Lady Liberty will counterpoise your losses.
Let her go, Sir Thomas Letgo: for if she be not a Fool, for cer∣tain she is wanton, or otherwise she would not be so well pleased with change.
He hath affronted me.
There is no change so visible, as the most opposite: but Sir Tho∣mas Letgo is both troubled and angry: wherefore Lady Liberty, you had best try to pacify him.
He is like little children, which despise what they have, but cry when they are taken from them.
Ha, ha, ha, prithee teach me something to keep in laughter, or I shall disgrace my self for ever.
Are you so loosely set together, that you cannot hold?
No, I shall burst out laughter at this ridiculous Wedding, before all the Bridal Company, and so be thought rude.
If you burst out nothing else, the company will excuse you: for Weddings are composed of mirth and jollity, and every one hath liberty and leave to sport and play, to dance and skip about.
But if the Bridegroom limping should come to take me out to dance, I shall laugh in his face, which he will take as an Affront, and then will kick me with his wooden stump.
O no, he seems too wise to take Exception, and too civil to kick a Lady; he will rather kiss you, than kick you.
I had rather he should kick me thrice, than kiss me once, by Iupiter. I would not be his Bride, to be the Empress of the whole World.
It is probable, nor he your Bridegroom.
Come away, the Bride is going to bed, and you stand talking here?
To bed, say you? If I were she, I would first choose to go to my
Grave. Hymen and Cupped bless me from such a bed-fellow as the Bridegroom.
Prithee let us watch, to see if we can descry whether he hath clo∣ven feet or not?
Should he have no Cloven Feet, yet certainly the Original of his shape came from Hell: for surely he was begot by the Devil, on some witch or another, and his Clothes were spun by the Devils Dam.
The truth is, he hath damnable old clothes on, they seem as if they were made of old rags, scraped out of dunghills.
I perceive, Ladies, you prefer Beauty and Clothes, before Fire∣tu and Merit.
Faith Virtue is too rigid to be beloved, and Merit is but an encore∣poreal Spirit, and an incorporeal Spirit is no good bed-fellow.
Wherefore I would have a Handsome, Personable, Fashionable, Courtly man.
Nay, if I could have my wish, I would wish for more than one man.
The truth is, that one man would have too much by either of those Ladies.
Was it not enough to win, but to affront me with my losses?
Its true; they say Losers have only leave to speak, but Winners may be merry.
Was there no subject for his mirth but I?
You are a false cheating fellow.
You are a base lying Villain, for saying so.
You have cozened me of my Mistress, and I will have her again.
I have won her saitly and honestly, and I will keep her with my Life.
For Heaven-sake leave off to sight for me, I am not worth the life you hazard for me.
Sweet Mistress, fear not, Death hath no power on me, so long as you stand by.
O let my sad complaints, like murmuring Rivers, flow thorough your Ears, that running into your Heart, may move it to a gentle pity.
You should have let them fight, to see whether Portune hath the same power on their Swords, as she hath on the Dice? whether she can dis∣pose of Life and Death, as of Honour and Riches?
You may part us now, but we shall meet again.
My dear Mistress, what makes your eyes to flow?
As my tears flow thorough my eyes, so I wish my life may flow thorough my tears, then might you live in safety.
Let not your love to me make waste of such Tears, that every drop might save a Life, nay save a Soul, they are so pure and penetrating. But your fears doe apprehend my Foe more dangerous than he is.
Faith confess to us your Maiden-companions, do not you repent?
So fat am I from repentance, as I should repent, were I not as now I am.
You will repent before seven years.
Seven years? you mean seven days: for seven years to our Sex, is se∣ven Ages; for Maids and Widows account it so before their marriage, and married Wives do account time so until their Husbands die.
Faith I think there are few women, but when they marry, hope to be Widows.
That's certain; and were it not for such hopes, men would hardly get Wives.
Fair Ladies, as other men strive to adorn themselves, to mend their broken Bodies, and patch up their decays with false and feigned shows, to cozen credulous women, that think them such as they appear, when they abuse your sweet &amp; gentle natures: But lest my Wife should think me better than I am, or expect more than I could give her, I formed my self far worse than Nature made me; nor have I promised more than well I can perform.
And if she loved me crooked, lame, and blind,
Now I am perfect, she'll not be less kind.
Heyday, Riddle me, riddle me, what's this? A man blind, and not blind, lame, and not lame, crooked, and not crooked, ill-favour'd, and handsome.
Faith it is like the Tale of the great Bear of warwick.
What Tale was that?
Why of a King that had three Daughters, and when they were of marriageable years, the King their Father asked them whether they had ra∣there to have a Husband that were a man a days, and a beast at nights, or a Husband that was a beast at days, and a man at nights? and if they would marry, they must choose one of those that were sometimes men, and some∣times beasts, or otherwise they must never marry; but they, rather than to live old Maids, were resolved to marry, were their Husbands at all times beasts: so the two eldest chose to have their Husbands men a days, and beasts at nights; for, said they, we can conceal their beastliness at nights, but not a days, for the light will divulge them to the public view of the World; but the youngest chose a Husband, one that was a beast a days, and a man at nights: for, said she, I will please my self, not caring what the World thinks or says: for I am sure, said she, the World cares not what I think or say; whereupon they were all three married, and the youngest Ladies Husband was a great Bear a days, but a very handsome man at nights.
O that every woman were so well matched! for then they would be always pleased, and never jealous: for in the day-time, when men doe Court and plead Loves Suit, and point out private meetings,
They have no words to woo, nor persons for to win,
And in the night their Wives their Arms do circle in.
But say your Husband the He-bear, should meet a Mistress She-bear, I believe you would be jealous then.
I confess I should be somewhat lumpish.
Hey, ho!
What is the cause you sigh?
Nature never made so handsome a man as the Bridegroom.
And you sigh because you are not the Bride.
Faith the Devil tempts me to break a Commandment.
What Commandment?
To covet my Neighbours goods.
Why he is no part of your Neighbours goods, unless he be a good man.
Well, he is a goodly man, and whether he is a man that is good, I cannot tell: But howsoever I will never trust the outside more, I will never believe a patched eye is blind, nor a bunched back is crooked, nor a wooden leg lame, as long as I live.
And if you will not believe it whilst you live, when you are dead, I doubt you will forget it; but howsoever the Devil tempts me as much as you to covet him that's none of mine.
Pray Ladies give me leave to remember you, in that you said you would not be his Bride, were it the way to make you Empress of the whole World.
It is true; but then we were blind of one eye as he was; but now we see with both our eyes as he doth.
Come, let us go into the Bride-chamber, and out-dare his beauty on the forfeiture of our hearts.
You need not go to seek Love: for he will catch you, although you run away.
And you will catch Love, if with the Bridegroom stay.
I doubt that.
Let me persuade you to be friends: for if you seem to mourn for that which you made slight of, and to quarrel unjustly, and sight for for that you cannot have, nor is not rightly yours, you will be thought im∣prudent, shunned as a wrangling Gamester, and accounted a Ranting Di∣sturber, and laughed at for a fool, for setting such a Mistress at a stake you thought too much to lose; but if you will save your Reputation, you must seem to rejoice you are quit of her.
Well, I will take your counsel; and I have this satisfaction, That I am not the first man that hath been deceived by Women, nor shall not be the last.
That's true; and so generally it is known, as it is become an or∣denariate saying, and the saying will be made good as long as mankind lasts: for
though men may dissemble to women, yet it is women that deceive men, and we glory in it.
Do you hear the News?
What News?
Why the Bridegroom is proved to be the Great Duke of Gran∣dy's Son.
How so?
Why you have heard that the old Prince of Grandy had two Sons, and the younger Son would not be persuaded from going to Travel, and it was reported he was drowned in a Voyage by Sea, for which his Father mourned a long time, as loving him extremely; and you know, to add to his afflictions, his Eldest Son dies, so as he became as childless, until this time that his Son is returned safe, for which he is the most joyed man that e∣ver was, and is so fond of the Prince his Son, as he continually embraces and kisses him, and hangs about his neck like a fond Bride.
Why did he come so privately, and in a disguise?
As for his private coming home, the reason was, That having oftentimes asked the Magor, to return into his own Country, and being as of∣ten denied, and at last threatened to be destroyed if he should offer to go a∣way, and quit the Magor's Service: for this Prince was General of all his Forces, and was the man that the Merchants cried up to be another Iulius Caesar, although they knew not of what birth or quality he was of; but to get away, he was forced to steal away in a disguise, in which disguise he wooed and won his Lady, the now Princess: for whilst he lay privately in the City, until such time as he could handsomely &amp; conveniently discover him∣self, he hearing the talk of the Public Wooing, and also of the Virtue, Beau∣tie, and Wit of the young Lady, went to hear and to see her, whom he no sooner heard and saw, and being taken with her good Fame, honouring her Virtue, admiring her Beauty, and being extremely delighted with her Wit, became a Lover, and also a VVooer; but for the better trial of her Virtue, he wooed her in his disguised, deformed shape, and unknown quality, left his Dignity and Wealth might have enticed her Ambition, and not his Merit, to have won her Love, or his Person might have caught her Eye, but not his Love her Heart.
The Gods are just, rewarding in the end the good intentions with good success, and Virtue with felicity.
Virtue and Honour you did take,
And Beauty scorned as voting;
Thus you a Godess it doth make,
Rove mortal Ladies trading.
They love the Body, you the Soul,
They Shape, but you the Mind,
Your Love those grosser loves control,
Which shows their Love is blind.
His wooden Leg is thrown away,
The black Patch for the blind,
The Bunch on's back assuaged to day,
As handsome as his Mind.
This now is your reward, Sweet Madam,
The Gods they are not lath
To give you one, handsome as Adam,
And thus enjoy them both.
Loves Miracles not ceased be,
The Lame to walk, the Blind to see,
The Crooked is made straight, it is true,
And these Loves Wonders made by you.
His Body metamorphosed is,
By your Ambrosia sweeter kiss;
Such power hath Love when you do sip
The Gods pure Nectar from your Lip.
All Joys attend you night and day,
Be each to other fresh as May,
Renewing pleasures everyhower,
And sweeter than the sweetest Flower.
Envious Ladies now rapine,
Since you are crossed,
In having lost
A Prince so handsome and so fine.
Mourn in black patches for your sins,
Despair each Curl,
And every Purl,
And throw away your dressing-pins.
Lay by your richer Gowns of State,
For now you'll faint,
For all your paint,
When 'think of your unhappier Fate.
For these Love-pitfals they are stale,
And all despise
Your glancing Eyes,
For all forced Arts in Love they'll fail.
Now let your specious gliding pass,
Or your Lips fed
With biting red,
Despair, and break each Looking-glass.
What, Ladies, are you Thunder-struck with the Princes Honour, or are you blasted with the Lightning of his Splendour, or crushed with the wheel of her good Fortune?
Lord, Lord, how blindly Fortune throws her gifts away!
One would think she had clear Eyes, when she bestowed her Fa∣vours upon the Princess.
She is become so proud, since she is become a Princess, as she will not look on us that were her companions; and she thinks scorn to speak to us: for she said not one word to any of us.
She had no occasion to speak to you; but I am confident, If you speak to her, you will find her as civil and obliging, as ever she was.
Faith we care not: for we can live without being obliged to her.
They are not the happiest that have the greatest Titles.
Pride will have a Fall.
I perceive it is hand to get the good opinion of the World: for you railed at her Course, laughed at her Choice, condemned her Marriage, and now you envy her good Success.
We envy her? you are mistaken: for she must be of greater va∣lue, and we less worthy than we are, to raise an Envy.
Nay Ladies, if you are angry, I will leave you.
Then we shall be rid of a prattling fool.
O, wisdom in youth is a wonder.
Happy is that Parent that hath a discreet Child.
Such Children give their Parents Honour in their Graves.
Pray let us Petition that a Law may be Enacted for this Pub∣lick Wooing.
We shall not need to Petition: for the Princess, I dare war∣rant you, will get the Prince to Enact a Law for this Public Wooing for her Fame, she being the only first that hath been wooed so.
Well, Daughters, make her your Pattern.
Yesterday, that was the Wedding-day, my Parents did condemn the Bride, calling her Fool, and saying she was mad, and forbid me to imi∣tate her.
It is no wonder our Natures are so various, when as our Educate∣on are so inconstant: for we are instructed to imitate Fortune, which is to be restless, and to spoil that good we have done.
Or to better the worse.
No faith: for I perceive Fortune hath more power to do hurt than good; for Fortune ruins, or at least disturbs Virtuous Acts, and frustrates Wisedom's Counsels.
Ladies, the Princess desires your company to dance.
Pray excuse me Sir: for I have so great a pain on my left side, as I can hardly fetch my breath.
And I have such a pain in my head, as I date not dance, for fear it should ache more.
And truly I have so straight a shoe, as it is a pain for me to tread a step.
And I am not well in my stomach: wherefore excuse us Sir to the Princess.
God give you Joy, I have not seen you since you were married.
You are welcome into the married Society.
I thank you Madam. Truly I am so tired.
With what, Madam?
With helping my Neighbour the Lady Breeder to hold her back.
Why, is she in Labour?
She is brought to Bed; but on my word she hath had a hard bar∣gain: for she hath had a sore Labour.
What hath God sent her?
A lusty boy. Indeed it is one of the goodliest children that ever I saw.
But how chance she did not send for me to her Labour?
She came on such a sudden, as she had hardly Time to send for the Midwife; but she was mightily troubled you were not there, she doubts you will take it ill.
We have reason: for if we could not have come time enough to her Labour, we might have come time enough to the cup of Rejoicing.
But she will bid you to the Christening.
That's some amends: But this hard labour of the Lady Breeders will fright you.
No: for I have as much courage as other married Wives have, though truly, Sir Anthony Gosling, my Husband, was very loath I should go: for (said he to me) prithee sweet Duck do not go: I answered and said to him, my hony-love I must go, for it is the part of one wife to help another; besides, a gossipping company doth help to ease the women's pains; and if I go not to their Labour, they will not come to mine.
Why, are you with Child?
No, but I hope I shall be shortly.
Come, we will go and chide your Husband, that he hath been ma∣ried a week, and his Wife not with child.
Yes, pray go chide him, and I will bear your company.
Sir, pray persuade the unmarried Ladies to dance: for I can∣not entreat them.
That's strange: for Ladies will dance without entreating; for no entreating will make them sit still.
It seems they are not in their dancing-humour to day: for every one finds some excuse for to deny.
Let them alone, and take no notice of their reserved humours, and they will dance without entreating; nay, they will entreat you they may dance.
If it please your Highness, the Ladies desire you would give them leave to Celebrate your Marriage with their Mirth, and to express their Joy with their Dancing.
We shall take it as a Favour to our Nuptials.
Did not I tell you they would desire to dance?
Truly I was so ignorant, as I knew not so much the nature of our Sex.
You knew not so much of their follies.
Let us strive to make the Bride jealous.
That's impossible now; but you may not work to good effect some a half a year hence.
Why I have known a Bridegroom leer her the next day he was ma∣ried.
Perchance a Bridegroom may: for men are sooner cloyed than women; but a Bride will fondly hang about her Husbands neck a week at least.
A week? nay a month: for a woman is fond the first month, sick the second month, peevish the third month, coy the fourth month, false the fifth month, and Cuckolds her Husband the sixth month.
Then a married man sprouts Horns in half a year.
Yes: for they are set the day of his marriage, and some half a year after they are budded, but not so fully grown as to appear to the pub∣lick view.
But will nothing hinder the growth?
No faith, but Death; and Death, like a Frost, doth nip those ten∣der buds.
Which death, the mans, or the women's?
The women's: for if the man dies, and his Widow marries again, the dead Husband is horned in his Grave, and the living Husband is horned in his Bed.
Then their Horns may be put together, as Stags in Rutting∣time.
I had rather make Horns, than talk of Horns; therefore I'll go dance.
Where have you been?
At Church.
Did a sit of Devotion hurry you to the Church to pray?
No faith, I went not to pray, but to join a pair of Lovers hands in Wedlocks Bonds: for they chose me to be their Father, to give them in the Church.
What Lovers were they, that were so foolish to marry?
So honest, you mean.
There is more folly in it than honesty, in my opinion.
Thou art an Infidel, nay a very Atheist.
I am a Naturalist. But who are they that are married?
Why Sir William Holdfast and the Lady Mute.
The truth is, he is a worthy Person, and she is a virtuous and sweet Lady: wherefore they deserve each other; besides, she is an Heir, and he hath a great Estate.
He hath so.
What, is the Wedding kept private?
Yes, there are only two or three Friends; but I must go dine with them, therefore fare thee well, unless you will go with me: for you know you shall be welcome.
I know I shall, therefore I shall go with you.

She's at the Charge of Wit to make the Play;
But if you think it not worthy of Praise,
Nor an Applause of Hands, her Fame to raise,
She doth desire that it in pawn may lie,
Till redeemed by a better Comedy.

When I forsake you, let Heaven forsake my Soul.
I do not doubt you: for if I did, I could not love you; and whilst I love you, I cannot doubt you.
O how it wounds my heart to part from you! my Thoughts are tortured, and my Mind is set upon a me∣lancholy Rack.
Since your Journey cannot be conveniently avoided, I will please my self with the hopes of your sudden Return.
Farewell, sweet Mistress, Death is the worst of Nature, and your Absence the worst of Fortune.
Good Master Steward, give Order for some Beef-suet to be brought in: for there is nor any left in the House, and I must make a Venison-pasty; and if I should temper my Pasty all with butter, you would be angry.
Why, cannot you take some of the fat from the Beef-broth for your Crust?
Yes, if every one that eat of it had as fresh a mouth as you, or lo∣ved drink so well as you do, it would serve, otherwise it would be too salt for their palats; besides, I am to make puddings in guts.
If they prove as the last you made, the dogs may eat them
for the guts stunk so much, as no man could eat any of them.
I'm sure it was your fault, in that you did not bring me where∣withal to make them, until such time as the guts began to putrefy.
No, no, you are a Slut, and did not take all the dung out of them, nor wash, nor scrape, nor cleanse them as they should have been; but you order the guts, as you do the dishes, the one is dungy; the other greasy; be∣sides, my Master complains, that his Fowl taste rank, and his Brawn tastes strong, and his Beef tastes musty, and that's because you are so lazy, as not to shift your Brawn into fresh Sousing-drink, nor make the brine strong enough in the powdring-tub, nor thrust your fingers far enough into the Fowls rumps, to draw them clean; besides, when they are roasted, they are as dry as a chip, for want of basting-butter; besides, your sluttery is such, as you will poison all the House: for in one place I find a piece of butter, and a greasy comb full of nitty hairs lying by it; and in another place flour and old-worn stockings, the feet being rotted off with sweat; and in a third place, a dish of cold meat covered with a foul smock, and your dirty shoes (for the most part) stand upon the Dresser-board, where you lay the hot meat; besides, by your carelessness you do waste and spoil so much, as it is unsufferable: for you will fling whole ladlefuls of dripping into the fire, to make the fire blaze underneath the pot; and because you have not the profit of the Kitchen stuff, you will never scrape the Dresser-board, nor Dripping-pans, nor lick the Platters, Trays, or Scummers, Frying-pans, Skillets, Gridirons, Spits, Ladles, Kettles, or any of the Kitchin-vessels, as you should doe, but wash them all with hot water at first, without taking off the grease before∣hand.
Well, if you do not like me, pray pay me my wages, and I will be gone: I'm sure I never served in any place for so small wages and few veils as in this service: I'm sure it is no ways beneficial to me.
I'm sure you'll make it beneficial one way or another: for you have your female Factors that lie abroad, to whom you send Commodities by your She-porters, that come hither every day to transport them. Thus you traffic upon my Masters Cost, and my Reputation: for I am thought the worse of either, as believing I am a false Steward, or a negligent one. Thus a True man is thought a Knave: for by your stealing I am thought a Thief.
You are a base man for saying I steal, I never was accounted a Thief in my life, but always trusty and true, in what Service soever I lived.
She's a pretty Wench, if she had but clean clothes on, by Venus she would be very handsome; a Silk Gown would make her a rare Beauty; her Tears fall on her Nose and Cheeks like gentle showers of rain on Roses and Lilies sweet. O she is a heavenly Creature!
Sweet-heart, where do you live?
In your Worships House.
And whose servant are you?
Your Worships.
How long have you served me?
A Quarter, and't please your Worship.
In what place serve you?
In the Kitchen, an't please you.
What makes you cry?
Your Worships Steward hath wronged me.
How hath he wronged thee?
He says I stole your Worships Kithin-stuff, when the Gods know I am as innocent as the child that is newly born.
He is a Knave for saying so, and I will have him turned out of his Authority for saying so: wherefore cry no more, fair Maid; for thou shalt be preferred to a higher Office.
I thank your Worship.

Nor you have not heard whether she is discreet, or witty, nor of what humour she is?

How long a time is required to go to that place where he is?
According as the wind is: If the wind be good, twelve hours
fail will land a passenger, and some eight hours riding from the shore, will bring them to the City.
Will you please to walk in and rest your self?
Lord, there is such a quarrel about the falling out of Briget Greasy and Master Steward, as it is wonderful: for my Master chides, Briget cries, and Master Steward maintains his words, as they do so offend and misprove, as you would bless your self.

My Wife, Master Doctor, is very ill.
She is so: for her Disease is not to be cured, my Lord; for we cannot restore the decays of vital parts: for as they consume, life draws towards an end.
But pray do your endeavour to prolong her like as long as you can.
We shall, my Lord, to the utmost of our skill. Your Lordships humble servant.

Well, then pray do not forget when you are called to pay that duty where you owe it.
If this News could deprive me of my life, it would have made me happy; but it hath almost deprived me of my Reason, and quite from my Patience, which makes me miserable, and Misery is worse than Death: for Death is a cessation of pain, and Misery a torment of life: But if this Report be true, I will lay more curses on his head, than a long pe∣nitential life shall be able to take off.
Lord, Briget is so proud since she is preferred to be my Ma∣sters Laundry-maid, as she will touch none but my Masters linen.
She is become very fine upon her preferment: I am sure it is not five or ten pound wages that will or can maintain her at that rate she goes: for she hath had, to my knowledge, two new pair of shoes within three weeks of each other; whereupon I told her, that the shoes that she cast by, would be very strong and serviceable, if they were cobbled; and her Answer was, what, did I think she would wear cobbled shoes? I told her, why not now, as well as she did? for she used to send her shoes to be cobbled three or four times over, and her waistcoat to be patched, and her petticoats to be new-border'd, and her stockings to be heeled, as the rest of us did; and I knew of no Lands that had befallen her, and therefore she may doe the same still.
And what said she then?
She bid me meddle with my own matters, and not meddle with her; and I dare not offend her, for fear I should be turned away: nay, she is so proud, as she turns her head aside when Richard the Carter comes to kiss her, and she strives to shun his company, when once within a short time, she would make haste to wash her dishes, that she might have time to sit in Richards Lap, and there they would sit colling and kissing until the sea-coal-site was burned out.
But now she sits in a better seat.
I cannot believe he will prove so false and perjurious, but this Disguise, I hope, will bring me to discover the Truth: And if he be false, for his sake may all the Masculine Sex be slaves to the Esseminate Sex, not bound by Love, but by base servile fear; may they long after the power, but never get it; may women govern the World, and when they command, the men dare not disobey, and be despised for their reward; may their Jealousies disturb their Rest, their Cares increase their Labours; may they work like Horses, fawn like Dogs, and bear like Asses. But if he be constant, may all the Masculine Sex be blessed for his sake; may all women desire, admire, and love him; may Pleasure embrace him, Health preserve him, and Time attend him; may he be armed with Power, crowned with Peace, and all Obedience bow to his command; may the sound but of his Name bring joy to all hearts; may all be pleased for his Birth, pray for his Life, and fear his Death; may good Fortune trace his ways, whilst he tides upon the wings of a glorious Fame.

Well read, well read: As for the Lord Widower, I know he will not come: for I hear his Lady is newly dead. This is the Nature of the World; some marry, and some die.

We have reason to weep: for you, my Children, have lost a good Mother, and I a loving Wife, and her servants a kind Lady; but we cannot alter Heavens Decrees: wherefore we must take comfort in what is, and not grieve for what cannot be helped: And now, Daughter Sprightly, you must be as my Wife, Friend, and Daughter all in one: for as your Mo∣there did, when she had health, govern my Family, so must you now she is dead; and you must take care of your young Brothers and Sisters, and Hey∣ven will reward thee with a good Husband and Children of your own: And as for her Maid here, who hath taken great pains all the time of your Mo∣theirs sickness, ought to be rewarded for her care: wherefore, Daughter, let her wait upon you, as she did upon your Mother.

A fair Wife Sir: for a drunken Serving-man told me that one Sir Francis Inconstant had married his Masters Daughter, and that the Wedding-Feast would continue a Week, if not a Fortnight.

How came the quarrel betwixt you?
Why now, forsooth, she is come to Order and to Rectify, she's not only grown light-finger'd, but fine-finger'd, as to touch nothing that is
not bright-scour'd, nor then neither, without her gloves; and she called for a candle and a candlestick to carry into my Masters Chamber, and I for haste run up with the candle, and forgot the candlestick, and had left it behind me: when I came, what, said she, do you bring a candle without a candlestick? Alas said I, I have forgot it; but hold you the candle, said I, and I will run and fetch the stick strait, and so I put the candle into her hand: with that, she up with her hand, and gave me a box on the ear, what, said she, do you give me a greasy candle to hold? I will teach you more manners, said she, against the next time: I being heated at the blow she gave me, cold her, that she had forgot since the Mouse bit her greasy face when she was asleep, taking it for a candles-end, or a piece of bacon: with that, she flew upon me, and I at her, where in the combat we made such a noise, as my Master came forth of his Chamber, and parted us, and then he bid me ge• me out of his house, but kissed her, and prayed her to pacify her anger, and not to distemper her self with a rude wench as I was.
And what said she then?
Why she told my Master I was a naughty Baggage, a dirty Slur, a base Whore, and all the ill names she could; but I will not suffer this, for I will be gone.

And is he married! O that I could pull out that part of my Brain which imprints his memory! for the wrongs he hath done me are so great and heavy, as I wish I could unload my Soul, and build a Pyramid of Curses, that may stand as a mark of his Infamy.
I had rather banish my self, than live in disgrace in my own Country.

But yet it is not fit Children should examine their Parents actions; and it were an indiscretion in Parents to allow of it.
She is young, she is young.
Wherefore your Lordship should have a care to have her pru∣dently governed; and if she be too young to govern her self, how can she go∣vern so great a Family as your Lordships is?
O she hath but the name, my Steward governs all.
Yes; but the Mistress of the House governs the Steward, and the Steward gives Orders as an Inferior Officer, delivering the Superiors commands.
You say true: wherefore you that have some more experience, should counsel her.
O, my Lord, it is not manners for me to give her counsel, neither will she take it from me: for when I humbly offer her my Advice, she checks me, and threatens to turn me away.
Doth she so? But I will have her to take cons, and to know she is too young to order after her own childish fancy.
Indeed, my Lord, she wants years, which should make her experienced. Sweet child, she is fitter to dress Babies, and order a Closet, than govern a great Family, which is a little Common-wealth.
Well, I will order her otherwise.

She writes as if she were dying when she writ this letter.

It is no wonder that Briget Greasy is so proud now, being ma∣ried to my Master, he having made her a Lady. Lord, Lord, to see the fortune that some have over others: why, if my Master would have ma∣ried one of his Maids, he might have chosen a prettier wench amongst any of us all than she is.
Yes faith: for she was thought the veriest Puss of us all; for she is neither snout-fair, nor well-shap'd, she hath splay-feet, and chilblain∣heels.
Nay all will grant she was the dirtiest slut in the House: for there was never a man-servant but would cry so at her when they kissed her; be∣sides, she was the veriest fool amongst us: But Lord, what Wealth and Ho∣nor will do! for now she is a Lady, she looks as if she never washed a dish, or scoured a kettle or spit.
But I wonder how she came to be his Wife, she might have ser∣ved as her Betters have done before her: I am sure there was Nan, a pretty pert, cleanly Maid, who was kind, and willing to do any thing, either to serve our Master, or fellow servants.
O but Nan had not an old woman that used to come to her to get suet and scraps, as Briget had; and this old woman, they say, counselled Briget to seem nice and coy.
I wonder what Richard the Carter will say, who was turned out of his service, because he should not share with my Master.
Faith I heard that Richard was told of her Advancement, and it is said he laughed, and said my Master had a hungry stomach, that he could feed of his leavings; but by his Troth he was glad she was become a Lady: for now he could say he had kissed and courted a Lady as well as the best Gallant of them all.
Daughter, ald ough you do govern my Family very well for your years, yet you are young, and wanting Experience, may be cozened; and though I have a great Estate, yet it will be all consumed, if Order and Method be not put into practice: wherefore I would have you take the counsel of Mistress Dorothy Subtlety, to assist you.
Who is that, my Lord?
Why, do not you know her? she that waited on your Mother.

from a Chambermaid to a Gentlewoman, I might easily mistake; besides, she is not so much older, as to have much more experience than my self: perchance she may have more craft, which was learned her in her poverty, than I, who have been bred at the Horn of Plenty, that knew no scar∣city, nor sharking necessity.
You have a sharp tongue when spite moves it; but let me hear no more of these words, but do as I command you.

Pray do Wife.
Sweet-heart, I was in your Bed-chamber, and in your Cabinet-chamber, and missing you in both, I was afraid I must have been forced to have hired a Crier, to have proclaimed my loss.
Many a Wife doth proclaim her Husbands loss without the help of a Crier: for the Wives Adulterous Acts proclaim her Husband a Cuc∣old, and the loss of his Honour.
But I am not afra'd of that: for I am confident of thy Chastity (al∣though the old saying is, Confidence makes Cuckolds.)
Your confidence of me shall never harm you.
But your too serious studies will harm your health; and if you be sick, I cannot be well; besides, it will decay your Beauty, waste your Youth, like Oil spent in a melancholy Lamp, where Life is always blinking.
It were better that my Body should be sick, than my Mind idle; my Beauty decay, than my Understanding perish; my Youth waste, than my Fame lost; my Life blinking, than my Honour sinking: for an idle Mind, not well employed creates a restless body, which runs from place to place, and hates to be at home. Thus Mind and Body both being out, extravagant Words and Actions run about, and Riot keeps possession.
And though the Beauty withers and decays,
Yet Wit and Wisdom with the ruin stays:
And if the Youth doth waste, and Life's Oil's spent,
Yet Fame lasts long, and builds a Monument:
A melancholy life doth shadows cast,
But sets forth Virtue, if they are well placed.
Then who would entertain an idle Mirth,
Begot by Vanity, and dies in scorn?
Or proud, or pleased with Beauty, when the Birth
Becomes the Grave or Tomb as soon as born?
But Wisdom wishes to be old and glad,
When youthful Follies die, which seem as mad:
If Age is subject to repent what's past,
Prudence and Experience redeems what's lost.
I perceive, Wife, the Muses have kept you company, although you walk by your self; but now I desire you will leave their company for a time, and entertain mine.
With all my heart; but the Muses are never with me, but when you are employed about serious Affairs: for though they are my Visitors, yet they are your Domestic Servants.
Dear Husband, where have you been?
My dear kind Wife, I have been in the Garden, where I have heard little Robin Red-breast sing.
That's a sign, Sweet-heart, we shall have warm weather, otherwise they would come into the House.
I had rather believe, my pretty Bird, we shall have cold weather: for they sing always in the coldest time of the year, as in the depth of Winter.

I never heard the Robin sing in Summer.

It is to me.

I will read this Letter once again, although it shakes my Soul, and makes me almost mad.
THe wrongs you have done me, are more than Heaven can give me patience to endure; for which wrongs, may thick black clouds of Infamy overspread your Memory; and may my Sorrows beat upon your Soul, as Northern Winds upon the Sea, and raise up all your thoughts in discontent, as raging billows, causing your voice to roar out loud with hideous noise, confounding all the Actions of your Life; and way your hopes be drowned in the salt water of despairing Tears. The Heavens can∣not condemn me for cursing a man which hath betrayed my Youth by Flattery, violated my Chastity by Proteslations, tormented my harmless thoughts with Perjury, disquiet∣ing my peaceable Life with Misfortunes. But the burden of my wrongs being too weighty for life to bear, hath sunk it to the Grave, where I hope all my disgrace will •e buried with me, though not the revenges of my Wrongs; for those will punish you when I am dead: For the Gods are just, although Mankind is not.
O Nick, what a Villain am I!
For what Sir?
For Perjury and Murder: for I did not only break those Bonds I had sealed with holy Vows, but my Falsehood hath killed a fair young La∣die: for she hearing I had forsaken her, and was to be married to another, she died for grief.
Alas Sir, we are all by Nature both frail and mortal: wherefore we must complain of Nature, of her Inconstancy and Cruelty, in making our Minds so changeable, and our Bodies so weak, the one being subject to Death, the other subject to Variety. But Sir, in my Opinion, you have no cause to grieve, but rather to rejoice: for what you have erred by Nature, you have repaired by Fortunes favour: for if that Lady which is dead, had lived, you would have been encumbered with many troubles.
As how Nick?
Why you would have been as a young Bear baired by two young Whelps; the forsaken Lady railing and exclaming against you in all Com∣pany she came into, and your Wife tormenting you with sharp words and loud noise, insomuch as you would have neither ear, drank, or slept in quiet. Thus both abroad and at home you would have heard noth gbut your own reproaches.
But shall not I be the same now she is dead, think you?

And can it hide the sin from the Gods, and the falsehood from my Husband, as well as from the World? But let me tell you, the World is quick-fighted as to Particulars, though blind as to the General, complaining against single crimes, yet never helps to mend them.
Faith Madam, the Gods easily pardon natural faults, and Hus∣bands dare not spy them, at least not to divulge them; and the World censures all the Virtuous as much as the Wicked, and the Chaste as much as the Wanton; besides, you are excusable, being married to an ancient man.
Doth Age deserve no Love?
Faith little: for Love wears out with Time, and Age wears out of Love; and if you said you did love your Husband, no body would believe you: for who can think you that are young and fair, can love a man that's old?
By Heaven I never thought my Husband old: for he doth appear to me to be just at Maturity; adorhed with all the Graces.
Surely you do not think his silver Hair Apollo's Locks!
No; but I think them Pa ass's his Head-peece.
Nor can you think his hollow Eyes, that's sunk into his Head, are Cupids golden Arrows?
No; but I think them Minerva's Loom, which hath inter-weav'd several Objects, making various and most curious works of Knowledge, and of Wit, where Judgment in the midst is placed, and Understanding bore∣ders it.
And can you think his shoulder, bent by weak old Age, are Cupids. Bow?
No; but I can think it's like a Bank swelled out by Generosity, to bear Necessities burdens on; or else a heap of Noble Deeds, fals'd by Heroic Actions, whereon Fame sits in Triumph, and blows his praise a∣broad, that all the World may hear it.
I will never believe you can think the surrows in his face,
ploughed up by Time, as smooth as waters be when in a calm.
No; but I can think them Tracks or Paths made by Experience, in which walks Prudence, Fortitude, Justice, and Temperance: And though you strive to make my Husband seem much older than he is, yet I believe that neither Time nor Age hath power over him: for to my sight his Skin is as smooth as Light, his Eyes as darting as Apollo's Beams, his Body is as straight as Serzes Wand, able to charm the youngest she, and turn her all to Love; his Strength is active, and his Spirits quick, to carry Arms, or sight his Enewies; and for his Brain, it is equally tempered, not burnt with heat, nor frozen up with cold; nor are his Sinews out of tune by flacken'd Nerves, but just set to Lifes Harmony, Strength strings the Cords, and Health doth keep just Time.

It were more just to treble my wages than hers; for I was the cause of the Out-cry: for when I beat her, she roared, and her voice thorough her throat, made as great a rumbling noise, as a foul chimney set on fire, and in my Conscience as much sooty phlegm fell from her head, as from a Cooks Chimney; and when she scolded, her words were so harsh, as they creek just so as when a door is taken off the hinges, which made my Lady strait ap∣prehend either Fire, or Thieves, or both.
No, you deserve nothing, by reason a man ought not to strike a woman.

If I had kissed you, Join, as I perceive my Master would have had me done, you had been silent, and in your silence my Lady would have died, and then my Master had been a lusty Widower, and a free Wooer, and a fresh man, as one may say, where now he is bound to a sickly Wife; and this is the reason my Master would not increase my wages: which if I had kissed you, I had been enriched by my Masters favour: wherefore Join, I will kiss thee, but kick thee no more.

Lord, Lord, this nasty love, or rather this heastly lust that doth corrupt all good manners, as gentle civility, free society, lawful recreations, honest friendship, natural affections; it cuts off the feet of obedience, it breaks the knees of duty, it wounds the breast of fidelity, it pulls out the heart of loyalty; it turns away prudence, it banishes temperance, and murders justice; it breaks peace and makes wars, and t•rns arms i••o petticoats. O sweet pure Chastity, how amiable thou art, how beautiful thou appearst in women, how heroic in men: for Chaste women have such innocent thoughts, such pure, clean, clear, white immaculate minds, such modest countenances, such gentle behaviour, such civil discourses, such no∣ble actions, such discreet entertainments, such cautionary recreations; o∣therwise they are bold, impudent, rude, flaunting, ranting, romping wo∣men: also Chastity in men makes them heroic, for propriety, justice con∣stance, and natural and honest love is the basis, pillars, or foundation where∣on true valour is built, when amorous affections make men effeminate, cau∣sing them to cast away their hard iron arms to lie in the soft arms of beau∣tie, and stops their cares from loud alarms, with charming notes of Music, it takes them from being masters of themselves, and others, and makes them become servants, and slaves; from commanding an Army to be com∣manded by single women, by whom he is checked like a school-boy, lead like a dog in a string, as after his mistresses humours, her frowns make him crouch like a cur, her smiles make him skip, and make face like a Jack a•∣apes, and their beastly appetites make them so rude, and wilde, as they re∣guard no civility of behaviour, no gentleness of disposition, no constancy of affection, they keep no friendship, constancy, or vows, they break all de∣cent customs, and disobey all honest laws; but this is a theme too wilde to be preached on.

But Youth and Beauty wife, when they plead, are greater Bawds, and have a more persuasive power than the Lady Procurer.
Truly all three, as Beauty, Youth, or the Lady Procurer, rather than persuade me, would divert me, had I a wanton nature; as first, for the Lady Procurer her baseness appeared such as made me hate my self for being of the same sex she was of, and grieved me to see the follies of mankind, the one appearing like a Devil, the other like a beast, so seemed the Lover and the Bawd, when men have Reason to govern, as much as Appetite to per∣swade, the one proceeding from the Soul, the other from the body; besides, Virtue is the Natural Complexion of the Soul, not Vice: for Vice is bred, not born in man: As for Youth, it is so fantastical, extravagant, wilde, and self-opinionated, doing such ridiculous Actions, putting themselves into such affected Postures, as I might be as soon enamoured with a Jack-anapes: Be∣sides, the discourses of Youth are so flashy, as it gives the hearers no relish; and their Judgment is so shallow, and their Understanding so misty, as when Reason discourses with them, it is apt to be lost in the darkness of Ignorance. Lastly, for Beauty in men, it is worse than unhansomeness in women: for an ill-favour'd woman seems masculine, as if she had an Heroic Spirit,
though she were a Coward; to have a judicious Understanding, though she should be a Fool; to be Chaste, although she were Wanton; when on the contrary, a beautiful man appears Effeminate, Foolish, and Cowardly, when (perchance) he may be Wise and Valiant, yet it is Beauty makes him seem otherwise; and (for the most part) a beautiful man is more nice and curious about his person, as in his clothing, dressing, trimming, perfuming, powde∣ring, curling, and some will pomate and pain themselves, all which seems to me preposterous to men, insomuch as I could as soon be amorously affe∣cted with my own Sex, as those that are accounted beautiful men; and you might sooner be jealous of Age than Youth, with a Sun-burnt face and a wi∣ther'd skin, than a face that looks as if it had not seen the Sun, or the Sun it, nor felt the nipping Frost nor parching Wind; but I hope you have a better opinion of your self than to be jealous, as to think I can like any man better, or so well as you: And if you have not so good an opinion of me, us to believe I am constantly honest, yet I have such an assurance of my self, as to know I am not liable to be corrupted, and I am so Chaste, as I have not a thought subject to fully the purity of my chaste Mind and honest Heart.

Yes; and its part of the Wives duty which she owes to her Hus∣band, to be content.
She is not bound to that duty.
She is bound to obey all duties: for the fundamental Laws in Marriage, are for the Husband to rule, the Wife to obey; the Husband to cherish, the Wife to love; the Husband to be Valiant to defend and protect her, the Wife to be Chaste, to suffer and submit; and when I leave to Com∣mand, you may leave for to Obey; when I leave to Cherish, you may leave to Love; when I am a Coward, you may be a VVhore: for when I base∣lie part with my Honour, you are not bound to keep it; but until I do part with my Honour, I charge you to keep it as you would do your life.
By these Rules married men are not bound to be constant.
Yes, to the Sex, but not to his Wife, in the case of Amorous Im∣bracements: for a Husband hath liberty for variety, but the Wife is re∣frain'd to one.
These are Laws that neither the Gods nor Nature have prescri∣bed, but only impartial men which make what Laws they please.
Nature taught men to make them for propriety-sake, and Gods command men to keep them, and that men should do their endeavour to force the Effeminate Sex to obey and practice them strictly, for the sake of Civil Commonwealths, wherein the Gods are best served.
But women are not such Fools, to be forced, such Asses, to bear such intolerable burdens of Troubles, Vexations, Crosses, and Neglects, from their Husbands and their VVhores.
Women are best pleased when they are made Asses.
