Then she must get some acquaintance, and turn Lady Bawd, and show Ladies how to dress themselves, and sell paint, pomatoms, wax-gloves, oyl'd-masks, and the like Commodities privately; or else she must pretend Skill in Surgery or Physic, and to make Plasters, Salves, Ointments, and the like, or make Cordial Powders, or Cordial Waters, and other wa∣ters and powders; then persuade old Ladies to take thereof, telling them those will make them look as young as one of fifteen.
But those things require cost to make them.
No faith, there requires not much charge: for Paint, Pom∣tom, and the like Commodities, will sell at any price, and will be made at a little charge: and for Salves and Plasters, and Oils and Ointments, Hogs∣grease, Turpentine, and Bole-Armonike, serves for all sorts of those things, and Bread, and Meal, and Milk, and some chopped Herbs, and Sallet-oyl, serves for all Pultesses; and for Cordial Powders, some hot Seeds, as Aniseed, Caroway-seed, Coriander-seed, and the like Seeds, with some powder of Liquoras, and beaten Spices, with some sorts of Gums, as Mystic, Myrrh, and the like, will serve their turn.
But Cordial Powders are made of Pearl, Amber, Coral, and the like.
Faith a little powder of posts serves as well: for they cannot be distinguished by their taste; but howsoever, it is but putting a grain of Musk and Ambergrease, and instead of Amber, Coral, and Pearl, it is but powdering some shaved Harts-horn and Chiny, and they will serve as well, and (per∣chance work as good Effects:) Indeed Cordial Waters are chargeable to
make: for they require fire to distill them; but there is some remedy for that: for it is but buying several sorts of ordinary hot waters, and mix them together, so as no one of the waters may predominate in taste, and it will pass for rare extracted Spirits, so as she shall never need to venture to distill, or lay out money, but just for the present to fetch it from those that sell Aqua∣vitae, Rosasolus, and the like, which may be had at a cheap rate, and she may sell them at a great price.
But what shall become of the poor young Children?
Why, he rooking, and she bawding, may make a shift to feed them with bread: and those two Trades will never fail as long as Mankind lasts: for VVhoring and Knaving will last till Dooms-day, or for ever.
But •rsly, my Lady hath given us warning to be gone: wherefore we must seek out new services.
My Lady is so good a Lady, as I wish I could serve her so as to maintain her, since she is not able to maintain a servant.
But since we cannot maintain her, nor she us, we must leave her.
O help me, help me, you merciful Powers, to destroy me, and let me not outlive my Husband.
It is like the Gods will hear your prayers: for ten to one my Ma∣ster out-lives you.
Why, is he alive?
Yes, and olive's like.
What makes you sweat so?
To bring you the good news of his well-being, and to prove the old Proverb a Liar, which says, Bad News hath wings, and good News no legs.
Where did you meet your Master?
In Westminster-Hall.
How did he look?
Healthful and well.
Did he seem angry or pleased, merry or sad?
Why he neither seemed angry nor pleased, merry nor sad, which I wondered at: for in Lawyers Courts, and places of Judicature, I never saw any face but was clothed with a merry green countenance, or a sad black countenance, or a red choleric face, or a pale malicious face; but my Masters face appeared like naked Truth, and clean Temperance, washed white with Innocence; being plump with health, and smooth with plenty.
But why did you leave him?
Why he commanded me so to doe, and to run every step, to tell you he was coming home, and I chose as the wisest to run, al∣though
I sweat for it, than stay and have a broken Head.
Well, I give you here a twenty-shilling-piece to dry your sweat with a cup of Sack.
May all my labours be rewarded thus.
I perceive you take the gift as a due reward, and not as my Ladies bounty.
Hold your prating: what need we thank the Gods, if Saints me∣rit Heaven?
Sir, I desire you would not think me undutiful to ask you a question: for I hope I am not so much in your disfavour, as not to re∣solve me, since it is in your power.
Well, what is it that you would know?
Whether you are married, or not?
What if I am? Marriage is lawful.
Yes Sir, but I doubt whether it be honourable or not: for it is said you are married to my Chamber-maid Dol Subtlety.
Perchance I am.
Then I desire your Lordship will let me marry too.
With all my heart, and I shall do my part towards thy mari∣age; but to whom would you be married?
Your Butler Sir.
Out upon thee base Girl, would you marry a Tipster?
Why Sir, a Tipster is as good as a piss-pot emptier; besides, they say you have done the fellow wrong: for she (they say) was his by pro∣mise, and if Conscience hath right, he ought to have her; and perhaps, did not Ambition come in the way, Affection might prevail: wherefore to gre∣tifie him, you ought in justice to bestow me upon him.
Well, because you shall not marry my Butler, I will not marry your Maid: for the truth is, I never had so low a thought. But let me tell you, it is in the way of disobedience to question a Fathers Actions, and a presumption for a Child to think their Father is not wise enough to govern himself; besides, Children were ungrateful to Parents, to desire that from them, which they cannot, or will not keep to themselves, as neither to suffer a Father to marry, or keep a Mistress: Do Children think a Father is bound to so many Children, and no more?
Sir, I dare answer for the part of Children, that they would be well content that their Father should have Mistresses, but they would be un∣willing and grieved that their Fathers should be their Mistresses slave, where∣by they incaptivate their Children, or ruin their Estates.
Well then inquire no more after any Mistress I shall have, un∣till you are incaptivated.

Sir Henry, by reason my Lady is gone abroad, I make bold to visit you.
I perceive I am obliged to my Wives absence for your Visit, Madam.
Faith, to tell you the truth, we women had ra∣there visit men when they are alone, than when they have company.
Then men and women agree better with particular, than with the general.
They do so, yet they love varieties best.
That's natural, for the Senses to delight in variety.
It is so, and yet our Civil and Divine Laws have forbid the use of Varieties, which (me thinks) is very unconscionable and unnatural.
But if some of the natural Appetites and Actions were not restrained by Laws, no Comman-wealth could subsist.
How did the Lacedaemonians subsist? they lived all in common; and had not all Greece been embroiled with VVars, their Common-wealth might have lasted to this day.
The Lacedaemonians had stricter Laws than the Common-wealth which we live in, and are of: for though they gave more liberty and free∣doom to some Actions than our Governments do, yet they were stricter in o∣theirs; and breakers of their Laws were more severely punished, even in the smallest breach, than the breakers of our Laws are almost in the greatest breach.
I am sure the Maker of the Lacedemonian Laws was a wise man,
and a kind-hearted man, in Decreeing for the Increase of Mankino, yet by some of his Laws he seemed but a Sloven: for he banished all curidsity and neatness, and I believe, many conveniences: Also he seemed to be a man of a weak stomach,
He rather seemed of a strong stomach, and a greedy appetite, by the course diet he brought men to live with; but (for my part) If I should judge of the Lacedaemonians Laws, I should judge that they strove to bring men to be like beasts, rather than to make them like as Gods, which men should strive to be.
By your favour Sir, there can be no Law that can keep men from being horned beasts.
Whose fault is that, Madam? not men's which make the Laws, but women's that break the Laws.
It is men's fault, for giving women such liberty: And let me tell you Sir, women are such subtle creatures, as they strive first to get an honou∣rabble esteem from their Friends and Husbands, and a belief of their Cha∣steady; and when they have secured men's jealousies, they make their Hus∣bands Cuckolds, which all their Neighbours perceive, although the Husband is blind and muffled with affection.
Madam, your Sex deserve a better Character than you give of them: for by your description there are few chaste.
Every woman knows the humours of her own Sex better than men know the humours of one another: wherefore let me advise you, Sir Henry Sage, to watch my Lady your Wife: for many, to my knowledge, seek for to corrupt her.
Madam, although she is one of your Sex, yet she is of an Angelical nature, and not corruptible.
Sir, I am your humble servant, and I wish your Angel may not fall from Virtue into Vice.
I have no jealous doubt, Madam.
I wonder at it: for wise men use to doubt.
Wife, I have given you warning twice, beware of the third time, that you receive no Masculine Visitors: for by Heaven, if you do, I will hang you up in my garters.
Do if you dare, I will have those that shall cut your throat.
You could not fright me with your Champions, were I a coward: for they are Carpet-Knights, and dare not fight.
They dare more than you dare.
By Heaven I'll give an Example to all men that love their Honour, and hate to be Cuckolds.
O Husband, Husband, spare me, spare me.
Wife, you may make me a Fool, but not unman me; you may flatter me, but not frighten me; you may make me commit an indiscretion, but never to be Effeminate.
O mercy, mercy, Husband, do but spare me this time, and I will be the best wife in the World.
Well, I will pardon you this time; and know, Wife, that though I am willing to part with my Breeches and Doublet to give them you, yet I will never part with my Sword and my Spurs, which is my Courage and my Management: And I will give you all liberty in Vanity, but not in Dis∣honesty; you shall keep the Purse, but not manage the Horse: Also let me tell you, that it is not enough to be honest, but you must give no suspicion to the contrary.
Come, Come Madam, are you ready? for Monsieur A∣morose hath provided a great and costly Banquet for you.
I am ready, I did only stay for you to go along with me.
But will not your Husband watch whither we go?
O no: for he believes I am going to the Lady Breeders Up∣sitting.
That's well be is so credulous to believe so easily whatsoever you would have him believe, and if he be but as obstinate of belief of that you would not have him believe you are happy, for let me tell you, that all men hath not that spiritual gift of Faith, but have strange opinions, and full of doubts, and suspicions.
Nay, I thank Jove, I have as good a Husband, as any woman whatsoever hath.
Prithee Madam leave some thanks for your loving servant, which loves, and adores you more than he doth Heaven, and worships you as his only Goddess.
He shall not pray in vain, nor shall I be as an Idol made of Stone, or Brass.
Come your ways then.
O man! O man! inconstant man! false and perjuri∣os man! flattering dissembling man! and the worst of Mankind is Sir Francis Inconstant! He hath not only forsaken me, but forgot me, drown∣ing the memory of me in his superfluous Cups. O Pluto, from whence all wickedness proceeds, make his fair Bride as false to him, as he hath proved to me, and sill his mind with furious Jealousy.
Who's there?
It is I, Husband.
I may bid you welcome, Wife: for you are a stranger here.
Truly Husband, I should not have disturbed you, but that I was afraid you were not well: for I came two or three times to the door, and heard no noise, which made me afraid you might be in a swoon, or dead.
I thank you for your loving fear and care of me.
You may think this is an over-fond humour in me; but I have heard of many that have been found dead in their Beds, and in their Closets, when as their Friends never mistrusted it, but thought they were asleep, or a• study, which if they had been found or known in time, they might have been recovered.
You say true Wife.
But now I know you are well, I will not disturb you any longer.
I will bear your kindness company.
Wife, thou art false.
It is strange to hear you say so, when but yesterday you made me such protestations of your Faith, believing I was Virtuous, Chaste, and full of Truth, which I did think Time had not power to alter your belief, and such Vows and Protestations of your Affections to me, as if the fire of Love within your heart did burn so clear, and flame so high, as nought could quench it out but Death's cold damps, yet not so much, but still a heat with∣in the ashes would remain.
I confess, Wife, my doubts of Love did make me to try, at least to say so to you.
True Love never makes doubts; and though you can dissemble with me, I cannot dissemble with you, could the Gods command me, as they cannot, things unjust.
I perceive you are angry, Wife.
No truly Husband, I am rather grieved than angry, to think my honest truth mistrusted: for Doubts are unjust to great Affections, true Love, and good Intentions; and Examinations are scandalous to a strict chaste life, and makes it seem as criminal: but could the World lay false∣hood to your charge, and should condemn you, yet my Affections would set you free, and rather tax my self for want of Merit to deserve your Love, than you want love to give Desert.
Prithee Wife be not grieved nor angry, for it is natural for Love to be suspicious: wherefore pray forgive my doubts.
My nature is to forgive, and not to bear a grudge or spleen in mind.
Then we are friends again.
My love is still the same, not to be altered.
Fool, How many degrees is there in Understanding?
Three.
Distinguish them.
There is a Celestial Understanding, a Terrestrial Understanding, and an Understanding betwixt both, as an Airestial Understanding: Those that are Celestial, are wise men; those that are Terrestrial, are fools; and those that are betwixt both, as Airestial, are half-witted men.
I thought you would have said that those that were Terrestrial, were beasts.
O no: for beasts are one degree above wise men, two degrees a¦bove half wetted men, and three degrees above fools.
But how will you make that good, that beasts are wiser than wise men?
By all their actions: for beasts (for the most part) are more endue∣strious, prudent, temperate, and peaceable, than the best of men; neither do they trouble their heads, nor break their sleeps, about the trifles of the World, but govern their Affairs easily, and live orderly, every several kind agreeing amongst themselves; besides, we are taught to imitate the Ser∣pent and the Dove, and Examples are Principles, and the Original is to be preferred before the Copy, the Sample before the Pattern. Thus a Beast is preferred before a Wise man, by reason all Men must learn of Beasts to be wise, and of Birds to be virtuously honest, as to be harmless.
Certainly Madam, you will starve your self with eating so little.
Why a little serves Nature.
Yes; but there are great differences betwixt Natures: for mankind requires more food than some kind of beasts or birds; for a man would be starved, if he should eat no more than a Dormouse, or a Chameleon, or a Sparrow.
But a Sparrow cannot eat so much as an Eagle, nor an Eagle so much as an Ostrich: Likewise, as it is with Bird-kind, so it is with Man∣kind, some would starve with that proportion another would surfeit on.
But surely there are none that could surfeit with your diet, as with Water and Air, nay (most commonly) nothing but Air, Camelion-like: for you oft times for a week together neither eat bit, nor drink a drop; and that which makes me wonder more, is, that you naturally have a very good sto∣match, and can eat, when you please, very heartily, and it thrives well with you; but my greater wonder is, that when you do fast, eating now and then a bit, week after week, nay month after month, yet you are not so lean, as to appear a Skeleton, nor so weak, but you can walk two hours without re∣sting, or being very weary.
Oh Custom is a second Nature, Join.
I would have your Ladyship accustom your self to live without eating, and then you will be set in a Chronicle.
Who would strive for that, since most think Chronologers are Artificers, and that their Chronicles are false.
Why some will believe it; and it were better to live in the memo∣rye of a few, than to die to all memory, and to live by nothing.
I would have my Fame live only by singular and transcending Merits, not by singular and melancholy Follies. I know my Errors, though I cannot mend my Faults.
Well Madam, you are to give me thanks for bringing you ac∣quainted with Monsieur Amorous: for he is as fine a Gentleman as any our Nation hath.
Indeed he is the most obligingst person as ever I met with; but pray Madam, what said he of me?
O he raves in your praise: He says you are the finest, sweetest, fairest and kindest Lady that ever was: but did not your Husband examine you when you came home?
No faith, not much, some slight questions he asked; but come into my Chamber, and there let us discourse of Monsieur Amorous.
I will make you humbler than to give me such unmannerly words. What had you to do in my Husbands, your Masters Chamber?
I went to speak with Tom my Masters barber.
What had you to do with your Masters barber? I am sure you had no use for him; but I will beat you so, as you shall not be able to stir, much less to go frisking into your Masters Chamber so often as you do.
What a Volley of words their gun-powder breath, and the fire-lock of their anger hath shot into my Ears, giving me no warning to barricade them up, but hath surprised my brain by their sudden assault, and hath blown up the Magazines of my Contemplations; but all creatures love to make a noise, beasts vocally, men verbally, and some actually in boyste∣rous deeds.
How now Fool, what's the matter?
Why this is the matter fool, thy Sister fool hath beaten her Maid fool, for kissing her Master fool.
For kissing her Masters fool, say you?
Nay by'r Lady, if she had done so, she had been wise: for if she had kissed me, she had not been beaten; but she did not kiss me, Ergo she's a fool.
Husband, why seem you so sad?
My love to you makes me sad.
To me? Heaven bless me, what do you see in me to make you sad?
Why for these passions and •rights that you fall into, like one in an Epilepsy, and now you look as pale, as if you were ready to fall down dead.
Alas Husband, consider it is a timorous effect of Love, which is to be pardoned, since it proceeds from the kindness I have to my Friends; it is honourable to the World, and no dishonour to you, but only trouble∣some to my self, and to those I naturally love, as Husband, Children, Father, Mother, Brothers, and Sisters: And though fond Love and vain Fears may be produced from the melancholy Spleen, yet those fears that proceed from my firm, true, and honest Affection, are created in the Soul: for noble, and honourable, and honest Fears, are the natural Issues of pure Love.
But Reason, the chief Magistrate of the Soul, and Governor of the Passions, should temper the Excess.
O Husband, when Love comes to be tempered, it loses or quit• the essential part, and the vertical strength: for true Love is pure like gold, which is debased with an allay.
But as Allay makes gold work better for use, so Temperance makes Love Happy for life.
Well Husband, I will strive to love with Discretion.
Pray do, and go abroad, to divert your melancholy, and eat as others do, that may have good meat and drink, and not live by the Air, as you do.
I shall obey you.
O Cupped, thou art a cruel Tyrant, making more wounds than remedies! And I am wounded so, as I am sick with Love, and
cannot live unless I am beloved again.
To make my Passions know, is all my care,
Lest he should love me not, is all my fear.
Sir Thomas Cuckold, Monsieur Amorous desires very much to make friendship with you: for he is so taken with your Civilities, and your courteous Demeanours when he was to visit you, that he swears you are one of the finest Gentlemen in the Kingdom: He says you are so gravely wise, so hospitably kind, and so generously free, as he honours you, and loves you with his soul.
I am his very humble Servant, and shall be glad, nay proud of such a worthy Friend as Monsieur Amorous.
Have you returned his Visit?
No; but I'll go wait upon him immediately.
Childrens eyes are always flowing,
Women's tongues are always going,
And men's brains are always musing,
And mans natures all abusing,
And mans life is always running,
And mans death is always coming.
Whose death is coming?
Yours for any thing I know: wherefore take heed; for let me tell you; Death is a rough fellow: for he pulls the soul out of the body, as a Barber-Chirurgeon doth a tooth, sometimes with less pain, sometimes with more; but many times Death is forced to tear the body, as a Tooth-drawer tears the jaw-bone, before he can get it out.
What Instruments doth Death draw out the Soul with?
Sickness, Wounds, Passions, Accidents, and the like.
But how came Death and you so well acquainted?
We are near a Kin: for Death and Ignorance are Cousin-Ger∣mans.
Faith thou art rather a Knave than a Fool, and a Knave is nearer akin to Life than Death.
Well, I am resolved to be Divorced from my Husband, for I cannot endure his tyranny any longer: for he will let me have my will in nothing, crosses and contradicts me in every thing.
Madam, we are taught to obey and humble our selves to our Superiors, and the Husband is the Master of his Family, the Governor of his Estate, and Ruler and Disposer of his Children, the Guide and Protector of his Wife.
Yes, he protects me well indeed, when he breaks my head.
May be your Ladyship doth provoke him with some unkind words.
What unkind words were they? I only said that Goos-quils made the best pens to write with, and he said no, that Crows-quils were better for that purpose: it is true, at last I returned as bad words as he flung at me.
Truly Madam, it is a great grief to your friends and servants, to see yoo live so disquietous together; besides, you torment your selves with your own anger.
That's the reason I would part: for I will never be a slave to his humour, I will rather choose to die first.
It were better we were parted, than to live in a perpe∣tual war together.
But Sir, is it not possible to temper your Passion?
No truly: for her words are so sharp, and pierce so deep, that they make me as furious as a wilde Boar that is hurt with a Javelin: And since she cannot temper her Tongue, nor I temper my Passion, it will be best for us to live asunder: for absence is the best and most certain remedy I can think of.
Have not you heard that my Master hath had a Quarrel, and is wounded?
Yes; and it is said he fought so valiantly, as he beat half a do∣zen lusty men, and followed them so close, as they were forced to take shelter; and I have also heard, that one of them he beat, swears to be re∣venged.
But if my Lady hears of it, she will run mad, or die.
O no, my Lady (Join says) hath left those follies, and is be∣come discreet.
Discreet? what is that? to be ill-natured, as not to care if her Husband or Friends be killed?
O yes, so much to care, as to pity them, and be sorry, nay sad, if they should be killed; but not passionately to drown themselves in tears, or to let their grief feed on their life, and die.
O my sweet Amorous!
O my dear Cuckold, the delight of my Life!
Faith Amorous I have been to seek you all the Town over, and my Lady Procurer met me, and sent me to the other end of the City, telling me you were at the Horn-Tavern.
Why do you not know her humour? she will serve you twen∣tie such tricks: for she is the veriest Wag in all the Town, although she is in years.
Well, if I be not even with her, as very a Wag as she is, let me be condemned for a fool.
O Madam, my Master is coming home, being wounded in a Duel.
Help, help, my Lady, my Lady.
What's the matter?
My Lady is killed with the report of my Masters being hurt.
It were fit you should be punished for telling her of it.
Take life again: for my Master is not so much hurt, as to be in dan∣ger of Death.
Do you speak this as a known truth, or for to recover me?
As a truth upon my Conscience, Madam.
Then I charge you do not discover my Passion.
We shall not.
Go, and give charge to my Footmen, that none of them run home to tell my Wife of my hurt, for fear of frighting her: for if she hears I am hurt before she sees me, she will apprehend me worse than I am, and that may kill her.
Sir, she hath heard of it already.
Rogue that he was that he was that told her: who was it?
It was I Sir, when I went to fetch your Leaguer-cloak to keep you warm.
Villain, I'll run you through.
What you please Sir; but my Lady takes it very patiently: for
when she heard of it, she was playing on the Lute, and did not leave playing at the report.
I am glad she is so discreet.
Truly Sir I think my Lady is now one of the wisest and discreetest Ladies in the Town.
What, for playing on the Lute?
No Sir; but for being so patient and temperate, as all wise persons are, who bear afflictions with that Moral Philosophical Carelessness, and (as they call it) passive Courage, composing their Faces into a Grave, surly Countenance, fashioning their Behaviour with Formality, walking with a slow and stately Pace, speaking nothing but Wise Sentences, and Learned Morals.
You are a moral Ass; and although my wounds are but small, yet I grow faint with standing to hear a fool talk.
Sir, I believe you may wonder, and think it strange, that a woman can love a stranger so soon and so much.
I doe not think it strange in Nature, but I think it strange you should affect me, a person which is no way worthy of your Favour and your Love, unless you (like a Deity) humbly descend to mortals, accepting of their Adorations and Offerings: And, as a mortal to a Deity, I offer up my Heart on the Altar of your Obligations.
Here I do vow to Venus, not only to offer you my person, and all delights that it can yield, but I offer you my Honour, my Fathers Honour, my Husbands Honour, nay their lives, if you require it.
I must confess your Husbands life is dangerous, for we cannot well enjoy our loves with safety, if that your Husband lives.

I cannot; for you must do it as you find Fortune gives you op∣portunity.

My revenge is too big for words, all actions to little for his pu∣nishment: wherefore you furies, I invoke you to assist me, and if Hell gives me not help, Heaven or Death give me ease.
Now Monsieur Amorous, you and the Lady Wanton shall not need to make so many excuses to meet, for your going into the Country, with Sir Thomas Cuckold, you will be always in the House with his Lady.
Faith, I have a great deal of business in the City, which may suffer, if I should go out of the Town.
Out upon you, make excuses already.
I do not make excuses, I only tell you the truth of my affairs.
Can you have any affairs greater, or of more concernment, than waiting on a Mistress, and such a Mistress as you were a dying for to enjoy, but a little time since? well go thy ways Monsieur Amorous, for thou art like a woman that hath fits of the Mother, often swouning and sick, but never dyes in any of them.
The Lady Chastity would be like a draught of cold water, to bring me to life again.
Let me tell thee, as those fits will never kill thee, so all the Cha∣steady in the Town can never cure thee.
Pray Iuno, my Husband doth not perceive I have cried.
You need not fear it, for the hot Cloth you laid to your eyes hath so•'d out the redness, and abated the swelling thereof; but I doubt you will cry when you see him.
I hope I shall be wiser, than to cry; for I would not have my Husband think me a Fool, or troublesome, for the world.
But surely Madam, you must needs torment your Soul, to strive so much against nature.
Love had rather torment it self, then torment what it loves.
Your Ladyship will make the old Proverb good, which says, love overcomes all things, and surely it overcomes all when it overcomes nature it self.
Prethy Fool watch thy Master, and my Maid Nan, and when they are together give notice, and I will give thee a new Coat.
I shall stand Sentinel, and give the watch-word.
Most Creatures their tails lies in their heads, or their heads lies in their Neighbours tails, nose to breech; for they are always thinking thereof; which makes their thoughts as sluts and slovens, their brains like to a heap•up Dunghill; but I must watch, my Master and his Maid to catch.
It is strange, that Sir Humphrey Disagree, and his Lady, cannot agree, yet they are both of good natures, and generous Souls; keep a noble House, and are bountiful to their Servants, kind and courteous to their Friends, and he a very understanding Gentleman, and a learned Scholar, and an honest Man.
And she is a very Chaste Lady, a good Huswife, and very or∣dearly in her House, as concerning what she is to take care of, or to direct, and is very pious and devout, and yet both to be so indiscreet as to fall out about light toys, and frivolous matters.
It is strange, and truly great pity; wherefore, we ought to do our endeavour, to try if we can make them friends.
Surely that might be easily done; for they are as apt, and as soon friends when their anger's over, as they are apt to fall out when they are friends, and I make no doubt to make them friends; but the business is to keep them friends, and the question is, whether it were not better they should be parted friends, than present enemies.
Yet we have discharged our parts, if we make or do our in∣devour to make them friends.
Well Sir, persuade the Husband, and I will try to persuade the Wife.
Sir, you do amaze me; for I have not been so long married as to give her time for Incontinence, nor have I been so ill a Hus∣band as yet, as to create, or beget her hate towards me.
Sir, if I do not prove it, I shall be content to suffer the heaviest punishment you can inflict upon me; and because your belief is wavering, I will place you, where you shall hear her declare her intentions, as towards your Death.
I long to prove the Truth.
Prethy my Lady Procurer, go into the Country with us, since we shall have such good Company this Summer, as Monsieur Amorous, we will be so merry, and have such sports and pastimes, as you shall not repent your journey.
Faith Madam I cannot; besides, you have no use of me now.
I am not as many others are, that when they can make no more use of a friend, they strive to shun their Company.
Well, if I can go with you I will; but I doubt I cannot, at lest I cannot stay above a week, or such a time with you.
Nay, if I once get you there, I will make you stay.
What a troublesome life is a Married life, bless me Heaven, who would Marry?
That would you if you could get a Husband; for Maids long to be Wives, and Wives longs to be Widows, that they might Marry again.
That is, because Maids do not know the vexations of Marriage, which Wives do.
Faith Women take a pleasure in being vexed, crossed, and injured; for then they have a ground for their anger, and revenge is the sweetest, and dearest employment they have, or would wish to have; otherwise, they would be dull, and idle without it; and to prove it, Widows are as •arae••, and industrious to Marry as Maids, and all is, because they would be vexed and crossed.
And are not men as desirous, and hasty to Marry as Women?
Yes, those that are Fools.
Why then you should marry, if any Woman would have you.
Such Fools as I, never, or very seldom Marry, for though we are Christened Fools, we were Born Wise (where other men were Born Fool•, but Christened Wise) as bearing the name of Wise and understanding Men, so as they have only the name, but not the wisdom; the Truth is, we Fool, and other men are fooled.
Then Women are Born Wise, for they Fool Men.
Nay saith, poor Souls, they are for the most part double fooled; first, thinking they fool, and then in being fooled.
Mistress, my Lady is very angry, that you let your Lute-Master stay, whilst you talk to the fool; she says you will be as much a fool as he, with talking so often with him.
Tell my Sister, I shall learn more good from the fool, than the sidler.
Mark you that Maid.
I mark that Children and Fools keep company together.
And the Maids and the Master.
Alas my poor Lady looks as if she would drop to the earth, so pale and ill.
How should she be otherwise, for she smothers in her grief, and dares not discover it; and then she seldom sleeps, or eats, or drinks: and is so restless, as she cannot sit still, but walks about her Chamber.
O Master Doctor, what do you think of my Husband, I hope he is in no danger, is he?
I dare assure you Madam, he will be very well again; for he is only weak and faint with loss of blood: for he taking the wound to be slight, did not take care to stop it soon enough, whereupon his Spirits with his blood issued out so much, as makes him so weak, as you see he is forced to keep his Bed.
But Doctor, Spirits is life, and if he wants the one, he must soon lose the other.
It is true, if there were no Spirits left: but let me tell you Madam, there is more danger when the Body hath too many Spirits, than when there is but a few; for many Spirits make the Body too hot, by giving the Pulse too quick a motion; which quick motion, fires the heart so much, as the blood becomes boiling hot; which Parboils the Liver, and the rest of the vital parts, and melts the fat, wastes the flesh, and weakens the Sinews, or Nerves, as being boiled as to a soft, tender, quaking Jelly; that is the cause that the Sick is so weak they cannot stand, having not that tough strength in their Sickness, and some after their sickness; and shall continue weak, until such time as the Sinews, and Nerves grow harder, and tough again; and many times from the boiling blood there arises such gross, and so many Vapours, which Vapours is Smoke, as they stiff•le the life, or at least disquiet the Brain.
But will you assure me Doctor?
As far as Human skill can assure you I will.
Fair Iuno hear me, send to thy Brother Pluto, to imprison Death in his dark Vault, or at least for to forbid him to touch my Husband; and fair Goddess, send health to raise his weary limbs from off his hated Couch, if not, give order to grim Death to strike me too; for thou hast power on all, as being chief in power.
Madam, my Master desires you would be pleased to come to him.
I will not only make me a Garland, but a Bower of Willow, where I will sit and lament all forsaken Lovers; nay, I will sit and Curse so long, till I have laid those Curses so thick together, as nei∣there sighs, nor tears, nor prayers, shall dissolve them.
I am come to bring you good news, Monsieur Amo∣rous.
What is that my comfortable Lady?
The Lady Wanton is come to Town.
Pluto.
What do you swear, because she is come to Town?
No I swear, because I must go out of Town.
I hope you will not go out of the Town, now she is come to town.
Alas my occasions are such, as I shall be utterly ruined if I stay.
Then let me tell you, the Lady Chastity begins to listen to your Suit.
And is there hopes I shall enjoy her?
I cannot tell.
Nay Dear Lady, speak some comfort?
It is a solly, if you must go into the Country.
Neptune shall swallow the Country, rather than I will endanger to lose a Paradise.
But if you stay, you will be ruined.
I rather shall be ruined if I go, for now I have considered it, I find, I have such potent affairs here in the City, as they will force me to stay.
O Iupiter! how Inconstant is Mankind; for what they have enjoyed they despise, and what they cannot get, they earnestly desire, and are restless in the pursuit.
What say you?
I say you are an unthankful Man, and not worthy of a Ladies favour, as to forsake her that loves you, and seek her that hates you; for know, the Lady Chastity scorns your Suit, despises your Person, and hates your Humour.
Pluto take all your sex.
If he should, you would whiningly follow them to Hell, rather
than miss their Company, refusing Heaven, for effeminate Society.
They torment men more than Devils do.
Now Sir Humphrey Disagree and his Lady are made good friends, they are become a loving Couple.
Heaven keep them so.
Truly I begin to believe they will; for they seem very sense∣ble of their errors, and they laugh at their one follies, to see, what ridicu∣lous, frivolous, and small matters, their quarrels are built with, and upon.
Look you Wife, here is the Priest that hath new married us, and our friend that hath joined us in a loving friendship again.
And I will celebrate this Union with a Feast, to which, I will invite my good friends as to my wedding day.
I perceive we shall be merry, pray let us have Fiddlers, and Dance.
That we will.
Come, come Wife, you are not so kind as you were wont to be; for you did use to watch my looks, my sleep, and how I fetched my breath in my sleep, and what I did eat, and how much I did eat, for fear I should be sick, and no help unsought to cure me: But I perceive you are as all other women are, inconstant; for now you do neglect me, and seldom come near me but when I send for you.
I dare not, for fear my diligence may prove loves indiscre∣tion, and so my service become a burdensome trouble.
You Cowardly Rogue, do you take the advantage of sick∣nos to work your revenge, do you come when my Husband is not able to defend himself?
Killed? if you had a thousand lives, my single life would kill them all, rather than suffer my Husband to be murdered.
You Company of dull dead statues, move for shame, and bear away this Villain, this murderous Villain.
Where should we carry him Madam?
Why any where, cast him into a Ditch, there let him lie and rot, like Beasts without Butiall.
Carry him to a Justice, and bid the Justice dispose of him as he thinks fit, telling him of his crime.
Let us search him, to see if he hath never another Pistol.
Go you Cowards, and carry him away.
O this effeminate sickness hath disgraced me; O how like a worm a sick man is, which lies so low, and is so shiftless, that any beast treads out his life?
Why, had you been in health and strength, it would have been no Honour to beat a Coward.
He seemed not such a Coward, but that he had some courage, or otherwise he would not have adventured himself alone into a House, wherein were many persons, which would have been his Enemies; but I am glad that you have the honour of his wounds, but it is a miracle to me, to see how valiantly you did behave your self, and yet by nature is so fearful.
Mistake not Love; for true Love is only a afraid when it cannot help, but when it hath hopes to rescue what it loves, Mars is not More valiant.
Well Wife, I owe my life to your love, and I shall account you as Pallas, that hath defended me with a prudent courage.
If you think I have done you service worthy a reward, pray give me a request.
That I shall, if it be that life you have defended, what is it?
It is to set love free from the Chains of discretion, and Joe∣ler of temperance; for it is impossible to confine love, but either it will die, or break out in revenge.
Well Wife, hereafter I will never oppose loves ways.
Sir, did you hear what your Lady said?
Yes, I heard her say, she would poison me in a mess of broth.
What will you do to prevent it?
Leave that care to me, I shall be my own Sentinel, to discern the approaching Poison.
Their Deaths will be my triumph, and my Death a re∣prieve.
I am come to invite you to a Collation, for the Lady Wanton, for whom you at first made costly Collations, is forced to invite you now to the like.
Faith Madam, I am so squezy stomached, that the very sight of a Banquet will put me into an Apoplexy, as with an obstructed Surfeit.
If you should deny her, you would lose you reputation amongst our Sex for ever.
Well I will go, upon condition that you carry a message from me to another Lady.
Most willingly, so it be not to the Lady Chastity.
Prethy Fool give me advice, as how to choose a Husband.
Faith you are wise to take a Fools Counsel; for Fools have for the most part, best Fortune, either in their Counsel or Choice.
Why, are Fools Fortunes favourites?
Yes, for by Fools Fortune plainly shows her power, when wise men usurp it, striving to take her power from her.
Then Fortune direct thee, to direct me.
Fortune is giddy, and directs by chance, which causes so many misfortunes.
Then by your direction, I may be unfortunate; but I will venture, wherefore tell me how to choose.
Why then, you must choose a Husband by the Ear.
By the Eye you mean.
No faith, those that would be happily matched, must choose a Hus∣band, or Wife by the Ear, and not by the Eye: for though report is oft-times false, yet it seldom flatters; nay for the most part, it is so far from go∣avenge merit its due Praises, as it detracts therefrom.
But Fortune carries worthless men upon the tongue of fame.
It is true, but Fortune being giddy, is apt to stagger, and so to stum∣ble, and oft-times flings those worthless men in soul disgrace.
But hopes and fears, bribe or force the World to praise a worthless He, or She.
It is true, hopes of gain are bribes, and fear of punishments are threats, for to persuade, or force the tongue to flatter; yet none but Gods and Kings, are subject to this flattery, and you are not to marry, either the one, nor yet the other; for Gods join not to Mortals, and Kings are far too proud to marry Subjects; nor were it good for you, if that they would, as that you were matched to a King: for happiness lives in equality.
Faith thou art too wise to wear a Fools-Coat; wherefore cast it oft.
And faith I should be more Fool than my profession makes me, if I should cast it off; therefore I will keep it on.
O my Dear love, I have such an opportunity, that For∣tune could never have given me a better; for my Husband is fallen Sick, and if I Poison him now, the World will say, and think it was his Sickness that killed him, and that will secure me.
I he be Sick, perchance he may dye, and that will save you the labour, and hazard of poisoning.
O But if he should recover again, then I were undone; where∣fore I will not venture to rely upon his Sickness.
Use your discretion, but tic not fit we should be seen together; wherefore, I will kiss your hands, and leave you for a time.
And I hope the next time we meet, we shall be rid of the obe∣structor of our loves:
Madam, did you give Monsieur Amorous the present I sent you to give him?
Yes, there was Shirts, Caps, and Handkerchiefs, of each two dozen.
There were so.
They were of the finest Holland, and Flanders Lace, that ever I saw, what might the present cost you?
Not much above five hundred pounds.
You speak as if it were but a slight present, but if your Husband knew of it, he would think it were too much by four hundred ninety and nine pound nineteen shillings eleven pence halfpeny farthing.
But what said Monsieur Amorous, when you presented that pre∣sent, as from me?
At the first he would not receive the present, saying it was too costly, and that he could not return enough thanks for it, and so should seem as ungrateful against his will; but at last upon my persuasion, he took your present, and to Morrow he will come and give you thanks.
I had rather meet him in some other place, than receive his visit at home, where my Husband is.
Husband, how shall these Children live?
By Heavens Providence Wife.
I fear they will starve, unless your providence feeds them.
It was imprudently done to get them.
But now they are got, they must be provided for.
Yes, as Beggars provide for their Children, put them to the Parish.
The Parish will not keep them.
Then sell them to Animal Merchants, they will Traffic with them into the Barbados, or Barmudes, or Virginy, or the like places.
And how shall I live?
Why you may go along, and be their Nurse.
And the Merchants Whore.
As you can agree; for he may sell you at as great a prize after, as if you were honest; besides, your Children will prove you to be fruitful, for which, they will give a double, or treble price for you; and if you thrive send me word, and I will come to you, if I cannot live here.
I thank you Husband, for you have made me miserably unhappy, by your mispendings, yet you would feed upon my good fortune, if it can be called good fortune, to thrive with dishonesty.
Faith Fortune hath undone me; but may be she will be chari∣table to you.
I hope so, for Fortune never befriends those whom Vices be∣sots, and though your deboysteries have undone you, I hope my Virtues will help to save me.
But I never perceived your virtue to do you any good, but for any thing I perceive to the contrary, you are like to starve, for all your virtues.
I hope when I am parted from you and your wickedness, Heaven will power down some mercy on me.
Pray Madam inform me where Monsieur Amorous is, for I have sent two or three times to his Lodging, and my Messenger is an∣answered still he is from home.
He is a wanderer.
I think he is wandered into some other parts of the World, for after he went from us, I sent a dozen Letters, whilst I staid in the Country, and received not one answer.
Faith Madam Monsieur Amorous is one of the lasiest of Mankind.
I am resolved when I see him to chide him, for I could not con∣veniently do it when he came to give me thanks for my present.
Sir Thomas Cuckold, you are welcome to the Town, for though I have had the Honour to see your Lady two or three times, yet I could not got a sight of you never since you came out of the Country.
My Wife did wish for your Company whilst we were in the Country, a hundred times.
I should be glad to be in any place, to do my Lady Service.
I was abroad even now, where I met Monsicur Amorous, who looked upon me as if he knew me not, or rather as if he did despise me.
Perchance he did not know you.
His memory must be very short, if he could forget me so soon.
Perchance Husband you looked strangely upon him.
Truly Wife I went to embrace him, as I was used to do, with kind love, and he crossed the street to shun me.
I dare lay my life it is some mistake Husband.
Friends (Sir Thomas) must never be exceptious.
I am not apt to be exceptious, I will assure you Madam no Man is freer from that humour than I am.
This feigned Sickness shall serve as a snare, to catch my Wives design.
My dear heart how are you?
Very Sick, so Sick as I fear Heaven doth envy my happiness, and will part us by Death.
The Gods forbid! I hope you will live so long, as to Crown your Virtuous life with aged years.
O no, I find my life draws towards an end, and Death will separate us from each other; but you being young Wife, will soon for∣get me, placing your love upon some other Man, in whom, all the remem∣bronco of me will be buried.
Dear Husband speak not so Melancholy; your words strike such terror into my heart, as I cannot endure to hear them, I had ra∣there Death should strike me, than you; Dear Husband, cheer up your self, your Disease is only Melancholy; wherefore take such nurishing things, as may give your Spirits strength and life; shall I bring you a little Burnt Wine, to comfort your Spirits, or some Jelly broth to strenghten your Stomach?
If you please Wife.
Now for the poisoned Draught.
Here my dear heart, drink this.
What mean you Husband to lock the Door?
Because none shall enter, until the Broth be drunk Wife.
No Wife, you must not go out, for I mean to nourish you with that Broth that you would have nourished me with.
Why Husband I am not Sick, I do not require Broth.
O yes Wife, your Soul is Sick, although your Body is well, and this Broth may perchance cure the one, although it kills the other; wherefore drink it.
I will not.
You shall, and if you drink it not willingly, I will force it down you throat.
Dear Husband spare me.
Why, I give you nothing but that which you prepared for me, and if it were good for me, it is good for you.
Dear Husband have mercy on me, and I will confess my crimes.
No Wife, no more mercy than you would have had one me, and therefore drink it:
It is Poison Husband.
That is the reason you shall drink it Wife.
Dear Husband, let me live but to repent my sins, which like a black thick cloud do cover all my Soul.
This will be a sufficient punishment, for if you be pu∣nished in this World, you may escape the punishment of the next.
Good Husband consider youth, that is apt to run into er∣rors, not being guided with good Counsel, as it ought.
I will consider nothing, and therefore drink it, or by Heaven I will force you to it, and therefore linger not.
You Gods forgive me my crimes, and let this deadly draught purge clean my Soul from sin.
Now Wife have you any Amorous desires to Monsieur Disguise.
No, the fire of my unlawful love is quenched.
Ha she is dead, what hath my furious passion done, I was too sudden to crop her tender life so hastily, without more strict exa∣minations; for it was likely thus spruce Gallant corrupted her with his al∣luring
looks, and smooth enticing words, which he knew well how to apply; and youth is credulous, and women soon persuaded, and being joined in one they easily are overcome. I do repent.
I will revenge my self of those that were the cause.
Where is Monsieur Amorous that he comes not with you, you said you would bring him with you?
Faith he desires to be excused, for he saith he is not well.
This is but an excuse, for he hath made an hundred within this week; but since he doth neglect me, I will have another that shall be more constant.
You are wise Madam: for since men are so various as they are, women would seem but fools, should they be constant.

Truly Join, so am I to see you.

Why she lives privately, but is likely to live happy enough; for let friends have now taken care of her and her Children, upon the condition that she will receive no visits from her Husband, but banish his Company; left he should increase their charge with more Children; neither will they allow him any thing.
By my trath he doth not deserve any maintenance; but I am glad she is provided for, being a shiftless creature for her self and Children, but where do you live Ursely?
Why I live with an old Widower.

to make a match betwixt them, that so we may live once again in a House together; for you and I were always dear friends you know.

Wife, where are the Fiddlers that you promised we should have.
I did forbid them to play, until such time as we had half dined, for their scraping would hinder our eating.
Pray wife let them come in, for I love my meat should dance in my mouth, my teeth keeping just time to the tune; and the Music will make my meat turn nimbly in my mouth, and will heat my cast to a high gusto.
The noise that they will make, will take away my Stomach, and will make my head ache; besides, no body will hear one another speak, neither will our Servants hear what we call for.
It will make our Servants the more diligent, for Mu∣sick will revive their Spirits, and will make them agile; wherefore pray Wife let them come in and play.
No pray Husband let them alone a little while longer.
If you keep them out until our Stomachs be full, we shall be so dull and heavy with the vapour of the meat, as it will not be in the power of Music to move our minds to mirth, or so drunk with Wine, as the Music will make us mad.
I hope you will not be mad before you are drunk.
No Wife, I will be merry before I am drunk, where∣fore Servants call them in.

in truth it is a sad Feast, and I was joyed to think how merry we should all be.

Why, so you may still.

That they can never do, so long as the sound of their tongues is within the distance of their Ears; besides nature hath not matched their dis∣positions, or humours.
You say right, intrude their Souls are mismatched, and therefore it is impossible they should ever agree.

O my Soul make haste and follow hers.

The Lady Natures Daughters are the only Ladies that are admired, praised, adored, worshipped, and sued to; all other women are despised.
We may go into a Nunnery; for we shall never get Servants, nor Husbands, as long as they live.
Why there are but three of them, and three women cannot serve and content all the men in the World.
No, but they may discontent all the men so much, as to make them all to be Male-contented Lovers, who will reject all, because they can∣not have what they desire.
Let us make a Faction against them.
Alas what Faction against them, can hurt and destroy Love, Wit, and Beauty?
Jealousy will weaken Love, Dispraise will disgrace Wit, and Beauty, Time will soon bring that to decay.
But Jealousy cannot weaken true and virtuous Love, nor Dis∣praise cannot disgrace pure Wit, nor Time cannot decay the Beauty of the mind; wherefore all the faction you can make against them, will do them no hurt; besides, you will be condemned by all the Masculine Sex, if not pu∣nished with infamy, for your treachery; and since you cannot do them harm, your best way will be to imitate them for your own good.
So we shall be laughed at, and stared on as Monkeys, and scorn∣ed; forasmuch as we offer at that which is beyond our abilities, and what∣soever is forced, and constrained, appears ridiculous.
Come let us leave speaking of them, and thinking of them, if we can.
Surely Wife you do not love me, you are not any way kind to me.
True Love Husband, is not so fond as ser∣viceable.
But true Love will express it self sometimes: for if you did truly Love me, you would hang about my Neck, as if you meant to dwell there.
If I thought my kindness might not Surfeit your af∣fection, I would hang about your Neck, as the Earth to the Center, and as you move should bear me still about you; but I am afraid if over fond, you should be weary of me, and account me a trouble, and I had rather starve all my delights, than make you loath my Company.
This is but an excuse Wife.
Why are you Jealous, that you think my words speak not my thoughts? have I behaved my self so indiscreetly, or have my actions been so light, as you believe I shall be wanton?
No, I do not fear your Virtue.

I hope you will give me no cause to fear, although Husbands are oftner dishonoured by their Wives Indiscretions, than their Inconstant affections.

I will go with you, if you will give me leave.
With all my Heart.
My Noble Lord, I am a Gentleman, one that is ruined by Fortunes spite, and not by my own Carelessness, Vanity, Luxury, or Prodigality; for my Poverty is honest: but though my Poverty hath an ho∣nest face, yet it is ashamed to appear in the open sight of public knowledge, which makes me whisper my wants to your Lordships private Ear.
Sir, if your necessities can conceal themselves, they shall never be divulged by me; and what I can honestly give you out of my Estate, and not very imprudently from my self, I shall freely, and secretly, distribute to you, and such as are in your condition.
Your Lordships Servant.
The mind is the best Tutor, and ought to instruct the Senses how to choose; for the Senses are but as the working La∣borers, to bring Lifes materials in; but O my Senses have betrayed my mind, in bringing through my Ears, and Eyes, Beauty, and Wit, which like as creeping Serpents, got passage to my heart, and winding round about with flattering embraces, yet sting the peace, and quiet of my mind, raising therein blisters of discontent, causing an anguish of restless thoughts, which work, and beat like pulsive pa•n.
But O had I been born both Deaf and Blind,
Then might I scope this Hell tormenting mind;
His Wit like various Music pierced my Ear,
Some being solemn, and some pleasant were
And when he spake, his person did appear
Like to the Sun, when no dark Clouds were near;
Fame of his valour, like a trumpet sound,
Through Ears from Heart, unto the Eyes rebound;
And then his person, like Mars did appear,
Yet so, as when fair Venus Queen was near.
O Love forbear, use not this cruelty,
Either bind him, or give me liberty.
What are you all alone sweet Mistress?
No Sir, I have the Company of thoughts.
Those are Melancholy Companions.
Indeed mine are so at this time; yet thoughts with thoughts may discourse wittily, and converse pleasantly together, without articulate words.
Certainly your thoughts must needs be pleasant, your words are so witty.
No truly, for my thoughts lie in my brain like a Chaos in a con∣fused heap, and my brain being young, hath not enough natural heat to dis∣gest them into a Methodical order; neither hath Time cooked them ready for the Mind to dish out, or the Tongue to carry to the Ears of the hearers.
The oftner I hear, and see you, the more I wonder at you.
Why, I hope Sir I am no Monster?
No, for you seem to me something divine.
Then you should rather admire me: for Admiration proceeds from things excellent, Wonder from things strange and unusual.
So you are strange, and unusual: for things divine are not com∣mon; and certainly you are a thing illuminated beyond Natures Art, and are the only delight of Mankind.
Men take no worldly delight in Celestial Creatures, but with Earthly; wherefore the most refined and illuminated, is oftenest rejected.
No Lady, they are not rejected, but as Angels, they will not reside with us.
Sir, for fear I should lose the Angelical opinion you have of me, I will depart soon as Angels do.
Come, will you go to hear the Lady Wit discourse?
Not I.
Will you go?
I will not go to hear a prating preaching woman.
O that all the Masculine Sex would say as much.
Let us go to learn Wit.
I had rather be a Dunce all my Life.
So had I, if I must have none but a Woman instructor.
Indeed women should learn, not teach.
It's a sign Men want Wit, when they go to hear a Woe∣man preach.
But let us go, if it be but to censure; for an hundred to one, but she will say something which may be contradicted.
Then let us agree to be her contradictors: for whatsoever she saith we will confute.
Nay by your favour, that you cannot do; for though you may contradict any argument, yet not confute it: for though Envy and Spite have bred Sophistry, yet Envy and Spite cannot confute the Truth.
Well, let us go howsoever, if it be but to see, and be seen of those men as will be there to hear her.
Content.
Great Fortune, I at this time do implore,
That thou wilt open every hearing door,
Which are the Ears: let not my Wit be lost,
For want of bearing, nor my words be crossed,
Nor yet destructed by a bustling noise,
Or gazing, or observing some light toys:
But let their Ears be sixth, as if their sight
Did view my words, till on their Ears they light.
Noble and Right Honourable,
I shall take my discourse at this time out of Ignorance, which discourse, I shall divide into Five Parts, the Gods, Fates, Nature, the World, and Man; for although Ignorance be obscure, and hard to be discovered, yet it is printed in a general Language, being spread and communicated over all the World. I begin with the First, and prime Creature, Ignorant Man. Man takes himself to be the most knowing Creature, for which he hath placed himself next to the Gods; yet Man is ignorant: for what Man is, or ever was created, that knows what the Gods are, or how many there are? Or what power they have, or where they reside? What Man did ever know the Mansions of Glory, the Bowers of bliss, or the Fields of plea∣sure? What Man ever knew whether the Gods were Eternal, or bred out of infinite, or rule, or govern, infinite Eternally?
Secondly the Fates. What Man is, or ever was, that knows the Fates? As whether they are Gods or Creatures, or whether the Fates are limited, or decree as they please? Or what Man is, or ever was, that knows the decrees of Fate, the links of Destiny, or the chance of Fortune, or the lots of Chance.
Thirdly. What Man is, or ever was, that knows what Nature is, or from whence her power proceeds? As whether from the Gods, or Eterni∣tie, or infinite, or from the Fates? Or whether the Gods, or Fates, proceed from her? Or what at first set her to work? Or whether her work is pre∣scribed, or limited? Or of what she works on? Or what instruments she works with? Or to what end she works for? Or whether she shall de∣sist from working, or shall work Eternally? Or whether she worked from all Eternity? Or whether her work had a beginning, or shall have an end∣ing? What Man knows the beginning of Motion, or the Fountain of Know∣ledge, or the Spring of Life, or Gulf of Death? Or what Life is? Or what Death is? Or whether Life, Motion, and Death, had a beginning, or shall have an ending?
Fourthly the World. What Man is, or ever was, that knows how the World was made? Or for what it is made? Or by whom it was made? Or whether it had beginning, or shall have end?
The Fifth and last is Man. What Man is, or ever was, that knows how he was formed, or of what composition, or what is that he calls a Rational Soul? Whether it is embodied, or not embodied? Whether it is Divine, or Mortal? Whether it proceeds from the Gods, or was created by Na∣ture? Whether it shall live for ever, or shall have a period? Whether it shall live in Knowledge, or lie in Ignorance? Whether it be capable of pain, or pleasure? Whether it shall have a residing place, or no certain place assigned? Or if it have none, where it shall wander? Or if it have, where that residing place is.
As for the Body, who knows the perfect Sense of each Sense, or what mistake, or illusions, each Sense is apt to make, or give, or take? What Man knows how the Body dissolves, or to what it shall dissolve? What Man knows whether there be Sense in Death, or not? What Man knows the motion of the thoughts, or whether the thoughts belong only to the Soul, or only to the Body, or partly to both, or of neither? What Man is there that knows strength of passion? As what Faith may beget? Or what Doubts may dissolve? Or what Hopes may unite? Or what Fears may dis∣order? Or what Love can suffer? Or what Hate can act?
What Man is there that knows the Circumpherence of Admiration, the ri∣gore of Adoration, the hight of Ambition, or the bottom of Covetousness? Or what Man knows the end of Sorrow, or beginning of Joy? And as for the Appetites, what Man knows the length and breadth of desire? As for the Senses, what Man is there, that knows the true Sense of Pleasure, or the ut∣termost bounds of Pain? Who can number the varieties of Taste, Sent, Touch, Sound, and Sight? What Man knows the perfect effects of each Sense? Or what Man is there that knows any thing, truly as it is? Yet cer∣tainly there cannot be an Athest; for though men may be so irreligious, as to be of no Religion; yet their can be none so wilful, and utterly void of all Sense, and Reason, as not to believe there is a God; for though we have not the true light of knowledge, yet we have as it were a perpetual twilight; Man lives as at the poles of knowledge; for though we cannot say it is truly day, yet it is not night. Man may perceive an Infinite power, by the perfect distinctions of all particular varieties, by the orderly production of several Creatures, and by the fit, and proper shapes of every several kind of Creature; by their orderly Births, by the times and Seasons, to produce, flourish, and decay; by the distinct degrees, qualities, properties, places and
motions of all things, and to, and in every thing, by the exact form of this World; by the prudent separations, and situations of the Heavens and Earth; by the Circumference lines, and poising Centers; by their bounds and limits; by their orderly, and timely motions; by their assigned tracts, constant Journeys, convenient distances; by their intermixing, and well tempering of the Elements; by the profitable Commerce, betwixt the Hey∣vans and the Earth; by the different kinds, several sorts, various Natures, numerous numbers of Creatures; by their passions, humours, appetites; by their Sympathies, and Antipathies; by their wars and parties; by the Harmony that is made out of discord, shows that there is only one absolute power, and wise disposer, that cannot be opposed, having no Copartners, pro∣duces all things, being not produced by any thing, wherefore must be Eter∣nil, and consequently infinite; this absolute, wise, and Eternal power Man calls God; but this absolute power, being infinite, he must of necessity be incomprehensible, and being incomprehensible, must of necessity be un∣known, yet glimses of his power is, or may be seen; yet not so, but that Man is forced to set up Candels of Faith, to light them, or direct them to that they cannot perfectly know, and for want of the clear light of know∣ledge, Man calls all Creations of this mighty power Nature; his wise de∣crees, Man calls Fates; his pointed will, Man calls Destiny; his several Changes, Man calls Fortune; his Intermixing Man calls Life; his sepera∣ting, Man calls Death; the Sympathetical, and Antipathetical motions of the Senses, and their Objects, Humours, and their Subjects, Man calls Plea∣sure, and Pain; the interchanging motions in Man, Men call Sense, and Knowledge; the separating motions, Man calls Ignorance, Stupidity, and Insensibility; my application is, that this absolute Power, wise Disposer, and decreeing Creator, hath created himself Worship, in making Creatures to worship him; and it is probable, Truth decreed Judgment, Punishment, and Bliss, to such of his Creatures as shall omit, or submit thereunto: my exhoration to you is, to bough humbly, to pray constantly, to implore ser∣vently, to love truly, to live awfully to the worship of this incomprehensible power; that you may enjoy bliss and avoid torment.
I wonder who brought up that careless fashion, to go with∣out their Swords; and I wonder more, how gallant valiant men, came to follow that fashion; for a Sword is a valiant mans trusty friend, to whose protection, he delivers his Honour, his Safety, and his Peace; for a Sword is a Mans Guardian, to maintain his Right, to revenge his Wrongs, or Disgraces, and his Mistress, for whole service he wears his Life, and studies the worth and use thereof, and takes delight in the Honourable, and allowable practices therein.
Faith my Lord I believe it was some Lover that brought up that fashion, who was loath to affright his Mistress, with so dangerous a weapon.
Some Carpet Knight upon my life my Lord.
It was no true Lover; for certainly he would be sure to pro∣vide a safeguard, lest his Mistress might be taken from him, or lest he should be affronted in her sight, which a Man of Honour, and a true Lover, will ra∣there die than part or suffer; and as for my part, I commend the Man that would neither eat, drink, nor sleep, without his Sword were by him, and made it his Bedfellow, and Board Companion; as a friend that held to his side, and would sight in his quarrel.
My Lord, if a man should do so in these times, his Neighbours would say it was out of fear, not courage.
O no, for a Coward is afraid to use a Sword, and a Valiant man is afraid to be without the use, otherwise a strong sturdy Clown, might cuff him down, and kick him like a Football on the ground, which a Sword, and skill to use it, will prevent; for a Clown hath not skill to defend, or assault a Sword, having no practice therewith, nor ought they to have; for the use of this kind of Arms makes a Clown a Gentleman, and the want of skill makes a Gentleman a Clown; for a Right bred Gentleman, is to know the use of the Sword, and it is more manly to assault, than to defend; also to know how to manage Horses, whereby we know how to assault our Enemy as well as to defend our selves; for it is not playing with a Fiddle, and dancing a Measure, makes a Gentleman; for then Princes should dub Knighthood with a Fiddle, and give the stick, and a pair of Pumps, instead of a Sword, and a pair of Spurs.
My Lord, we are so far from wearing our Swords our selves now a days, as we give them our Footmen to carry, as if it were a disgrace to carry a Sword our selves.
Tic true, and we are well beaten for our follies, for disarm∣ing our selves, and arming our Slaves; for now a Groom is made a Gentle∣mans equal, nay his Superior sometimes; for if a Groom kills a Gentle∣man, the Gentleman dyes in disgrace, and the Groom lives with Honour, and gets the Fame of a gallant Person; for that is the phrase to all those that have fought, although they were forced thereto as Slaves, not distinguishing true valour, which is voluntary, temperate and just.
Why then there should be a Decree, of Law, that none should wear Swords but Gentlemen, nor Arms allowed, but to those of approved merit.
You say right, unless in time of Foreign Wars, and then there should be a difference in their Arms; for if there be no difference of Arms, no difference of persons, and if there be no difference of persons, there will be no Supremacy of Power, if no Supremacy, no Royal Govern∣meant; for as the Sword maintains the Prerogative of the Crown, so it doth the Honour of a Gentleman; and as the Sword keeps up the dignity of the Crown, so a Sword keeps up the Heraldry of a Gentleman; and no man ought to be accounted a Gentleman, that knows not how to use his Sword, and manage his Horse; for the one defends himself, and kills his Enemies; the other, doth front and charge his Enemy, and pursues him if need require.
Lord Wife you are very brave to day.
I strive to be so every day.
For whose sake.
For yours.
For mine? why sure that is not so, for certainly you would not take that pains, and bestow so much cost, for one you do enjoy already, for a Husband that is tied to you for life, and cannot quit on Ho∣nourable terms; wherefore it is for one is loose and free, which you do strive by setting forth your self with garments rich, for to attract, and draw to your desires.
The Circumference of my desires is only your delight.
Why, my delight is in your Virtue, youth, and Beau∣tie, not in your Clothes.
But Virtue is best acceptable, when Beauty doth present it; and Beauty finds most favour, when well attired; but were I sure you would like me better in mean Garments, and careless dresses, I then should Cloth my self in Freeze, &amp; like a Hermit my loose course Garments tie with single cord about my waste; but I will go and pull these Clothes off, since they are thought a crime, and I thought false for wearing them.
No, I like them very well, if I were sure they were worn only for love to me.
I never gave you cause to think I wear them for the love of any other.
Mademoiselle La Belle is cried up to be the only Beauty in the Kingdom.
Lord that is nothing, for sometimes opinion will carry a black Blowse up to Fems high Tower.
Yes faith, and most commonly they are cast down in disgrace.
Why should she be cried up so? for she is neither well fea∣tured, nor well shaped, nor well fashioned, nor well dressed, nor well bred, nor good natured; for she is of a brown Complexion, a heavy Eye, a sad Countenance, a lazy Garb; she dresses Phantastically, speaks Childishly,
looks shamefastly; she is proud, reserved, coy, disdainful, and self-conceited.
Let me tell you, it is reported that she hath most lovely features, a clear Complexion, a modest Countenance, a bashful Eye, a pleasing Speech, a winning behaviour, a Majestic presence; besides it is reported that her disposition is civil, courteous, and obliging, her Nature sweet and gentle, her Education virtuous, her life temperate and Chaste, her actions noble and wise, her discourse witty and delightful.
Hey day, hey day, good Mistress Tell-truth run not so fast in the ways of vain Reports, lest your judgment fail into a Quagmire.
Monsieur Fantasy, tic said you are one of Mademoiselle La Belles admirers.
All the World would admire her, if they saw her, she is so Heavenly a Creature.
If she be so Heavenly a Creature, she would be known to the whole World by the splendour of her Beams.
Heaven is not made known to all; neither can the glories be suddenly comprehended, by weak Mortals.
Good Lord, if she hath such an infinite Beauty, that it cannot be comprehended, it is obscure.
But those that comprehend least will be astonished, and struck with deep amaze.
I believe you are struck with Love, which makes you Blind, or Mad, that makes you think you see your own imaginations: wherefore fare you well, until you are sober.
I am struck indeed, for I am wonded deeper than Swords can pierce, or Bullets shoot at.
Your Lordship rid to day beyond Perseus on his Pegasus.
No Monsieur, he went (if Poets speak truth) in higher Capreols than ever I shall make my Horse go.
He might go higher my Lord, but never keep so just a time, and place, as to pitch from whence he rise, his feet in the same Circle, his legs in the same lines, and your Lordship in the same Center.
The truth is, my Horses went well to day; they were like Musical Instruments, fitly strung, and justly tuned.
And your Lordship, like a skilful Musician, played rarely thereon.
Come Gentlemen, let us to Dinner, for I have uncivilly tyred your Stomachs with a long fast.
Sir, you may very well start to see me here, I do not use modesty, pardon me to be so bold to visit Men; it is the first visit I ever made your Sex, and hope it will be the last, but I am come, since nei∣there Letter, nor Messenger, could have access to be resolved by your own Confession, whether you have forsaken me or not.
No, I have not forsaken you.
But your affection prefers another before me.
If I should say I did not, I should belly Truth, which baseness I abhor.
I am glad for your own sake you keep so much Honour, though sorry, that you are no constanter, and more sorry for the Oaths you took, and Vows you made to me, since they became the witnesses of your perjury. I was not suddenly, nor easily brought to draw a Supreme Love to one; for before such time my Love was placed on you, my affections run equally in purling Brooks of Pity, and Compassion, and clear fresh Rivulets of Cha∣rity and Humanity, from the pure Springs of good Nature and Religion; and hard it will be for me to turn this River to each stream again, if not, yet I shall be a rest, twill overflow my heart and drown me.
Oh I must curse my Fortune, and my Fate; la∣meant my own condition to love without return, and only pity what I loved most.
Great Mercury to thee I now address,
Employ thy favour, help me in distress;
Thou God of Eloquence, so guide my tongue,
Let all my words on even sense be slrung,
And let my Speech be tuned to every Ear,
That every Ear each several word may hear:
That every passion may in measure move,
And let the figure of the Dance be Love.
Noble and Right Honourable,
I will discourse at this time of Love, not of the superfluous Branches, or withered leaves, or rotten fruits, but of the Root of Love, which is Self-love; It is the Root and Original Love in Nature; it is the Foundation of Nature, it is the Fountain from whence issues all the several Springs; Self-love was the cause of the Worlds Creation; for the Gods out of love to them∣selves, caused Creatures to be Created, to worship them: thus all Cry∣tures being created out of self-love, and their chief being proceeding out of self-love, is the cause that every particular Creature loves themselves in the first place, and what Love is placed on any other, or to any other, from any particular, is derived from self-love; for we love the Gods but out of self-love, as believing the Gods love us; we adore the Gods but out of self-love, because we think we proceed from them, or were produced by their commands; we pray to the Gods but out of self-love, because we hope the Gods will help us in distress; we bless the Gods but out of self-love, be∣cause we do verily believe the Gods will exalt, and Crown us with everlast∣ing glory; and to show that we Love the Gods, not as they are Gods, but for our own sakes, as believing they will or can do us good, is, that we are apt to murmur at the Gods, when we have not our own desires; we are apt to accuse the Gods, when any wordly thing crosses us; we are apt to curse the Gods at ill Accidents, Misfortunes, or Natural losses; we are apt to forget the Gods in the midst of pleasure; we are apt to think our selves Gods in the pride of prosperity; we strive to make our selves Gods in the hight of worldly power; and we do not only strive to make our selves equal with the Gods, but to raise our selves above the Gods, taking, or command∣ing to our selves more worship than we give unto the Gods; nay, those that are accounted the most holy and devout Servants of the Gods, belie the Gods, taking the name of the Gods to cover their own follies; as for exam∣ple, whenever any eminent person hath had ill success, either in, or after their Foolish, Ambitious, and Vain-glorious actions, they charge the Gods Decrees and pleasure, as it was the Gods will it should be so; like as she that Vaingloriously had her two and only Sons to draw her Chariot, like two Horses, or Dogs, or Slaves, and being both found Dead the next day, she had prayed to the Gods to reward them with that which was best for them, and being both dead, she said the Gods accounted Death as the best reward, when they no doubt dyed with over heating themselves, striving beyond
their natural power and strength; yet these two Sons that drew the vain Mo∣there in a Chariot, drew and died out of self-love; either like as vain Sons like their vain Mother, vaingloriously to get a fame, or believing the Gods would reward them for their Act, either with extraordinary prosperity, pow∣er, or blessedness in the Life to come; and many the like examples may be go∣ven; for how ordinary is it in these our times, and in former times, for the politics to persuade the people, with promises from the Gods, or to tell them it is the Gods commands they should do such and such acts, even such acts as are unnatural, wicked, and most horrid? thus Men belly the Gods to abuse their fellow Creatures. But most Noble and Right Honourable, my explanation of this discourse is, that since Self-love is the Fountain of and in Nature from whence issue out several Springs to every several Creature, wherein Mankind being her chiefest and Supreme work, is filled with the fullest Springs from that Fountain, which is the cause that Mankind is more industrious, cruel, and unsatiable, to and for his self ends, than any other Creature, he spares nothing that he hath power to destroy, if he fears any hurt, or hopes for any gain, or finds any pleasure, or can make any sport, or to employ his idle time; he melts metals, distills and dissolves plants, dis∣sects animals, substracts and extracts Elements, he digs up the bowels of the Earth, cuts through the Ocean of the Sea, gathers the winds into Sails, fresh waters into Mills, and imprisons the thinner Ayre; he Hunts, he Fowls, he Fishes for sport, with Guns, Nets, and Hooks; he cruelly causes one Creature to destroy another, the whilst he looks on with delight; he kills not only for to live, but lives for to kill, and takes pleasure in torturing the life of other Creatures, in prolonging their pains, and lengthening their Deaths; and when Man makes friendship of Love, it is for his own sake, ei∣there in humouring his passion, or feeding his humour, or to strengthen his party, or for Trust, or Counsel, or Company, or the like causes; if he dies for his friend, it is either for fame, or that he cannot live himself happy with∣out his friend, his passion, and grief, making him restless; if Man loves his Children, Wife, or Parents, tic for his own sake;
