But Sir, pray consider the advantages that you will lose by refusing the Emperors Daughter; besides, the Emperor will take it as an affront, and will endeavour to revenge it with Fire and Sword, for certainly he will make a war with you.
Why, if he should, I make no question but I shall be able to encounter him, at least to resist him.
But now Sir you live in a happy peace, wherein all your Sub∣jests grow rich, and your Kingdom flourishes with plenty, and your Highness lives in pleasure and magnificence, all which a War may bring to ruin; there is nothing got by VVars Sir, the venturers are losers; wherefore good Sir consider what danger, at least trouble, you will bring upon your self by this Marriage.
How comes it you staid so long?
I could no see the Lady.
Would no she be seen?
No Sir, but after a long stay the Lady her Mother came to me, to receive your Highnesses Letter, and the Message your Highness sent by me, which when I had delivered, she bid me present her humble duty to your Highness, and to pray you to put her Daughter out of your thoughts, at least not to think of her for a Wife, for she had taken a Religious Habit, and had put her self into a Religious Order, wherein she would pray for your Highness as long as she lived.
Oh Fool that I was, that I did not prevent it.
Your Highness did not know she would enter into a Religi∣os Habit and Order.
But I might have mistrusted it by her refusal, but I will en∣devour to get her out; perchance she hath not made her Vows yet.
And is she entered into a Religious Order? I am glad of it, for it will be some ease, and rest unto my restless Soul, that she is safe and well secured.
My Lord, the Princess desires your Company, for she hath grumb∣ling pains as if she would fall in labour.
Have you seen the new Devote yet?
Yes, with much ado: for she will not be seen, unless to some particular persons, or near friends.
And how doth she become her Religious Habit?
So handsomely, as she is far handsomer in her Peas habit, than when she was dressed with all the Arts of Vanities.
What manner of Habit is it?
Somewhat like the Normetanes, but much more becoming.
Well, I will go to the Lady her Mother, and entreat her to let me go with her to see her Daughter.
It is said that now the Lady Perfection is incloistered, that the Treaty goes on betwixt the Arch-Prince and the Emperor.
What's the matter you run so hastily?
I am running to give the Arch-Prince notice, that his Niece is in labour, and is so ill she is like to die.
We will not stay you shen.
It's said the Lady Perfection hath entered into a Religious Order, she is happy, would I were so.
It is a question whether you would think your self so, if you were as she is.
I think the happiest life is to be a Devote.
Faith Mistress you wish to be a Devote, not so much out of a devo∣tion, as for a change in life, as many wish to be married out of a desire to alter their course of life, and when they are married, they wish to be unmoor∣ried again, so would you do if you were a Devote.
Oh no: for though those that are married wish to be unmarried, by reason Marriage is the most troublesome, unquiet life that is, but a Devotes life is the most peaceable and quiet life that is; so as there is as much difference in the course of a Married life and an Incloy∣stered life, as between Heaven and Hell.
Then the most part of the World prefers Hell before Heaven, for more are Married than are Incloistered.
Truly by the course of the World, and the action of men, one would think there would be more Devils in Hell than Saints in Heaven.
You hear the news of the Princess delivery, and her Death.
Yes I heard she died as soon as delivered, but she hath left a Son and Heir to her sorrowful Husband.
I do not believe her Husband is much troubled or grieved for her Death, as his Father is.
Indeed I think the young Lord had no great affections for her.
No surely, for he loves the Lady he was first married to so well, as he could spare no love for any other woman•
If that Lady had not entered into a Religious Order, he might have remarried her, but now he cannot.
I believe that if the other Lady had known the Princess should have died so soon, she would not have been so Religious as to have Incloistered her self from the World, and to ha'bard up her liberty with Vows.
It is like when she hears of the Princesses Death she will repent the acts of devotion.
Then Repentance is not always for acts of evil, but sometimes of good.
There is Repentance of all sorts and degrees, and there are more enter into Religious Orders out of Discontent, than for Love to God.
That is an uncharitable opinion.
Nay it is not a bare Opinion, that may be proved, nor uncharitable to speak the truth.
Oh Nan I am undone for ever.
As how Mistress?
Why by your neglect and carelessness; for your not watching my Fathers coming home, to give me notice, my Father hath found my Chair: for I hearing him come, run to hide away my Chair, he coming and seeing me scuttle about the room, imagined I desired to hide something from him, for which he searches all my Chamber over, at last he went and looked into the Cole-hole where I had flung my Chair, and finding it, he car∣ried it away in one hand, and led me along in the other hand, and causing a fire to be made of the Chair, made me stand by to see the Martyrdom, whereat I was so afflicted, as I lost my fight in tears, which tears I let run on the fire, hoping to quench it out, but they were so brent with grief, as they did rather augment the fury of the fire, than abate the rage of the flame; so that which I thought would have been a preserver did hasten the destruction.
Faith Mistress it is none of my fault, for your Mother sent me of an errand, and whilst I was absent by your Mothers commands, it seemed your Father came home.
This is an excuse.
You may believe it it is no excuse, but truth; for I that ventured the loss of my Soul by telling a lie to save your Chair, would not neglect the watch, had not I been commanded away.
I am of an opinion you were bribed to betray the life of my Chair, and bribes are so powerful as they corrupt promises and vows, even the Soul its self; though the Soul makes no use of bribes, yet it will venture to be damned for a bribes sake.
Well Mistress, since a mistrust is all my reward, you shall tell the next lie your self.
No prithee Nan let us be friends, for I shall never get a Servant that will so readily tell lies for me as you do; wherefore let us shake hands and be friends.
Well Mistress, let me tell you, that my hand and tongue is at your service, the one to work, the other to lie for your service.
I thank you Nan, for many Servants will lie, but few will work.
The Lord Melancholy hath such a sober, sad Countenance, as I never saw any young man have the like.
Indeed I never saw him smile in my life.
I asked a Gentleman that waits on him, whether his Lord did ever smile, he said he never saw him smile since he parted from his first Lady.
Then he hath not smiled this nine years, for so long it is since he parted from his first Lady.
If the siege last one year more, it will be as long a siege as the siege of Troy.
Indeed the causes of either siege resembles each other, as both for the love of fair Ladies; I know not whether the effect will prove alike, as whether it will be the destruction of his heart, as the siege of Troy wa• the destruction of Troy.
But the Lord Melancholy is rather like Helen than Menelaus, for he hath had two wives, and the Lady Perfection is as Menelaus, for her Hus∣band is taken away from her, as his wife was from him; but leaving this siege let us return to our own homes.
Madam, yesterday when you were pleased to speak with me, as now through this Grate, you were pleased to tell me your Vows were so binding as they could not be dissolved; wherefore I am not now come to examine, or persuade, nor to trouble your Devotions, or to hinder your Meditations, but to take my last leave, for I shall never see you more, at least not in this World.
Are you going to Travel?
I cannot say my body is going a far Journey, I know not what my Soul may do.
Shall not they go together?
No, Death will make a divorce, as the Law did be∣twixt you and I.
Are you resolved to dye?
Yes.
Why so?
To be at rest and peace: for know, that ever since I was last married, my life hath been a Hell, my Mind was tortured with thoughts of discontent, and though I am releast from what I did dislike, my mind is restless still for what it would enjoy; this resolution is not new, it hath been long considered; for since I cannot live with that I love better than life, isle try whether the passions of the Soul doe with the Body dye, if so, Death will be happy, because it hath no sense nor feeling.
How long have you been resolved of leaving life?
I have pondered of it ever since I was last Married, but was not resolved until you entered into this Order.
Can I not persuade you to live?
Not unless you break your Vow.
That I may not do.
Nor can I persuade you, for I love your Constancy.
Will you grant me one request before you die?
Yes, any thing but what may hinder my dying.
Swear to me you will.
I swear by Heaven and Love I will.
Then the time you are resolved to dye, come hither and dye here, that I may bear you Company, dying the same minute if I can that you do.
How?
Nay, you have sworn it, and if it be best for you, it will be so for me; for when you are dead I shall possess those torments that you in life feel now, and if you love me so well as you express you do, you will not desire to leave me to endure that you cannot suffer.
It is fit you should live to be a President to the World.
Were I a President fit for the World to follow, yet the World would not practice my precepts, it is too bad to follow what is good, and since my life cannot better the World, and Death will ease my life of that which will trouble and afflict it, I am resolved to dye. And in the grave will bear you Company.
I do accept of thy dear Company, &amp; Heaven so join our Souls they never may be separated, and to morrow we will leave the World.
Let me advise you concerning the manner of our Deaths, get a Sword pointed sharp at both ends, and when we are to dye put one end of the Sword through this grate, and just when you set your heart to the end towards you, I will set mine to the end towards me, and thrusting forward as to meet each other, the several points will make several passages or wounds into our several or rather our own united hearts, and so we dye just together.
I shall follow your advice, and be here to morrow at the time.
Which time will seem to me like as an Age,
Till that our Souls be fled forth from their Cage.
My Soul will fly your Soul to embrace,
And after Death may hope a resting place.
You here the match is concluded betwixt the Emperors Daughter and our Prince.
Yes, and I hear that the Lord Dorato was a great Instrument to help the match forward.
Methinks they should need no other Instrument to forward the match than the Princes interest.
It is true: but the Princes affection being placed upon another Lady, it was hard first to draw off those affections, and then to place them anew; besides, the Death of his Niece was some hinderance.
All great Princes doe soon cast off all Funeral sadness: but the Lord Dorato methinks takes the Death of his Daughter to heart.
It is a doubt whether he will continue in such great favour with the Prince, now his Niece is dead.
There is no likelihood he should be in less favour since the Prin∣cess Death, for it was the favour he had with the Princess that caused the match with his Son; besides he hath left a Son, which the Prince no doubt will favour the Grandfather the more, for the Childes sake.
I wonder whether the Lord Melancholy the Princesses Husband will marry again, for he had ill fortune with his Wives.
Methinks he hath had good Fortune, for the Laws have quited him of one, and Death of the other; but that Husband hath ill fortune, that neither Law nor Death will free him from.
Sweet, here is that will quit us of all trouble.
Indeed life is a trouble, and nothing is at rest but what lies in the grave.
Are you not afraid of the sight of a murdering Sword?
No more than you are afraid of the sight of the glo∣rios Sun.
You seem to have a courage above you Sex.
My love is above Life, as far as my Courage is beyond Fear; I neither fear Death, nor consider Life, but can embrace the one, and fling away the other for Loves sake.
Then dear Wife, for so you are, my heart did never own another, I wish our breaths and bloods might intermix together, and as Deaths Ceremonies might join our Souls.
They are joined already by love, and Death's sufficient to bring them both together, and our bloods it is like will run in trickling streams upon this Sword, to meet and intermix.
These Buttons are like troublesome guests at Marriage Nuptials, but are you ready Wife for our second Marriage?
I am now ready to go into the Bed of Earth.
Hold, and stain not this sacred places with murde∣rears blood. Lady, is this the Devotion profess, wickedly to murder your self?
Father, know I accounted self Death no wickedness, and I will venture on my own belief.
But the Church hath power to absolve you now, if you desire personly to meet.
Yes, such power as the Laws had to dissolve our Marri∣age; but the Churches absolving can no more acquit my Conscience from my Devoted Vow, than the Laws could from my Marriage Vow.
Pray give us leave to plead.
Take it.
You have vowed Chastity, and a retired Incloy∣stered life.
I have so.
Why, then marry this Lord again, and let him make the same Vow, and enter into the same Cloister, and into the same Religi∣os Order of Chastity, and being Man and Wife you are but as one person, so that if you be constant and true to your selves, you keep the Vow of Cha∣steady; for what is more Chaste than lawful Marriage, and Virtuous Man and Wife?
Husband, are you willing to make the Vow of Chastity, and to live an Incloistered life?
I am all will to that Vow and life, for so I shall enjoy thy Soul and Body; and good Father re-marry us, and then I will thank you for Life and Wife.
First you shall make your Vow, then take a Religious Habit, and then be re-married, and go along with us and we will order you fixed for to enter into this Religious Order of Chastity, and if you be both happy in life, as sure you will, thank your Nurse, who hearing your cruel, and as I may say irreligious design, informed us, and placing us within a Loby, we heard you, and saw you, though you knew not that we did so, for you had barred the outward Door, but being within we were ready to come forth and hinder you as we did.
Well Father, since you have hindered our Deaths, pray make me sit to enjoy Life; my Heaven of Life, or Life of Heaven.
Come then.
Why do you weep Mistress?
Because my Father will have me marry.
Many young Maids weep because they cannot get Husbands, but few weep to enjoy one.
I do not cry because I shall have a Husband, but because I shall have a Foot to my Husband.
There are few wise Husbands, and fewer wise Men.
What difference is betwixt a wise Husband, and a wise Man.
Why a wise Husband is to rule and govern his Wife, well, but a wise Man is to rule and govern himself, well, and there is more that can tell how to rule and govern others than themselves, like as there may be good Kings and not good Men, and good Men and not good Kings, or as there may be good Teachers as Preachers, and not good practisers; so this Gentleman you are to marry may be a wise Husband, although not a wise Man.
But he will be both a foolish Husband, and a fool∣each Man.
If he prove a foolish Husband you have no reason to cry, for then you will have the more Liberty.
The more liberty to be a Fool you mean.
Indeed liberty to women makes them rather foolish than wise: for women know not how to use liberty discreetly, for when they have liberty they run beyond the bounds of discretion.
Faith if I marry this same Gentleman that my Father says I shall, I shall run beyond the bounds of Matrimony.
That is to run into your Neighbours Bed.
Do you hear of the new Religious Order?
What new Religious Order?
Why the Order of Chastity in marriage.
That's a new Order indeed, never heard of before, at least not practised; but this Order, if it continue, will make marriage as Religi∣os in life as the marriage of Saints.
Why the marriage of men and women is a type of the marriage of Saints.
But the type often commits Adultery, and for my part I would not be one of that Religious Order.
No, for on my Conscience I believe you would disorder the Order.
But who hath brought up this foolish new Order?
The Lord Melancholy and the Lady Perfection, who are re-marri∣ed, and have both vowed Chastity in marriage, and an Incloistered life, and have taken a Religious Habit.
The more unwise they, that will bind themselves so strictly.
So honestly.
I hate honesty that way, or that way of honesty.
You hate that way of honesty, because you love the ways of Adultery.
I come not to complain, nor reprove your Chaste wife for denying my Suit, nor am I come only to give you joy of your new mar∣riage, but your new Religious Order of Chastity in marriage, which Order, I believe that few besides your self will enter into.
Then few will be so happy Sir as we are.
Indeed happiness lives more in Cloisters than in Courts, or Cities, or private families; but my Lord Dorato your Father here will want the comfort of your Company, which should be a Partner with him in the Rule and Government of his Family and Fortunes.
I have left him a Grand-Son Sir to be a comfort to him in my absence, and I wish he may prove as obedient to him as I have done.
Faith Son the first time of your marriage, was without my knowledge or consent, but howsoever now I wish you joy, and for your sake I will never cross Matrimonial Love whilst I live, and I hope God will bless you both, so as that you may beget a Religious Generation.
All the Children they beget and bring up must be of the Re∣ligious Orders.
If they will follow their Parents purities and precepts they will.
There may proceed from these two a great Generation, which may spread all over the World, and be famous for Piety and Acts of Devotion.
I hope your Highnesses words are Prophecies of what is to come.
I wish they prove so; farewell, all happiness dwell with you both.
Long may your Highness live and flourish.
My blessing on you both.

My Dear Gadder.
My sweet Kindeling.
Faith Ladies Nature never made women to kiss each other, and therefore it is unnatural, and being unnatural it is unlawful, and being unlawful it ought to be forbidden.
Yes, you would have us kiss you men.
No Ladies, we men will kiss you women, if you please to give us leave.
You will take leave sometimes.
It is when we think we shall not be refused, or at least not to be disfavoured for it.
What, kissing again? faith Ladies you will make us believe by your often kissing, that you desire we should kiss you, and with that belief we may run into an error, if it be an error to kiss a fair Lady.
Fie, fie, you men are odd Creatures.
No, you women are odd Creatures, when you are not with us men.
Preethy Gadder and Bridlehead let us go do something to pass away our time.
What shall we do?
Let us go to Cards.
Faith I have made a Vow not to play for money.
We will play for Sweet-meats.
No, preethy let us play for a Sack Posit.
O no, we will play for Sweet-meats.
I say a Sack Posit.
Let the most voices carry it.
I will speak for the men, we say a Sack Posit, for that will make us both good Company in the eating the Posit, and after it is eaten, whereas Sweet-meats will make us heavy and dull.
Well then let us go play for a Sack Posit.
Faith a Sack Posit will make me drunk.
You will be the better Company Lady.
Fie Bridlehead, you should not say drunk, but your head giddy.
That is better than to be drunk: for a giddy head hath a light heel.
The Lord Poverty is a gallant Noble person.
They are gallant and Noble that are Rich, and titled Honour without Means, is like a Body without a Soul.
You are mistaken friend, it is rather a Soul without a Body.
Alas titled Honour without Means to maintain it, is despised.
If the person hath Merit worthy of his titled Honour, that titled Honour is worthy to be respected and bowed to by all inferior persons; nay put the case that Honourable titles are placed upon Unworthy persons, yet all ought to give respect to those Titles, and to do homage thereunto, though not unto the Person, yet because it comes from a lawful and Supreme pow∣er; as Natural rays of light do from the Sun; and those that strive through envy and through spite, for to Eclipse the light, deserve to be in a perpetual darkness; so those that do detract from titled Honours, ought never to be honoured with Titles or respect.
Why, it is not only I that have no such titles of Honour that speaks against them, but those that do possess them, and their fore-fathers long before them.
They that do so ought to be degraded, as being unworthy to wear the badge or mark of their fore-fathers Merits, or heroic Acts, for they do show they have none of their own; but those that get their own Ho∣nurse, by their own Merits and worthy Actions, deserve them best; for they, like as a clear and glorious day, appear; for oft-times their posterity, like Clouds begot from gross and drowsy Earth, strive to quench out their Fathers flaming Honours, and by their Baseness obscure the light of their fore-fathers great and glorious Fame, and in the end bury themselves in dark Oblivion, as vanishing to nothing, as being never mentioned nor remembered; but those that for their loyalty and their fidelity unto their King and Coun∣try, have hazarded lives, and lost their liberties and Estates, and are grown poor for Honesties sake, and Virtuous causes, yet they in after Ages will live with great renown; for it is not in the power of spite to pull them down; for the Gods give Fame to Noble Actions, as Kings give titled Honours; though men that are base will not relieve them, yet Fame will remember them; and though base men will rail against them, yet Fame will praise them; and though they dye with Poverty, and should end their lives in a foul
Ditch, yet shall that Ditch be honoured by their Death, more than the rich unworthy man be honoured by his stately Tombs and costly Funerals.
What's the matter with you to day Lady Solitary? you look as if you were in a married humour.
Why Lady Examination, what humour is a married humour?
Why a mass of ill humours mixed or put together; as a lumpish, dumpish, dull, stupid humour; or a peevish, fretting, pining, whi∣ning humour; or a brawling, yowling, quarrelling, scolding humour; or a jealous, suspicious humour; or a fawning, feigning, dissembling humour.
If these humours are woven into the marriage knot, I will never marry, for I would be loath to have the peace of my life strangled in discon∣tent: for whosoever be subject to these humours can never be happy.
You will change your mind, and rather live with these hue∣morse than without a Husband; but I am come now to fetch you abroad, for their is a Company of sociable Ladies and gallants, that have made a meeting some league of, where there will be Mirth, Jollity, Plenty and Pleasure, and they desire you will be sociable for once, and go along with them.
Would you have the Body which is the habitation of the Mind a wanderer, travelling from place to place, disturbing the mind with un∣profitable journeys?
No, I would have it remove so as it may always situate it self in a wholesome, profitable, plentiful, pleasant, and pleasurable place.
I perceive you prefer the pleasures of the Body before the de∣light of the Mind.
Why the mind can take no delight without the body; for the body gives the mind a being and habitation: for there would be no mind if there were no body, but if there could be a mind without a body, yet the mind could receive no delight without the pleasure of the body, for the pleasure of the body is the delight of the mind, and not the delight of the mind the pleasure of the body, for the mind doth never give nor return; wherefore come away, and leave your Solitary musing to those whose con∣dition of fortune denies them the use of the World, and worldly pleasures, and do not deny your self, for I hate a self-denying Creature.
Well, you shall prevail with me for this one time.
Have you seen Monsieur Thesis Book of Poems that is newly come forth?
Yes.
And how do you approve of them?
As well as I do of an Anagram.
There is never an Anagram in the Book.
Why the whole Book is an Anagram of Doctor Costives Poems: for he hath only new placed the words, as they do Anagrams of names, but the whole matter, sense, and conceits is the same.
Indeed he hath imitated him.
By your favour, imitation is only to be like another, and not the same; but his is the very same, as I have told you, for which he deserves less praises than a Imitator, although those that do imitate any Excellent Poet, do not gain so much honour to themselves, as they give honour to those they imitate; as for example, the Imitators of Homer give more honour to Homer than to themselves; for Imitators are only as Painters, where he that is imita∣ted is as Nature, or the Gods, for the one draws but Copies, the other makes the Original; so that there is as much difference as a Man, and the Picture of a man.
But a Painter that draws the Picture of a man, very like the life, he may be more famous than the man that is drawn.
But not worshipped and adored, as Nature is, that made him: for Art cannot out-do Nature, nor do as Nature hath dove, and doth do; and an Imitator is but an Artificer, when as the Original Author is a Creator, and ought to be accounted of, and respected, and worshipped as Divine; but there are or have been but very few Poets that have such powers and parts to make a perfect Creature, which is a perfect work, as Poems, scenes, or story; but some Poets are like Chemist, that strive and labour to make as Na∣ture makes, but most fail in their work, and lose their labours, wanting that Natural heat, or well-tempered matter, which should produce such Cry∣tures as Nature makes, yet some it is said have made gold, as Raimond Lully.
Then Homer is a Raimond Lully in Poetry.
Nay rather Raimond Lully is a Homer in Chemistry: for no man ought to compare Homer to any Creature, by reason he hath out-wrought Nature, having done that which she never did; for Nature never made Gods, Devils, Hells, and Heavens, as Homer hath done.
For my part I had rather be Raimond Lully than Homer: for I had rather have the Art to make Gold, than the Nature to make Poems.
You would not gain so much by Gold as Wit.
Why, what shall I gain?
Fame.
But Gold will bribe Fame to speak as I would have her, if I have •old enough to bribe her.
But Poems will force Fame to speak for you without a bribe.
That were all one to me, so she speaks well, whether she be for∣••d, flattered, or bribed.
But there is a fate of Poverty on Chemists, as much as on Poets, so that if you were as Excellent a Chemist as Raimond Lully, you would be as poor as Divine Homer.
Not if I could make Gold.
Yes, for Chemists spend more in the making of Gold, than they gain by it when it is made; and how should they do otherways, when they must needs spend a pound or pounds to make a grain? for the limbeck of a Chemist is but a little Still set a-work by a wasting fire, whereas Natures limbeck is the Earth, set a-work by an undecaiable fire, which is the Sun; this Chemist becomes as poor by an over-greedy Covetousness, as Poets by a despising Carelessness.
Then Chemists are like those Bodies which become lean with over-eating, and Poets like those Bodies that becomes lean by over-fasting; the one surfeits, the other famishes.
Indeed Chemists are so greedily Covetous, and feed so much on hopes, as they never leave until such time as they have vomited out all their wealth, and then they become sick and lean with Poverty.
The Lady Faction is of a strange busy Nature, she runs into eve∣rye House, takes upon her to govern every ones Family, yet cannot rule her own; she condemns all Actions, be they never so Just or Prudent; all Officers, be they never so worthy, or fitly placed; all Laws, be they never so beneficial, or expedient for the Common-wealth; all Customs, be they never so ancient or harmless, indeed all peaceable, wise, and well or∣dered Governments: she hates and delights in nothing but disordered change.
It is said she is in love with Sir William Admirer.
And he in love with the Lady Peaceable.
She is a sweet Lady.
I will sit and listen to what you say, and learn from you what is the noblest way to entertain the life.
Alas I cannot learn you, I have not long experience, my Soul is
young, a mere novice Soul, it wants both growth and experienced years, for I am like a House that is newly built and is unfurnished.
Though you are young, you are wise.
How can you expect youth can be discreet and wise, when those that have lived long, and have had much experience, are oftentimes Fools? wherefore I can only entertain you like a Parrot, only with words, not wisely to discourse, and if you should listen to me long, I shall surfeit your Ears with idle words, for the Brain will be as soon over-charged with noise, as the Stomach with meat.
I can no more be weary of thy words, than Angels are with Heavenly Music.
Lady Peaceable, the report is you are Ambitious to get away my Servant Sir William Admirer from me.
I am only Ambitious to live Virtuously, and dye Piously.
Why Servant, I hear you have forsaken me.
I despaired of ever being entertained, and so I never really ad∣dressed a Suit, but by way of raillery.
Your Mistress doth not believe you, for she blushes either for your faults, or her own.
My Bashfulness proceeds not from a Guiltiness, either of base actions, wicked thoughts, mean birth, or breeding, or evil or erroneous open∣nions; for my bashfulness is only an effect of Nature: for as some are natu∣rally fearful, so am I naturally bashful; and as Melancholy produces a sad Countenance, so Bashfulness produces an extorted and a Convulsive Coun∣tenance; as Grief produces tears, so Bashfulness produces blushing.
Lady Faction, spare my young Mistress, lest she should out-run you in a full speed.
Your Mistress is too grave, and speaks too scholastical for a wo∣man, she seems as if she had been bred in an University, which breeding is fitter for a man.
No surely, for men should be bred with Heroic Actions, wo∣men with Modest Contemplations, as I have been.
If you have talked so seldom, and have learned so little, how come you to know so much?
My knowledge is not copious, yet I have learned as much as
my years could embrace, and my desire is to know as much as Modesty will
allow of, Honour will give leave to, Capacity can comprehend, or Life can
reach at; but the longest life is but a short time to gather knowledge in;
but Madam, I should think I had learned well, if I knew how to do you service.
Let me tell you, it is Craft and Subtlety that you practice, to catch fond, facile Fools under the veil of Civility, but not good Nature; for you, like a Sorceress as you are, Enchant and Bewitch all that come near you, with this dissembling, for which you ought to be banished from all noble Company.
Take heed Lady of sharp-headed Curses, that Shoot through innocent Lips, they seldom miss the mark they aim at.
Shoot as many as you will, I fear them not.
My dear sweet, wife, Virtuous Mistress, be not angry, for all the World knows the Lady Faction is a disturber of all good and peaceable Society.
No, I am not angry with her, but I will watch her, lest she should do me some harm.
Prithee what art thou writing?
I am writing Fancies.
Prithee what are Fancies?
Why, Fancies are minzed Objects, pounded and chopped by Ima∣gination, which Imaginations are the several Cooks which serve the Mind, and as skilful Cooks of several meats make Becks or Olioes, so doth the Imagination of several Objects; and as skilful Cooks will mix several meats, so as not any one particular shall be tasted, so doth the Imagination of several Objects or Subjects.
But some say Fancies are Created by Motion in the Brain, which would be there were there no such materials as Objects or Subjects, which the Senses as Caterers bring in.
The Brain can no more Create Fancy without the materials of outward Objects, and Subjects, than Nature can Create a World without matter to make it withal; so the Brain can no more Create Fancy without the help of the Senses, than Nature can Create a Creator without the help of Motion; for though Fancies are the works of the Brain, yet the Brain could not work unless it had something to work on; but Objects and Sub∣jests of Objects, may be divided in the Brain so small, or beaten so thin, as the first form may be beaten out, and when the first form is gone, we deny the matter, like as if we should deny that Paper is made with Rags, because the form of Rags is beaten out; thus by the subtle and curious motion of proud Conception joined with the dazzled memory, we deny the Senses a share, as not being Partners therein, or labours thereof, the same way we conceive the Gods, for the Conceptions of the Gods is but minzed Ima∣ginations.
Lady Censurer, pray what think you of the Lady Retorts wit, hath not she a great wit?
Oh fie, she hath a Chamber-Maids wit.
What wit is that Lady?
Why a snip snaply wit.
Indeed I have heard many Nursery Maids give so sharp and quick replies, as amongst some would be judged to be great wits, yet come to discourse seriously with them, and they were not much wiser than Beasts; but what do you think of the Lady Sharps wit?
Her wit fetches the skin off of the Ears, it corrodes the minds of the hearers, more than Vinegar the tongues of the tasters.
How approve you of the Lady Courtlyes wit?
Her wit is tedious, as all Complementing wits are, they tire the Ears of the hearers.
What say you to the Lady Stronglines wit?
Her wit is costive, and is delivered with labour, difficulty, and pain.
What think you of the Lady Learnings wit?
Her wit is an Alms Tub, it yields nothing but scraps, frog∣mints, and broken pieces.
What think you of the Lady Subtilties wit?
Her wit is Lime, Twigs, Snares and Traps to catch Fools in or with.
How like you the Lady Fancies wit?
Her wit indeed is a true Natural wit, it it is sweet and delight∣full, easy and pleasing, as being free and unconstrained.
How like you the Lady Contemplations wit?
Her wit is wise, and distinguishing well: for all Comtemplative persons judge, weigh, and measure out the right and truth of every thing, and find out the easiest and profitablest ways, by the help of consideration; yet Contemplative persons when they come into Company, or public So∣cieties, their tongues do as Boys, that having been kept hard to their studies, when once they get a play day, they run wildly about, and many times do extravagant actions: so Contemplative persons when they are in Company their tongues speak extravagant words, and their behaviour for the most part is unnatural to their dispositions; but of all wits the Contempla∣tive wit is the best, by reason it is a near Neighbour to Poetry.
Come friend Kindeling, and friend Bridlehead, let us go to the Lady Censurers; for there is the resort of all the gallants at her House.
What should we do there? for all the men will hearken so much to her discourse, as they will take no notice of us.
Why then we will take notice of them: for if we should stay at home, and not seek out the Company of men, faith we shall never get us Husbands.
It is easy to get the Company of men, not so easy to get Hus∣bands: for we have a great many men that come often to visit us, but none offer to marry us.
But the more acquaintance we have, the more likely we should get Husbands; for it were a hard: Fortune, if amongst so many men we should not get one Husband.
Why one Husband will not serve us three.
I mean each of us one.
Well then let us go.
Oh thou Clod of Earth, sit not idle here, but go abroad and receive the comfort of the Sun, which works to all effects.
I need not, for my Mind is as the Sun it self, and hath the same of∣fects; for my Mind doth contract, attract, dilates, and expulses, for sometimes it dilates it self as the Sun doth, in beams of light, which is Inventions, at other times the Mind dilates, as the Sun his hear, which is in Poetic flames, and in rarefied fancies; likewise the Mind attracts, as the Sun doth Vapours from the Earth, so my Mind attracts knowledge from the World, as from se∣viral subjects and objects, as the Sun from several Climates; likewise as the Sun contracts porous matter into a solid sustance, so doth my Mind contract loose thoughts into solid Judgment; and as the Sun expulses united Bodies into parts, so doth my Mind expulse its serious Contemplations, and united Con∣captions into several discourses.
Prithee expulse this discourse amongst thy sociable friends.
What amongst the sociable Virgins?
Nay faith, Wives for the most part are more sociable than Maids.
Sir, I hear you intend to be a Soldier in the Wars.
Yes Madam, I am come to take my leave, and to kiss your Ladyships hands before I go.
Sir you have chosen an honourable Profession, for though it is an industrious, careful, painful, and dangerous Profession, yet it is a noble Protection to the Weak and Infirm, to the decrepit Age, and shiftless Youth; to the faint and tender Female Sex; it is a guard to the ashes of the Dead, and to the Temples of the Gods; for without Marshal Discipline no Peace would be kept, Truth and Right would be torn from the owners, Ju∣stice pulled out from her Seat, and Monarchy quite from his Throne, and though a Soldier may lose his life sooner than Nature did determine, yet in recompense, Honour buries him, and Fame builds up his Monument.
Your descriptions Madam are able to make a Coward a Vali∣ant Man.
Some have thought the World was but as Stage, and that the several Creatures are the several Actors, and that every several Gene∣ration is a new Play.
No every several Generation doth not seem as if they were new Plays; for there seems to be but one play, and that to continue to the end of the World, and that every Generation seems only new Actors, that play over the same parts, for we well perceive that the following Generations act but what the former Generations did before them; it is true the World seems to be the Stage, and the Seas, Rocks, Rivers, Plants, Hills, Dales, Ci∣ties, Towns, Villages, and the like, are as the several Changes, the Animals as the several Actors, the several Seasons the several Scenes, and the Specta∣tors are the Gods, and the end of the World the end of the Play, and then they must make another World, if they will have another Play.
Surely Mercury is their Poet.
It is very likely, also it is probable Pallas helps him.
Nay it is probable that Venus and Cupped helps him, for Love and Beauty doth at all times assist a Poet.
There is no excellent and extraordinary wit, but hath many as∣sistants,
as first Nature is the chief; so likewise Mercury, Pallas, Venus, Cupped, and the Muses.
The most foolish Actors of all Actors, are women.
The truth is, it it is very unhappy for women, that they are not instructed in the rules Rhetoric, by reason they talk so much, that they might talk sensibly, whereas now for want of that Art, they talk mere nonsense.
But all women are apt to speak more than to Act, by reason words are easily spoke, and deeds so hard to be done.
Faith women are as full of Actions as words; for all their life is employed with talking and running about to no purpose.
Come let, us go abroad, for I love to refresh my self in the Serene Air, taking the pleasure of every Season, as when the returning Sun sp•ns Golden Beams, which interwaves into the thiner Air, as Golden Threads with softer Silk, making it like a Mantle, Rich and warm, which wraps the Body of each Creature in; so in the Summer when lifferous winds do fan the sultry heat; then in the Autum that's like a temperate Bath, which is neither too hot nor too cold; then in the Winter, when free∣sing cold doth purge the Air, as Physic doth the Body from most corrupt humours, and binds each loose deshevered part.
The Winter will bind up your active limbs, and numb your flesh, and make your Spirits chill, besides Winter doth bedrid Nature, the spiteful malicious and wicked Season, for it doth strive for to destroy each several thing, and it yields nothing good it self; besides it doth Imprison many things, binding them fast with Icy Chains, taking away their Natural Liberty, also it doth not only frown, and lore on the bright Sun, making his light dim and dusky, but Winter doth untwist, and doth unweave the Suns bright Golden Beams, and wind them on dark bottoms.
The cold sharp Air is as sharp unto the touch, as a Lemon to the taste, and works alike in some effects.
Yes be'r Lady in causing frowning, and crumpling faces.
Not only so, but sharp Air, and sharp Lemons, do both cleanse from Putrification, and keep from Corruption.
But hot Air works upon the Body, as strong Liquors upon the Brain, for hot Air distempers the Body, as strong Liquors do the Mind.
Beshrow me, I have felt some Airs as hot, and as burning, as Brandy-wine.
What Wine is that?
The Wine of Wine, the Spirits of Wine.
Indeed that Wine, if you call it so, which is Strong-waters, will work upon the Body as soon as the hottest Air, causing Feavours and other Malignant diseases.
It seems that hot and burning Air, works upon the Spirits as much and as soon as the hottest Liquors, and hot Liquors upon the By∣die as much as hot Air, both causing Feavours and Frenzies.
In truth, and I heard that Air is liquid, and so is Drink, and Drunkards, like frantic persons, will do mad tricks sometimes.
And there are several sorts of Air, as there are several sorts of Drinks, some colder, some hotter, some moist, and some hath dry effects, and some Air refreshes and quenches heat, other some dissipates and ex∣pels cold, some revives the Spirits, and some enrages them, some corrupts Bodies, and some preserves them.
By my Faith, I perceive Air and Drink have many good and bad qualities, but I had rather have good Drink and bad Air, than bad Drink and good Air, there is some substance in the one, but the other is like unto that which I have heard of but could never see, which is Incorporality; for that which is not subject to my sight, I can hardly believe it is any thing.
Indeed very thin Air is next unto nothing.
Tom. Adventurer is gone to be a Soldier.
Yes, and he may chance to get a glorious Fame.
But particular Fems are like particular Creatures, some dye and decay sooner than others, but few live to old Nestors years, and some lye Bedrid, and a great Company are decrepit and lame, others are crooked and deformed from their Birth, and some by evil Fortune; and many are Or∣phans, and abundance Bastards and Changelings; and though War makes the loudest noise in Fems Palace, yet Wit for the most part lives the long∣est therein; for Wit is such a delightful Company, and such pleasant pa∣stem, as old Father Time takes great care to preserve it, lapping Wit warm in the Memory, and feeding it often with Rehearsals.
Come, Come, you will never get you a real Lover, if you delight so much in Solitaries.
I desire none: for real Lovers do oftentimes prove inconstant,
whereas feigned lovers are as constant as the Contemplator would have them, and as many as they would have; besides, a crowd or multitude of thoughts may rise up in the brain, and be as Spectators of one single thought, which if the Contemplator pleases may be a Lover, and the rest of the Spectators thoughts may censure of that single thought, as of his good parts, or bad, his virtues, or vices, some may praise, others dispraise, and the like; thus a Contemplator can never want Lovers, Admirers, Censurers, nor any other Company, since the Mind can present them with what thoughts they desire, not only the thoughts of Men Women and Children, but of any other Cry∣tures that Nature hath made; for why should not our Spirits or Soul delight and content us, without the real possession of outward Good, as well as the Spirits or Soul doth torment us with a real Evil? for why may not Opinion, or Fancy, as well and as much delight us, as Opinion and Fancy affright us, as they often do?
But an over-studious Mind doth waste the Body, for the Thoughts feeds as much upon the Body, as the Body upon the meat we eat, and the Body nourishes the Thoughts as much as meat nourishes the Body, and for the most part, as the Body is effected so is the Mind, for a distempe∣red Body makes a distempered Mind, as a Luxurious Body makes an Amorous Mind; and a Fever in the Body makes the mind frantic, for the heat of a Fever is like Strong-water, it makes the Spirits drunk, the Thoughts dizzy, and the Mind sick.
Indeed the Body and the Mind do most commonly agree, as in Monarchy the King and the Subjects do, the Subjects obeying the King, and the King commanding the Subjects, yet sometimes the Subjects compel the King, and sometimes the King forces the Subjects, so sometimes the Appetite compels the Reason, at other times the Reason forces the Appetite to a Mo∣deration, and sometimes the Humours of the Body which are like the sense∣less Commonalty, and the Passions of the Soul, which are as the Nobles, of∣tentimes fall out, where sometimes the Humours of the Body usurp with an uproar the Passions of the Soul, and sometimes the Passions overcome the Humours by a wise policy; but when as the Kingdom of Man is in Peace, the Imaginations in the head send down thoughts, as metal into the heart, wherein they are melted and minted into current Coin, each thought as each piece having a several stamp, some is stamped with Hate, some Spite, others Malice; some with Jealousy, some Hope, some with Fear, some Pity, some Love, but that of Love is of the highest value; but these Coins serve for Commerce and Traffic in the Body, from the Authority of the Mind or Soul, whose stamp or Image each piece bears.
Dear Mistress how I love you!
I wish I had Merits worthy your Affections.
You are all a man can wish in women kind, for you are young, fair, virtuous, witty and wise.
Alas all youth hath more follies than years, whereas those that are old, have or ought to have more years than follies.
You might be thought old by your speech and actions, by rea∣son you speak so experienced, and act with such prudence and discretion; wherefore I should judge you were instructed by those that are old, and knew much.
Indeed my Educators were Aged, and my Tutors, like as Pain∣ters, drew with the Pencil of the Tongue, and the Colours of Sense, and the white of Truth, on the Platform of my Brain, many figurate discourses for the Understanding to view, but my Understanding hath weak Eyes.
Your Understanding neither wants sight nor light, but the Lady Faction wants both, or else she had not been so uncivil to you as she was when I was with you last; were not you very Choleric with her?
I am of too Melancholy a Nature to be very Choleric.
Why, are those that are Melancholy never Choleric?
I cannot say never, but yet very seldom, by reason they want that heat which makes Choler; for though the Spirits of Melan∣choly persons may be as quick as those that are Choleric, yet they are not so fiery, for there is as much difference betwixt Melancholy and Choler, as freesing and burning, the one contracts into a sad silence, the other expulses in blows, and many extravagant actions, and angry words; but those persons which are seldom angry, as all Melancholy persons are, who are of a pati∣tient, peaceable Nature, yet when they are angry are very angry; to those persons that are naturally Melancholy, that are seldom seen to be merry or to laugh, yet when they are merry, their mirth is ridiculous, and they will laugh extremely, as at nothing, or at any thing; so those that are naturally Contem∣plative, when they do speak, they speak beyond all sense and reason, their speech flows like as a Torrent, rough and forcibly; thus we may perceive that extremes one way run into extremes another way.
I can truly witness that you are not apt to be angry, or at least not to appear angry; for I did wonder at your humble behaviour, civil ans∣wers, patient demeanours towards the Lady Faction.
I may suffer an injury patiently when I cannot avoid it, but I will never injure my self in doing such actions, or speaking such words as are unbesitting, unworthy and base.
Pray Charge, thank this Gentleman for his gifts and favours to me.
Governess, let me tell you, that they do themselves a courtesy or
favour that do a courtesy or favour to another; and therefore there needs no thanks.
But Lady you ought to thank me, for coming out of my way so far as I have done to see you.
No truly, for if you came out of your way to see me, if it were for affection, it is a duty to Love, if for gratitude, it it is a duty to Obligation, if for civility, it it is a duty to Honour, if for Charity, it it is a duty to Hey∣ven, and where a duty is due, the owner receives but his own when it is paid; wherefore it were a vain and extravagant civility, like unto madness, to give thanks for what is justly their own.
I do confess Lady I am yours, and therefore whatsoever I do, the best of my actions is due to you, and I repent for saying you ought to thank me for coming out of my way to see you, and I crave your pardon for my error, and ask forgiveness for my fault.
I will forgive you, so I may be rid of you, for I love not Comp∣ny but Solitariness.
Sir William Admirer is like Argus, stuck full of Eyes, but Sir William's are the Eyes of fair Ladies that gaze upon him.
The truth is, when he is in the Company of our Sex, all the wo∣men gaze on him.
They may look if they please, and admire him, but I can assure them he loves and admires but one, which is the Lady Peaceable.
Why, is he in love with the Lady Peaceable?
So much as he is to be married to her within two or three days.
I thought he had loved the Lady Faction.
No, no, for he denies that ever he had any Matrimonial love for her.
Will they make a public wedding?
No, it is said the wedding will be kept private.
Where have you been Lady Censurer?
Faith at Court, amongst a Company of Ladies and their Gallants.
And what was their pastime?
Why Singing, Dancing, Laughing, and Jesting; but I have earned an Angel amongst them.
How prithee?
Although not by the sweat of my brows, yet by the expense of my Spirits.
Prithee tell.
Why the Court Ladies in a scornful jesting, for Courtiers love to put persons out of Countenance if they can, prayed me to sing an old Song out of a new Ballad, as knowing my voice fit for no better Songs; but I told them, that if I did sing they should pay me for my pains; for there was never a blind Beggar, or poor young Wench, that sings at a door, but had something given them; they told me they would give me a penny, I ensue∣red, that when they sung to Gentlemen or Ladies guts, that they had a shilling at least given them, and unless they would give me twelve pence a∣piece, I would not sing; so they out of a laughing sport, borrowed a Crown of the Gentlemen to give me.
Oh that's the Court fashion, for the women to borrow of the men.
How should they live if they did not so? for in my Conscience they could not have made up twelve pence amongst a dozen of them, not in money; for their Clothes though costly and rich, yet are worn upon trust; but as I said, I was to sing them a Song for my money; so I sung them an old Song, the burden of the Song, Oh women, women, monstrous women, what do you mean for to do? but because the Song was against women, they would have had me given them their money back again, I told them no I would not, for it was lawful gain for me to keep it, since I gained it by an honest industry, and that those that made a bargain must stick to it; then they told me, that if I would sing them a good old Song, they would give me another Crown; I told them I would have the money in hand, for fear they should dislike my Song when I had sung it, or at least to seem to dislike it, to save their money; so although they were loath, yet at last they borrowed another Crown to give me, thinking it did disgrace me, in that my voice was fit for nothing but old Ballads, for all their Admirers, and Courtly Servants, or Ser∣vents for Courtship were with them; so then I sung them Doctor Faustus that gave his Soul away to the Devil; for I knew Conjurers and Devils pleased women best.
They fright women.
By your favour, all Conjurers gain more by women's coming to them to know their Fortunes, and for to find out losses, than they do by men; for where one man goes to a Conjurer or Fortune-teller, their goes a
hundred women; but as I have told you, I sung the Song of Doctor Faustus.
For my part, I had rather hear a plain old Song, than any Italian, or French Love Songs stuffed with Trilloes.
That's strange, when as in those Harmonious Songs the wisest Poets, and skillfull'st Musicians, are joined to make up one Song, and the most excellent voices are chosen to sing them.
I know not, but I am sooner weary to hear a famous and Artifi∣cial Singer sing than they are themselves with singing, for I hate their Quavers, demi, and semi Quavers, their Minnums, Crochets, and the like.
The truth is, I have observed that when an old Ballad is plainly sung, most hearers will listen with more delight, than to Italian and French Singers, although they sing with art and skill.
The most famous singer in these latter times I have heard in France, it was a woman, and an Italian sent for into France, where she was presented with very rich gifts for her rare singing, yet I durst a-laid my life for a wager, that there were more that could have taken more delight to hear an old Ballad sung, which Ballads are true stories put into verses and set to a Tune, than in all there Italian and French Love whining Songs, and languish∣ing tunes.
Well, but what will you do with your gettings?
Faith I will go home and consider, and the next time I will tell you how I will employ my ten shillings.
What makes you Booted and Spurred, are you going out of the town?
Yes faith, I am going to a wedding, Swish and Spur.
What, art thou going to be married?
No, I am not so hasty, for though I can spur to another mans wedding, I cannot be spurred to my own.
Whose wedding are you riding to?
To Sir William Admirers, and the Lady Peaceable.
Faith their names and marriage do disagree; for never did Husband after the first Month Admire his Wife, nor a Wife after two Months live Peaceably.
How have you employed the ten shillings got by singing?
I must tell you, I have been extremely troubled how to imp∣loy it, insomuch as my Mind hath never been at rest; for their hath been such arguing and disputing and contradiction amongst my Thoughts, as I did verily believe there would have been a mutiny in my head: for first I did resolve to put my ten shillings to pious uses, and then I thought to build some Alms Houses, as building one long room like a Gallery, making in it several Partitions, and the outward doors all alike; these Houses, or rather partitioned rooms, for poor old and infirm persons, that could not work nor beg for their livelihood, to live in; but when I had well considered, that when I had built my Alms Houses, which is as I said one long Room divided by Partitions, I should have nothing left to maintain them, and they to have only House-room, and have neither Meat, Drink, Clothes, nor Fi∣ling to feed them and to keep them from the injuries of the cold, having neither Fires nor Beds, I thought the Parish wherein they were Born, would better provide for them, so that instead of praying for me, they would Curse me; besides I considered, that after I was dead, had I means to leave an al∣lowance, yet when it came for the Magistrates to choose, those that should be put in they would leave out, and choose idle young Housewives, or foul Sluts to dwell therein, such as those Magistrates would visit sometimes, to see what they did want, so as I let that design pass; then I thought to build a Church, and much were my thoughts concerned, whether the Roof should be flat, or vaulted, or sloping; but after I had resolved how the Roof should be, and where the Belfry and Quest-room, I was sore perplexed in my Mind, as where or how to place the Pulpit, whether at the East or West end, or at a Corner in the Church, or at one of the sides of the Church close by the Wall, but at last I resolved it should be placed in the midst of the Church, in the very Centre, that the voice of the Minister might spread round to the Circumference, so as all the Congregation might hear him; but when I con∣sidered that when my Church was bnilt there was neither Benefices, Lands, nor Tithes, nor any allowance for the Minister, and that there was none that did or will preach merely for Gods sake, but for gains sake, as to have a maintenance thereby, or some advancement therefrom, I desisted from that design; then I thought to build a Bedlam, and be the Keeper my self, but I considered that if any of the mad folks should get loose, they might kill me, besides they stink so horribly, and require so much cleansing, not being capa∣ble of keeping themselves clean, as I resolved not to go forward with that design; then I thought to build a free School, and I to be the chief Tutoress my self, but when I remembered the confused noise the Scholars make read∣ing all at once, that neither I could hear nor they understand what they read, I thought it would be to no purpose, because the Scholars would profit but little by their reading, and then I should be thought an ignorant Tutoress; at last I thought to give my ten shillings to the poor Beggars, but when I con∣sidered the Alms that was given to Beggars did more harm than good,
causing them to be idle and lazy, and encouraged them to go roving and To∣guing about, I changed my Mind from that Act, but finding I could not employ my ten shilligns in any pious Act, I thought to employ it in something to be remembered by, as for Fame, whereupon I resolved to build a Pyramid or Cross, the Pyramid to be vastly high, and the Cross to be gloriously gilt, but then searing a Rebellion, and knowing that in a Rebellion a Confused and su∣perstitious rout, would certainly pull them down to the ground, and that when the Cross or Pyramid was down, I should be utterly forgotten, I de∣sisted from that design; so finding as little employment for my money to any famous act as to any pious use, I resolved to employ it to my profit, so then I had a design to set up a Shop of small wares, but when I considered how dead Trading was, and how fast Tradesmen did break, and instead of being enriched became poorer than when first they begun, for to set up a Trade requires some stock, but when they break, they have not only lost their stock, but owe more than ever their stock was, so I went from that design; then I intended to buy me a parcel of Land with my ten shillings, but hearing there was much danger in buying of Land, for that many have mortgaged their Lands to one, and sold them to another, or by an old Deed that hath lain in some old Trunk, Desk, or Box, which may be brought forth to claim the Land again, so as I must be forced to go to Law for my Land I bought, which would cost me more than my Lands, besides the infinite pains and trouble in following my Law Suit, and vexed with quirks, and quilters Lawyers find to prolong the Suit, or else I must let my Land go, so lose it, finding this, I thought to put my money out to use, but then I con∣sidered that first I had only a piece of Parchment for my money, besides, it is a general rule that few or none take up money at use, but those that are Banckrouts, and when they had once got my money into their hands, I should neither get Use or Principal, for should I Imprison them, I should be never the nearer to get my money, for where there is nothing to be had, says the old Proverb, the King must lose his right; after this I intended to build a Ship, and Traffic with it on the Seas, but then considering the Various Winds, the Tempestuous Storms, the rough Seas, the lurking Sands, the dreadful Rocks, the gaping Floods that might split and swallow my Ship, and be drowned my self; I was resolved not to follow that design; then I thought to buy a place at Court, but when I considered how I must cringe and creep, flatter, rail, and be factious, and at last the expenses at Court would be more than the profit of my place, by which I should become a Beggar, or at least a Shark, I left off that design; but after all these considerate∣once I concluded with my self that the most profitablest way to employ my ten shillings was to build a Bawdy house, for I was sure that as soon as ever it was built Customers would resort thereunto; besides it was the most certain gain that was, without any expenses, whereas all other Trades or Profess∣once require means or stocks to begin with, whereas in these Professions or Trade the poorest may set up without borrowing or begging, for a stock to begin with; neither can alterations of times ruin it, for in all times whether Peace or Wars, and in all Nations, this Trade never fails, whereunto if you please to come Ladies, you shall be very welcome.
It will not agree with my humour, for I love Solitariness, and there will be too much Company.
There may be a great resort, but their Conversation is by single Couples.
You are a wag Lady Censurer.
If I were to choose a Wife, I would choose the Lady Solitary.
Why?
Because those that are Solitary love not much Company, and being alone love not much noise, and loving no noise, love silence, and loving silence, love not to talk, so as in having of her, I shall have a Solitary, Peaceable, Quiet, Silent Wife.
And if I were to choose, I would choose the Lady Censurer, for she would let nothing pass her judgment: for she will give her opinion of all things, persons, and actions; so in having her to my Wife, I should have a general Intelligencer, or at least her opinion of all things.
But if her Judgment were not good, her opinion would be iron•os.
I care not, it would serve to pass an idle time with.
And if I might choose, I would choose the Lady Examination for a Wife.
Why?
Because she knows most humours and passages of every body, and their affairs, so by her I should be entertained with news from all ply∣ces, as of all actions done, opinions held, words spoke, or thoughts thought.
I would I could have my wish as easily, as you might have your choice.
What would you wish?
I would wish to be unmarried, for if I were, I would never be troubled with a Wife again; but let me advise you, for I love to have mar∣ried Companions, that you three should go a wooing to those three Ladies, they cannot nor will not deny your Suit, being all three of you rich, young and handsome.
We will take your Counsel.

You hear how this Kingdom of Reformation is proper∣paring for War against the Kingdom of Faction.
Yea, for I hear the Kingdom of Faction resolves to War with this Kingdom of Reformation.
It is true, for there are great preparations of either side, men are raised of all sorts and ages fit to bear Arms, and of all de∣grees to command and obey, and there is one of the gallantest and noblest persons in this Kingdom, which is made General to command in chief, for he is a man that is both valiant and well experienced in Wars, temperate and just in Peace, wise and politic in public affairs, careful and prudent in his own Family, and a most generous person.
Indeed I have heard that he is a most excellent Soldier.
He is so, for he is not one that sets forth to the Wars with great resolutions and hopes, and returns with maskerd fears, and despairs; neither is he like those that take more care, and are more industrious to get gay Clothes, and fine Feathers, to flint in the Field, and vapour in their march, than to get useful and necessary provision; but before he will march, he will have all things ready, and proper for use, as to fit himself with well-tempered Arms, which are light to be worn, yet musket proof; for he means not to run away, nor to yield his life upon easy terms unto his Enemy; for he desires to Conquer, and not vain-gloriously to show his courage by a careless neglect or a vain carelessness; also he chooses such Horses as are use∣full in War, such as have been made subject to the hand and heel, that have been taught to Trot on the Honchos, to change, to Gallop, to stop, and such Horses as have spirit and strength, yet quiet and sober Natures; he regards more the goodness of the Horses than the Colours or marks, and more the fitness of his Saddles than the Embroidery; also he takes more care that his Waggons should be easy to follow, and light in their carriage, than to have them painted and gilded; and he takes greater care that his Tents should be made, so as to be suddenly put up, and as quickly pulled down, than for the setting and Imbrodering his Arms thereupon; also he take more care to have useful Servants than numerous Servants; and as he is industrious and careful for his particular affairs, so he is for the ge∣neral affairs.
A good Soldier makes good preparations, and a good General doth both for himself and Army, and as the General hath showed himself a good Soldier by the preparations he had made to march, so he hath show∣en himself a wise man by the settlement he hath made, in what he hath to leave behind him; for I hear he hath settled and ordered his House and Family.
He hath so, and he hath a fair young and virtuous Lady that he must leave behind him, which cannot choose but trouble him.
The wisest man that is, cannot order or have all things to his own contentment.
My dear heart, you know I am commanded to the Wars, and had I not such Wife as you are, I should have thought Fortune had done me a favour to employ my life in Heroical Actions for the service of my Country, or to give me a honourable Death, but to leave you is such a Cross as my Nature sinks under; but wheresoever you are there will be my life, I shall only carry a Body which may sight, but my Soul and all the powers thereof will remain with thee.
Husband, I shall take this expression of love but for feigning words, if you leave me; for it is against Nature to part with that we love best, unless it be for the beloveds preservation, which cannot be mine, for my life lives in yours, and the comfort of that life in your Company.
I know you love me so well, as you had rather part with my life than I should part from my honour.
It is true, my love persuades me so to do, knowing fame is a double life, as infamy is a double death; nay I should persuade you to those actions, were they never so dangerous, were you unwilling thereunto, or could they create a world of honour, fully inhabited with praises; but I would not willingly part with your life for an imaginary or supposed ho∣nor, which dyes in the womb before it is Born; thus I love you the best, preferring the best of what is yours; but I am but in the second place in your affections, for you prefer your honour before me; it is true, it is the better choice, but it shows I am not the best beloved, which makes you foal∣low and glue to that and leave me.
Certainly Wife my honour is your honour, and your ho∣nor will be buried in my disgrace, which Heaven avert; for I prefer yours before my own, insomuch as I would have your honour to be the Crown of my glory.
Then I must partake of your actions, and go along with you.
What to the VVars?
To any place where you are.
But Wife you consider not, as that long marches, ill lodge∣ings, much watching, cold nights, scorching days, hunger and danger are
ill Companions for Ladies, their acquaintance displeases; their conversation is rough and rude, being too boisterous for Ladies; their tender and strengthless constitutions cannot encounter nor grapell therewith.
It is said, that Love overcomes all things: in your Company long marches will be but as a breathing walk, the hard ground feel as a Fea∣ther-Bed, and the starry Sky a spangled Canopy, hot days a Stove to cure cold Agues, hunger as Fasting days or an eve to devotion, and danger is honours triumphant Chariot.
But Nature hath made women like China, or Pursleyn, they must be used gently, and kept warily, or they will break and fall on Deaths head: besides, the inconveniences in an Army are so many, as put patience her self out of humour; besides, there is such inconveniences as mo∣desty cannot allow of.
There is no immodestly in natural effects, but in unnatural abuses; but contrive it as well as you can, for go I must, or either I shall dye, or dishonour you; for if I stay behind you, the very imaginations of your danger will torture me, sad Dreams will affright me, every little noise will sound as your passing Bell, and my fearful mind will transform every object like as your pale Ghost, until I am smothered in my Sighs, shrouded in my Tears, and buried in my Griefs; for whatsoever is joined with true love, will dye absented, or else their love will dye, for love and life are joined to∣gether; as for the honour of constancy, or constant fidelity, or the dishonour of inconstancy, the lovingest and best wife in all story that is recorded to be, the most perfectest and constantest wife in her Husbands absence was Penelope, Ulysses wife, yet she did not Barricade her Ears from Loves soft Alarms; but parled and received Amorous Treaties, and made a Truce until she and her Lovers could agree and conclude upon conditions, and questionless there were Amorous Glances shot from loving Eyes of either party; and though the Siege of her Chastity held out, yet her Husbands Wealth and Estate was impoverished, and great Riots committed both in his Family and Kingdom, and her Suitors had absolute power thereof; thus though she kept the fort of her Chastity, she lost the Kingdom, which was her Husbands Estate and Government, which was a dishonour both to her and her Husband; so if you let me stay behind you, it will be a thousand to one but either you will lose me in Death, or your honour in Life, where if you let me go you will save both; for if you will consider and reckon all the married women you have heard or read of, that were absented from their Husbands, although upon just and necessary occasions, but had some Ink of aspersions flung upon them, although their wives were old, illfavoured, de∣crepid and diseased women, or were they as pure as light, or as innocent as Heaven; and wheresoever this Ink of aspersions is thrown, it sticks so fast, that the spots are never rubbed out, should it fall on Saints, they must wear the marks as a Badge of misfortunes, and what man had not better be thought or called an uxorious Husband, than to be despised and laughed at, as being but thought a Cuckhold? the first only expresses a tender and noble Nature, the second sounds as a base, cowardly, poor, dejected, forsaken Creature; and as for the immodesty you mentioned, there is none, for there can be no breach of modesty, but in unlawful actions, or at least unnecessary ones; but what Law can warrant, and necessity doth enforce, is allow∣able amongst men, pure before Angels, Religious before Gods, when un∣choosing persons, improper places, unfit times, condemn those actions that
are good in themselves, make them appear base to men, hateful to Angels, and wicked to Gods, and what is more lawful, fitting, and proper, than for a man and wife to be inseparable together?
Well, you have used so much Rhetoric to persuade, as you have left me none to deny you, wherefore I am resolved you shall try what your tender Sex can endure; but I believe when you hear the Bullets fly about you, you will wish your self at home, and repent your rash adventure.
I must prove false first, for love doth give me courage.
Then come along, I shall your courage try.
He follow you, though in Deaths Arms I lie.
Well met, for I was going to thy lodging to call thee to make up the Company of good fellows, which hath appointed a meeting.
Faith you must go with the odd number, or get another in my room, for I am going about some affairs which the Lord General hath im∣ployed me in.
I perceive by thee that public employments spoil private meetings.
You say right, for if every one had good employment, vice would be out of fashion.
What do you call vice?
Drinking, Winching, and Gaming.
As for two of them, as Drinking and Winching, especially Winching, no employment can abolish them, no, not the most severest, devotest, nor dangerest: for the States-man Divines, and Soldiers, which are the most and greatest employed, will leave all other affairs to kiss a Mistress.
But you would have me go to a Tavern and not to a Mistress.
Why, you may have a Mistress in a Tavern if you please.
Well, if my other affairs will give me any leisure, I will come to you.
The Lord General was accounted a discreet and wise man, but he shows but little wisdom in this action of carrying his wife along with him to the VVars, to be a Clog at his heels, a Chain to his hands, an Encumbrance in his march, obstruction in his way; for she will be al∣ways
puling and sick, and whining, and crying, and tired, and •roward, and if her Dog should be left in any place, as being forgotten, all the whole Are∣my must make a halt whilst the Dog is fetched, and Trooper after Trooper must be sent to bring intelligence of the Dogs coming, but if there were such a misfortune that the Dog could not be found, the whole Army must be dispersed for the search of it, and if it should be lost, then there must seem to be more lamentation for it than if the Enemy had given us an entire defeat, or else we shall have frowns instead of preferments.
The truth is, I wonder the General will trouble himself with his wife, when it is the only time a married man hath to enjoy a Mistress with∣out jealousy, a sprightly sound wench, that may go along without trouble, with bag and baggage, to wash his linen, and make his sealed Bed, and at∣tend to his call, when a wife requires more attendance than Centuries to watch the Enemy.
For my part I wonder as much that any man should be so fond of his wife as to carry her with him; for I am only glad of the VVars, because I have a good pretence to leave my wife behind me; besides an Army is a quiet, solitary place, and yields a man a peaceable life compared to that at home: for what with the faction and mutiny amongst his Servants, and the noise the women make, for their tongues like as an Alarm beat up qua∣ters in every Corner of the House, that a man can take no rest; besides every day he hath a set Battle with his wife, and from the Army of her angry thoughts, she sends forth such volleys of words with her Gunpowder anger, and the fire of her fury, as breaks all the ranks and files of content, and puts happiness to an utter rout, so as for my part I am forced to run away in dis∣content, although some Husbands will stay, and fight for the Victory.
Gentlemen, Gentlemen• pray condemn not a man for taking his lawful delight, or for ordering his private affairs to his own humour, every man is free to himself, and to what is his, as long as he disturbs not his Neigh∣bours, nor breaks the Peace of the Kingdom, nor disorders the Common∣wealth, but submits to the Laws, and obeys the Magistrates without dis∣put; besides Gentlemen, it is no crime nor wonder, for a man to let his wife go along with him when he goes to the Wars, for there hath been examples; for Pompey had a wife with him, and so had Germanicus, and so had many great and worthy Heroics, and as for Alexander the great he had a wife or two with him; besides, in many Nations men are not only desired, but commanded by the Chiefs to let their wives go with them, and it hath been a practice by long Custom, for women to be spectators in their Battles, to encourage their fights, and so give fire to their Spirits; also to attend them in their Sicknesses, to cleanse their wounds, to dress their meat; and who is fitter than a wife? what other woman will be so lovingly careful, and in∣dustriously helpful as a wife? and if the Greeks had not left their wives be∣hind them, but had carried them along to the Trojan Wars, they would not have found such disorders as they did at their return, nor had such bad well∣come home, as witness Agamemnons; besides, there have been many women that have not only been Spectators, but Actors, leading Armies, and direct∣ing Battles with good success, and there have been so many of these He∣roicks, as it would be tedious at this time to recount; besides the examples of women's courage in Death, as also their wise conduct, and valiant act∣once in Wars are many, and pray give me leave to speak without your being offended thereat, it is not Noble, nor the part of a Gentleman, to censure,
condemn, or dispraise another mans private actions, which nothing con∣corns him, especially when there is so gallant a subject to discourse of as the discipline and actions of these Wars we are entering into.
In truth Sir, you have instructed us so well, and have chid us so handsomely, as we are sorry for our error, and ask pardon for our fault, and our repentance shall be known by that we will never censure so again.
I have heard our Generals Lady goes with the Gene∣ral her Husband to the Wars, wherefore I think it fit for the rest of the Commanders, if it were only for policy, to let our General see that we approve of his actions so well, as to imitate him in ours, carrying our Wives along with us, besides the Generals Lady cannot chose but take it kindly to have our Wives wait upon her, wherefore Wife it is fit you should go.
Alas Husband I am so tender, that I am apt to catch cold if the least puff of wind do but blow upon me; wherefore to lie in the open Fields will kill me the first Night, if not, the very journey will shatter my small bones to pieces.
Why, our Generals Lady is a very fine young Lady, and she ventures to go.
There let her venture, for you must excuse me, for I will stay at home, go you where you please.
Well Wife consider it.
Wife prepare your self to follow the Army, for it is now the fashion for VVives to march, wherefore pack up and away.
What with a Knapsack behind me as your Trull? not I, for I will not disquiet my rest with inconveniences, nor divert my pleasures with troubles, nor be affrighted with the roaring Cannons, nor endanger my life with every Potgun, nor be frozen up with Cold, nor stewed to a gelly with heat, nor be powdered up with dust, until I come to be as dry
as a Neats-tongue; besides, I will not venture my Complexion to the wroth of the Sun, which will tan me like a Sheeps skin.
Faith Wife, if you will not go, I will have a Landery-Maid to ride in my VVaggon, and lie in my Tent.
Prithee Husband take thy Kitchen Maid along too, for she may have as much Grease about her as will serve to make Soap to wash your Linen with, and while you ride with your Landery-Maid in your Waggon, I will ride with my Gentleman-Usher in my Coach.
Why Wife, it is out of love that I would have thee go.
